reviews.review: Wonderful Temple. I came across this place in my travel books and wanted to go. Quite a number of steps to get up before you get there and along the way you have all these different gold buddhas. It was tiring by the time you got up the top but it was worth it. I would stop every so often, take pictures, admire the buddhas, etc. The temple at the top was beautiful as well. I thought this temple was better than some of the others I saw. Would very much recommend going. Take the MTR to get there, very close by.

Glad I went here. I'd been to Hong Kong a few times and after visiting a couple of temples I thought I wouldn't again but I'm glad I eventually did this as it's nice to get away from the busy streets of Hong Kong and this has something different to offer over all the other temples in the busy areas. There aren't as many tourists and people visiting and the climb to the pop on a nice day offers quite a different view and something different to do/see. There are usually monkeys hanging around in the trees as you walk up too so keep and eye out and you may see a few, they blend in well but do come quite close sometimes. There is also a tower like building when you get to the top which you can actually go in and climb up if you want to go a little higher.One thing to watch out for is the fake monks just before you enter. They will act all kind and try to sell you bracelets and demand money in a bowl, do not fall for this as real monks will never beg for money. Just move past them and you'll be ok.

So pretty and calm amongst the high rise. The park is not huge, but you can lose yourself in it and get away from the city, although surrounded by it. Hong Kong has these parks - like Kowloon Park - that are just beautiful - and beautifully tended - havens from the bustle that is so near. Hong Kong Park has some lovely water features - a waterfall, babbling brooks, a little lake.
Lovely monastery - off the beaten path. This was a lovely excursion with very few tourists. LOTS of buddhas!. It was nice to visit a shrine where people actually worshiped!

Great Attraction. It is free of charge, and was quite a hike. Wear comfortable shoes, as it does get steep near the end. There were some rest stops in between though. It is definitely worth the climb.
Nice hike to this temple. The monastery is overrated, not very well maintained. The view is fabulous, the little cafe ok and the buddhas on the way up good to look at....

Incredible!!. WOW!!! I am so happy we decided to visit this Monastery!! Get ready to get your exercise in !! It is a hike up to the top but man is it worth it!! All of the Buddhas on the way up are extraordinary !! Not to mention the view from the top!

Didn't fancy this at first but glad I went. Not the easiest to find as for some reason there are no sign posts to this monastery. If you have internet whilst out then google the walk through on Utube. I would never of found this place without following the video footage as I went.Once there make sure you have plenty of water and a camera ready. It hard long climb up to the top there are benches dotted up the path for a rest. You need to be reasonably fit to get up here. My legs where like jelly once got to the top but wow it was a great journey up so many photos taken.It's a must do attraction
visually stunning. A lot of eye popping detail to see. Amazing work by very skilled people. Wonderfully preserved and maintained.

Ten thousand buddhas monastery. Good place to have extra fitness in Hong Kong.You can go further up to the mountain and reach wild place in jungles where a lot of wild monkeys under your head. It's just 30 minutes walking from the monastery.
lots of photos. this was one of the nicest monasteries we went too - maybe because it was less crowed - not sure if it was a fluke, it meant we could take less cluttered photos...

Tranquil. This place was better than expected from reviews. It's at Sha Tin and an easy walk from station. The walk up the hill, through the grounds is quite short although just a little steep in places. Along the walk is an endless array of golden Buddha and a number of temples and associated buildings. There are seats along the way so you can just sit and enjoy the peaceful environment.

Very Cool!. This place is off the beaten path and not touristy at all, if that is your thing. It can be a bit difficult to find. In fact, none of the taxi drivers knew about it, so I recommend having the phone number handy for them to call.There is an Ancestor Worship Hall right next door which is also worth a few minutes exploration. The path to the Monastery is off to the right.The hike up the hill is cool, but a bit strenuous. It is lined the whole way with golden Bhudda statues. No two appeared to be alike to me. This goes for a mile or so I'd say. It is very quiet and lush jungle type scene.At the top, there is a Stella, and a number of Bhudda statues. The main hall has thousands of tiny lit buddhas. Living in China, I've done a number of Buddhist temples now, and this one is unique.It is a bit of a pain to get to, but worth the trouble. Oh, and it's free, which is nice.

Quiet area in the busy city. We walked here from our hotel. Reading the reviews we expected a really big hill, but it's quite a short walk and well worth it. The views are great and the peace and quiet is lovely. Such a contrast looking from the monastery down to the busy city below. at the end of the walk there are several places to get a drink and snack in the nearby shopping centre.

Worth the walk.. The walk up from Sha Tin takes quite some effort, prepare to get VERY sweaty, but is definitely worth it. The collection of Buddha statues that lines the walk is amazing, each one completely individual and distinct. At the top is really peaceful and also has great views back towards the built up areas.

quite the workout- but worth it!. It's a STEEP walk up a hill - but it is an amazing sanctuary on top with beautiful artwork and some great views of Hong Kong. Don't go on a really hot day - we are pretty fit but went on a hot day and were pretty wiped out at the end. There are also monkeys at the monastery - we recommend you stay away from them. ;)

Loved it . I really enjoyed the walk up to the Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery! Even with sandals on it was an easy walk up the stairs to the top. I was lucky to go on a clear and beautiful day. It didn't take to much time out of my day and was easy to navigate via train to the Sha Tin station and back to the Central station.

Understated but impressive!. We heard about this from a friend and were really curious about the idea of ten thousand Buddha statues in a single place. We visited on a cloudy Thursday morning. It's a bit of an uphill walk up the steps of the monastery but this should not be an issue for those that are generally fit. You will find that you stop a lot on the way up (and down!) as you stop to admire and wonder at the various strange expressions and features of the statues. We saw a few monkeys at the start but none after that. There is a little pond right at the top level with fishes and turtles which pleased our boys! The views are really great and it's a lot quieter than the more popular attractions like the peak. We are glad we visited and would highly recommend it!

Well worth the climb. Spectacular is a word that comes to mind when you visit this temple. It's really hard work to make your way up to the top but it's a walk you don't want to take at pace anyway, because you will miss a lot of hidden treasures along the way. At the top you will find a quaint place to site and get a cold drink and a snack. Beware of the monkeys. And look for the grottos with all the turtles inside. Highly recommend for a spiritual and cultural experience.

Beautiful to see Temple and surrounding landscaping is lovely. Beautiful to look at, an idea of what a Buddhist Temple looks like. For a westerner it is a different type of "religious" building. Eye opening.

Beautiful, but hard work!. The monastery itself is absolutely stunning. The buddhas lining the walkway up to the Monastery (no longer a working monastery!) are amazing, and the views when you reach the top are lovely. However the walk up is quite tiring. I did it on a particularly hot day and was drenched with swear by the time I reached the top, and I'm fairly physically fit! Definitely worth a visit, just make sure you're wearing good shoes.

Worth visiting in hk . One of the most worth visiting in HK besides victoria bay. Exit sha tin station, heading to the shatin city hall and you will find the way to the temple easily (you can ask people there)

Worth a visit. An esoteric collection of ten thousand buddhas in all shapes and sizes... Free and worth the walk up the stairs of you can find it (not very well marked out, perhaps intentionally). Watch out for monkeys and turtles.

Good workout - interesting monastery. it is a beautiful walk uphill but a tough workout, especially after leg day :) make sure you take some water with you before you venture up there.The monastery is beautiful and has some gorgeous statues outside - superb photos awaiting to be taken.

Be prepared for a workout. I have been to the 10,000 Buddhas Temple/Monastery twice. I went in May 2011 and then again in September 2016. Both times, I remember the monastery being really hot and feeling quite tired when I reached the top. However, in my travels in Asia, I have not seen another monastery quite like the 10,000 Buddhas one. With so many different Buddhas, the artwork that went into making the temple is truly special. If you are looking to get away from the hustle and bustle of central Hong Kong, I would highly suggest traveling to the New Territories and the 10,000 Buddhas for a bit of tranquility in the mega metropolis.

One of the best Chinese temples/monasteries I have seen!. Very close to the Sha Tin MTR station although not so well signposted! Pretty steep hike and lots of steps to the top but doesn't feel too long as the path is lined with hundreds of large golden Buddhas to look at on the way! The monastery itself was bigger than I expected and had lots to look around including the call with the 10,000 Buddhas itself. Make sure you continue up to see more halls, more Buddhas and great views! With the walk up and down and a good explore it took about 1.5-2 hours to wonder at own pace. Make sure you take plenty of water although you can buy from the small restaurant at the top if you forget. The monastery is open 9-5 and is free. Would definitely go again!
You have to visit this!. Very nice view, is a nice monastery but is a new one. From here you have to buy a traditional hat because nowhere in Hong Kong you`ll find.

Be sure to take plenty of water. we both enjoyed this, but be aware when they say 482 steps(we didn't count them) it is a lot of steps, so take plenty of water for the walk up, and go to the white Buddha as well (that one is of to the right of the first temple you get to)that was beautiful.

Ten Thousand Buddha's. Very easy to navigate to and find from the metro station. Clearly sign posted / directions. If in doubt, there are many people to ask should you get lost. Take refreshments with you, and wear comfy shoes. This is one of the temples you need to see whilst in Hong Kong. You wont be disappointed.

Fantastic day out and lots of surprises. Lovely day trip out to Sha Tin. The temple is fairly well signposted and easy to find. It's a nice steep walk up past all the monk statues to the top where you find the 10000 buddhas. If you keep going up there's a lovely very large newer statue at the top and more temples. Great views over Sha Tin and don't forget to check out the New Town Plaza on the way back - though not so new town any more! :-)

Excellent and very interesting. This monastery is reached by walking up stairs through a forested area with many Buddha statues lining the way. The entrance is near Sha tin MTR (railaway) station and you do a short walk around to the entrance which is between two large office buildings. The Buddha statues lining the way was very amusing and the various temples at the top are beautiful. We also saw a bunch of wild monkeys which was a lot of fun.
Ten thousand Budhas. Steep walk. Allow time to rest.Can be slippery if raining. Dress lightly on hot and humid days. Check directions. Ask other tourists if lost.scenic view worth visiting.

Unique. This is a must see in Hong Kong. Near Sha Tin station, this is not very easy to find but people will be happy to help as everybody is looking for this area.On your way to the top, you will also free monkeys and all these Buddhas with their different faces.Once at the top you will discover several Monasteries, several places and beautiful statues. This is a different and peaceful place. I would definitely recommend.

Look for directions before!!. I accidentally walked up to the monastery next door first, which led to an even longer walk, take plenty of water as very tiring but funny seeing buddhas' face. Apparently there is a risk of fake monks asking for money being there, I didn't experience this but watch out anyway

Good Hike Up Lots of Steps, Very Lovely and Interesting Monastery.. Have gone here several times. The walk up to the Monastery is lovely with plants and statues. Monastery easy to walk around, peaceful and interesting.
Must see. Loved this place, a must see in HK. A short walk from the mrt station to the Buddha lined stairway that goes on forever, on top the 10000 Buddha temple.

Defiantly a must see. Make sure to look up how to get there from the station as there are no signs. The hike up isn't too bad, along with the heat it does take maybe 30 minutes. The vegetarian restaurant was great as well!
Amazing. Its little difficult to climb the place because of steep height. But if you are fit enough to hike, this is a must visit in Hong Kong and view from top is simply beautiful

Fantastic... Despite the terrible rain (being from the UK we were used to it but not the humidity that goes with it), it was a fabulous visit. I absolutely loved this place. Both sides of the path up to the temple are lined with the bhuddas...there are so many facial expressions, some are really comical. I think there are more than ten thousand... This place has such a feel good factor to it... You can't fail to be cheered up by it.

Cultural Visit. A place for you to experience something DIFFERENT. You have to climb around 400 steps up to the top of a mountain. Even the journey may be harsh, but definitely you will get impressed with those golden buddhas lined up.Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery is a quiet place, particularly if you want to relax yourself from a busy life in Hong Kong - ENJOY!

unique cultural visit. A long walk up and a long walk down! We were very sweaty!! but on the walk up we saw wild monkeys- a mother with a baby clinging on! The 10,000 buddhas are really extraordinary, starting with the life size gold statues lined up the stairs and continuing in miniature form inside the temple. There is a small snack bar at the top, if you want a soft drink and a bowl of noodles. It doesn't take all day to visit but it is very colourful with lots to see, the children liked it for that reason. A quirky visit!

Interesting and different. Easy to see from the station but harder to find, the pathway /steps to the top are lined with golden Buddhas . There are rest stops along the route . At the top there are various shrines and temples all adorned with Buddhas of all shapes and sizes. We didn't see any monkeys but there are fish ad terrains in the pools at he dry top. There is a small vegetarian cafe selling drinks ad a small variety of dishes. Definitely worth a half day journey if you're wanting a break from the city. Photogenic too.

Walk around. This can be easily missed. Because we went during the rains it was rainnig and we were almost about to miss out on one entire side.Itsa little away from the main buddha statue but make sure you walk around and find it. Its breathtaking.

Stairs and Buddhas. There are LOTS of stairs so be prepared. Summer time bring lots of water. I felt it best to visit this location in cooler months, it makes the trip much more enjoyable. I went one time on Chinese New Year and so many people were go up the path. It has lots of buddhas to see and a very good view of ShaTin area from the top. Plan to stay at least 45 minutes or so to check it all out. Depending on your fitness, walking may take 45+minutes. I have been here 2 times and cooler weather was best.
Not easily accessible, route signage not eye catching, but worth visit.. 15 minutes uphill walking, path entrance hidling behind buildings. But 10000 difffernt buddhas, each is unique.

Very interesting place. Every single Buddha is different & it's really interesting to look at their faces. There are a huge amount of steps to climb so it's not for people with walking difficulties. Spent a god 4 hours walking around. Worth a visit.
must see. Long walk but each statue is different and the whole trail is a wonderful visit and just crazy fun to see and you will remember it
1, 2, 3... 10000. There is a lot of Buddhas with different positions, arranged in a hill to have a nice walk. Far from the city but worth it 100%

431 stairs. Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery.It is a famous Buddhist monastery located on the mountain behind Shatin Pai Tau Village near the Shatin station. Although it is really beautiful place, were there almost nobody. Only few foreign tourists and few local people.There are 431 stairs to the peak of the monastery. Weather was hot and very humid. But it worth to climb all those stairs. At the top of the path is the terrace with the main temple and a beautiful red pagoda. There is at the highest point a huge white Kwun Yam statue in front of a waterfall. It looks like from a fairytale.It is really nice place and I was very surprised, that weren't almost any people there. Maybe tourists don't know about this monastery, or they are lazy to climb all those stairs. :-)I can recommend to visit this place.

Hundreds of Unique plaster Monk Statues. I went during busy season on a weekday, and it was very peaceful. As others have mentioned, it's a bit tricky to find, but behind the government buildings there is a sign and an arrow leading to the path.The hundreds of monk statues lining the path up to the main pagoda and hall are only plaster, and have chipping paint, but were wonderful in their own regard. They were all unique, with different shapes, expressions, and props. The further you go up, the more impressive they become.At the top, (there are tons of stairs) there is a pagoda and a hall lined with possibly 10,000 small Buddha statues. There are also some toilets. No one was selling any water or food when we went, but there seem to stalls up there. We saw some monkeys in the trees, and many signs that saying not to feed them.

Lots of steps.. This Monestery is easy enough to reach. The MTR stops just steps away and though a pretty non descript entrance, it is easy enough to find. I was amused to see the "Beware of fake Monks" sign greeting me at the entrance( though no real or fake monks were anywhere to be seen)The trip up to the Monestary is quite the workout(over 400 steps) but the steps are lined by Buddha statues, so it is a picturesque walk upwards. Hiking up these steps in early July was quite tiring with the temperature and humidity both extreme, but the payoff comes at the top when a pretty Monestery is revealed and then further up more steps, a great view of the Monestery below and it really is quite relaxing. I would suggest to go early in the morning to avoid the heat in summer, and bring plenty of water.

600+ steps and worth it!. Im giving this property three stars because I got tired from climbing the stairs...They are not joking about the 10,000 buddhas!!! You will definitely see thwm while climbing and whe you reach the top! No worries because they have a canteen where you can drink and eat after that long climb!

Hidden gem!. It's so fun and interesting to see all of the different golden Buddhas as you walk up. It's quite a walk, especially at the height of the summer heat but well worth it!! There are even wild monkeys that come and walk around, jumping on the Buddhas and swinging on the trees, it's lovely to see them in their own habitat. They were minding their own business when we were there but I can imagine they could pester people. The monastery itself was absolutely incredible. The amount of detail that has gone into decorating each Buddha is amazing and it was lovely to see and smell the culture and religious atmosphere. The area itself had lovely views of the city and was a very peaceful area. Loved visiting this.

Not so well known among residents. It is a peaceful location in HK that we enjoyed but if pressed for time you may skip it. The pro's for visiting it: get to see the more traditional buildings on your way there, not so crowded, a nice walk in the shade. The cons: not so easy to find, the buddhas on the way up aren't anything wow-ish but they are an eye opener to human imagination. Take a mosquito replant and some water for the way up. Since we wandered about find our way there, some instruction to find the way as the residents of the neighborhood or people working there didn't know. Once you are next to the Grand Plaza Mall , head towards the Government Offices - there's a street in between the two so you have to walk that one for about 50m even though it looks like a dead end. As you reach the end head to your left on a shady path -- no worries you aren't lost. Walk that way and you will soon get some pavement under your feet to know you are on the right track. The way up starts just behind the Governmental offices and when we visited there were no signs. It is a peaceful location and gives a nice view over a part of Hong Kong. We didn't go up nor down to the memorial as it was extremely hot and were pressed for time.

A different side of Hong Kong. Be prepared for stairs ! It is quite a way up and the entrance is difficult to find. We took a cab and the driver dropped us at we considered to be the entrance. However, it proved to be a local cemetery and we had to come down all the steps again and restart for the monastery. After the trip, we were quite exhausted.... The trip itself is certainly worth the effort and if you have some time in HK this makes for an excellent side trip

Steps, steps and more steps.. Not for the faint hearted to reach this monastery on top of the hill to see the 10,000 buddhas but the views at the top are worth it as is the Monastery itself. On the way up the path / steps there are also life size buddhas to greet you on the way, I have no idea how many there are but they are all different. A local lady serves tea and basic food in an area in the courtyard outside the Monastery.

Dare to count!. From its main entrance, left and right are golden statues in different poses and smiles. Be ready though, as the way up to the monastery is a bit tiresome. Miniature Buddhas are located in the main temple which are uniquely placed and arranged around the walls. It is a must see monastery.

Does it even exist? They don't seem to want visitors. After being ripped off by the Hong Kong MTR once again, we found ourselves outside yet another shopping complex studying the map on my phone to find the temple. After working out the direction, we set off in the right direction. We came to a path under a motorway bridge that the map said was there, and finally noticed the first sign for "Ten Thousand Buddhas" pointing us through some greenery towards what looked like a temple roof, above a small roadside shanty town. There had been no signposts for the monastery anywhere near the MTR station, and it was not located on the station map of the local area. Even in the Grand Plaza, there was no indication of where the monastery was. We followed this one sign up the only path, until we came to a staircase.The staircase led us past a few Buddha statues, and after an exhausting climb, to a platform with several rows of rather colourful small Buddha statues along the cliff side. Another flight of stairs brought us to the top, where a very modernised tiny one-room shrine housed a great many Buddhas... In the form of wall carvings. They were all identical, and they were all tiny. We left after five minutes, disappointed. Upon getting back to where we were staying and looking at the photos on TripAdvisor, I am left slightly confused. None of them seem to be of the temple we encountered (though half of them seem to be of Po Lin monastery on Lantau Island for some reason), although the place we found was in the right map location, and at the dead end of the road directed to us by the only signpost available. Do both TripAdvisor and Google have the temple in the wrong location? If not, and we did still somehow manage to get to the wrong place, it is nigh impossible to find due to poor signposting locally, and for us was a complete waste of time, energy, and money.

This Monastery is amazing and beautiful!. I was greeted with an amazing sight of statues lining the steep path, helped by 431 steps from the base of the hill up to the Monastery, and surprised to find monks not buddhas, each with different expressions, poses and dress. So I must correct everyone regarding the 500 "buddhas" that lines the path up to the monastery. They are life size gilded Arhan statues. Arhan, is the local word for "buddhist monks" who are very senior and can serve the buddhas. We were climbing the hill on a relatively warm and humid day, so dread to think those who climb in the heat of summer, when temperatures can reach 40°C, would probably die of heat exhaustion! Definitely, need to remember to carry a few bottles of water with you. By the time we reached the lower level of the monastery (it is built over two levels overlooking Sha Tin), I was glad to find a large dining room of the vegetarian restaurant right in front of us, where we can have a cold bowl of sweet grass jelly dessert, the sweetness of the syrup helped to replace the perspiration from our glowing bodies and the coldness to cool us down.After suitably cooled we ventured out to the building next door, the main attraction, which was The Ten Thousand Buddhas Temple. This temple is amazing as its walls are covered with miniature Buddhas, all unique, all handmade, on 30 shelves (yes, I counted!) rising from the floor to ceiling, each bearing an inscription of the name of its donor. The buildings of the Monastery took eight years to complete, but it took a further ten years to complete all the miniature Buddha statues displayed, and which actually numbered almost 13,000 (in Cantonese words "ten thousand" simply represents a term for an extremely large number). In the centre of this Temple, in a glass case, resides the body of the founder of the Monastery, Rev Yuet Kai, embalmed with lacquer and gold leaf, adorned in robes, and seated by the altar, with a sign that reads, "The Diamond Indestructible Body of Yuet Kai."At the opposite end of the Temple, on this large terrace, is the nine storey pagoda and in between is a pavilion housing a large statue of the Goddess of Mercy. Apparently, the pagoda was featured on the HK$100 note.On the upper level, the path leading up is lined with goddesses this time, there are more temples and a turtle pond, and views across to Sha Tin from the waterfall, in front of a large white statue of a Goddess, which looks relatively new.

A bit confusing to get to it and quite the hike. Went there today. Take the mtr subway to Sha Tin and look for the exit signs in the mtr that indicate which exit to walk there. I didn't pay attention and just grabbed a taxi. Three min later I was there. Noticed the sign when I returned. The entrance is not well marked. There is a large marble wall with its entrance flanked by big stone lions. That is not the entrance because thAt is for a cemetery. To the right of the marble wall is an alley between the parking lot and government building. Walk down it and then you will see the sign sitting on the ground leaning against a post. Then keep walking up many many stairs up the side of the mountain flanked by 10,000 Buddhas in all shapes and sizes and postures. Some were actually quite funny. The view at the top is beautiful. Lots to see. No one or no signs that offer any guidance or history. But view is nice and you just need to do your research before to know what you are looking at. Took about 45min to hike up with a few breaks thrown in. Wear light clothing and take some water.

Hilarious. I loved the Buddhas various expressions and poses all the way to the top. It is an easy hike and very quick to do. The name is slightly deceiving as there are only about 4-500 big buddhas along the way to the top. The remaining are miniatures all lined up in a room once you're at the top.

An unexpected surprise. This place is amazing, and only a few minutes away from the Shantin MTR. Its not overly complicated to find just locate the police department and its the path right beyond the parking structure. The walk up is amazing, and the monastery is breath taking. This place even rendered my very talkative 8 year old speechless! Now the stairs up can be daunting but I took a cue from the locals and would stop every once in a while to look at the buddhas and I got up the many steps in no time flat and not at all out of breathe! This is a must stop and will not take but a an or two to explore. In my opinion its a must do if your in Honk Kong!

Beautiful. Worth to travel at this destination. It is not so popular in travellers this place. And there is no fees to visit this place. But worth to have a life time experience. You have to climb alot of stair case to reach up. But once you reach on the top you will think you have achieved something really good. There are many Buddha's starting from the ground base which will boost you to go up stair. Every statue has a different meaning and different resemblance. And when you reach up you will find small beautiful statues over there. And they are still under construction they are building few more stuffs as well. When you reach the top amazing view you can admire from there. And you will realise that how much upside you have come.

Interesting Monastery. This is an interesting Monstery in Sha Tin. It is close to Sha Tin MTR, but not easily found, unless research is done beforehand. This place has around 10000 buddhas in various forms, and sizes. You start from the base, and work your way up the hill, which can be very tiring. Once you are on top though, you get stunning views of Hong Kong, temples within, and bigger sized buddhas.

Beautiful . Shatin Plaza or Shatin Central Exit A. Walk down the ramp pass the buses and mini buses. You will see home square in from of you (IQEA) and walk down the road between the back of Home Square and the government buildings. The path isn't signposted but you can see a metal fence and greenery so head for that. You will then see the signs and head up the steps passed many Buddha statues. It is quite a trek up the hill especially in the heat but I love visiting and eating Dim Dum at the Veggie cafe at the top.This place is far more authentic than the Big Buddha at Ngong Ping and a lot quieter especially if you go during the week.

Incredible journey :-). Located a few minutes walking distance from Shantin MTR. It was a bit complicated for us to find the place since there is a only few small ineligible signals :( The main journey up to the monastery is an attraction itself, as the path is lined on both sides with golden Buddhas, each unique and in different poses. Please be aware of the fake monks at the entry of the monastery and do not give them any money. Once you are in the main plaza, there is a restaurant and other facilities. You have to climb lots of stairs, so prepare yourself and take a bottle of water with you.

Twice visited . I've been to the 10,000 Buddha's Monastery Shatin twice now, the first time the Pagoda near the entrance was being repaired then a year later wow it was impressive. The site is a short walk from Shatin mtr but the walk is quite steep but it's worth the hike to take photos along the way. There is a vegetarian restaurant nice food reasonable prices. If you have a snack please be aware there are monkeys around so DONT feed them. They are shy you probably won't see them as I didn't. But there is signs around saying not to feed them. Both times I've spent the whole day there it opens 9am. If your into Buddhism this place is a must.

Worth a trip. I was staying in Shatin so i was close it anyway but it is so close to the MTR station that it would be worth a trip if you're further away.i went once on my own on a cloudy day, hardly anyone was there it was so peaceful.I went again with my husband when the sun was out and it's definitely worth taking a spare t-shirt if it's hot!take mosquito spray.take water.at a very leisurely pace, stopping taking pictures etc it probably took 1.5 hours.the buddhas are v impressive as are the monasteries. there is a veggie cafe (which i didn't eat at) and toilets up there.try and go on a week day & the morning, it's definitely aiming to go when it would be quieter.would be tough for anyone who struggles with steep stairs.

Utterly unique . This is a unique attraction in a vibrant city. Have to walk up about 500 steps (not difficult )Surrounded by hundreds of golden buddha statues each with a different expression. At the top there are great views and nice temple areas. Huge pagoda. Beautiful fountain. It's truly nice and peaceful and tranquil in a busy city. Enjoyed so so much. Location Shatin MTR station. Exit B. walk out to the bus depot and keep left. Walk towards to the central plaza. Keep left past a basketball court. You'll see a grand entrance in front. This is a cemetary. Need to take a right between the cemetery and the gray building. Looks like a tiny dead end alley. Trust me. Walk the path and you'll see the statues and steps.

Great place for peace and quiet in the city. This is a really interesting place to visit, although it would be great to have some signs in English explaining what everything is.Don't miss the Good Fortune Garden at the back of the Monastery it's beautiful!
So many Buddhas. Steep walk up and is a hidden attraction. We caught the train and walked over to it. So many Buddhas to look at and they are all different. This is a worth while visit.
long hike. It is along hike along the mountain to visit the temple. two things that make the effort worth it are the variety of buddha statues and the view from a top

I Love This Place!. Really enjoyed visiting this place since it was free and very interesting! Despite the rain (be careful on the slick stairs), the statues are fascinating. Temples at the top are worth checking out.

A perfect way to spend half a day . The then thousand buddahs monastery is perfect if you want something different to do. The main attraction for me was all the buddahs lining the stairs on the way up. They are not apart of the ten or more thousand minatures inside the prayer rooms but are in my opinion more fun to look at with their various poses / abnormalities. You could climb the stairs to the top in well less than an hour including stopping to look of take photos and there is not much ground to cover once you have reached the temples.It is one of the less known attractions of Hong Kong and you should get some good directions before venturing out. I also recommend bringing some water and climbing in the cooler hours of the day in summer.
Peace and Tranquility. Mmmmmmm - I can see this place when I close my eyes. So peaceful. You get a sense of calm when you enter. Another great cultural experience.

Worth the stair climb!. Take the train to Shatin, exit from the side away from the main mall heading towards Grand Central Plaza / Homesquare. The start of the walk up is just past and behind that building. It's a lot of steps, obviously harder in the humid summer months, but even those not so fit can make it up if you take it easy. At the top the monastery and the surroundings are picturesque and interesting to explore. You can grab a vegetarian lunch where a lot of the food looks and partially tastes like meat, but it's all soya. Strange! Worth a visit at least once.
Bring some water and walking shoes. The climb can be exhausting and during summer the sun can be burning hot so go prepared. Once you reach the top you will see it is all worth it.

Get your walking legs on. Be careful, the walk up the hill can be taken at a leisurley pace and the gradient is not too steep. My legs let me know the next day that coming down had really used my muscles to their capacity. II have stayed in Sha Tin several times and it is a great place to be away from the frenetic pace of Kowloon. The temple is a good side trip to do if you are in this area.I purchased a couple of items from the temple but remember the monks dont handle money so either leave it on the counter or in the honour box.

Climb to the Top. The Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery is easy to get to by MTR or taxi. Take the Eastline to ShaTin, Exit B - it is a short walk from there. Don't be confused (like we were) and go to the Cemetery nearby. Ask the locals where it is - it is not well signed and easy to miss. Make sure you have insect repellent, sun screen, a sun hat and water - it's a long way to the top but well worth it. Once you get to the top there are a number of small temples, the main hall and a pagoda. The views are spectacular. Well worth the climb to the top!

loved it! involves walking up hill but well worth it!. one of the special places in HK a great nature trail with over 10000 Buddhas along the way walking uphill to the temple, you might see wild monkeys and just a beautiful place, free of charge, its a bit of a ride from the city center but a great day out- it would tale at least an hour to get there by MTR bit there is a station right by it.

very nice. there is a lot to see
they must spend a lot of time looking after it
lot to see bring your camera you wont be disapointed but dont bring selfie stick not aloud
Beautiful view. Quite crowded but still very peaceful. The cable car is a must do! The view was amazing. A lot of cows around this place :)

Worth the hike. This is a bit out of the way, a hike from Sha Tin. It involves a steep climb with some nice views and, indeed, some 10,000 statues of Buddha and related figures. Worth doing on a day that's not too hot.
Well worth a visit and it's free. Excellent, lots of colours and experiences, interesting and free. Easy to get to using public transport, lots to see.
Great place and view from the top. A long walk to the top but very good view. Very quite and had a great view along the way to the top..

long walk to top. This was quite the workout to get to the top. Then it was amazing to see all the Buddas and wonder how some of them got there.
It was well worth it

Every step is worth it BUT...... This Monastery is hard to find, there are no signscoming from the train its apprx less than 10 min walk but again there are no signs, we had to ask for directionsfirst we though we arrived but than we found out it was a cemetery which looked like a temple entrance next to the cemetry is a house and a wall you have to go through the isle maybe 3 min walkIt doesn't really look nice and we weren't sure that it was the right entrance till we saw the sign.Wow seeing all the gold statues was amazing !!!Beware its a steep climb up and you need to have a good fitness level and good shoesIt was boiling hot when we visited but it was all worth it.make sure you are going right up to the top where you have to climb more steep steps but on the way you can rest on even ground and see all the temples and Statues insideWe loved the place but we were really exhausted.Its a long steep uneven pathway with steps. But a beautiful scenery

Amazing. This was such an amazing monestary. We went while it was raining. The hotel tried to discourage us from going but we went anyway. The place was almost totally empty and the rain made it so peaceful and relaxing. Rain or shine though, I highly recommend this place if you are interested in Buddhist shrines and temples. I have been to so many all over Asia and this ranks among my top few. Prepare for a bit of a hike up the hill. It's not bad, but could be a real challenge for elderly or physically impaired.

Nice place to see if you stay in HK for a long period. It is not my favourite and I do not bring people who stay less than 4 weeks in HK (so many better things to do). You climb around 400 steps in a concrete path with life-sized golden painted bouddha statues on your sides. And you reach 4 (5?) temples, pavillons and a pagoda. It is supposed to be founded in the 50s, but everything had been (re)built within the last 10 years.Not especially well maintained either. And not recommended when it rains (risk of landslide?)It is not one of the best of Hong Kong

SPECTACULAR.. You have to take a dodgy looking pathway to get to the monastery. you cannot miss it. the stairs leading to the monastery is lined with life size buddhas on both sides in all different poses. it is quite a walk up. once at the first level monastery, there is a temple structure with lots of little buddhas and a small souvenir shop. There are other figurines around the building. as you walk up higher, there is another temple building and a large sleeping Buddha on the right side. there is another short walk up some stairs on the right side where there is a figure with a waterfall in the back. very beautiful. alongside is also buddhas in the forest. Definitely worth the trip.

Depends on how much time you have. We saw this on our first day, it was interesting but we enjoyed so many other things in Hong Kong, that it depends on how many days your have. Other highlights would be Hong Kong Island, Victoria Peak, Nan Lian Gardens, Big Buddha, Kowloon street markets. If you are in Hong Kong for multiple days then take a trip here. We combined visiting this monastery with the Nan Lian Gardens and nunnery. The Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery is not that easy to find. Exit the MTR station and walk with the crowd past the open shopping area. You will see a large shopping mall ahead of you. Right before the mall, make a left and walk to the end to the road. There is a government facility here which you might think is the monastery. Instead take the small pathway to the right and you will see small sign leading you to the Ten Thousand Buddhas. The walk uphill is not easy but take you time and enjoy the variety of golden buddhas along the way. On the top of the hill, we enjoyed the temple, surrounding buildings and the views.

Highlight of my trip!. Makes for a good hike on a hot summer day. I was pretty amazed with the variety and number of the figures. Worth going all the way to Shatin, plus there's a mall there you can hang out in after you have visited the monastery

It felt like I was climbing Everest. Don't be mistaken there are 10000 Buddhas of all shapes and sizes. Can become a very steep climb but well worth the experience. When you reach the top their are a few temples very spiritual experience. Also beautiful view of the skyline.

Put on your comfortable shoes on and make sure to be there in time. We went there a bit late in the afternoon. If i was not wrong it closes at 17:00. So be there on time. It takes a few minutes to get up to the temple. I'm sure you want to take some pictures and buy some souvenir. All the way up is very tiring and do not recommend people coming with baby prams cause there are no elevators nor escalators. Cool place near to the MTR. Lastly be careful for the monkeys!!

Highlight of my trip. This place was the highlight of my trip, I found this place in book i brought before arriving in Hong Kong, it is quite hard to find as it isn't sign posted and is not publicised to tourists,

What a climb. Unfortunately the weather was bad when we visited which made climbing all those steps even hardier as it was like walking up through a river. Good to see but found it all rather grubby. Do realise it is a monastery but more English translation would have been helpful. Felt I didn't learn enough about it. The cafe at the top was ok for a canned drink but no way would I have eaten there.

A walk to remember. The monastery is a real treat to visit. Either side of the hill climb has Buddha's in various avatars painted golden. There is a ramp and steps side by side to help travelers. Waypoints along the incline give the weary traveler breathing time. The only negative is the approach or lack of it for the traveler. Shabbily hand painted sign boards point out the path. The approach is through some abandoned backpath. There are restaurants serving vegetarian food on the top (typical asian food). Good experience.

A tranquil climb. This is probably not there on most `packages'. If you are in Hong Kong for a few days and you want to look beyond the cityscape and visit places of spiritual interest, you should not miss the Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery. Not far from the metro station. We took a shortcut lane from the plaza across the station. The lane is next to a flower seller. There are two ways up hill, the stairway with all the Buddha statues and another short cut. The ten thousand Buddhas are miniatures inside the temple and not the ones along the way, which are more recent installations.We had lunch at the vegetarian restaurant in the monastery. Communication was a problem. Had fun practicing with chopsticks. They serve Chinese tea along with the meal which is quite refreshing.

Went to this place on my second day in HK. If you have asthma or heart conditions, have second thoughts before going to. Hong Kong Disneyland Theme Park is dedicated to the young and the young at heart. Your admission ticket gives you a full-day pass to Hong Kong Disneyland, where Disney characters come to life. Embark on a magical journey through various themed lands, such as Fantasyland and Toy Story Land. The whole family will enjoy the numerous rides, shows and attractions the park has to offer. Hotel pickup and return by MTR (Mass Transit Railway) to Hong Kong and Kowloon are included.
Tiring. Went to this place on my second day in HK. If you have asthma or heart conditions, have second thoughts before going to this place, the temple at the top is worth the tiring climb.

YOU MUST VISIT HERE!. Talk about a hidden gem! We took the MTR and followed the directions to find the (somewhat) hidden entrance to the monastery. We went first thing in the morning so it was not busy at all. We were one of 10 people there. For a visit to HK this is the best place to get a sense of what HK is all about. The many Buddha's were so interesting. And the climb will give you something to talk about for years to come. Bring a lot of water and make sure your camera is charged because this is a photo op like no other in HK. Can't say enough. We all really enjoyed it.

Religious site. One of the place to visit when in HK. Not in the center, u have to take the underground for an half hour and walk for an half mile to reach the start of the path. then u'll see the path going up and at the side the buddhas. Every buddha is golden and different. After a tiring walk u'll reach the top, here there'll be a restaurant, a temple (with a lot of little buddhas inside) and some altars. From here there is a beautifil view from the terrace. There is the possibility to buy some gift from the shop in the temple (tourist gift**)
Lots of walking and stairs...but worth it!. A great experience...even wild monkeys! I enjoyed this place so much. It is not crowded and has some great photo ops. I would go again!

Very unusual. Interesting to walk up past hundreds of these Buddhas- need to be fit- lovely at the top, very peaceful.Follow directions on website, is not that easy otherwise.Worth the train trip to Shatin. Can do round trip including walk up stay awhile and back in 2-3 hours depending on walking speed.

Go Early -- Make Sure to Walk Up the Side with Buddhas. Recommend getting directions from Concierge -- ours gave us excellent directions and upon leaving MTR his recommendation took us directly to walk where the Buddha's are lined up both sides. Then when you leave walk down other exit which takes you by all the monkeys and through the houses to the MTR. Great views, impressive Monastery and there is a restaurant at top to grab a drink or eats -- recommend taking bottle of water for the climb as not hard, but if hot you will sweat for sure. Very serene and not crowded at all like the Big Buddha can be.
Worth the effort, great views and peaceful atmosphere.. Nice walk up, early morning seemed best. Not too many monkeys around but would be cautious of them if a too many.

Serene place amidst HK . It's around 25 minutes hike to reach the top of monastery. As it is private, it is not marked well on the statues but it is amazing with the way such huge statues installed on top of mountain.Reading through history it seems that all this was done manually without any major support which is commendable. The views if shatin from the top are superb. A decent vegetarian Restaurant serves hot food to ease ur hike hunger. A small souvenir shop also sells interesting stuff at reasonable prices. Do give it a try.

Interesting. The 511 steps up could prove a challenge but there are seats to take a breather if needed. I am pretty fit and the heat did sap my energy, but taking it slowly helped. If it is a hot day do take water although there are a couple of cafes at the top. Slightly intimidating having all the Buddha's staring at you but it provides some culture in a place that is rapidly loosing it. Not that easy to find so check the tourist maps first, easy walk from the MTR.

Not too far from shatin mtr station if you follow the instructions on google search. Not many people come here because it can be quite tedious to climb the many storeys lined with ten thousand golden buddha statues to reach the monastery at the top. During the climb you will get to see many different deities with different expressions. When you reach the top you get to see a spectacular view of the Shatin area. Here not many visitors come because it is not right next to shatin mtr. It is about 10 minutes walk from there behind the government buildings. The climb will be quite tedious for the elderly. There is some construction going on there i wonder if they are constructing a new lift to aid the elderly and handicapped. There are also many taoist deity statues up at the monastery with the ain hall lined with ten thousand small buddha statues hence the name of the temple. Good to explore this temple. Very peaceful.

You need to adventure out on the MTR. Very peaceful, although in a city, once you have climbed the hundreds of steps up to the top it is quiet. Amazing to see many more than 10,000 Buddhas. Beautifully painted and covered in gold leaf. It is an active place of worship and should be treated as such although visitors are welcomed. Beware of the monkeys!

Worth the walk. After accidentally going into the wrong place, I eventually found the walkway up to the 10,1000 buddha monastery. The walk was good, each buddha is different and some are quite funny. This makes the walk a bit more interesting, as on a humid hot day, the walk can be a bit taxing!I didn't walk the whole way to the top, I stopped at the monastery. It was excellent.The level of detail is excellent, the views are brilliant, and all of the colours are so vibrant. Inside the monastery, it is very impressive and also very calming, much like the whole area. It is one of the most impressive temple areas I have seen in Hong Kong, maybe because it is quieter and so vibrant. It is nice just to walk around.I did not have anything to eat as I went in the later end of the day as it was closing, but that was quite nice as the crowds had died off.I would say only do the walk if you are fit enough,if you want to take photos, do so discreetly as there are many signs advising against photos, and the same goes for when you pose with the buddhas, it is frowned upon.Easy enough to get to from the MTR station, just make sure you dont make the same mistake I did, as it isn't sign posted, so walk past the entrance where you think it should be, follow the metal fencing and soon you will see the buddhas.Also, watch out for the many many monkeys!

interesting place. An interesting place to visit, close to the giant Buddha statue.It has a nice atmosphere, the buildings are well maintained and you get to see the old architecture and artworks. It also has a vegetarian restaurant as meal option.

Great visit, but not for the feint hearted!!. Visited the temple but had to walk up nearly 10000 steps up a mountain to get there. It was really really hot too! Worth doing though but make sure you go prepared with decent shoes and loose fitting clothes. No photography allowed which is a shame because it really is quite amazing. Free to visit so even better!! Drinks and food available. Wild monkeys are sometimes seen in the surrounding forest.

10,000 steps. Wow, we just kept going up and up, and steep. Forget how many rest stops we had to take, but when we got to the monestary it was definitely worth the "climb" not ideal for those with a weak heart.

Off the beaten track, worth the walk up. The Monastery is worth a visit - despite the steps up the hill. Golden Buddhist statues will greet you all the way up to the temple. Not two are similar, all friendly and welcoming! The access is a bit tricky. From MRT Sha Tin, exit B, walk in the direction of the central Plazza. Take the street on your left before the shopping center. You will reach the imposing entrance of the cemetery - misleading as you need to take a small lane between a grey building and the cemetery fence. There's a small sign on the ground pointing the way. 5 mn walk from the MRT exit when you know the way ... free entrance.

Great experience and novelty. No place like it!. A great experience, lots of different and sometimes entertaining buddha statues. Larger monastery with statues at the top of the hill. A lovely temple visit with spectacular architecture and design.NOTE: They ask not to take pictures at the temple at the top of the hill as this is still a place of worship.NOTE: Its up a hill/ mountain. two routes as far as I know up to the top. May be difficult for small children or mobility impaired.NOTE: There is a large cemetary/ memorial worship temple immediately in front of the ten thousand buddhas monastery. Easily confused as the cemetary is big, lots of people visiting with escalators etc. Ten thousand buddhas is behind this and up the mountain.Route 1: Where the big memorial entrance is, turn right as if going between the shopping centre and the memorial site. The entrance is quite obscure, behind fencing. this route sees most of the gold statues which you can take photos of and is a winding slope/ steps up to the top. This may be difficult for those unsteady on feet or when its wet.Route 2: Through the village. When exiting the tram station via the bus station (towards the big shopping centre with ikea) go through the market/ village area on the left. follow signs for the chi lin nunnery or a bee farm. This is all steps, with handrails and a bit steep.

Ancient Lifestyle. We visited Hong Kong and just had to see this place. It was built over 15+ years on a hillside by hand...absolutely incredible. We took the MTR out of town and changed over to an above ground train...it took about 30 minutes to arrive at the train station so very close to central business district and hotels. Once you leave the train station get your phone out and have it direct you up the 2 local streets to the pathway which leads to the entrance. The pathway is hidden behind a large home furnishings mall and a government building. There are no directional signs although you see the main red monastery building on the hillside from the exit of the train station. There are 10,000 statutes and all are different with personalities. The monks were praying while we were there and incense is burning everywhere. Monkeys live in the trees around the monastery. So much to see so make sure you Try It.

THIS WILL GET THE HEART RATE UP. Although there are well over 400 steps to get to the top, it is well worth it. As you walk up the avenue of Buddha's you can see fantastic views of the city and when at the top the main hall is an eye opener. Take plenty of water to drink when climbing.
Liked!. It was good to be there for Ten thousand Buddhas Monastery. I enjoyed to watch different shades of Buddha, and quite honestly liked it.
Hard to find but worth it. Make sure you take detailed instructions on how to find this place, the entrance is pretty hidden - well worth the effort though!

Interesting once you find it after leaving the train station. This was an interesting monastery which is difficult to find once you come out of the train station. (Best to head in the direction of IKEA... the the monastery enter acne is behind it).There around 400 steps to the top which is lined with gold painted Buddha's (fibreglass I think). More of a theme of a theme park feel than religious....There were some monkeys on the path which added to the experience.At the top there is a selection of temples which catch your attention. (It's not as commercial as Big Buddha which makes it more relaxing). Views from the top are worth a photo or two.(There are signs asking you not to take photo's in the temple area's).Signage once again at the top temples is so poor that we took an exist on the way down by mistake and missed the mid-level temples...... Therefore I would advise anyone to visit the mid-temple area on the way up to be sure of seeing everything. !Overall very interesting but Google the directions before setting off.....If in the area I would strongly recommend you visit the Heritage Museum which is nearby and excellent.

A worthwhile visit. This isn't actually a monastery - there're no monks residing there. It's a rather interesting Buddhist temple. The trip up to the halls of the temple is an adventure in itself. The many (many!) steps are lined with life-sized buddhas. Every one is different - expressions, poses, dress etc. The halls are something to behold - there's a wonderful sense of serenity as you enter. The countless mini buddhas lining the walls of the halls are also all unique! A thoroughly enjoyable experience.
A long climb to the top but worth the effort. A very long climb but take your time and it definitely is worth it. We enjoyed it once there. Coming down was quicker than going up. Glad we did do it.

Ten Thousand Buddhas - made of plastic!. Take the metro to Sha Tin MTR station and find your way to a monastery which is the home of more than 12 000 Buddha’s – mostly made of plastic. Do not expect a hundreds of years old place of worship – it is relatively new, but still worth a visit. We visited on a rainy day, the fog was hanging over our heads and the steep way up still made us sweat a little. Having reached the top we found this newer monastery and we liked it. As I said, worth a visit; but not on the top ten list of places you should see in Hong Kong

Monkeys and Ten Thousand Buddhas!. We almost did not go here because we had seen so many temples already, what is one more? If you go to Hong Kong, you definitely will want to go to this Monastery. There is a lot of history but the temple is beautiful, the grounds are very well kept, and there are monkeys everywhere. The monkeys were the highlight for my teen daughter. They also sell some jewelry and souvenirs there that are beautiful and very nicely priced.
walk over 400 steps up to the hill with our faith.. Around 10,000 buddhas stay in the front of way that you walk up to this temple. You can walk from Shatin MTR station about 600 m.

Lovely to visit (despite the rain). Getting to Sha Tin Station by MTR was easy. The directions from here to the Monastery needed to be a little clearer (but good directions can be got off the web).Having found the entrance there were about 430 steps up to the main level of the Monastery. Along the way there are about 500 Large Golden Buddhas (these are not the ones that give the Monastery its name). Near the top the path splits - both parts lead to the main Level. Here if one goes right one finds an ipper Gorge with a Statue of Kwun Yam above a waterfall. to the left is the way to the Ten Thousand Buddha Hall. along the way are more Golden Buddhas & Devas. There is also a small terrace with a number of (non-gilded) Buddhas.Reaching the Main Plaza there is the Main Hall (13K miniature Buddhas in here give the the name to the Monastery), the Nine Storey Pagoda and a number of other Pavilions.Directly from here is an alternative route back down to Sha Tin with a few motre Golden Buddhas

Curious but interesting..... The monasteries at the top of those steps are worth looking at, all very beautiful and feel pretty old. The buddhas on the way up and quite humorous, clearly not that old being made of plastic, but from what I could tell all unique and the kids and I had some sporadic fun making up stories about what they were doing on the way up (which distracted somewhat from the many steps!)They were dead set on closing at 17:00hrs, with a tannoy blasting out that fact every 2 minutes from 16:30 (which was a bit of a shame as it did rather bust the tranquillity of the place!).There's a small shop and cafe at the main temple - although we didn't need to use it so can't comment on its quality.

Late afternoon visit. Be prepared for many steps to the top, surrounded by buddhas the whole time. Once at the top, it's a great place to visit as well. We were descending right around 5 PM and saw a dozen monkeys on the path. Locals said that dusk was the best chance to see them...they were awesome to see and hear. Great way to end a day full of sightseeing !

Really cool statues!!. We didn't think the climb was that bad- and we had 4 young kids (8,6,3,1) with us! We are very active and had perfect temps (70 degrees), though! All of the different statues were pretty amazing! Take your time up the hill and enjoy all of the different faces! We didn't love the vegetarian food up top- but we enjoyed the sites and views!! It was definitely worth the trip out! Follow the directions given in other reviews!! It wasn't too hard to find.

Must in Hong Kong. It was one of the most interesting places.First of all it is closed at 17:00 and you need to be there latest 15:30 because you need to climb up the stairs which may take around 30 minutes to leave sometime to spend at the top. In the stairway on both sides you will see the buddha statues till you reach the top. The monastery was breathtaking where you can see more than 10.000 buddha statues inside.

Need to be fit. This was a great walk up some shorts small steps , but hundreds of them to the top , need to take plenty of water to drink if a hot day , views we stunning once at the top , well worth the pain lol

An interesting monastery in a quaint village. There really are 10,000 Buddhas, probably more. The walk is taxing for the unfit in hot weather but easy during the cool season. It's easy to reach from Shatin MTR and the village is a quaint departure from the bustle of the city. Beware of monkeys if you have food. Avoid feeding them or trying to get to close to them. They will attack as my 11 year old son found out to his cost.

Incredible.. From the Sha Tin station, the entrance can be tricky to find. It is between basketball courts and a mall. The walk up to the top is steep, but it is lined with interesting Buddha statues. At the top, there is a building with thousands of small Buddhas. It is an incredible site, and there are other shrines at the top, plus a view of the surroundings. This is a must see in Hong Kong and worth the walk. Another important note, the monastery closes at 5:00, which means they shut various gates at 5:00, so you could enter the base at 5:00, but get to the top and have it shut. Plan enough time! Also, on the way down, after the monastery had closed, there were dozens of monkeys around the base of the path.

Worth the walk up the hill. At the Sha Tin station, take the exit towards the bus terminus, turn left and walk along the basketball field. Across the road you will see a huge entrance, beautifully decorated and lots of people going in with flowers up the elevators. DO NOT go there. I went half way up to realise that was the way to a cemetery.Right next to that entrance is a tiny sign on a narrow path that appears to be leading nowhere - this is where you need to go.It's quite a walk up the hill but the smiling Budhas all around give you strength! Right at the top, towards the left is main temple area and to the right (walk up a few more steps) some more Budhas and small temple complexes. It's really beautiful and I would suggest a trip here to everyone. There is a restaurant at the top although I didn't try it. Seating available at short distances for the climb up.
Special. Make you trip early to avoid the crowds. It takes time to take in the magnitude of this wonderful experience.

Very steep!!!. You'll certainly not have seen anywhere like this before - the route up is extremely steep!! The Buddhas on the way up are somewhat bizarre and "amateurish" but the stop off at the pagoda half way is worth seeing, the views incredible and the top temples interesting! WellWorth seeing. Don't confuse it with the other temple/cemetery below!!!

Incredible variety of Buddha figures. This is one of the great sights of Hong Kong. If I you have limited time and are considering going to the Great Buddha on Lantau Island I'd recommend this instead. It's near the Sha Tin MTR stop. After going down the ramp from the station you follow Pai Tau Street until Sheung Wo Che Road where you take a right. At the end of the road there's a small traffic circle and a poorly marked path that leads to the trail. If you see escalators up a mountain you've missed the turn. The escalators lead to a cemetery which is an interesting sight in itself but not the Ten Thousand Buddhas. The variety of statues on the path and at the temples is amazing.

Nice monastery, but feels a bit run-down. 10,000 buddha monastery is easy to access from the subway. The street up to the temple takes 20 to 30 minutes and is not too exhausting. I didn't count the buddhas, but there are a LOT of them. Is it 10,000, I don't know... but very nice to see. The temple itself is quite nice, and is truly used for prayers by locals, so it's not a hollow place where only foreign tourists go and buy t-shirts. The backside of the temple also offers a nice view of the valley. There was one thing that kind of took me out of the experience. The preservation of the temple isn't perfect. You start reaching the temple road between fences, and some of the buddha status, if not most, are a bit decrepited and run-down, with the golden coating coming off. The feeling was a bit similar in the actual temple, making it a bit hard to feel the holiness of it all. Still worth a visit!

Definitely more than 10.000. The trail starts at the bottom of a very steep path towards the temple, during your way up you are accompanied by large statues of golden Buddhas each of them certainly representing something, but too many to identify. When you reach the top, you will be surprised by the beauty of the main temple where the inside walls are fully covered by mini Buddhas that glow from golden light (unfortunately inside no photography is allowed).

A Buddha Filled Hike. I really enjoyed my visit here, and I put this on my own list of must visit places in Hong Kong. I am not sure if there is more than one way to access the monastery, but I found it kind of difficult to find from the route I took. From Pai Tau Street (a short walk from Shatin MTR station), turn right onto Sheung Wo Che Road. At the dead end of the road, turn left into some trees and there is a trail that picks up behind the government offices which is not labeled. Once finding it, the hike is pretty amazing as the buddhas go on for what feels like forever up the climb. Each statue is unique and has its own personality. I had the place to myself going on a weekday which made it even more special. At the top of the climb, there are some temples and a place to buy drinks and snacks. Keep climbing a little further to make it to the fish pond, water fall, and beautiful view. Make sure to take water with you because the steps can be intense in the humid weather.

Worth a Visit. One of the first attractions outside of Hong Kong Island and Kowloon that I ever visited in Hong Kong. Located in the New Territories in Shatin, it is easily reached on the MTR system. A lot of steps up the side of a hill bring you to the monastery and the walk is worth the effort. Great photo opportunities and tons of buddah's on display. Well worth a trip out of the urban side of Hong Kong with great views of Shatin and the NT at the top of the hill.

So. Many. Buddhas.. This place is amazing. It really does feel like there are 10,000 buddhas here. Or, at least too many to count. Each buddha is unique, differing from his enlightened brethren in pose, facial expression, or attire. It's a bit of a hike to see it all, but well worth the blood, sweat and tears you'll shed along the way =P Besides the Buddhas, there are a few opulent temples, a waterfall, and some fantastic views from the top. If you visit Hong Kong and don't go out of your way to see this, you'll have missed something truly incredible.

Fantastic views at the summit; a must-see in Hong Kong!. If you are physically fit and want to see something truly special (and free), go here!!! You'll climb what feels like 10,000 steps, flanked with rows upon rows of glowing golden buddhas. Every statue has a different expression, a different face; some happy, some sad, some riding animals, some with several faces, different colours etc. BRING WATER and decent footwear! The monastery buildings at the top are awash with vibrant colours, giant statues and incense, and the surrounding greenery comes alive with families of wild monkeys and tropical birds, and there is a waterfall with turtles basking at the bottom. The view of Hong Kong from the summit is breathtaking. This was one of the highlights of our trip. So magical.

Hidden Gem. Awesome place! Really worth visiting. Not many tourists know about this and miss out the opportunity to see this wonderful place. My daughter (10 yrs old) had a blast and was not prepared to leave the place :)Just a word of caution -- be prepared to climb up a steep slope and beware of the beggar monks at the bottom trying to pan you the wrist bands!

Brilliant!. Firstly, make sure you are wearing comfortable shoes! there are a lot of steps to climb on the way up and can take about 30-40 minutes depending what pace you walk up at. The entrance to the path up to the top is quite hidden so make sure you try to find directions before you head there as it will save alot of time and energy. At the top there is the main temple then a few smaller ones located around. very beautiful and the views over Sha Tin are breathtaking (On a clear day). Take a camera for the way up but you are not meant to take photos in the temple itself (although some people do). There is no entry fee, so make sure you place some money in the donation boxes located all around the monastery.
Have your walking feet with you. What a place I do not know if there are ten thousand buddhas, but there are a heck of a lot thats for sure.
Extraordinary Designed!. Very spectacular design, dominated with gold ambience. Combining spirituality with ancient luxury ambient.

Wow!. This place is a must see for those who seeks peace... or a nice long hike! The clue is in the name... so many buddhas, it is truly an amazing sight!Make sure you have comfy shoes on though as it is a long walk :)

A very nice hike up with golden statues alongside. Can't imagine the scale and the "goldeness" of the statues! They have 500 different ones, some even using the faces of Qing dynasty emperors. We went up from the Pai Tau Village, the other side of the monastery, and we saw a lot of monkeys, they are quite friendly. After we reached the temple we went down the stairs that have 500 golden statues alongside.Really enjoy the trip! Be prepared to walk quite a bit.

amazing, peaceful and impressive. It is a really great place to visit, be ready to walk up some stairs, while passing by hundreds of all possible buddha versions along the way. There are some monkeys running around so better do not carry any food. Otherwise a peaceful place within the city. Definitely a must see.

Nice temple - lots of stairs. I really nice place, kinda far from the center, but still worth it. Dont have to pay anything to go in, but they have a huge stair walk, so you must go prepare to climb lol they have a nice view and its well preserved. And yes, they have 10k buddhas.

Unique experience. I was here 8 years ago on my first trip to Hong Kong and it is worth a visit when you are in HK. However the cemetery is right next to the monastery so be careful not to go into the wrong place like we did. We went on a humid, wet day, it is a lot of stairs to climb to get to the top however along the way you are greeted by unique golden Buddhas all with different expressions and faces which makes it interesting. I am not sure whether it has changed ever since, but you need to be careful of the wild monkeys loitering around and it would advisable not to take any food up there as it can attract them.

Boring. Very hard to find. Nowhere is no indication that close to 10 000 Budha. It located next to the cemetery and only thanks to the cemetery staff responsiveness we found 10 000 Budha. Go between the adjacent multi-storey buildings and a fence, then you will find the entrance! Entrance is free of charge, at the very top is a cafe. Warning that attacking wild monkey is not serious!
Breathtaking. This place is amazing, it takes your breath away, the gold Buddhas that line the walls are exquisite. No matter how many people are in the room the wonder of it takes over.

There's more that 10,000 Buddhas at this monastery. The walk up to the monastery is step but there are hundreds of life sized, golden Buddhas on either side: some old, some young and some are even women. The temple itself is lined with several thousand Buddhas as well.

Lots of buddhas. This is located close to Sha Tin MTR station. It is a long and step path to the monastery so not for all, but for those who can make the trip it is very worth while. There may really be 10,000 buddhas there. The whole path up to the monastery in lined with them, and each seems different from every other. Inside the temple at the top there are thousands of small buddhas lined from floor to ceiling on shelves.

A Must Visit when in HK. Take the train to Shatin station and walk towards the cemetery. There is a trail next to the entrance of the cemetery. Follow the trail and you will pass a lady selling joss sticks and temple paraphernalia. Continue till you come to steps leading to the Monastery. Along the climb you are being watched over by the many sculptured monks that line the pathway up to the monastery. The faces, facial expressions and poses are as different as there are in the number of sculptures. Some are cheeky, some kindly, some submissive, some humble. We went on a Sunday which meant that there were lots of worshippers and picnickers. It lent a festive air to the place. Though the climb was arduous for me it was worth every step. You arrive at the lower courtyard where there is a pagoda, a hall, two pavilions and a tower . The main hall which is an impressive building houses the ten thousand buddhas and the body of the founder. A small restaurant serves tasty vegetarian snacks if you wish to replenish the calories you lost in the climb. I did not go to the upper level as we wanted to visit the cemetery which is located by the monastery but has its own notable entry.
Must see in HK. The most colorful and interesting tempel we have seen in our year in Hong Kong. So beautiful and so peaceful. A must see. Interesting also for children.

away from HK Island or Kowloon, but worth the trip !!!. away from HK Island or Kowloon, but worth the trip !!! the entrance way is a bit hiding from SHA TIN Station, but worth the searching. Going up, one can see already a lot of Buddha Statues. I went there, when it was really HUMID, so swaeting badly. However, very much WORTH IT ! An amazing place

Lots of stairs but really peaceful!. Wasn't really prepared for the walk up to the temple ! Bring tennis shoes. The entire walk up you're surrounded by monks that are all different from one another so it keeps the hike up interesting! Once you're up there it's relaxing. I went on Saturday and there wasn't a lot of people. The temple is nice and lots of people are there to pray. It was super hard for me to find this place though... Ended up going to a cemetery on top of the hill before realizing i wasn't in the right place lol

Beautiful, although can be maintained better. Literally well over 10 thousand buddha statues all in one place. A walkway going uphill with buddhas in various poses and expressions. The temple on top is definitely the highlight, so do not miss it (closes by 530pm). There is also a small cafe serving vegetarian food.
Beautiful monastry. The monastery is beautiful, lvishly decorated nd a centre for prayer. We were glad to have visited this impressive love.

Interesting place. On your way to monastery you pass number of statues covered witch gold (though the cheap one..). Some of statues have strange faces or poses. The monastery itself is very beautiful. We tried some dishes in the vegetarian restaurant there and it was not a good move...

Enlightening afternoon. Spent an enjoyable afternoon at the Ten thousand Buddha monestary. It can be a little tricky to find, just walk behind the Sha Tin government building and through the fence. The walk up to the monestary past hundreds of golden Buddhas is a bit of work, the payoff is at the top where the 10000 Buddhas can be found.
So cheesy it is nice. Interesting insight into HK culture and traditions. Nice place to walk around. A place that feels very Chines in stead of 'international'.

Be ready to walk. The Ten Thousand Buddhas monastery is a must visit if you are in Hong Kong and have a few hours free. There is a walk through 100's of golden Buddha statues. It is up hill and be prepared for a bit of a walk. If you go on a hot day take some water.At the top there are a number of buildings to visit and the views are really great from the top.
Visit this as well as the buddha.. This is worth visiting as well as the buddha. Also, if time allows, eat at the vegetarian restaurant. Good value.
must see if in Lantau. The scenery combined with the amasing architecture of the monastry makes it one of the top attractions to visit

An amazing place to visit. An incredible place to visit and experience. Pretty steep walk up the trail but absolutely worth it. Could easily spend plenty of time there!Make sure you know how to get there from the MTR as we found there was very little signage. Fake monks are known to walk around the areas, and you know they're fake because real ones will never ask you for money.
