Trip to see the Ten Thousand Buddhas. There are some many things to see in HK - this is one of the hidden gems. About a 10-15 min wa;k from the MTR stop. Warning - it's a bit of a climb up - be prepared for a good workout. Once you get there, it is pretty peaceful and the 10000 statues are a sight to behold. Gets pretty hot in the summer - be forewarned. That is true for all of Hong Kong - especially if you have to walk.

Enjoy every step of the way. Easy to get to by MTR. I really enjoyed this from the bottom of the hill to the top, no reason to race to the top just take your time and take it all in. There is so much to explore and discover. The views from the Monastery are spectacular. It is so much more than I expected, it is a journey of 10,000 Buddhas and more!

Definitely worth seeing, very convenient location off the Sha Tin MTR stop. It was amazing to see all the different buddhas at the monastery as well as getting a little workout in at the same time. The buddhas are all different and once you get to the top you can have a pretty great view
Kitchy, but fun. Definitely tacky, but the views are stunning and the temple is really striking. The walk up is a bit taxing, but the statues are great and make good photo ops!

Highlight of our trip. Really amazing walk up the hill lined by Buddha statues along the way. The small restaurant at the top was inexpensive and had really good vegetarian food. Also a really nice play top buy some souvenirs - including Buddha statues and the like. The walk is pretty steep - be forewarned.

Definitely worth a visit. Not as many people go here because it is not marketed by the government. If you do a google search, you can find excellent directions how to get there. It was great to visit a place that was less touristy, but still interesting to see. Be prepared for a decent hike. There are more than 400 stairs to reach the top, but it was worth it. We even saw wild monkeys on our way down the steps out the back door.

Worth the visit!. Ashamed to admit that having lived in Hong Kong for almost 9 years, this was our family's first visit. We decided to do it this year on the first day of the Chinese New Year holidays because we wanted to do something spiritual to mark the start of the new year. It is a bit difficult to find as there are no signposts but locals were helpful with directing us to the path. We drove to Shatin and parked in the shopping centre carpark right next to the entrance. The walk up is quite steep but there are resting points along the way. It's amazing to see all the different Buddhas along the way, each with an individual facial expression, size, etc. The view from the top is also worth the effort. We had bought incense sticks and lit them in front of the temples at the summit. There's a local restaurant but we didn't try it. Well worth a visit - if only once!

Highlight of the day. We decided to see either Big Buddha or this and ended up going to see this: and we definitely don't regret our decision! Finding the way to the Monastery was a bit difficult and we actually walked through "wrong way" (and walked down the other way where we saw all the buddhas): on our way up we got so scared when we saw monkeys everywhere! Couldn't really believe we were just thirty minutes away from Hong Kong's hustle and bustle, the atmosphere was completely different. There weren't so many other tourists which we really liked so we could look around in peace.

Worth the Walk. Great place to escape the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong! The walk to the monastery is a pleasant hike through the bush and the quiet, calm atmosphere a real contrast to the Giant Buddha.

Little piece of tranquility in a busy city. Beautiful temple not far from Shatin metro station and definitely a must if your visiting Hong Kong and enjoy culture and a little piece and quiet after the busy city. It can be tricky to find as they are not allowed to put up signs as don't want the place overrun with tourists. The entrance to the temple is a dead-end, opposite the entrance to a multi story car park. But cross over to the dry river bed and look left down a small ally and you'll see the entrance. A fair climb to the top but plenty of places to sit and rest and worth the journey when you arrive, it's stunning!We also ate in the small restaurant at the top and the veg fried rice was amazing and have to say the tastiest and freshest we had during our trip.I hope the place retains its authenticity.
Nice Temple. You can get to the Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery using the MTR and then walk about 10 minutes to the temple. It's quite nice and if you have some extra time, go check it out!

if your in hong kong its a must. we wasn't sure if we should bother or not ....we are so glad we did
what an amazing site the ten thousand buddhas where amazing ( they say there is more like 13000) take your camera and make sure it is fully charged

Nice Place. Good place to visit...it is in Sha tin...very well connected from MTR. Get down and walk for around 400 mtrs and you will be at the gate of this Monastery. There are more then 10k Buddhas each sitting in different posture and different from another by face as well. It's quite steep so for aged its a tough exercise. There are escalator in different route as well but you will miss the nature so i preferred to use the traditional route and go by the steep road which has stairs followed by seats for rest also. In top there is a temple for worship also one restaurant to eat. Entry to this place is free.

Eye opening . Actually 2007 for brother's wedding. I needed something spiritual growth at the time and had very limited time in Hong Kong so my brother decided to take our family there. The hike up at first was hard since we are not fit people but once up there it was breathtaking. Seeing the shrines and statues was amazing. Felt centered after that trip. Would love to go again when I visit in October of this year

Really nice way to spend a couple hours. I usually don't have much time to sight see in Hong Kong but I had a day off and wanted decided part of the day would be spent at Ten Thousand Buddhas. As other reviewers mention, it is a tiny bit hard to find but take MTR E Rail to Sha Tin station and follow blue gov signs.....enjoy the journey finding it. There are lots of stairs and you are headed up so if you are pushing a stroller or have problems walking you will need to plan for more time. It was a little overwhelming seeing all the Buddhas....I always get asked "were there really 10,000...". According to the literature, there are actually 12,800 Buddhas but I didn't count. At the top there are several monasteries, a small informal restaurant (didn't try) and a gift shop. The views from the top are beautiful. As it is a place of worship it is a nice place to sit quietly, enjoy the view and reflect. It is free of charge but there are several places you can make a donation. I say it's good for anyone (who can make the climb) and understand the overall atmosphere is on the quiet side.

Great walk. We didn't plan ahead to visit this place and decided to do so on the same morning based on TripAdvisor reviews and it turned to be one of the best days we had.The walk was very pleasant, not difficult ( though we did count the steps and got the result of around 470 for the first level and about 150 more for the second level).Don't miss the second level terrace- the views from there are beautiful (especially from the furthest point where the little waterfall is)

Nice visit. Wasn't easy to find the entrance to the temple. Like most first visitors, we found the Po Fu Shan temple/cemetery (or crematory) first. The path to the Ten Thousand Buddha Temple is actually the path on the right hand side of the green fence separating PFS (left hand side is the car park entrance to PFS). If you look carefully the hand-written sign showing the way to Ten Thousand Buddha Temple is place near the floor on the green fence! The other way to the entrance was though the tree path at the end of the first street before reaching PFS.On the way up to the temple is a steep path with golden monks/deities (not Buddhas!) on both sides each with a unique expression and pose which we found amusing and fun rather than spiritual. There were seats periodically set out on the sides for visitors who need a rest.At the top is where is temple complex resides. From the top of the mountain we could see PFS and the rest of Shatin down below. It was genuinely awarding to see. Those who seek to worship Buddha or give charity may enter the large temple. Taking pictures aren't allowed inside. There is a small vegetarian restaurant too but we found it a bit pricey. But not as pricey as Po Lin at Lantau Island.Near the back of the area are steps which lead down back the mountain. Around here there are lots of monkeys jumping around. While not aggressive the larger ones did look like they didn't want to be disturbed. We didn't go all the way down the steps as we saw it headed to some village rather than back to the town center. We asked a couple of visitors on the way up where the steps led to and they confirmed it led to "no where but some quiet village" and they "learned the hard way by going down there".There are toilet facilties and lots to see at the temple but not much to actually do. I don't think it's a place for kids but it's a good visit to occupy the first half of the day if you haven't got much to do in NT area or Shatin - it is a temple after all not Ocean Park! Do make sure you have the right footwear and clothes to walk up there!
Very interesting with good views. Easy to find read other reviews. There are some funny Statues on the way up to keep u entertained . Awesome views at the top

well worth the hike. Luckily, the security lady (guarding an empty field?!) saw us take the wrong path and guided us to the correct one. The Buddhas are cool, each being different. The snack shop / restaurant at the top serves decent food, but it is one guy trying to serve everyone, so be prepared for a leisurely lunch. There are wild monkeys that hang out around the main plaza.

Do not miss it!. A wonderful path with Buddha statues all along the way, leads you to the Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery. An extremely fascinating sight, with huge colorful statues and many smaller temples to visit. It is situated on a hill which is surrounded by nature. Really astonishing...

Really worth while!. Like a million stairs up, but with cool statues on the way, and the monestary is really beautiful. And if you're lucky you can spend some time with the monkies. Just make sure you take the right way so you dont walk into the crematory.

How to find it?. Out of the main tourist area, this monastery is worth some 20 min metro ride north to Sha Tin metro station. But there, no signs for it, nor people speak good English (it's a residential area) to direct you. From the metro station you should walk to the shopping mall ahead (some 5 min), go round it to the back side, and then you'll see a cemetery gate. To the right of it is a small path that leads to the beginning of a very steep ascend (stairs) to the monastery.Be prepared for a sweating climb, certainly 15-20 min. During it you pass thousands of all different golden plastic Buddhas on both sides of a stairway. Very calm in a woods shade, take a few breaks for great pics.

WORTH A VISIT. Wonderful hike up the hill. The statues keep you busy and excited while walking up. The more you go up the more creative these statues get. I absolutely loved this place here. Wished I could have had more time. It closes around at 5pm. So make sure you are there at least 2 hour before if you wanna go up all the way. I know I would have if I had the time. We were almost at the time but the place was closing soon we had to turn around. There is another temple area close to this place across the mall. The further you up there they have buildings there for paying respects to the ancestors. That was also very interesting to see.
Yeah the walk up. Beware it is a long walk to the top of the monastery but it is well worth it when you reach the summit

Impressive. A little bit out of the main district, but well worth an extra half an hour by metro. You have to walk ut quite a few steps, but anyone can do it - just take your time and enjoy the mane buddhas (all different) along the way. Make sure you use some time at the monastery, and take in the view, see the fishes in the dam etc. Worth the trip.

Jaw dropping.... But my problem with this is that they built the monastery just to have it and because they raised the money to build it. It is new, oppulent, with access of gold and details. What a waist of money they could otherwise use for good causes. So much for modest monks. Totally disappointed.

Beautiful Temple. Friends to Hong Kong Try to visit the Ten Thousand Buddhas .During this cold weather, bundle up.It is comfortable, but it was me. It must certify that climbing up 420 steps to reach it. The view is stunning Getting there is very straightforward and MTR East Rail Line to the Blue Line station at Sha Tin Exit B when leaving the station Shatin Exit B, then we went to the left side.Go left indefinitely to a ramp down to the bottom. Let's look to the left to see.The walk to Pai Tau Village, down the slope along the bridge a few pulses.Will begin to see signs to the Valley.The Thousand Buddhas MTR 500 meters away from the line of sale. Source Shopping Lot Open - Tips :-Closed 9:00 to 17:00 pm

Combine short hike with visiting temple area. If you have 3 hours to spend in Hong Kong away from the shopping malls and this is a great place. It requires a nice hike up and down. While going up , you will many statues along the paths. At the first terrace you will see the actual 10;000 buddha temple.Don't forget to visit the UPPER TERRACE with wide variety of smaller buildings. You can take a rest at the small restaurant at the first terrace... The snacks ARE GREAT

12,000 chinese Buddha statues, steep climb, more climb. Actually not a monastery, 10,000 Buddhas has no monks, and has more than 12,000 statues. The statues are painted in gold were laid on the elevated sides of the climbing path to the main shrine. I don’t recognize most of the statues, looks like depicting Chinese Mahayana Buddhism. Getting there. Taking the MTR and stopped at Sha Tin, follow the main road to the left. There is an open field with small shops and resto selling pizza, snacks, flowers. Taking the left turn, you will find a white Chinese gate which is NOT the gate to the 10,000 Buddhas monastery. Follow a small yellow sign to a small pedestrian path which leads to the stairs. The climb is quite tough but they provide some shelters to sit down and take a rest. At the end of the trail is a fork, one is to the Pagoda and Main shrine, the other is to the smaller shrine and more climb. The Pagoda is red facing a white chenrezig statue. There are other statues but description only in Chinese.There is a vegetarian resto next to the Main 10,000 Buddha Hall.On the left path, there are more shrines, statues, more climb, and Goddess of Mercy sprinkler.

Gorgeous and Golden!. Like others have said, it's worth the trek out of the main city and into the Northern Territories. Hidden and beautiful. Others have posted directions so I won't go into it too, just remember that YES, that unmarked dirt path that looks like it leads to some sort of jungle is indeed where you are supposed to go! I didn't find the trek up the stairs to be hard at all, but I'm relatively young and was stopping every few feet to take closer looks at the statues that caught my eye. Really lovely up at the top as well, with more statues to see and pretty vistas. As a vegetarian, I appreciated the cafe up top, too...deeeelicious, and very clean!Beware of the fraudulent "monks"; keep your eyes peeled for the monkeys!

Quirky Buddha's. Once you find this, it's beautiful;a) At Shatin take Exit A2 at the station and turn left down the covered ramp down to street levelb) Follow it and cross over to the entrance of the Home Square Centre (and IKEA large sign) c) Don't go in, turn left signed for Sha Tin Govt Offices. d) The entrance to the car park is on your right but you can take a little alley to the unmarked entrance to the temple e) The welcome sign is attached to a fence around the corner.I would also watch out for fake monks around the entrances, they offered necklaces and bracelets. Enjoy all the quirky Buddhas on the way up, it's quite a step climb so I took my time and looked at all the different statues. All the incense smoke gave me a headache so I didn't stay at the top as much as I would have liked but I appreciated the views and saw the wild monkeys.

Worth visiting for relaxation and meditation. A worth sight to see. Small, calm, impressive, less tourists, cosy. It has its charm being hidden by the high tropical trees and colorful flowers. Monkeys that live there are not aggressive and cute.

The climb is worth it. Be prepared to climb a lot of steps, quite a work out but take your time and admire the many different statues along the way. this is not that popular with tourists so not so many people there. It is amazing when you reach the top. You can get a vegetarian snack at the top too. Great photo opportunities. I have made the climb several times, encountered monkeys on one visit but they were no trouble.

WORTH THE CLIMB. Not too far from Sha Tin centre so easy access via MTR. Go past the Po Fook memorial hill (well worth a visit as well) to find the path. The climb is not too arduous and is made very interesting by the 500 or so golden statues of the Buddha which line the steps. There are more Buddhas in the main temple and still more are being added. There is a vegetarian cafe with drinks at the top but watch out for the monkeys! Beware of the fake monks at the start of the path!
amazing monastery. easily accessible by sha tin metro station.. just 3-4 mins walk from mtr station and can start climbing very well made staircase on mountains. beaware of wild monkeys.

Offbeat but worth the walk. Shatin can be accessed easily via the MTR, which connects to a huge shopping arcade and also has lovely gardens alongside the less lovely river.Follow the online instructions as to how to walk to the Monastery, it isn't far, but it is a proper walk and climb. We met wild monkeys on the way as it quickly leaves the city and is sited amongst the jungle-like foliage on the hill above Shatin. Will much less ornate, in some respects, than the zoo Lin monastery on Lantau, this one has a simpler charm and probably greater variety of levels and religious artefacts (and oddities) to look at. Peaceful location, away from the noise, and with a great view on to Shatin and the surrounding hills. Would be hard work on a very hot/sticky day, but still worth the effort.

Amazing, unique and free entrance. Really unique statues of Buddha and lots of them. If you are a average walker, it should be no problem to walk uphill. Not recommending for disabled people because of the steps. We went early morning (9am) so it was not that hot when walking. There was no entrance fee, which was a pleasant surprise. It is just at ShaTin metro station, but can be hard to find (pass IKEA when walking). If you have problems to find it, ask locals.

Superb when you find it :). 1)I loved this place. Whilst it is very photogenic, it is not a tacky tourist trap that I was prepared for. It felt a far more scared place than Big Buddha and was more about creating an accessible open sacred place. It is free but think of it like a cathedral that suggests donations without even suggesting how much like the UK. The 10,000 Buddhas is about remembering loved ones, in the halls each Buddha is linked with a remembered person. A Very special place.2) finding the right entrance !to say it's difficult to find the right entrance is an understatement, so here goes with my definitive guide :) The hundreds of steps up is lined with quite a few of the10,000 Buddhas the way to the proper route up is:a) Exit A2 at the station and turn left down the covered ramp down to street levelb) Follow it and cross over to the entrance of the Home Square Centre (and IKEA large sign) c) Don't go in, turn left signed for Sha Tin Govt Offices. You will have the football pitch on your left go down until you reach the council officesd) Turn left at the Sha Tin Govt Offices down Sheung Wo Che Road go right to the end e) The entrance to the car park is on your rightStraight ahead is the unmarked entrance to the temple f) The welcome sign is attached to a fence around the corner ! g) You can come back this way or for a quicker descent there is an exit in the large square at the far end from the Temple.Hope that helps, it took me 40mins to find.

Great views. We were a bit confused as to why the statues on the way up looked like they did. We later learned that they weren't meant to be the buddha, and the 10000 buddhas were actually in the main hall at the top. Lots of interesting statues over 2 levels plus the steep climb up. The walk up is steep but very doable as there is lots to look at so you can take your time. There is a ramp as well as steps but wouldn't say it is wheelchair accessible due to the incline and uneven ground!

Amazing!. Pros:A lot of steps, but is amazing to see all the buddhas. Time to relax, a really good hike.Easy to find, but get the address/instructions to get to the place. MTR (Sha Tin station) - Exit B, turn left go down ramp and walk until you find a shopping mall (IKEA sign). I liked more than the Big Buddha.Free entranceClose to the MTRCons:Beware of people at the entrance.

Delightful visit. The Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery is quite a climb but totally worth it. The monastery area is peaceful and serene. Worthwhile going to visit.
We were amazed at all of the Buddhas; each one has a personality of its own!
Beware of the monkeys.

For those in search of the weird. Exiting the MTR, I saw no signs for the monastery. You will find it by exiting on the left side of the MTR and going left towards the mountain adjacent to the station. It is past a soccer court and you will then see some rather small signs guiding you to the stairs. Once there, you are greeted with a funky vibe that I would expect from an American roadside attraction. These aren't all just regular Buddhas. I found one with 5 foot eyebrows, a Mr. Fantastic rubber armed one, and one that looked like a demon with arms coming out of its eyes. A lot of fun to poke around and see these silly statues. Additionally, on one side of the mountain, you'll find wild monkeys. This attractions is a little away from city center but easily accessed by MTR. I recommend going if you like odd attractions. If you do not, stick to the main part of town.

So many buddhas. This is a lovely place, the facial expressions on the buddhas are amazing. Beware of the monks standing near the entrance, hitting people up for money (not just small change either). It's a tough walk uphill, but mainly shaded.

Awesome Activity. This was a great activity to do! We did it in August - so hot, so take a towel and lots of water. View from the top was awesome - We decided to go down an off the path route - was a little confusing! I suggest you stick to the same route. To get there, stay right when you travel from Home Square in Sha Tin - and be aware of the fake buddahs down the bottom on the stairs. Make loud noises and just say no - one of them tried to touch my partners necklace to -swap/trade- Anyway - worth it for a small trip.

A great quirky off-beat attraction with an added bonus next door.. I've been to many many temples all over Asia, but this one is special. The Buddha lined path going up to the Monestary is the real attraction. To see a few hundred life-sized incarnations of the Buddha in various forms (a Roman Buddah, a Japaese Samuri Buddah, a super tall Buddah next to a short rolly-Polly Buddah) gets one thinking of his many incarnations and life experiences the enlightened one had been through. Too bad none are women, but we live in a sexist world, right? The walk up the Monestary is a nice little workout, not too hard, but not for the frail. The 10,000 Buddahs refers to the 12,00 or so small ones in the temple at the top for what it's worth. The founders remains are preserved in the temple and you might miss that if you don't look for it.Now, what you should also know is that right next door is a mausoleum complex/cemetery well worth a visit--that one could combine with your Monestary visit. It is also up on the hill with its own funicular and escalators to ascend--so you don't have to do the climb a second time--but you can't cross over from the masoleums to the Monestary unless you can pick locks or leap over barbed wire. I accidentally went up the funicular elevator thinking I was going to the 10,000 Buddah Monestary missing the small sign pointing to the Monestary at the entry to the cemetery. The site is a complex of open rooms with plaques memorialize the dearly departed with funerary offering ovens nearby. Relatives come to pay respects and burn offering for their loved ones. it is customary to burn paper simulacrum like money, cars, cell phones, and watches so the spirits may have these things in the afterlife. On my visit, there seemed to be grocery-bag sized parcels of unknown contents being burned. The masoleums are not a tourist attraction, so behave with quiet deference.

A great experience - Recommend visiting. Warning, there are Buddhas at the bottom of the stairway - they are FAKE and ask for money. Ignore them and carry on. Really monks do not ask for money. It was an amazing journey, so many sculptures to view along the stairway to the temple. At the top there are multiple temples to visit, all of them were beautiful. A couple of hours very well spent.
Impressive .. More then 10000 buddhas, small and big size , nog so easy to find . A little bit disappointment way up , because of iron plates boarding THE stairway. Up Hill Nice view !

A Buddha here, a Buddha there, Buddhas everywhere. This was truly fun and a great workout. An uphill climb to the monastery was rewarded with a path adorned with Buddhas in various poses. You can tell a lot of work and respect went into this place. At the top you are treated to beautiful views and you guessed it, more Buddhas. I wonder if there really are ten thousand but there are so many it doesn't really matter. Easy enough to get to by metro and a short walk from there.

Nice diversion from busy ShaTin. It is not quite a calm oasis in a sea of concrete jungle and humanity like the Chi Lin Nunnery in Diamond Hill, still it is a nice few hours visit not far from the ultra crowded Shatin MTR and surrounding malls.Direction from MTR can be found on the right hand column here in TA, it is not well marked but the street between the IKEA building and the Government Building/ICAC will lead you to the entrance.From there depends on your physical ability, it is about 20 to 30 minutes hike on a staircase/slope. Along the way you will see many Golden Buddha statues, each with different look.When you get to the top (actually only about 2/3rd up since they built more stuff further up) you will see the main temple and the vegetarian canteen and more statues.Further up more temples, statues of all kind and at the end there is a female Buddha (see photo).I also attached a photo of worker with Motorized cart going up deep slope. That's how they transport goods up and down daily.Vegetarian meals are decent, standard fare.All in all a nice visit on a beautiful weather day.

Lovely but geared for the tourist.. I went here with my brother, brother in law and a few children.The climb up is quite the feat, lucky for me with a bad leg my brother packed me on his back part of the way. It's a great place for a bit of exercise or to wear out some active children on the hike alone.Once at the temple the beauty, nature, views and peacefulness is so worth it!! There is another small climb to the top where you will find some awe inspiring treasures.I would definitely recommend this to anyone physically capable. Beware monkey thieves everywhere and fake monk blessings at the entrance.

Nice little place. Had problem in locating it, asked for directions but no help was forthcoming. So it was back to fiddling with the GPS and google map. It helped. It is about 10 mins walk from the Sha Tin MTR station. There are no signage.A steep walk uphill but very doable. I am obese yet was able to do it comfortably, it is about 450 steps. The stairs are lined up with golden life size statutes of monks. It is said no two statutes are same and there must be more than a hundred of them. The temple at the top is beautiful. Calm and soothing. There is a small vegetarian restaurant at top, but did not try it. A great view from the top.Worth the effort anytime.

Quite a trek to the top but awesome view!. First off it is a steep climb to the top of the Monastery. When we say steep we mean steep but there are benches to stop and rest along the way. The steps are lined with Buddha statues from the beginning of the climb to the very top. We found the view worth the hike up.

Whew! walk UP for a great view!. This place is not easy to find as there are no signs for it; however, from Sha Tin metro stop head toward the Big mall (with the IKEA store) but do not go in. Follow the street beside the mall (looks like a dead end) until you get to the cemetery entrance. There is a small path on the right - follow it and look for some very small signs that indicate the entrance to the Monastery on the hill.From the entrance one starts the long upward walk. The path is lined with the 10,000 statues painted gold, each one different from the other. There may be people who look like monks trying to sell trinkets, but they are not monks.Some parts of the trail are quite steep and we had to stop and rest several times. The first plaza has a large temple. Buy incense here to place at several incense burners around the plaza. From here one can walk up to the upper plaza.The Vegetarian restaurant offered a good menu.The walk back down was much easier! We stopped to take some photos of the cemetery with its waterfall and beautiful flowers.A nice outing on a Saturday morning - no crowds.
Well served food and nice view. The restaurant inside provides great food for vegetarians. Also you can enjoy the great view to have a look of the Shatin new town. Good exercise for reaching there.

If you have time then worth a try. A friend recommended it to me. Since there are no signs marking the way to the temple from the MTR station, you should first search for the way. Once you know the way it'll take only 10 minutes from the station to the entrance of the temple. Be prepared to walk many many steps, so nothing for summer. I didn'yliked the buddha statues, as they were made of plastic, but each of them look different, so might be interesting to look at. On the hill you have a great view down on the city. I would recommend to go there early in the morning when it is quiet

Simple Hike and Nice Place. One of the must place to visit in HK. 5 minute walk from Shatin MTR station. This place has more than 10000 different Buddha statue. The hike is very simple and the view from the top is awesome. There is a veg restaurant at top. You can cover this places within 2 hours and take lots of pictures.

Very special temple in hk. The place has been re-decorated and you can see all many golden Buddhas status in every corners.It is located 10mins walk from Shatin mtr station n you will have another15mins upward hike to the temple. There is vegetarian food available at the temple.You can have a refreshing day in traveling this thousand Buddhas temple.

Great site. Recommended to visit here and it was worth the trip. All the Buddha are individual although they do not look like the traditional Buddha figure. Get to the xxx MTR go down the slope and bear left until you get to opposite the home furnishings store, then there are 2 ways to get to the site one follows the path along the side of the football pitch to the left this is quite a steep climb up but brings you straight into the site without seeing any of the Buddha The other route to the right past the Home Square home furnishing store turn left opposite the car park takes you up the path past the golden statues into the site. There is a canteen on the site but can’t comment on how good it is as did not use it or the toilets. Overall the site is dramatic with some great statues and an elegant pagoda. The main temple has multiple small very individual Buddha’s donated by lots of different families. The walk up/down can be strenuous but managed if you take your time even if you have dodgy knees like me. Glad we went.
Excellent and worth visiting. The restaurant was excellent and splendid views - I really enjoyed my visit and saw splendid views! My meal well great value and tasted fab!

Moving Experience. The Monastery is well worth a visit with intricate designs and very ornate walls & ceilings highlighting the work & money involved in the building. No photographs are allowed however the doors are left wide open so you can take pictures from the outside

Fantastic and free. This is a fantastic place to go, but be prepared to climb a lot of stairs but it is well worth it and there are a lot of places to stop. There is a great little restaurant at the top as well as other buildings and even a turtle pond. This is unquestionably one of the must see things to do in Hong Kong. It can be a little hard to find but if you find the Ikea, you are close.

Love this place. Have been to quite a few temples throughout Asia but this one of my favorites. Lots to see and very impressive structures throughout with very intricate sculptures and decorative details. It can get busy but any popular sight in HK will be.
Eye opening for kids. It was the first time I brought my kids to place like that. It's different and very Chinese. Worth visiting if you don't mind it's religious setting.

What's a nice place!. It is really nice and quiet place, which is different from other parts in Hong Kong. Fresh air, not pack with people, delicious and valued vegetarian dishes in their resturant, pretty scenery. Although it has many stairs to climb up to there, it is really worth to go!
Really impressive. extremely convenient to visit while visiting the giant Buddha. Beautiful compound; quiet and peaceful.

A good hike. There may be ten thousands Buddha's (or more) I'll never know cuz I lost count. You will build up quite an appetite by walking up to the top. In summer its very humid and you sweat a lot but the temperature on top is much better as its nestled between mountains and the views below are very nice.

I can't believe I've never been here before.... Whenever I'm in Hong Kong, I tend to stay in my ancestral village in Sha Tin, which, as you travellers will know, is in the New Territories.Now, I've heard about ten Thousand Buddha Monastery, but I've just never been, I always found myself in other areas of Hong Kong - TST, Mong Kok, Lan Kwai Fong, you know, that kind of place. It was, however, on a lazy free Sunday, on a very recent trip, that we decided to actually visit the monastery.We caught the bus into Sha Tin New Town Plaza, headed for the MTR station and Exit B and managed to find the place using instructions from a previous review on Tripadvisor. For such a location it's a bit odd that it isn't readily signposted, in fact, I don't think I saw any signs that we were in the right place except at the foot of the stairs leading up to the monastery...As we began our trek upwards we were met with three "monks", one of whom was about to offer me his beads (presumably in exchange for money), but luckily we already knew that the monastery, despite its name doesn't actually have any resident monks. The site is apparently maintained by volunteers, so don't be fooled, they're not monks, they're scam artists out to separate you from your cash.Anyway, the walk up to the monastery wasn't as "gruelling" as I was led to believe, however, I imagine it being a bit tougher in the height of summer - we went in late November at a temp of around 24 degrees celsius, and although we were sweating and out of breathe by the time we reached the monastery, it's well within the ability of most.You can approach the walk in two ways - the steep stairs or the steep ramps, we did a bit of both, mostly to stop and take pictures or to avoid people doing the same, as, on your way up the 431 step climb you path is lined with about 500 life sized "gold" Arhan statues, each one apparently different, though I could swear I saw some repeats, with some really "freaky" ones dotted about - we saw some stood on top of fish, some with multiple faces, and one with arms coming out of his eye sockets... Yes, you read the last one correctly.Every now and then you get seats on your way up if you need to stop to take a breather, however, once at the top of this path you're greated by the Monastery itself, which is indeed packed with approximately 13,000 (I didn't count, but they were stacked from floor to very high ceiling) little Buddha statues. Also in the monastery is the corpse of the monastery's founder Reverend Yuet Kai sat in a glass case.Just across from the monastery is the Kwun Yam (The Goddess of Mercy) Pavilion, a 9 storey Pagoda (which we weren't allowed in), there's a vegetarian restaurant, cases features more statues, oh and monkeys. Macaques specifically...I had no idea that the site was home to monkeys. We witnessed them taking fruit from bags that visitors had brought with them as offerings to the Gods/Goddesses, we even saw one "attack" someone, but it was chased off by a worker who threw a broom at it. However, mostly the monkeys only interaction is to wander around you to see if you have any food - so try not to have any food or even carrier bags with you if you visit. I had no idea that monkeys were that close to the city, I just assumed that they were concentrated in the various country parks such as Lion Rock and Kam Shan...Continuing up wards we were met with a giant Kwun Yam Statue sat by a waterfall, however, we couldn't get too close as part of the area was closed off for repairs or construction I presume. However, there are more golden statues and an area packed with tortoises.Whilst on the upper terrace you can get some breathtaking views of Sha Tin.Ten Thousand Buddha Monastery is well worth a visit (it's free so why not?) and should be considered in your itinerary for your visit to Hong Kong.

10,000 Buddhas Monestary. A true cultural and spiritual location. While not as popular or busy as the Big Buddha it gets many points for being a more authentic religious institution and not touristy. Being behind the government building also makes it seem like a hidden gem behind the busy streets of Shatin. The climb up the stairs is quit a haul but, is manageable with the resting seats along the way up. Once to the top the monastery is beautiful and serene. Yes, it's a bit away from the center of HK but, worth the trek and while you're out there in Shatin you should also visit the HK history museum and especially the Bruce Lee exhibit.
Its a tough walk. Best to do when it is a cool time of the day and you are feeling fit. This is a tough walk. Lot of history and worth doing but pace yourself.

Beautiful statues and a steep hike . The monastery is located quite high and hike to it is quite steep but you can sit down on multiple places on the way up so take your time. Statues looks beautiful. While up in monastery do NOT leave your things unattended, monkeys are ready to grab and run :D

A special temple. This temple is a little out of the way and quite a climb to reach the monastery but it's so worth it. All the different Buddhas line the pathway climbing up the hillside to the monastery. There are benches along the way so you can rest while making the climb, these were very welcome. I wouldn't advise visiting here on a hot day! Also I'd advise taking a bottle of water. Once at the top there is a cafe where you can purchase vegetarian food or a drink. Small souvenirs are also available. It's not a huge site and can easily be combined with a visit to the local shopping mall or even the nearby ikea store!

A must visit during your HK tour. It is a Buddhist temple in Sha Tin, Hong Kong. This is not a residential monastery and you should not expect see monks here. The path to the top of the monastery is lined on either side with 500 life-size gilded Arhan statues. Take MTR East Rail to Sha Tin Station to get there.

Superior to the Big Buddha. Easy to get here using another Trip Advisor reviewers directions: http://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowUserReviews-g294217-d593160-r53916427-Ten_Thousand_Buddhas_Monastery_Man_Fat_Sze-Hong_Kong.htmlThis was such a good find. We arrived around 1pm on a Tuesday and there were hardly any other people. I loved having the walk mostly to ourselves so we could take our time and point out some of the weirder looking buddhas. The stairs were really easy to climb and we were never out of breath (partly because we stopped so much to look at the buddhas also because the stairs and not steep and are quite gradual). We went on a beautifully sunny day and the view from the top was lovely. We probably stayed for an hour and a half total I enjoyed the whole afternoon!I travelled here with my husband. We are 28 years old, in good shape, hate tourist traps, and prefer things "off the beaten path".

Stunning place worth the trek. This site was incredible and one of my favorite stops in Hong Kong. Every Buddha is different, and monkeys are everywhere! Highly recommend going out there. To get to the site, don't get fooled into going to the cemetery with the arches, waterfall and pagoda (although it's lovely too). Look for small signs, and go around the back of the office building. There will be a small path between a red and green fence and the building. It'll make sense when you're there! The hike up will definitely get your heart racing, but it's doable. My non-athletic mother who is in her 60s was so glad she did it. There are steps and slopes, so you can pick which path is easier.

Definitely a must see for Hong Kong. You can easily spend a good few hours touring the monastery. Bring good walking shoes as it is up in the hills and you will be climbing a lot of stairs to get to the top but it's worth it. Great views over Hong Kong and a great example of Chines culture.

Once there must see. Place to see. Just at the entry beware of monks selling and blessing you>>>they are only crabbing money of the bracelets. Go up and see all. Could be useful to read more about the statues there before entry.

Tiring uphill climb.... This monastery is off the the beaten path. It's a good place to spend some leisurely time in; for some, it is not worth the tiring uphill climb to the top. But, if you are into these things, why not? Be prepared to spend at least 2-3 hours. Beware of the fake monks outside the monastery who prey on visitors.

Worth a visit. Firstly this place is really hard to find! Getting off at Sha Tin station head towards to exit which says government buildings. The ten thousand Buddhas monastery is also sign posted on the way out of the station. Follow the road down and to the left. Before you get to the end of the road you'll have the government and tourist info on your right with a small road with a roundabout at the end with the ikea/shopping centre next to it. Go right to the end and there's a small passage that leads to the entrance. If in doubt go and ask in information!The monastery is quite something. The climb isn't too bad and there's loads of Buddhist statues to help you on your way. Once at the top there's a temple with a small gift shop, toilets and a vegetarian restaurant. There's loads of amazing statues. The view is excellent. If you go up more stairs there's a second level with again brilliant views and more temples. There's also an outside water feature with a big statue and a fish pond. It's really relaxing.We weren't harassed by fake monks - didn't see any. I got bitten by insects so make sure you have some insect repellent! This is slightly out of the way but didn't cost much at all on the MTR and took about 50 mins to reach.

Pretty Special. This is a piece of old Shatin from way before reclamation, race courses, resettlement estates and shopping centers. It's a reasonably short but hard walk up, especially in the summer, but it is worth it. The main temple with the '10,000' Buddhas is very impressive.

This attraction should be higher on the list of "must see in HK"!. Perhaps it's a little off the beaten path for typical visitors to HK but totally worth the effort to get there and see! It was really great to get out of the hustle and bustle of downtown and see a different side of Hong Kong. It was easy enough to get to, just a five minute walk from an MTR station. The hike up to the monastery itself probably isn't for the infirm or anyone pushing a stroller, but for the moderately healthy/in shape person is great! Plus there is so much to see on the way up you can take your time! Even though it's call ten thousand buddhas there are actually more like 23,000 of them on the premises. The view from the top is beautiful and the whole experience was so peaceful and wonderful. I'm SO glad I made the effort to visit while in HK! You won't be disappointed.

A GOLDEN RETREAT WORTH THE CLIMB. This was the highlight of my trip to Hong Kong and best of all getting here was very easy.Take the MTR to Sha Tin Station, exit B and walk down the ramp to the left, follow this down to Pai Tau Street which veers left and continuing along Pai Tau street a short walk brings you to Sheung Wo Che road on the right, cross the road and walk to the end of this street about 50 metres on the left you come to a dead end and a wire fence, turn left and follow the path a little way and turn right between the wire fence and you will start to see the golden buddahs.It is really very quick, took my daughter and I about 10 minutes to find the beginning of the climb up to the top from Sha Tin MTR station.I am very unfit but I walked up the 468 steps without a problem, I didn't even puff and pant like I thought I would. There is a hand rail all the way to help you if you need it and seats to stop and rest if you get tired. I didn't sit once, I am 51 and a little overweight and unfit, so believe me if I can do it 'anyone' can do it lol !The buddahs are amazing and so well made, each one has a different expression. The walk up didn't seem to take long at all as I think I was just too impressed taking photos and amazed with all the buddahs, around every turn was a whole new lot of buddahs.At the top was an impressive red pagoda and amazing views over Sha Tin.The main building was filled with small buddahs without a gap between them, unfortunately there is no photography allowed in here.I pushed my luck and got a photo that I zoomed in from outside just to show how many there were.We were forewarned about the fake monks that lurk around the trail asking for money on the way up, we were surprised when we didn't see any but on the way down, there they were, so we quickly walked past and ignored them.There are warning signs everywhere explaining about the fake monks !! This place is definitely worth a visit, you wont be disappointed.

Beautiful Monastery. This is a hidden treasure located in Sha Tin. We took an Uber from HK and reached the base of the monastery. There is another monastery at the base and many tourists get confused and go there. The walk to the top of the temple takes around 30 mins and its lined with golden colored statues of buddhas. Once you reach the top of the mountain, there is a beautiful hall with 10,000 small statues of the Buddha in different poses. Also in the center are large statues that are majestic. There is a small vegetarian restaurant at the top where you can have some good food. Overall a recommended visit if you want to experience the calmness and peace of a Buddhist monastery.
beautifull place. i really like the place and the spirit. you can see mong there and people really religious coming pray. the temple is very beautiful.
Beautiful temple. Had a very enjoyable time but didn't manage to count the full 1000 Buddhas , perhaps next time around

Escape from the crowds!!. Once we found this place, thanks to previous reviews we thoroughly enjoyed it.Yes its a big climb but take your time and enjoy looking at the buddhas on the way up and down!We didn't visit Lantau but I am pleased we did this instead. Very quiet, peaceful place, not touristy in the slightest but definitely recommend as a day out. MTR was easy to use, it took us 4 MTRs from where we were located but this was only a 30min journey!!
Phew!. If you like Bling this is for you. Stunningly glitzy while being deeply religious and moving. A must-see for more than one reason.

Hard to find but worth the Look. We came on a day that we had planned on hiking up Bride's Pool but it was very stormy so we decided to find this place instead. We used our Lonely Planet book and followed the strange directions and found it easily but heard many tales of getting lost while trying to find it. Even in the rain everything was clear to see and very interesting. Also, perk, no one else was there.

Nice trip. The Ten Thousand Buddhas are including the Buddhas on the way up to the Monastery and lots of them in the Monastery. The whole trip is not that impressive but it is a nice thing to do if you are in Hong Kong for a long time and have a spare afternoon.

amazing. A short walk from the MTR station..You will walk a hundreds of staires but you will never get tired coz you see Buddhas with different faces, facial expressions and they said they had different history that amazed me. Its worth a walk. You well see the ancient culture of the Chinese people and how they valued their tradition. Just a reminder respect them when taking pictures.

Interesting. Be prepared, there are a lot of steps but along the way there are a lot of Buddhas once you get to the top have a wander around lovely view you can then go down the monastery way downs the steps which is much better... Worth a look definately but nothing too exciting

Buddhist monastry. There are over hundred steps to reach monastery and on the way there are numerous different Buddha figures and one thousand Buddha figures at the monastery. A place for worship. It gives breathtaking view of central Hong Kong .it is a lesser known tourist attraction but good for religious minded people

very nice renovated and historical temple easily accessible with short climb from Shatin MTR. A piece of Hong Konerest for decades in Hong Kong. As a child growing up in Hong Kong this was always a point of interest as we often came here on weekends to walk up to this beautiful temple and taste the street vendors selling freshly fried stinky tofu and riding bikes in dusty Shatin, a outlying village miles from Kowloon where business is done and people lived i Kowloon.

Buddha Everywhere. I had a quick visit before heading back to Manila with my friend who works in HK. Literally, the place was full of Buddha from the bottom to the top. Upon reaching the top of the mountain a nice view was awaiting us. I cant remember how many steps to climb the mountain but I will tell you Buddha are more that the staircase. I suggest try to visit the place on winter time and if you are going on summer (please bring extra t-shirt, water, water and water).
Lots o' buddha. We took a 20 minute subway from Kowloon. Totally worth it, we went very early on a weekday, 7:00am, and had the place to our self's.
A Must!. Instead of the big buddha, we changed our itinerary to go here, it was great! The vegan food at the restaurant was nice and, the place is nothing compared to the brand new big buddha

One of the most beautiful places I ever visited. This place is absolutely amazing. When I noticed the first Buddhas I could only say "wow". This place is breathtaking.A long time ago there was a man Yuet Kai, whom collected all these Buddhas. He loved the buddhism, but wasnt a monk. However he wanted to share this love with everybody and therefore he spend eight years to build up/create this place. You will find here more than 10k Buddhas and a temple. But before you reach this temple you have to climb up the mountain; only 430 steps. It sounds a lot, but in real life it is easier than you might think. Unfortunately I wasnt lucky; when I arrived at this place it started to rain. Try to visit this place when it is sunny; you will have a great view from the top of the mountain.There is no entrance fee; you can visit this place free of charge.I was surprised to hear that most of the locals dont know this place. It is more visited by tourists.
Spectacular. The mural tile work of Ten Thousand Buddha is a never seen before artwork. The other sculptures and murals in the monastery are also amazing
Recommended. Can be Quite a climb but will be woth it you can get a nice view of the area around the temple from Top.

Something different and new (old!). I used to live in HK and had never before visited this beautiful sweet temple in Sha Tin. Take the train to Sha Tin Station then walk for a few minutes. The way wasn't too well signposted from the station, if you can say 'Man Fat Sze', you'll probably find a local who can direct you.When you do find the bottom of the footpath/stairs there is no doubt as the way up is lined on either side by what looks like hundreds of golden statues. It's a tiring but worthwhile walk. At the top you can catch a great view, there is a reasonably priced vegetarian restaurant, turtle and carp pond, places to sit and relax, and the temple itself is lovely!!As you walk up, it's worth bearing in mind that the founder and his disciples apparently carried all the original building materials up manually, despite the fact that he was 70+ years old :)
Beautiful and Serene. The Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery is a place in the making - beautiful and serene and the same time.

10,000 Buddhas. Just a nice place to go. Escelators take you to the top. And you can either take steps down, or ride the incline elevator (recommended). Very well kept and a nice place to stop while in Hong Kong.

324 steps to heaven. A narrow path twists and climbs up and around a hillside above Shatin. It is flanked on both sides by Buddhas. All painted gold, fashioned from wood and everyone different. Not in size, they are by and large all the same size, but in expression and in appearance. Near the top there is a temple and 9 storey pagoda overlooking the town below. It's the temple that is adorned with ten thousand buddhas lining its walls from floor to ceiling. Very, very impressive.You're not at the top yet, but here you will also find basic refreshments and toilet facilities if you need them.Onwards and upwards. Through the continuing buddha guard of honour. At the top there is a waterfall (artificial, not natural) cascading into a well-stocked Koi pond. More views over the town, more buddhas (larger, this time) to enjoy the view with you. You have walked up 324 steps to get here, or you've pushed a wheelchair up the adjacent ramp. But you will feel that it has all been worth it for the sound of cascading water, a white buddha looking serenely down on you whilst you take in the view through the greenery to the town and plain below. Inspiring.

Hefty climb, but worth it.. Definitely one of the more unique experiences we had in Hong Kong. essentially a lovely step hill climb to a monastery where you surrounded by ornamental gold statues of Buddhas in various poses. The temple at the top is a rather nice crowning centre piece. If you manage to hike all the way to the top there's a lovely pool full of turtles.

Quite unique, but don't go out your way. The Ten Thousand Buddhas attraction was a place i decided to visit after living in Hong Kong for a couple of years. We had some visitors over so we decided to bring them as we had never been before. It certainly is a place that is unique even though it can be hard to find. The Buddhas are quite cool as they all look quite different. I'm not really a fan of going to see Buddhist temples, so for me the trip was average. If you are interested then I would recommend this trip but bring a bottle of water for the walk as there are a lot of steps.
Best thing in Hong Kong. This was the first and best thing I have seen in HK. There are a lot of steps to climb, but it's totally worth it. It's spectacular.

A pleasant diversion not a must-see. Decided to visit this place having lived in HK for a few months now and looking for weekend trips. Path is a little hard to find due to a lack of signage. At Sha Tin MTR follow signs to shopping mall (IKEA) then follow road round following government offices sign. Path you need is a lane running to the right, do not mistake entrance to graveyard as the path - this has a white gate and an escalator going up.When you do find correct path BEWARE THE FAKE MONKS who prey on westerners, they'll try and shove bracelets on your arms etc and charge you for them. Just ignore them, push them off. Happened to us today but we knew in advance.Climb up to the top does make you break a sweat but it's not horrendous (I've done far worse in other parts of Asia). If you're of average fitness you'll be ok. Bring a bottle of water on hotter days.Path is lined with gold figurines, all with their own unique character. Atmosphere slightly ruined by all the selfie sticks that inevitably dominate at tourist attractions now. Actual temple, pagoda and halls are colourful and pleasant but nothing out of the ordinary. If you have been to a few temples in Asia this is a very bog standard modern example. Vegetarian restaurant is reasonably priced and food was quite decent. We ate lunch there. All in all a decent place to visit if you have time, live here etc but don't go out of your way in a short trip to HK.

Family lost . We were dropped by a taxi a good 10 minute walk away and failed to find any signs for the temple. Even outside it was difficult to find. In the end the walk on the way up was lined with two troops of monkeys which actually made the trip for our kids. I would definitely make more to identify the place.

Long walk High above HK. Nice trip to take if you need to kill off half a day. Train or taxi to Shatin will get you most of the way there but be prepared for a long, although very nice, walk up the 400 odd steps. When you arrive at ground level, you see a temple. This isn't the monastery. You need to take the alley to the right and walk behind the temple. The path is surrounded by large monk statues, every one is different. At the top you arrive at the Monastery which has the thousands of small Buddha statues within. The veg restaurant is pleasant and basic and presents with some nice views over NT, basically the other side of Lion Rock. There is also a pagoda which the tour guides say you can climb however was closed due to safety reasons when I visited. A further walk up takes you to another area where there are more buildings and a great waterfall with monk statues and a great lady Buddha. The whole experience is around 45 mins walk up and down and another 45-60 at the top is adequate. Taxis and buses circulate below and another temple is at the bottom of the trail.

Unseen Hong Kong. Not well known but really interest place near MTR Sha Tin Station. Just 10 minutes by walk from MTR.Here you can find 200 Buddhas Sculpture on the way up the hill. After long way up you will find peaceful temple with Ten Thousand Buddhas in it.You need to be strong to walk up the hill. If you are too old or your legs not quite good. I don't think you can make it to the temple.Beware (fake) monks on the entrance. They will try to sell you some amulet.

And now for somewhere completely Different.. You reach this place that is not on the HK tour guide by having to climb up steps for about 15 mins,be warned.However along the way you pass hundreds of life size Buddhas in all shapes sizes and themes that at least distract you.At the top the monastery and surrounding area is once seen never forgotten,so an interesting way to spend a couple of hours.

Rough around the edges. I'm glad I visited, but wouldn't recommend visiting if time is limited. There are many more better maintained and classic temples in Hong Kong. Also, this isn't really a monastery.

Beware, closes at 5PM. The area around Sha Tin provides a very welcome relief from extremely busy Kowloon if you are staying in this part in HK. Man Fat Sze is a good destination that can motivate you to visit these places. It is close to MTR (Sha Tin station), but closes very soon (5 PM). There is a steep alley (rather a staircase) lined with the iconic Buddha statues that you can climb even if the monastery is closed. On the way from MTR, you can see a lovely Pai Tau 'village'.
Breathtaking, literally. ..it is a great climb. The climb up can be daunting if you are not used to climbing, but the Buddhas and view are well worth it

Amazing!!. A marvellous temple atop a very,very steep hill. Involves a very long and tiring climb but it is truly worth the effort (and it is an effort!!!) . The closest MRT is Sha Tin. The statues are incredible and are ALL different.
Under reconstruction. The place was under some reconstruction and open portion was small and very smoky with some oriental wood. Time to spend 15-20 minutes at least while under reconstruction.

Full of buddha. If you like visiting temple and monastery, you cannot miss this location. About ten thousand Buddha create a lot of good pattern for photography. Be prepared to climb uphill for around 20 minutes.Once you reach there, you can enjoy a good landscape scenery of shatin too.

An interesting and peaceful morning. We missed the Ten Thousand Buddhas Monestery on our first trip to Hong Kong, so we were determined to make it this time. It's east to get to on the Light Rail line to Sha Tin, although there is quite a walk to get to the top via the walk lined with some of the thirteen thousand Buddhas. There is no charge, but a blessing from a monk will cost if you can't resist it, although you will pay less than the bracelets cost at the monestery or in Hong Kong stores. We combined the visit with and afternoon at Hong Kong Disneyland

Impressive so many Buddha's. Really fun to go there and take the hike up. It surprises me how bad it is signed to go there. Basically go to IKEA Furniture Mall in Shatin and before entering the mall from the train station, stay left walk along the sports field. Then before the next government building take a right. At the end of the dead-end street take a left into the walking path going up the hill to the 10,000 buddha's. It is a hike up there, but your are joined by many Buddha statures. It is fun. At the top is the pagoda and other statures. You can go up more, which is recommended if you have more energy. A small waterfall is nice to see there as well there.

Utterly Amazing. Came here and was blown away. Every Buddha statue was different and amazing. Be prepared for a long hike. I came with a couple of friends and they couldn't get to the top of the long trail. Once you reach the top of the mountain there is a temple there with some really nice statues and an amazing white dragon with a waterfall. A must see!

Very beautiful and interesting!. I dragged my boyfriend to the monastery. I enjoyed it, but he didn't think it was all that great. I loved looking at all the different buddhas in different shapes and sizes. The climb to the top is definitely worth it. The view at the top wasn't that spectacular, but I did manage to get some great pictures. It's not a must-do attraction, but if you have extra time I would do it.

Great Holy Place!. This is a place you really have to visitthough its quite far, we took a long metro ride, but worth it!its a short walk from the metro, and first visit 2 temples which you will see. very nice and peaceful. on the second temple when we came, the priests met us in bright clothes with colorful decorations!they celebrates some holy holiday and the atmosphere was amazing! bright and happy.and the 10000 buddhas monastery is amazing place!but be aware of fake monkswe really thought they were real monks, thanks god 1 british lady came and told them on chinese something so they ran away.the way to the monastery is very difficult! very!it is high on the mountain and it so many stairs. though its so funny, with huge golden statues on the both sides of the stairs, with so funny faces :)and of course the nature is stunningonce you there - you recognize that it was really worth to climb herebig square with the temple and gods statues and city viewsamazing!inside the temple all over the walls are small buddhas they are so many - look so cuteand the temple is very beautiful insidethe way down is much more easierand there is central plaza mall just near so you can do some shopping and eat after a visit.

Long beautiful walk. It's kinda hidden and Google maps seems to not have the latest roads to the temple, so you have to search for it a little. Once you find it, you can't miss it. Along the road up to the mountain you will enjoying the view of different kinds of statues. Up the mountain there are several temples and a nice friendly cafe to enjoy the view. Don't miss the turtle pond by the waterfall.
Interesting Monastery. Interesting monastery, and a decent walk up plenty of stairs next to plenty of Buddhas. Its not a must do attraction, but its still a good place to visit.
Nice visiting. Nice to spend an hour visiting this temple. However, you need to walk up 400 over steps of stairs to get there.
Amazing place. Well hidden in Hong Kong its is an amazing place to visit. Be fiscally prepared as its a long walk up the hill. Breathtaking views.

10,000 BUDDHAS MONASTERY. Have just visited this monastery and found it quite an amazing place. Firstly, there are quite a few instructions available on the interwebby thing as to how to get there, I hope these are the most accurate, AFAIK, go to Shatin on the MTR, take exit B and turn hard left, walk straight ahead then turn right onto the ramp which takes you down to street level, the Pai Tau villiage will be on the left of you. As you reach the Grand Central plaza directly ahead of you, turn left into Pai Tau St, walk about 50 mtrs, cross the road and make a right turn into Sheung Wo Che Rd, walk down past the Government offices, and follow the small path at the left hand side where the street ends, a few meters up the path you will see the yellow 10,000 Buddhas sign. Sorry to repeat these instructions here, but I stopped to help several groups on the way back who were lost, so help this helps you find the way.  Now the hard part, I visited on a hot muggy day about 10am, and found the stairway quite a challenge in the heat, you will need lots of water and frequent stops on the way. I keep pretty fit and climbed the stairs in about 10 minutes, but passed one group on the way who had given up and turned back, not an easy climb in the heat. Please dont let the climb put you off, its worth it, the monastery is amazing, very serene and peaceful and you can buy a cold drink at the cafe there, and yes there really are over 10,000 buddhas. Stop in the airconditioned comfort of the Grand Central plaza to cool off on the way back, before heading back to the MTR. Hard to find but worth the effort.

Very nice. Very impressive, never though i could see so many different buddhas. Went on a rainy day though, that didn't help. A lot of steps to reach the top. Impressive temple, full of lights, each for a buddha.

Breathtaking!. Of all the sights I visited in Hong Kong, the 10,000 Buddha's Monastery was hands down my favourite. Located a quick walk from the Shatin MTR station, this trek up the side of the mountain is filled with thousands upon thousands of golden buddha's each that is unique and captivating. At the top, the actual temple itself is breathtaking, with hundreds of Buddha's lit up in the walls. I went in the morning before it got too hot, and before there too many other tourists. I would recommend you do the same!
Uphill walk. One of the most interesting and fascinating places to visit around HK. It's almost surreal, the uphill walk is a bit 'tiring but definitely worth it!
Relaxing Outdoor Experience. I had some time to kill so I went and walked around. It was a very peaceful and serene experience. I definitely recommend it if you're in the area!

Visit in conjunction with Big Buddha. The monastery is beautiful. It's a working monastery, so you'll need to be mindful of services ongoing throughout. Try visiting after you visit Big Buddha. You can have a vegetarian lunch and stroll around the monastery.

Place to visit recommended. The Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery is situated on the hill side in Shatin District Hong Kong. You can take bus or train to Shatin then walking up to the hill about 30 minutes to reach the monastery. More than ten thousand Buddha statues sitting at the halls. It was great to see the mummy of a monk sitting in the main hall.

Beware of the monkeys. The monastery was a little run down looking, but still really neat to see. You walk up a lot of stairs to get up to it, so the views are great as well. I will say to beware of the monkeys though. On the way down, we found ourselves surrounded by 4-5 monkeys, with one only two feet away bearing its teeth at us. We managed to scare it a bit and run off, but it was a pretty scary experience.

Great place to visit, Beautiful. Great place to visit and great experience. The Monastry is high up on the hills so get great views from teh top. 10000 Golden Buddha awaits you.I really like it, beautiful Monastery and great place to visit. (Alot of Steps, see if you find the Shortcut to teh top)

Quite simply stunning. Perhaps we were lucky to see it with very few people around, but the Ten Thousand Buddha's Monastery was truly breathtaking.See this while on Lan Tau island on your visit to the Tian Tan Big Buddha.The Monastery is tucked out the back so you need to seek it out, but make sure you do. Look it up on the map and don't miss it.(The air conditioning is incredibly welcome on a hot day!)
Cute, nice views.. Fun. You have to find it though. Lots of buddhas there. If you're lucky, you can get "tofu fa" at the end of the visit from a local vendor..

Surprisingly entertaining.. I didn't come here on my first trip to Hong Kong. Having spent a lot of time travelling Asia I didn't want to see any more Buddhas, let alone another 10,000. But a friend persuaded me and I was pleased I went. The buddhas lining the entrance were particularly interesting. The really are so different, and often quite comical. Make sure you look at some photo blogs on how to get there as it's not signposted. The photo blog I looked at even had a sign that seems to have been removed to make the site even better hidden.
Beautiful Experience. Remarkable place to visit. beautiful sight. pity you aren't allowed to take pictures. Vegan Lunch available.

Spend few hours there to see what Budha monastery is. It's a very nice place to go. If you spend just less than an hour in MTR you see the HK from completely different side. There you see all the towers on a skyline but you are walking throug the jungle sort of. Monkeys are funney but might be annoing

Definitely thousands of Buddhas . To find this place we took the MTR to Sha Tin and walked about 5-10 minutes to get to the entrance (well hidden) which is down a side alleyway to the right before the white arch entry to the crematorium do not mistake the white arches for the entrance it is to the side and behind this large premises. The walk up is steep and about 400 steps so I recommend wearing decent shoes. Take some water as its abit of a trek and hot. It closes at 5pm so I advise going well before to have a decent look around. There is mosquitoes so be warned I usually don't get bitten but these ones seemed to love me. I enjoyed the walk around, the Buddhas are all made from gold coloured plastic and there is a lot of them all with different expressions. I wouldn't say this attraction is amazing if your into temples I preferred the Chi Lin Buddhist nunnery and bonsai gardens in diamond hill, Kowloon its stunning and seemed a lot less tacky.
If your doing the Buddha you should do this. The ten thousand Buddha's line the walls of the monastery, there are also dome beautiful golden buddha's.

A rewarding experience.. No trip to Hong Kong should completed without a visit to the 10,000 Buddhas Monastery. The views as you walk up the hill are gorgeous and you have a trail of buddhas everywhere... when you get the top you are rewarded with a gorgeous view and a stunning Monastery and temple!... Must see!

Worth it. Probably the best thing we did in HK. It was a little difficult to find (we accidentally ended up in crematorium), so make sure you check out google maps first! There are lots of steps, but the views from the top and the individual statues are fantastic.

Really great day out walking up the hill to this Monastery. Not far from the MTR Shatin, this is a really great day trip. Get there for lunch and try their vegetarian cafe. Its quite a steep walk getting up the hill, but the views at the top make it very worthwhile. Its also peaceful and secluded, a treasure in Kowloon.And do the return down from the rear exit stairs rather than going back down the front entrance. Walk to the far right-hand rear viewpoint and there are some stairs heading down to the river/stream at the bottom, just past the bee farm. It leads out towards the MTR station so you won't get lost.

Plenty of Stairs. A sporty walk uphill from Shatin station you will find this nice Temple. A liitle difficult to find, but take the direction to the Ikea shop than let between the building you will find the accessgate.

Hard to find but well worth the hike. This place is not signposted along the main road by the MTR station. It is behind a shopping mall and government office. The entrance is to the side of the latter. I made the mistake of going into a crematorium which is on the hillside next door. This has a fancy entrance with escalators to get up all the steps. Big mistake...When I finally found the entrance down this small trail, the hike up all the steps was worth it. Bring plenty of water on a hot day as you'll need it. Each statue is probably unique and you can see the different takes on the image of Buddha. Once you reach the top with the main temple you can continue uphill until you reach the waterfall. Allow a couple hours and wear comfy shoes!

Ten Thousand Buddhas. Really? Really!. Amazing place-tranquil and serene. The entrance to this place is at the end of a short street hidden away from everybody. There are no signs or directions but our gps confirmed we had arrived. We asked 2 people sitting on their bikes if we were close but they did not know eiither. We ventured around the corner and went down the path about 50 metres then saw some gold glittering in the filtered sun. This had to be it. It was. We were greeted by life-sized and very realistic statues of Buddha lining the path. We assumed that 10,000 was a generalistion but really there are more than 10,000. On the walking path itself which is quite steep, there are about 400. Each one is different and that is amazing in itself but the eyes of the staues also seem to follow you-or maybe that was just the effect of this spiritual place. Nearly at the top, there is a praying place and inside are thousands of Buddha statues around the 4 walls-another mind-blowing sight. There is a vegetarian restaurant at this level and it provides a good range of welcome refeshments. We decided not to go to the very top because of the steep incline and our time commitments but imagine the views over local shatin mountains would have been worth the extra effort. Be aware that this attraction is suitable for generally fit and able people. The path is steep and in places the handrails have been removed.

Don't miss the Ten Thousand Buddhas!. We were amazed at all of the Buddhas! Each with a personality of its own! They were delightful! And the monastery was very interesting and very peaceful and serene! Something very mystical about the Ten Thousand Buddhas. Worthwhile going to see!

A lot of stairs to climb. To be visited, for sure!Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery is a Buddhist temple in Sha Tin, Hong Kong. It is not an actual monastery as there are no resident monks and is managed by people who do NOT belong to the clergy.When entering the area, you have to climb up a sinuous stairway bordered by numerous giant statues of Buddha.The statues along the stairs lead to the Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery.A the top of the stairs, you have a panoramic view.

Must visit for International traveller. I did not know that I will visit a rare monastery in Lantau. Once in, felt the calmness all around. Nicely maintained, great peace of architecture I missed taking photos as these are not allowed. Would like to visit again and again.

good hike but worth it. Checked this out at the last minute deciding between here and Che Kung Temple and so pleased to have chosen this. The hike up is tiring and with the humidity a bit uncomfortable, took plenty of water. The way we went up was a steadier slope and step access it was shaded more with plateaus to rest. From the bottom of the walk up to the top it was decorated either side with golden coloured statues.Ignore the fake buddist monk at the bottom greeting you. Once up the top there are some temples and a great view. On this level there is a little refreshment place selling cans and water. Cans were $10HKD. Go up to the next level more steps and golden statues to more temples.Photographs in some of the temples was not allowed at all. The route we took up...take MTR to Sha Tin station and take exit B. This is where quite a few buses are parked up. Walk to the left down the slope and head towards the shopping centre you will see a sign with Ikea on it. Turn left into Pai Tau Street ( you are then walking in front of the shopping centre), walk towards the Sha Tin Government building and turn right down this street called Sheung Wo Che Road. Do not mistake the cemetery for the temple which is in Pai Tau Street beyond the government building. As you walk along Sheung Wo Che Road you will see car parks on the right and left at the end of this road. In the left hand corner at the bottom you will see some metal railings snd see the start of the walk and the golden statues...there was the fake monk in grey at the entrance.....on the way back down we took some steps to the left of the toilets on the first level..these are very steep and would not be a pleasant way up but a quicker route down, there are hardly any statues lining this walk down. You walk by old houses and come out in the market place area by the MTR station. .
Well worth the long walk up the stairs. Make sure that you make it out here, it's a lot of steps to get here, but well worth it! Make sure that you bring a bottle of water with you.

10,000 or 13,000 Buddhas are fun.. This is one of my favourite temples in Hong Kong. Never busy, HK tourism does not promote it as they think the pathway is unsafe, but I find it steep but ok if taken with care.
