They currently have about 13,000 buddhas there and are competing for sponsors with Nong Ping. See: http://www.lc-stars.com/manfat.html

Best monastery in Hong Kong. One of the most dramatic sacred sites in Hong Kong, the Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery is perched at the top of a hill in the town of Sha Tin, and visitors must climb more than 400 stairs to reach the temple and the famous nine-storey pagoda. The monastery actually contains nearly 13,000 buddha statues within its walls alone, and many more stand sentinel along the pathways and stairs. The statues come in a great variety of shapes, postures and sizes and the temple complex is breathtakingly colourful with beautiful views. Unlike many famous temples in Hong kong, the Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery has retained its tranquil atmosphere and still feels like a holy place; it is not commercialised and is seldom swamped by crowds. This is partly why it tends to make such an impression on tourists. There is a small restaurant selling simple refreshments at the top but it is advisable to bring your own water for the climb, which some find tiring. In some parts of the complex photography is not allowed - be sure to take note of the signs.In early 2013 the very top section was being renovated and it is now ready. It is a tall white statue of a lady Buddhist. Very scenic. When you exit from Sha tin station it's a ten minute walk. Go to the Sheung Wo Che road. The road will end abruptly and onto the left of the dead end there is a muddy pathway which will take you to the monastery. Please don't miss this.

Scenic place with a ridiculous number of buddhas. Easy to get to - the stairs start just a few minutes walk from Sha Tin station. You walk up the hill between forests and hundreds of interesting statues, then reach a few buildings at the top, including the spectacular hall of buddhas, plus a waterfall. You also get views over Sha Tin and the mountains. It really is a nice place.

Peaceful and worth the uphill walk. Its a nice place to visit , away from the crowded Hongkong Island. Worth visit for people who like peace.don't forget some water.10,000 step is little difficult but once you reach the top its worth it.View from top , temple architect is really nice

The golden ticket. Well worth a look, not easy to find either, but once you are there you feel as though you are in a Bond film. Watch out for the sneaky guys dressed up as monks at the entrance. They are not real and are just waiting for the next tourists to part with cash. Look out for the monkeys up the top, great fun.

1000 Buddhas...and 1000 steps. Nice place but a lot of steps to get to there. Maybe as much steps as buddha's :-)Worth to see but not to spend more then 1 hour. Can be quite hot to get there with all the steps, don't forget some water.
Be prepared for a steep walk. Was well worth it and the view was amazing at the top. It doesn't go right to the top of the hill but a great work out...

Only of u really like temples!! . Ok maybe choosing a summer Sunday w 3 kids aged 3,6&7 to climb hundreds of steps was not the best of decisions. Summary: - hot, crowded w people n mosquitoes- yes loads of Buddhas but which looked too kitsch for our liking - cafe up there served one of the worst Chinese teas we've ever had- confusing to get there as indications are few and it's easy to end up to a different temple that had a lift and an escalator - obviously not stroller friendly - a few "false monks" around, asking for money after they supposedly bless you (monks do not normally ask for money) So yes skip it.... There's lots of small pretty temples to visit in HK as well as better hikes and views..

Serenity away from HK. Visited this today and was really impressed by the colours and detail. The site was well designed and the renewal process is in full flow. This is a good escape from the frenetic rush that is Hong Kong Island and Kowloon.

Well worth the uphill walk. After a long climb up to the monastery the trek was well worth it. The temple and shrines were magnificent and the restoration work is ongoing to make it even better in the future.
The spring rolls in the café/restaurant were tasty and cheap.

Really good view of city. First time i got there, really confused about the entry gate with the cemitery, and we meet two fake monk who ask for money, and yes we just leave them with no money (real monk wont ask for money)Insider we climb like hundred of stairs with a lot of statue around, really good, and at the top of stairs well find a good canteen with vegetarian menu and affordable as well. really good view from the top of the temple, but smell of incense really storng.

Fantastic experience. This was absolutely worth the climb (which takes about 25 minutes and is up a steep hill - wear comfortable shoes and take water). The entrance is up a small laneway just behind the large mall. After ascending a pathway lined with unique golden Buddha statues you reach a wonderful oasis at the top. Find a quiet corner, breath in the scent of the incense and look over the bustling city below you. Wonderful!

What a surprise . My cousin lives in Hong Kong, so as we were only had a couple of days in there we had a fast track tour of it. I didn't know what to expect as I hadn't heard about the monastery and it was a pleasant surprise. All the Buddhas had different expressions and the walk up lovely. It wasn't busy in fact it was refreshing to get out of the hustle and bustle of HK City. I'd recommend going in sensible footwear, not wedges like I did but because it was a dry day it wasn't a problem. Take a drink too as there isn't anywhere to get one until you get to the top.

Interesting to see. Getting there was bit tricky. First we visited other place nice to see in hope we are in correct place, but its not Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery as the Lift/tram up was not working, so we had to walk around it and then we found the stairs. View from top is very nice as well as the waterfall, going up with all different buddhas is nice to see. Not so many people, which is good for pictures.

Excellent visit and an amazing experience. Be careful temple closes a 5 pm. A real good experience in the new territories just a few stops from mong kok. Amazing collection of buddhas. Well worth the climb up.

WAterproofs needed. On a very wet and thundry day a pleasure climbing to the temple good coffee welcomed us and the few other tourist, All British, had great fun looking around in the thunder and lighting and finding our waterproof gear was only showerproof, the Monastry did a good trade in ponchoes

Underrated!. I'm really pleased I made the time to visit the 10,000 Buddha Monastery; I expected it to be packed but only saw a handful of other people on the way up. It's a bizarre place, kind of kitsch but full of great photo ops.

Great place to visit. Very interesting place! There's small temples within this monastery. There's also food inside cheap and delicious - we tried vegetarian food inside and it was delicious). A must visit in Hong Kong.

Once you find it, it's worth it. I've been there twice and both times struggle to find the entrance. It's behind the shopping centre down some local path ways and signs are in Mandarin for the initial part. When you find the right entrance you have life-size Buddhas leading you the way all to the top and each one unique. It is an easy walk up when you are stopping and comparing. Spend at least 1-2 hours here including climbing.

Colourful and fun but beware of fake monks. This place has really taken off as a tourist attraction in recent years and as such the owners have spent money repainting, remodelling some of the plasterwork and putting up the 500 golden arhans along the entrance route. It's entertaining to see all the different faces but beware of fake monks asking for donations along the route. In HK true monks do not beg (nor are they allowed to by law) and sadly many tourists give these beggars money under the belief they are real monks. Do yourself a favour and put any donations you wish to make into the contribution boxes that can be found in the main temple.
A temple overlooks Shatin. The new way to walk uphill is much visitor-friendly. Many movies or TV programmes were shot in the main hall. Come and you may see pop stars.
Beautiful. Whilst visiting the big Buddha don't miss the opportunity to also visit the Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastary. It is a beautiful building and the Hall of a Yhousand Buddhas is spectacular.

A great and interesting hike up.. A fun and easy walk up. Interesting and has much more character than the big buddah at Ngong Ping (which is too touristy). Great for a morning hike, but do note that it is not so easy to reach as the signage is not too good. Importantly, don't confuse it with the nearby columbariam next door. You know you are on the right track once you see the golden buddah statues at the start of the hike.
Bling. It was a long walk to the top and it needs to be a nice day. Quite a good view from the top and worth the walk. Drinks available at the top.

A Must visit for Lord Buddha follower but beware of fake monks. It is a peaceful place and if you like and you follow Lord Buddha you will definitely love this place. Wherever your eyes go you will see Lord Buddha statues of different shape and sizes.The Main temple is having more than 10,000 Miniature statues of Lord Buddha stacked on shelves around the walls of the temple where each statue adopts a different pose and expression.Caution: Beware of fake monks. They know English very well and they will come to you for money. Best option is to ignore them and move.

Buddhas Galore!. Quite a hike from Centro but lots and lots of Buddhas...I think even more than 10,000! Lady Buddhas, baby Buddhas, smiling Buddhas, serious Buddhas...you name it..all in a lovely setting.

A must see!. This place is amazing. A bit of a pickle to get to. Other reviews have said that there is a yellow sign pointing you in the right direction. This has gone! From Sha Tin follow signs to the Government offices. Follow the road with the government offices to your left and a carpark on your right. It looks like a dead end, but if you continue on your left and follow the pathway by the wire fence (pictures below), then you will see the golden Buddhas. We had been warned of fake monks, but there weren't any when we went. Do not buy from them though! It is a long walk up but lined with amazing gold statues and it is worth the walk. It is beautiful. So much to see at the top! (And a cafe so you can have a rest). Definitely brave the walk to go and see it!

Nice temple and nice work out!. First of all, when you get there there is a fake monk who´ll try to sell you some stuff,Don´t buy from him.(he´s a con, I´ve warned you) Once you´ve passed him if he is there, then you´ll start the ascecion to the temple. Walking up the stairs with all the statues reminded me of some temples in Myanmar.Make sure to take your time and examine the statues as there are some scary and funny ones. Ones you are on top you´ll have this beautiful temple with all different buddha statues. The highest point of the religious sites has a nice view on this area.Bring a bottle of water if it´s hot you´ll need it.

This is beyond a tourist attraction. This was a moving experience! The monastery site is gorgeous and the stairs past all the Buddha statues bringing you ever closer to the temple enhance the pilgrimage mood. Watch out for the wild monkey who like to steal the fruit offerings.
The restaurant is very good with pleasant, English speaking staff.

Very nice and interesting place. If you plan a visit in Honk Kong is a must see place. To made the journey till Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery you can chose to go walk or to pick a cabin from Ngong Ping Village depend of the available time you have to made the visit.

One of my favorite places in Hong Kong!. Every time I visit HK I come to this place. The path is lined on either side with 500 life-size gilded Arhan statues, some of them are super funny and you can end up taking 1000 pictures while walking up to the temple! Don't be lazy, but do visit this temple!

Good place for Non-Asian foreigners to visit. Not far from Sha Tin Station, take a few mins to walk to the entry of the path. There is a chinese vegetarian food restaurant next to Main Tempo Building, but not recommend it.

Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery. Probably one of the best sites to see in Hong Kong. Hardly anyone there as not on the official Tourist map. Don't get conned by the fake Monk or Monks at the entrance as we did. The warning sign is further up.Get off the MTR and head for the Government building and walk around it. It is signposted from there.You will be amazed at the amount oh buddhas.

10,000 Buddas, a long walk. We traveled to the new territory to visit the 10,000 Buddhas monastery. Kind of interesting, but a very physical walk up a very steep hill. It was interesting but I am not sure it was totally worth the tough walk in some very hot and humid weatherIf you have the time and are up for a hike, see it. Its very unusual.

Not worth a visit. It took us about 45 minutes to get there from Kowloon and I was pretty disappointed when I got there. Yes there is a lot of Buddhas but that's about it. In my opinion it was a waste of time going there

Surprisingly impressively.. I'm staying close by so it was well worth the visit, but I don't think I would go out of my way to see it.Great climb and we gave up trying to count all the statues! Really pretty place as well. We got lost and went to the cemetery first, but even that is lovely with turtle ponds and large statues, so if you do get a little lost- don't fret! Just explore.
Beautiful Monastery. A beautiful monastery with amazing interiors and architecture, however, photography is not allowed inside the temple. A must if you are visiting the Giant Buddha.

Well worth the climb! . Although the stairs may appear steep and daunting it's very worth it, the Buddhas at the top of the hill are fantastic, if your lucky enough to have some sunshine the view is also pretty good! Well worth a visit

One of the best things I did in HK. I had a real moment of tranquillity and awe during this walk. It's probably the best thing I did in my 7 weeks stay in Hong Kong.There are lots of steps, but the statues get better and better the more you climb. Don't forget to stop off at what looks like a café about half way up - there's a gorgeous temple and pagoda.

Not worth a visit. The place is not well maintained and the background of the buddhas along the stairs give you the impression you are walking around in a construction side. Not worth the effort going all the way up that hill

Ok if you happen to be around Shatin. The buddhas are all one of a kind, so that is interesting. I wonder if I can use face recognition on Facebook to tag them :) Only really worth it if you like to hike in my opinion.It is difficult to find the road up to the buddhas, there is a small ally you need to pass through next to a huge building. and there is a small sign on the floor pointing you in the right direction.

A long climb up. The ten thousand buddy's monastery is quite difficult to find so ensure you research the area and route (perhaps printing a map) to take with you. If you end up in the cemetery as we did you have gone wrong - the entrance to ten thousand buddas is actually just adjacent. The climb is long and quite steep however it shouldn't be too hard if you are reasonable fit. Be sure to take water with you.
Top on the to do list in Hong Kong. The number of golden buddhas built along the sloping stairs are just amazing, and each with a different expression, simply cannot be missed!

if you like temples, great, if you don't, also great. yeah,the statues are a show by themselves, each one has a diferent face, body and personality.the temples are interesting and beautiful. Bonus: sightgeeing of hong kong.

Worth the trek to Sha Tin. Beautiful hike up the hill - the path is lined with gold-painted Buddhas in various reincarnations. The views from the top are incredible. You are allowed to photograph everything except for the halls of worship. There is a sign about avoiding feeding (& this being bitten by) monkeys but we did not see any. It was a peaceful place devoid of commercialism. There were no hawkers hassling tourists, no high-pressure gift shops. Definitely worth the trip.and will definitely help you work off all that dimsum you had for breakfast! There is a small cafe that serves up vegetarian food in case you get hungry. We did not try this since the place did not look very clean and the food was not heated. But we did get ice cold soda - much needed after the strenuous climb under the inrelenting July heat. Note: lots of climbing so wear comfortable shoes. Always remember this is a place of worship so don't make too much noise and don't smoke!

Worth the trek. It has been raining constantly and I was worried I wouldn't make it to this attraction. It is not listed in many of the hotels or travel brochures. It is not a real monastery and you won't find Monks here or anything like that. Once the rain stopped for a second, my husband and I decided to give it a go and took the train, which was a neat experience, to the area. Once getting off the train we walked to the monastery. You could see it on the hills. We ended up walking up one way, getting drenched in a short downpour, which almost deterred us from continuing. As you ascend you are walking through some desolate neighborhood, which was quite interesting and worth some pictures to the steps. Once you reach the steps you begin the see the golden colored statues, which continue with more frequency on your trek upwards. You will finally reach the "plateau" where you are greeted with some more statues and a pagoda, which was closed during our visit as they are renovating. We stopped at the little cafe, as I needed a break after the walk ( I need to get back in shape, whew). In the cafe we were approached by the owner/waiter who quickly dipped a cup in a bowl of steaming water in front of us ( apparently to clean it), then poured us some tea. I was pretty thirsty and didn't mind drinking the tea. We ate some sort of vegetable spare ribs??? and spring rolls, all very interesting and tasty. It is a vegetarian restaurant. We didn't get sick, so kuddos :-).... We then explored the statues and climbed some more stairs to the waterfall ( don't stop at the restaurant)..It was very serene and not packed with tourist. I loved looking at the different expressions of the statues and relaxing by the Koi pond at the base of the waterfall. There was another way up and down to both the waterfall area and to the temple itself. As we were tired an a little afraid of getting lost we opted to go back down the way we came rather than through another path with even more statues ( my husbands request, I was all for the adventure :-) I think it was an excellent day trip one I would highly suggest!

Hidden Treasure - worth your effort. Forget about the other commercial tourist attractions. We took the MTR to Sha Tin station; and followed the map to get there. The track starts at the end of Sheung Wo Che Road. Both side of the hill slope are lined with golden status of human size Buddha figures all the way to the top of the hill. The view and statues at the top of the hill were fabulous. Lots of photography opportunities. Very serene and peaceful place with none of the commercial tourist shops and buzz. This place is definitely worth the effort.
loved it !!. 10,000 buddha monastery was awesome !!! once u enter first step u will see 1000's of golden bhuddhas ..... from the first step till monastery ...

Take your time. Definitely one of the monasteries in Hong Kong well worth getting to. The walk to the top is very steep, just take your time as the climb and heat will mess with you. Once at the top the monastery is stunning, the hallway, the statues, and the view is amazing. Spend a little time there and take it all in. Be careful you don't do what my friends and I did, there is a cemetery type temple at the end of the street that is easy to mistake for Man Fat Sze, we spent 30mins there before reading a notice that said the temple was on the other side. Highly recommend.

Really enjoyable visit!. A real gem in the heart of Hong Kong. A short MTR ride To the Sha Tin station, then a short walk to the begining Of the steps. Yes, ir is a lot of steps up to the top, but they Are really enjoyable as you pass the thousands of Buddhas.It's really very cool to walk past them as you trek to the topWhere the Monestaty is. This is a must visit.

Great views from the top. Just expect to sweat a lot. . This has great views from the top. It also has the preserved corpse of Rev. Yuet Kai which is kind of cool. It's also a good place to take lots of pictures. The only bad thing about this is the steep climb. Expect to sweat much when traveling here during summer since summers in Hong Kong can be quite hot and humid.

Well worth the steep sweaty climb. Actually its not that bad but it was a bit hot and sweaty. There are some lovely buildings to look at too. I was disappointed not to see any monkeys on the way down the forest steps but if one had jumped out after my veggie snacks from the cafe, I might not have been so pleased to see them anyway:-) Very good veggie snacks by the way, although the ordering was confusing and I ended up with a lot of tofu too which was just too much tofu and looked a bit like raw meat so a bit off putting.

View from top was nice but be prepared to climb and sweat. Great if you want to burn some calories from all the dimsum you've been indulging. You think you're almost there, but nooooo...nearing the end, it got a little steep at one point. The view from right at the top, nearing some "waterfall" of sorts, had a pretty good view on a cloudless day.Note though that it might be misleading and if you laugh off this little sign and walk through a gate at the start, you will end up at some temple where they keep the ashes of people who have moved on.

Worth a trip. Really nice place to go. You will sweat like crazy since it is a bit of a hike (I guess when it is hot). But it'll be worth it! You will see gold plated statues on your way up on both sides. When you get to the very top, there is a pretty sweet view. You'll get to see big beautiful Buddha statues and a temple (place of worship).

nice view from the top, stunning details. Although there is soo much to do in Hong Kong, if you have time you should also add a visit of this monastery on your list. It is quite a workout to reach it, especially during hot and humid day as you have to climb hundreds of steps, so go in the morning. It also tends to get little crowded towards afternoon. The monastery is beautiful, focus on the details, you will be amazed.

Every step you take, they'll be watching you.. This is by far the best temple to visit, if you can manage the 10 000 steps to get up to it! Lining each side of the pathway are golden Buddhas in various poses watching you as you make your way up the steps. But it is worth the effort because of what you'll see at the top.

Easy to access, no admission fee, really cool experience. This place is easy to access via subway and not too far from the main/central Kowloon stations eg. Jordan. Just walk out of the subway and walk behind the government building (there are signs to this building). The hike is better than Big Buddha and the site is more impressive. It is free and very peaceful.
Buddhaland. Liked the place a lot. Aswell as the walk up to it. Lots of inspiration and fine views. IKEA was nextdoor.

Interesting place mostly discovered by tourist. It is weird that when I go visit the Monastery, majority of the visitors there are non-HKers. It is not those famous spot and I appreciate their effort in discovering HK.It takes some effort to reach the Monastery , including stairs but with no doubt less than that of the big Buddha.The name already tells you what makes this place special , the ten thousand BUddhas. You may try to count the buddhas but i will just trust it haha.
Combo this with big Buddha. Wonderful place to visit whilst there see the big Buddha Plenty of options for food and drinkBetter value for tat than going to the temple street market
a great visit. another well kept secret in Hong Kong. Worth a visit and enjoy the atmosphere. its a good contrast to the rest of hong kong

Good views. They have better signages than the last time I came (October 2014) and you're less likely to get lost. It's still a walk from the nearest MTR station. A lot of stairs to be climbed, but its worth it in the end. There's a nearby IKEA where you can dine for lunch.

"Peaceful, really worth visiting". It's a long climb, but absolutely beautiful. There are rest areas along the way though, very interesting every Buddha is different. It is well worth it when you get to the top, when you look at the Monastery continue up the steps for more Buddhas.

Worth the climb!. Went up the mountain with my parents, we climbed a long flight of stairs and there were these golden buddahs on the way, the moment we go to the top, the view was just spectacular. If you're too lazy to go to the gym you can climb up the mountain here haha!

A heck of a climb but well worth it. To get to this attraction, use the MTR to get to Sha Tin. From there you have a level walk to get to the entrance. Beware of men dressed as monks who are just there to take your money, they are just well dressed vagrants. The climb is very steep and I counted 497 steps to get to the top. It is a photographers paradise and whilst there we saw wild monkeys and some beautiful butterflies. There is a "café" at the top but from there you can climb higher to another area. Well worth the visit to see so many Buddha statues.

10K Buddhas. Hidden behind an anonymous government building there's a grotty tack that leads to the stairs. The pay off is the temple and buildings at the top, at time of writing the buddhas are in need of some care and attention.

Highlight of Hong Kong for me. I can't put in to words how much I enjoyed this place. I was on my first solo trip, and although there are plenty of tourists, the are several opportunities to find peace. The tram up there is very pretty, but the statue is breathtaking. Highly, highly recommend this to everyone.

Amazing and really worth visiting. Once you actually find the entrance to the walkway which is an unpromising looking path behind the shopping centre this place is extraordinary. The climb is not for the faint hearted with nearly 500 steps, but studying all the Buddhas as you walk up the hill brings lots of smiles to your face. Each one is different with different facial expressions and poses. At the courtyard at the top of the first path, there are some amazing statues, but the steps and path goes further until you come to a wonderful white Buddha and fish ponds. The way back down is a lot easier!

Well worth the climb. We decided to have a look at Monastery so we set of, it is quite a climb on a hot day, but there are rest areas along the way very interesting every Buddha is different. It is well worth it when you get to the top, after you look at the Monastery continue up the steps for more Buddhas and great view. Its alot easier coming down than going up but enjoyable.

Beautiful and peaceful. It's a long walk up the mountain on a hot day but well worth it. If you go up along the path with the Buddhas you will be impressed by the uniqueness and character of each one. Keep going to the top and find a wonderful statue of Guan Yin in a Grove with a waterfall near the tortoise pond. People are still memorialised here so please be mindful, but it is so beautiful and peaceful. Back at the monastery the main temple is awe-inspiring. Take some time to learn about the history of the man who made it happen: it's an extraordinary story.
very interesting . first time to this place, very interesting! truly enjoyed this. I only went to the monastery, however you can also eat vegetarian dishes there if you wish to do so. =)

Enjoy the views, the peacefulness and the buddhas. A pleasant hike to the top where we passed lots of interesting buddhas. The views from the top were rewarding and we enjoyed the calm serenity of it all. There is also a neat cafe to refresh yourself with a cool drink before the descent down. A great way to spend an afternoon.
Quite a walk, but worth it. it is quite a walk up there, with some monkey's along the stairs, but there are several places where you can rest for a minute. The monastery is nice to see.

Interesting & different. It is an up hill walk lined with Buddha statues. All gold colored and about the same size in very different poses. The Temples at the top are well maintained and the view from up there is beautiful. It would be more enjoyable in the cooler months.

Bit Tricky to get to. We had to take four trains to get there from Tin Hau, luckily you don't have to walk very far to each different train and the fair was very reasonable. Upon leaving the station we got a little lost but luckily found the entrance which is just a path between wired fences. Otherwise it was a fun experience and the walk up only took us 20 minutes from the station, (more if you're slower). but we really enjoyed looking at all the statues and the Buddha Hall.

In awe and respect to the work. Prior to climbing, I was wary by previous reviews that this might be a tormenting climb but hardly anything from it. Being a frequent visitor to Sabarimala, climbing the steps up the Sha Tin monastery embracing the umpteen Golden Buddhas in different forms is a sight to savor. I climbed in the middle of the afternoon after having taken the east line metro and alighting at ShaTin station. The entrance to the monastery is hidden away behind the Grand plaza between the mall and its car park. Taking the road between the Sha Tin government offices and the mall leads you to a tiny board directing you to the monastery. The skyline view from the upper level is beautiful. The religious craft is well visible at both levels. The 9 storeyed pagoda overlooking the Hong Kong skyline is a must visit. The faithful have plenty of crafts available to purchase and also free material to read on Buddhism. A place not to be missed while visiting hong kong.

Long Climb but Well Worth It!. When approaching the monastery you'll be greeted by lines of Buddha statues but be prepared for some serious climb. Even when you reach the main "square", there are additional levels with beautiful small temples and colorful statues. It's difficult to count how many Buddhas are there but they are all different and interesting. If you want to see the whole place, allow at least 2-3 hours of patient climb and exploration of all the nooks and crannies of the amazing monastery.

Hard to find the entry, but totally worth it. It is one of the great monasteries in Hong Kong, but it was hard to find. When I got off the train station I was expecting to see signs pointitng to it, but nothing, it took us a while to figure out where it was. Going up the monastery requires quite some effort as the place is up in the mountain. The good news is that in the way up you will see lots of nice golden sculptures of monks, once you get to the top there are other figures of people closer to illumination until you get to the sculpture of Buddha (sort of the path to illumination). Really nice walk.

Wow but be prepared for the hike up.. A short stroll from the MRT in Shatin. A beautiful and serene attraction well worth the walk up. Can be a little exhausting in the hot weather but there are seats to rest on the way up.Once you get to the top a temple awaits you with tiny buddahs covering the inside walls, breathtaking. Take water and wear comfortable shoes. Beautiful views of Hong Kong.

Hong KOong's most popular monastery for locals and tourists. The temple was founded in 1949 by the Reverend Yuet Kai and completed in 1957. It is really interesting to visit this very popular site for locals and tourists. The main temple have walls lined with almost 13,000 miniature Buddha statues. The site is not very elegant with all these buddhas and structures in various bright colors: gold, red, blue, pink, white, etc. But this is representative of the Chinese culture and it is important to see it.You can take metro and exit at the Sha Tin station, in the new territories. It then takes a 10 minutes walk and 400 steps away!

Stunning & peaceful ... lots of stairs so make sure you are in shape. The Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery is defintely one of the top 2 temples in Hong Kong to visit. it is within walking distance from the Sha Tin MTR station in the New Territories is one of Hong Kong’s most famous Buddhist temples. There are several different levels on the grounds with over 500 gold statues and 400 steps lining the path to the main (1st) level. The main level has the primary temple, several pavilions, statues and a beautiful 9-storey pagoda which is featured on the HK $100 bank note. The 2nd level, up about 50 more stairs has several more pagodas and a beautiful garden area with a small waterfall, a large white Buddha statue and many more golden statues scattered through the garden area.I imagine this would be a tougher place to visit with small children or elderly although there are both stairs and a ramp / hill so if you have a stroller or wheel chair and can push it up, it is possible but would be quite demanding physically. There is no elevator or tram to get up and it is a bit difficult to find. there is also another small garden area next door with an escalator and small tram but that is not the monastery ... you have to walk to the right of that garden area through a small passage and then you will see all the golden statues which start the stairs / path to the monastery. Lastly, there is a small restaurant and shop at the main level to get water, especially important for the hot and humid summer days in Hong Kong. They also serve food if you are hungry for a snack.

Peaceful and serene. This should be one of the top ten attractions in Hong Kong. It is not easy to find from the Sha Tin MTR as signage is very limited. Turn left from the MTR towards the Plaza and the sign is at the end of Sheung Wo Che road. The path up is lined with Buddhas, some with comical facial expressions. It makes the steep climb pass quickly and there are seats at various intervals.The title comes from the Buddhas in the Temple at the top, 12,800 in all and each with a different pose. Given the terrain, the entire project which commenced in 1949, is remarkable.The views back over the city are panoramic and offer a refuge from the hustle and bustle of the city. Lots of greenery and waterfalls and it would be easy just to sit a while and read or just get lost in thought.In all there are five temples, four pavilions, one pagoda and verandah.

Fascinating site. I visited the ten thousand Buddhas temple in HK the other day. It is a fascinating site. After taking the MTR to Sha Tin it is only a short walk past the main shopping plaza and Government offices to the start of the steep climb up to the temple. All along the climb are various statues of Buddha in different poses. Once you reach the temple complex take note it is spread out over two levels so there is a bit more climbing to get to the very top but well worthwhile. The temple and associated structures are well worth the climb as are the views. The place is quite peaceful with few tourists. I suggest you do the climb up when it is not too hot.

Mesmerized. I was there when everything was hidden in thick mist, and they were prepared the Birth of Buddha the next day, so it was qute preparation, everything was gold and brigh at the main praying hall. They had the ceremony, so we could see everything when it was supposed to be (a religious place) and not as one of many tourist destination in HK.

Peaceful and fansinating. After a relatively short train ride, the slow walk up to the main temples is well worth the time and effort. The detail, colour and serenity of the various temples are very thought provoking.Beware the fake Monks at the entrance who tried to extract $100HK out of us for a "blessing" and some beads.

The strangest place in Hong Kong!. It is a really strange temple. You have to walk high (but it's still ok for my 60 yo parents) the stairs along which there are big (human size) golden status of founders of the temple. All looks very bizarre. On the top the temple is very tranquil and the view is nice. It's worth visiting for sure!

long walk but worth the time. the golden buddha's are not the 10.000 ones :) there are in the temple up the mountain. Do not go up with the running escalators, this is the wrong temple. The entrance to the ten thousand Buddhas Monastery is behind it on the backside of the parking.

Nice getaway from the bustling city. Have been to that place a few times. It's far off the beaten tourist paths. Although not super spectacular, it's a nice place for a short uphill hike and escape the noise and crowd in HK.

Hiking Exercise. If you want a free place to while your time away then be prepared to hike Hong Kong's ten thousand Buddha. On your way up, you'll have a lot of photo opportunity so make sure to bring extra battery and sd cards!

Tiring but enjoyable!. If you are a Buddhist and Buddhist by heart, this is the best place for you. Located in the upper area of Sha Tin a bit tiring to go there because of its distance from MTR. You will be welcomed by Buddhas before you enter the site. This is a sacred place for prayer and meditation. Quite a serene vibe in the place. Bring extra clothes and towels. A bottle of water will help once you reach the top. A must see place in HKG away from noise.

Long climb before seeing the price. Not for senior citizens or person with mobility issues. Will walk uphill pathway lined with Buddha statues along the way. The temples on top and different Buddha statues are great! Don't get lost though, a lot of tourist mistakenly go to the cemetery beside the pathway going to the 10,000 Buddha. Just walk on any side of the Sha Tin government building and it will lead you to the pathway leading to the 10,000 Buddhas Monastery.

A world away from the teeming masses. The monastery itself was of less interest to this reviewer than the walk to and from the Sha Tin MTR station.Yes, there are lots of stairs (and let's face it - I'm not so fit) but you can take breaks as you climb up past hundreds and hundreds of Buddha statues lining the route. There are even benches to facilitate a rest. In late May there were mosquitoes a plenty. Be prepared!We got lost (just a little) but the reward was seeing how people were living on the edges of a highly urbanised environment. It was much more like a village existence with small, slightly primitive housing, lots of trees and undergrowth, open streams and narrow paths. No cars at all. Quite the antidote to days in Kowloon and on HK island! The monastery itself is worth a visit - other reviewers have done it more justice.There is a 'back gate' to the monastery which takes you in the direction of the MTR via a slightly different route. Arrive one way, depart the other. You may even see a small temple near the MTR ...right next to a pizza joint. Whatever you do, enjoy the journey, not just the destination (and take insect repellent).

Feasted by mosquitoes. Insect repellant is absolutely necessary! The mosquitoes were huge and plenty. I felt like I was feasted alive! Haha. I took about 15mins to climb up the stairs to the temple. There are two paths leading there. One has numerous statues lined at both sides,the other cut through the 排頭村。It's quite scenic up there, with view of Shatin. Cold drinks are available at the vegetarian restaurant, HKD10.

All tipes of buddha. We literally run up the stairs (a lot of them!...) to see the monument and it was totally worth it! :D There was so many different buddhas and some real monkeys too!Great temple in the middle of the city.

Amazing Buddhas. As for the title of it, it's ten thousand buddhas and you will see those stairs and you will think it's also a ten thousand steps though but as you go up each and every step you will amaze by each of the different looks of the buddhas very wonderful and their faces are all different as you reach at the top you can see more amazing buddhas there. You can't feel the tiredness as you see them all. It's worth it!!

An excellent jaunt. There are a lot of stairs but the many golden statues of varying character and expression keep you entertained on the way up. The terrace at the top holds some absolutely glorious buddhist statues and some fantastic views. Beware the monkeys!!! - They come in from the trees from time to time to steal the offerings made at the temple and have no problem taking anything you may be carrying.

Peaceful and interesting place. Delightful. Every Buddha different.. This wasn't in the top 10 sights but should be. Fascinating place and easy to get to on the MTR/train (light blue line). Go through the bus station and you'll see IKEA on the opposite corner. Turn left towards white arch and you'll pick up a little sign for 10000 Buddhas. 400 steps so not for wheelchairs or buggies. Cold drinks at bottom "pay what you think it's worth". Of course we paid extra as entrance is free. Delightful spot. The Buddhas who adorn the steep climb are all different. The 10000 Buddhas at the top is a sight to behold. A peaceful oasis with the juxtaposition of high rise buildings in the background in what would've been a beautiful vista.

Ten Thousand Buddhas Literally. Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery (Man Fat Sze) is a little off the beaten path but accessible by MTR. Like many sites in Hong Kong there is a slight hike involved but this place is awesome. There is also a nice vegetarian restaurant at the top as well. Bring water, face towel and your energy to hike up quite a few steps.

Loved this! Highlight of our trip!. We took MTR to Sha Tin and found it following instructions from previous reviews.The walk up is steep and hot but there are stairs (easier than steep hill) and lots of seats along way to have a break.The 10,000 Buddhas are not those that line the path, but rather it's the 12,800 Buddhas that are in the temple. We just loved every minute. It's the most visually busy place we have visited! Stunning hills, stunning temples and most amount of Buddhas we have ever seen. Keep walking up to next level and there are more beautiful things to look at.We loved it. It's about 20mins from city. Enjoy!

Peaceful, serene experience. Apart from the stairs, in my opinion, something you should do if you can fit it in. A work out for the legs, but worth it. The view at the top when you get there is amazing. I will visit again when I go back to HK!
Worth a Visit. Lovely to see and experience. Very calming and interesting - well worth a visit, especially if you're going to see Big Buddha.

A more traditional monastery full of personality.. Lets get the first hurdle out of the way, there is a steep hike up a hill involved and even though it is shaded and the hike trail is lined with hundreds of Buddhist idols along the way, you are going to get steamy and hot, especially in the summer, no matter how fit you are! Bring some water to both drink and pour on yourself! The walk isn't terribly long, but you'll feel it. There may also be mosquitoes, so bring some repellent. Having said that, don't be deterred. There is a very nice view from the top, the monastery is well kept and full of grand Buddhist images. You can take respite in the vegetarian restaurant that serve simple but surprisingly good food. From the first levels you can still go further higher for an even better view, you can visit the moseleum that is in these higher areas. Its interesting to see how most Hong Kongers are interned after death, there are not much space of cemeteries here! Just to respectful and have a look around.So if you are in the Shatin area, this is certainly worth a quick look if monasteries are your thing. The entrance to the park is very secretive, its behind the ICAC building BELOW the carpark. The area about the carpark leads to crematory area, you don't want to go there. Opposite the ICAC building is a shopping center that is a nice mall that sells household furniture and products that is worth a look too.

it's a walk...... you'll won't see all 10,000 monk statues while you're climbing up the probably 10,000 steps! it seems to go on forever but it does end. there's a veggie restaurant on top, small store, great views and an additional stairs for more if you still have the energy.

Hidden treat. A wonderful spiritual place, up many, many steps to a hillside location with temples and other buildings. Walk up one side and down the other. On the way up (behind Ikea) the steps go past many statues. On the way down, you pass by some remaining squatter settlements and then exit by a couple of shops selling paper goods for people to buy and take up to the temple to burn. Fascinating. If you go on a weekend you can see lots of people there to pray and honor their ancestors. Nice views over Sha Tin.

A must see from Hong Kong. Not easy to find (see below) in Sha Tin in the Hong Kong territories this monastery is well worth planning a visit. From Hong Kong central the trip will take about 30 minutes by train. Once you arrive at the gate you are greeted by a poorly had written sign and an alley with bamboo growing either side. A bit like you just walked through a broken chain link fence. But what you will find on the other side will blow you away. This was one of the greatest sights. Not for the feint hearted, or those out of condition, to get to the top you will have to climb 400 steps up a hill side, lined all the way with gold Buddha's. Truly fascinating. At the top after a cup of tea to refresh you, the sights and layout of this monastery are like no other. This is one memory I will have forever. Seriously there are more than 10000 Buddha's here, turtles in a pond, a happy Buddha in the hillside. Make sure you go right to the top. If you are going to Hong Kong plan this in. How to find it. Take the MTR to Sha Tin, this involves changing to an overground train for a few stops. Exit the station at exit B and walk down the ramp. Follow round to the left as the road curves. On your left are some original Chinese dwellings. ☺ At the next junction you will have a large office block in front of you. Turn left at this junction. And then first right. It will look like you are walking between two underground car parks. At the very end of the road (50 mtrs) is a turning circle for cars. In the left hand corner is the entrance.

Majestic. Great trip to see the Ten Thousand Buddhas - although very hard to find, we ended up in the cemetery next door! Follow the little yellow sign at floor level which appears to lead you down a back alley next to the shopping mall... it's down there! The complex is lovely - lots of statues of different figures leading you up to the 10,000 (or really something like 13,000!) Buddhas. It's a bit of an upward climb but there are seats to rest on along the way.
wonderful spot. Tucked away up on a hill, many steps but worth the climb. Buddhas are on both side up the hill with stopping points to sit and rest.

Quick visit. It was certianly a nice temple located near the "Big Buddha". It was nice to show the kids what it would look like. The complex itself felt like a massive tourist trap.The ornate temple was a good addition to the day.

Nice place to visit outside the HGK Center. This monastery is located outside the center of the city, but very easy to reach by the public transportation.Be aware, there are almost 10000 stairs till you get to main building and the statues of Buddah will follow you all the way.look for another stairway to go down. it is located close to the toilet room and if you will have luck you will meet monkeys.

Worth the hike!. Just one raccomandation before going! Be sure to take the right street because I went in to the cemetery next to it before and had to do a double hike :S Otherwise I really suggest going! Very interesting!

Best Hidden attraction in Hong Kong. We wanted to explore less visited attractions in HK and chose to find our way to the Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery. The connectivity in HK is excellent. From East TsimShaTsui we went by MTR to ShaTin. The gate to the monastery is a 5 min walk from the MTR station (right behind IKEA). It is a must watch attraction. There are 2 temples here. Do not forget to climb all the way to the top for the ultimate experience.

Great day out. we visited on a very misty day and enjoyed visiting the Buddha, the monastery and the walk out to the wisdom path. Buy picnic supplies at the local supermarket when you get off the ferry or buy lunch at the monastery

10000 Buddhas Monastery- Well worth it. My wife and I visited the 10000 Buddha monastery in April 2015. We have been to Hong Kong a few times but had not made it out here before. It is well worth making the trip.Getting thereHead out to Sha Tin MTR station. About 45 mins from Central. It is a 10 minute walk from the MTR to the bottom of the steps. The station was extremely busy outside when we arrived. We turned left straight out of the station, curve around to the right, and follow the road past the bus stop below to the shopping centre. You have to walk behind the shopping square which is a very modern (mainly furniture and homewares including IKEA) and past the Sha Tin government offices. Locals will help with directions if you get lost. There are around 500 steps and it is at times step. A bit sweaty on a warm day.The walk upThe path is lined with gold Buddhas all the way to the top. The signs say don't touch or climb in the statues, don't. Some tourists we saw were being rather disrespectful and climbed up for photos, a security guy appeared form nowhere and was not happy. At the top of stage one is the temple which is very spectacular. Great views as well. No photos are permitted inside the buildings. You can then climb even further to buildings that appear to be mausoleums. Didn't ask what they were so not 100% sure. There are yet more Buddhas and finally some ponds and a white statue at the top. Exceptional views down the hill from here.Entry is free, opens at 9am. Shopping centre has reasonable coffee and cold drinks on the way back. Well worth the trip and a nice break from the hustle of the island and Kowloon.

Something different. A steep climb (apparently 431 steps but felt more than that!) to the top along a path lined with Buddhas. At the top it is serene, with great views and more statues and temple. Something special after the consumerism of HK

Great for a morning/afternoon visit!. Get ready to wear comfortable shoes, the entrance is slightly hidden but I prefer it that way!The walk up is lovely and the different statues really adds to the walk up!Up top is a lovely view of Sha Tin...overall a great place to visit!

Extravagant monastery. Very large, very ornate, beautiful. 3 huge gold covered Buddhas as well as 10,000+ Budha tiles. We were told that everything which was gold colored is actual gold ;I assume gold covered, not solid gold. None the less, a lot of money invested in that place. Worth seeing as part of the Big Budha tour.

Worth a visit!. This was one of the highlights of our trip. Great to escape the crowd of HK and just take a taxi to this place (or the subway which also stops nearby). The location is very special and the walk up there is great. There are hundreds of golden (colored) Buddhas at each site. The Monastery itself is a beautiful place. This is not for everybody (don't expect a tourist circus!) but if this is your thing go and visit!

Beautiful Monastery. It is located near Shatin village. More than 10000 statues showing different postures of Buddha, have been erected on both sides of the path leading to the Monastery. The Monastery on the top is very good. Stairs leading to the Monastery are very steep. People with joint pain should think twice before visiting this place. One can have a distant view of the city from a height.One should pay a visit to this place while visiting Hong Kong.
Amazing. So far the biggest Buddhist temple I've visited. It is very peaceful and very impressive. It is on the top of a mountain so we got there on cable car which was very nice.

Interesting!. Easily accessed via the MTR and then a short 5 minute walk to the start of the stairway to the monestry. Stairway can feel very long if it's a hot day, but should take no more than 10-15 minutes to get to the top. Best done first thing in the morning when it is cooler.

Unbelievable. We have been to many Buddhist temples but by far this has been one of the most amazing ones. Each tile on the walls is a Buddha, how amazing is that. The whole room decor and the images are just breathtaking which gave us a sense of peace. Definitely worth the visit.

worth the climb!. well worth the climb although steep and hot. the Buddhas on the way up are all different and in different poses which means you have to stop every so often to look at them!! The view from the top is spectacular.
We had a cup of tea in the restaurant, the waitresses were very attentive.

A lot of time and money went into that. It is cool to see, but they spent a lot of money and time in that monastery. I appreciate the depth of their faith in installing that, but always wonder how could they have used that time and money and invested in helping someone's life. Would Buddha want it spent on the gold or spent helping someone out

Sweat and Monkeys. It's a good experience to walk all the way and sweat!! Great adventure especially being so scared of those 'monkeys' and the sound of crickets. Going alone? Maybe NOT but with a group then it's fun!!Different sizes of Buddhas with their facial expressions will surely make you ask questions to the locals.I love their soya bean drink to quench your thirst after a tiring walk hehehe...but it's worth it!!

See the Avalokitesvara Bodhisattva Statue too, not just the 10,000 Buddhas. The 10,000 Buddhas are very impressive, so is the statue of Avalokitesvara Bodhisattva situated on top of the hill. See how the holy water from the Bodhisattva's nectar vase flow never-ending towards Hong Kong prospering the residents and the island of Hong Kong. Very auspicious Feng Shui.

The most interesting temple in HK. I lived in HK for more than 10 years. In my opinion, the most interesting temple in HK is the 10,000 buddha monastery in Shatin. It's right near the train station - 5 minutes walk to the bottom of the path up. It's a moderate walk up the hill towards the temple, with the statues also ascending in their development. Unusual and has always been a great hit with our visitors. Combine with a trip to the museum on the other side of the train station, and you have a brilliant day in the real HK.

Fascinating place. I didn't take the cable car but took the bus instead. A real adventure to say the least. My bus driver thought he was am Indy race car driver and took the steep curves both up and down the mountain at well above the posted speed limit. What a thrill! A roller coaster to say the least. Arrived at the monastery just before opening and I was glad I did. I had the whole complex to myself, including the Hall of the Ten Thousand Buddhas! Truly a lovely spot to counter the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong.

Wow! Worth seeing! Beware - Lots and lots of stairs!. We saw a lot of Buddhas in and around Hong Kong, but this was the most impressive collection. It's only about a 5 minute walk from the subway station, but once you get there it's hundreds and hundreds of stairs to see most or all of the Buddhas. Just pace yourself, bring water to sip, and don't give up. It's worth seeing.
beautiful. it leaves you speechless. there are 10000 tiles which have buddhas image of them. the gold there really glitters. the sheer way the temple has been built makes your eyes pop out.

Steep climb. Just not what you might expect - a very steep pathway leads you past numerous strange looking Buddhas. Not for the weak and faint hearted! Very steep in places - ensure you have water with you as limited refreshments en route.

A hidden gem worth looking out for. We discovered this place while we were staying in a hotel in Shatin and its definately worth going to escape from the noise and traffic in the city - apparently the Hong Kong tourist board doesn't advertise this place to avoid large crowds and to keep the place intact. I'd recommend bringing comfotable shoes as there's alot of steps to overcome but worth it once you've reached the top. The statues are abit tacky and freaky but plenty to observe and take pictures of. Also be aware of fake monks at the entrance who may ask for donations, there is a sign warning tourists who may be targeted.

So ... many... stairs... and Buddhas. OK - when you walk to the 10,000 buddhas, the first place you see with the pretty white columns is NOT IT. This is a masoleum. jajaja yes, it has an escalator. That's not the place you want. Go NEXT DOOR The signs are very small. But you will see "monks" asking for money and selling stuff. Then make the 400+ stair climb to the top. It's tiring but worth it. I got so many pictures. There are soooo many different Buddha statues. They are unique and clever. I saw one that looked like my uncle, one that looked like an older version of my brother in law and one that looked like Jesus. The stairs will tax your knees so if you have knee braces - wear them! If you need a cane to walk - bring it! Also, bring extra memory cards, batteries, or film because there is so much to take pictures of. Once you get to the top, you can see the city beneath you. It's gorgeous. And there are turtles in a small pond. So cute. To really soak it in, it takes about 3 hours to walk up there, take pictures, look around, sit and rest, and walk down.

Worth the climb!. This is an interesting buddhist site with all sorts of buddhist statues, sculptures, and the like. Entrance is free of charge and you should bring your comfortable shoes since there are a lot (a LOT) of steps to climb to get to the top where the monastery is located. It has a small restaurant so you can purchase snacks/water and also souvenirs available. We even saw some monkeys climbing around and playing in the water!

Bit disapointed. To get to the Ten Thousand Buda's it is either a taxi ride, quite expensive or hire a car, not recommended. We were lucky as my nephew who lives there took us. It is one hell of a walk to the top and the Buda's not very impressive. There are better things to do in Hong Kong
Only visit if you have lots of spare time. Difficult to find, arduous climb in the heat, abit 'tacky' once there! There are much better places to see temples and Buddas in HK

Different world. The thousand buddhas takes you immeditaly into another world. Unbelieveable to see so many golden buddhas in all shapes, all kind of faces, all kind of poses. We enjoyed the visit very much (although it was raining at the time).

10000 Buddhas and nearly as many steps!. This steep winding path takes you through all these golden life-size Buddhas and if you can manage your way to the top it is well worth the trip. The Monastery closes at 5pm and we managed to get there about 4pm by which time there were very few of us there so it wasn't crowded. There is a cafeteria at the top and yet more Buddhas to capture with your camera as well as a small temple. It seems a lot quicker coming down than going up! Take your time and look after your knees!

The best place to visit in Hong Kong. I wandered around Hong Kong for 3 days and I found this monastery the most amazing place. Dress for a steep hike, have water on you, because it is a long hike. It is not super easy to find the entry once we get out of the subway. Ask locals to show you the way, it is hidden at the back. Must go !

A Hell of a Climb for a... nother Temple. I think I've reached a saturation point on Buddhist temples after traveling around India and Nepal. The climb was very strenuous for some 30-somethings that were a little out of shape (and just got over a major illness). Two years ago, it probably would've been only mildly taxing.I'm not sure we made it ALL the way to the top, but we made it to the level with the actual 10,000 Buddhas. It was... full of Buddhas. They've done an admirable job maintaining it all and making repairs after the big fire. If you aren't tired of seeing Buddhist temples, definitely come see it. In a different context, this probably would have been one of the better ones we've ever visited. Presumably better than the über-commercial Big Buddha that was built in the 90s to attract tourists.
Be prepared to be amazed.. After a long climb up the steps you are confronted by an incredible site of all the Buddhas. Every one is different. Give yourself plenty of time to really appreciate it.

perspective from a local: a commercial setting only. This temple had disappeared from my memory for long time before it got renovated some years ago. I decided to go to have a look after learning the high ranking by the Tripadvisor. But I must say that I am very disappointed. It seems that most visitors are not local people, probably because it is not functioning as it should be. It is not friendly to visitors: photography is forbidden in all the halls, an uncommon practice among other temples. Many of the halls are now housing niches for ashes of ancestors, a lucrative business. This temple cannot represent other functioning temples in HK
Beloved Buddhist Temple. it is the wonderful and beloved buddhist temple that i ever found in my destination. there were so many Buddha here. Wow.

Beautiful indeed!!. It was worth the visit...the amazing architecture and golden buddhas...each with different expressions and hand gestures!! You will feel amazed how come they made alllll of it. And if you're lucky you willl hear the priest chanting their prayers and trust me you'll feel peace within you!!!

A nice place. Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery is one of the most popular monasteries in Hong Kong. This monastery was founded by Rev. Yuet Kai in 1949 and completed in 1957. The monastery is divided into upper and lower portions and occupied over 8 hectares. It consists five temples, four pavilions, one pagoda and one veranda. There are 12,800 pieces of exquisite Buddha statues each with different postures placed on the walls. At the opposite side of the main temple is the 9-storey Pagoda which was selected as the symbol of Hong Kong printed on the HK$100 banknote. One has to climb a number of steps to reach the monastery. People with high blood pressure,heart ailments and joint problems should think twice before visiting this place.
Good exercise . The trail itself was tough. The views and sights were OK... Nice views of the mountain side and of the city. Interesting walk and I will do it again.

A nice place to visit. 10,000 budhha is a nice place to visit in hongkong. It is not a MUST go place but definitely a nice place to go. As the name suggests, it is a budhha temple with thousands of budhha idols. All idols in different poses. You have to get off at shatin MTR and from there, it is walking distance. There are a lot of stairs to climb. If you are not feeling fit or have trouble in climbing stairs, then think before you there. I was living near shatin so i visited this place 4-5 times. From the temple, view of new territories is very beautiful. One restaurant is also there where you can get some veggie food items.If you are in hongkong, and you have enough time, you can plan for this place. it is a sweet and nice place. If you running short of time, then you can skip this one. So it depends on the time you have.
10000 BUDDHA TEMPLE.. Nice place and a bit far from downtown, the tourist should be in healthy because need to took about many step up there place
Do not miss it. Gorgeous !. Absolutely a must. Just beautiful buildings, in quiet area. The colours are blinding. Nice little patio all around the various building

Buddhas everywhere.... This place is 10-15min walk from Sha Tin Station. There is no tourist sign direction from Exit B. I google the direction on how to go to this place. No need to take taxi when you use the MTR. Just walk down straight along the bus terminal (follow pai tau street) then when you see a mall/big building cross the street and find this Sheung Wo Che Road. Go straight and you will see the ten thousand monastery signage. Allocate at least 2 hrs for this tour. The entrance is at the bottom where you will see different buddhas statues while climbing up. Sadly we didn't have enough time to reach the top due to our afternoon flight, at least 30min climb is needed and there are rest stops. One of the tourist showed some photos what it looks like at the top instead. Yeah, definitely going back next time to see the pagoda and more amazing buddhas at the top.

Beautiful, peaceful, and free!. I recommend going in the middle of the week where there isn't much foot traffic. Wear sneakers there are a lot of stairs! Beautiful location and extremely peaceful. There is one tiny place to buy souvenirs at the top in one of the halls. I don't recommend going when it's humid and hot but it is worth the climb. There is a beautiful entrance that looks like the place to start but no signs in English so when you start walking up it turns out to be some sort of cemetery. The only place where the signs are in English are where the ten thousand buddha climb starts. If you don't see them you are going the wrong way! Don't make our mistake of climbing all the way up to realize you have to go back down and up another set of stairs.

Absolutely Amazing. It is worth climbiung up the mountain accompanied by hundreds of Buddhas. Up at the top, great view and Relaxing, because here it is absolutely quite and noone distrubs you in any kind

Worth the climb. This is a very interesting monastery, it really does have all those Buddhas.It has been undergoing some improvements of the upper levels and is almost complete. I love the new large white statue of Guan Yin. The cafe has very good vegetarian food and there is a pagoda to climb. I always visit when I go to Hong Kong, it is not so 'touristy' as some of the other places like the Giant Buddha which is now like a theme park ,they have over commercialised it so the atmosphere is spoiled.I would recommend a visit, it is quite easy to get to on the MTR too. However there are a lot of steps to get up and down.

All the Buddhas. Easily accessible from the MTR, but it's not listed on the MTR exits and the signs are a bit hard to find initially. A great "double-feature" with the Bruce Lee exhibit across the river (at the heritage museum. Which actually has far more than that, but hey, Bruce Lee!). Get directions to the museum, it's not far as the crow flies, but it's very confusing on the ground.
Gruelling short climb. Yes it is a tough walk to the top, but once there you are rewarded with some great views, plus the Monastery buildings etc. Dont miss it.
Beautiful. Absolute serenity and easy to contemplate. Many opportunities to make offers and buy good luck charms for nominal price.

Unique place in HK. I really enjoyed my trip here, it's a very unusual spot, right from the gold monk-lined walk up to the overall sense of not being in HK, not to mention the Buddhas! It's a bit run down, and feels like sites in other parts of Asia that aren't as polished as those in HK. Definitely worth a visit if you have a free afternoon.
Worth the climb. Even with so many visitors there was a sense of peace & what a glorious place. A great contrast to the city.

A unknown pleasent surprise. Not busy at all, and not promoted. There's a never ending line of golden buddhas on both sides of of the steps. There's a lot of steps, with areas to stop and rest as you go. The monastery is quite nice as well, very ornate. As this is not a heavily promoted item, it doesn't get busy. One note, the monk asking for money at the bottom is not actually a monk.
heavenly !!. it is right next to Big Buddha' statue. the hall with 10000 buddhas is astoundingly beautiful!!....u gotta see it to believe it!!
Beautiful. Structure was gorgeous! If your lucky you will hear the monks chanting while you are there. If you are seeing the Big Buddha this is right next door and the architecture is stunning.

It took my breath away!. Incredible, incredible, incredible. The way the statues are lined up to ascend to the sky, the detail of expression on each statue, is absolutely insane. I could have spent all day staring at each statue, all with different faces and poses, and all eerily staring back at me. And it's all for free! I highly recommend it, it's a little far out from central HK (Sha Tin) but totally worth the visit. It's a little hard to find as it's hidden behind a narrow walkway and there are no signs. From Sha Tin MTR station Take exit B (Grand Central Plaza) and turn left. Follow the walkways down out of the station. Keep left, walking straight ahead. When you hit the first main intersection, cross the road and turn left. You will see the entrance to an Ikea-esque shopping centre on your right as you walk. Walk for a short time (no more than 1 minute) and then turn right down a narrow non-descript walkway right after a governmental-looking building. The Buddhas are at the end of this walkway. It's not that far from the station (10 minute walk max) and if you get lost just ask the locals.

A religious spot for tourists. This monastary in Shatin is easily acessible. Take MTR East Rail and get off at the Shatin Station Exit B. Go along the pavement on your left. You can either take the route through the Pai Tau Village, or go a bit further to a route behind the Hong Kong Government Office Building. The latter route is the main route to the temple.On this main route, you can see many golden statues of Lo Hon on either side of the path. Once up there, you can see the main temple, and on route further back up the hill a bit, there is a tall white statue of Kwan Ying that you'd not miss seeing. The main building and all the buddhas statues are worth seeing.On the way down hill, take the alternate route to the opposite side of the main route. There you can find many monkeys on the hill slope. Do not feed them though.We visited the temple many many years ago and these days, it has changed a lot. It becomes more of a tourist spot than monastary, with groups and groups of tourists taking photos here and there, yelling and even some of them enjoying their beer (which is supposed not to be) inside the compound. At the entrance of the main route, you can even find impersonated monks asking for money!
Worth the climb. Take the East rail line to Shatin and look for the IKEA store. To the left is a gate pointing towards the temple. Steep walk up the hill but just Buddha's all the way

Lovely gem. This place is located in the sha tin area near a mtr station. It's worth the visit, esp if you are staying in the Kowloon area. Only short train ride away. Loads of bhudda's to admire along the way up a step path. Nice view of the city too. Take good walking shoes. Do ask at the entrance, as there is an easy mistake of following the crowd and ending up at a memorial site near by. As some people describe off the beaten path but worth it.

Wonderful. This is a less advertised Temple and for that reason is far more interesting than most. An amazing number of buddhas, all unique, with stunning views across to Lion Rock Mountain and over Sha Tin. a great place to bring visitors to Hong Kong to show them the real use of a temple.

So many figurines. This is a little gem of a place that you can reach quite easily from the Sha Tin MTR station. There were 500 statutes each different from the other along the path leading to the top of the hill. The temple at the top was quite beautiful and really worth the trip.

Off the beaten path but one of the most memorable experiences. It's a long stroll up a hill to the main monastery with thousands of Buddhas of every imaginable type along the trail - it was so unique and odd that it is a must do.

A little creepy. we felt out of place walking around the monastery and lots of people stare at you. theres a vegetarian restaurant we didnt eat at it tho. There is a room with beautiful gold buddhas in it.
Day trip. This was a day trip arranged through our hotel found it very enjoyable & informative. Loved walking round everything.

Worth the effort but take a map. After traversing the subway and making our way through a convoluted path to get there (watch out for fake Monks on the way - they'll take your money for a "blessing"), you'll begin a climb up hundreds of stairs, accompanied by many golden Buddhas. It's interesting to see how they're so different from each other, and there are different areas to the Monastery once you get up the top with different statues. We weren't there long and we made our way out via the back way, which has yet more Buddhas. The route back to the station that way isn't well signposted but you do eventually get somewhere familiar. Just takes a while and is kind of isolated.
excellent. ten thousand Buddhas in the same is a treat to the eye.Most of them Glittering Gold .very interesting to visit.
A holy place. WOW! Breathtaking and so peaceful. Couldn't help but look in awe. So colourful, but not in a tacky way.

Love this temple. I love going to this temple. A little off the beaten path and away from the crowds of the ig Buddha. 450 steps to reach the top but well worth it because you have all the many versions of Buddha to look at along the way. There are a few BIG Buddhas at the top and and gift shop. I did not see many westerners at the temple but totally safe and welcoming.

10,000 Buddhas. I think this is a much better site than the Big Buddha. Lots of steps on the way up however the stairs are lined with large Buddhas. It's also in a slightly more interesting area than the Big Buddha with a lot to do before or after your visit. There's Che Kung temple and old "village" area around Sha Tin West - that individually aren't worth a stop - that you can include to the Big Buddha trip. You can also explore the Tai Wai area first. There's a good coffee/desert shop, Uchi Coffee, on the far side of town from the MTR Station - the walk there passes through a few historical village areas too.10,000 Buddhas closes at 5, so if you visit at the end of the day, grab a coffee at the Pacific Place in the nearby Mall, then head to Chan Kun Kee for dinner - this is a Dai Pai Dong that's buried in the depths of several public housing estates.

Just one more tourist spot.... Go there only if you are very fit and want to visit a "different" kind of Buddhist Temple.The temple is a 15 minute walk from the MTR. It is a steep climb up and is not for the aged or if you are carrying kids or baggage. The entire route is lined with statues of Buddhist monks of various races and expressions.The temple has statues of 1000 Buddhas from where it gets its name. Devotees make offerings. The courtyard is big and has interesting spots for shooting pictures. Toilets are there but were not clean. The restaurant had been hyped-it is totally vegetarian but staff lacked service and communication skills. Prices were high.Nice place.But go only if there are no other options.

Nice to visit.. The Buddha's are on the path on the way up to the top. You might need there help when you are on your way up the steep climb. The Buddha's themselves are not that impressive, but it's worth going to the top and seeing the monastery and the views.

Do it if you have time but not as great as made out to be.. So, I did this the day before my travel partner arrived. I took the metro out here then walked up the hill checked it out and came back down. If you are a person that likes to pose for photos with odd things, this is definitely for you think of it like a wax museum but only with budhas not made of wax. I am glad I did it but it did not meet my expectations from the descriptions I read. If you have time hit this place up... if not don't sweat it.

A great way to spend an hour while in Shatin. This was a fun and very different experience. Finding the Monastery may be a bit of a challenge because there are no "official" tourists signs. However, it's easy to get to from Shatin MTR station when you watch this video that someone has kindly uploaded to YouTube.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L8kkKpHxJpgThere are plenty of photo opportunities, but be prepared to walk up a steep hill.I spent an hour exploring the grounds and took a lot of photos.It's probably worth combining a visit to the Monastery with something else in the Shatin area (such as shopping - Shatin has Hong Kong's IKEA - or a trip to the Heritage Museum).

A Must Visit during your visit to HK. The road and climb lies on the back side of the IKA building in Pai Tau..The start of the climb to the Monastery has no signs..Its a easy walk up hill with statues of Buddha on both side..At the Monastery there is a simple Veg restaurant which is now open on all days

Wonderful place to explore, beautiful views. I loved visiting the Monastery. The walk up is steep, but I loved looking at all the Budhas as I walked and there are benches if anyone in your party needs to take a break. The views from the top are beautiful, and it was so peaceful. I highly recommend.

Amazing views, very peaceful. Very easy to find after following some directions someone kindly left on here. The views were beautiful. It was nice to leave the city for a more tranquil experience of hong kong. We ate at the vegetarian restaurant at the top, the staff were super nice and helpful and assisted us with what was good on the menu. The food was delicious! Yes some of it is quite tacky but I actually enjoyed that aspect. It would appeal to all ages and is free so its hard to grumble! Steep climb is easy and enjoyable along as you are wearing comfortable clothes and shoes. Signs advise not to feed the monkeys but we were rather disappointed that we didn't see any! The toilets are clean, but with non western floor toilets. However! At the very end on the right hand side there is a western toilet for those who aren't brave enough!

Impressive. We followed the unobtrusive sign to the 10,000 Buddhas exhibit, and almost missed the fact that there is an upper floor that is the more impressive. If you are in the room with the three large golden Buddhas, go out and around the building to find another set of steps up.

Beautiful and delicious. Be sure to eat the vegetarian lunch at the monastery as your ticket gets you into the special exhibition under the Buddha. The lunch is splendid. The monastery is clean, beautiful and a must see event with the opportunity to take wonderful photos.

don't forget the deep heat. Beautiful monastary reached by a very step incline past buddist statues, not very far from the MTR station down an alley. don't let that put you off as the view are fantastic.

Best free activity in Hong Kong. Tremendous walk, no handicap accessible, bringing your walking shoes (all paved, no large steps, just a long uphill walk). Don't want to give too much away- just make sure to stop and admire each of the statues on the way to the top!

A very good workout.
