If staying in Sha Tin, this monastery is at your back door, and if staying elsewhere, it is a short walk from the Sha Tin station.The walk to the start of the climb to the monastery is interesting in itself. Sha Tin was a rural town prior to what they do best in Hong Kong (reclaim land from the sea and build numerous high rise buildings on it) and there are small remnants of what it may have been like before the high rise and shopping malls.There are about 460 steps up to the monastery, but plenty of places to rest. All the way up, there are large gold painted Buddha's on both sides of the path. Whilst this is impressive, keep walking for a more impressive sight.Once at the main temple, there are 13,000 small Buddha's lining the walls which are all different. Well worth the climb. If you keep walking up the hill, there are additional temples and Buddha's. The views across Sha Tin below are pretty good as well.There is a vegetarian restaurant at the main temple and the spring rolls and fried vegetables with rice are very nice.This destination is up there with the Big Buddha.Put it on your list.

nice , please go there. its a nice temple , with nice hapy people and visitors , try to get there early before tourist busses with china travellers get there.its close to cat street and upper street, so get some shopping done

worth going. Have been there so many times, literally every time we have got visitors over from back home.I think since they have repainted the buddhas along the steps up to the temple they all do look a bit tacky, silly even to our Western eye but it's a peaceful way up and just worth going - mind you as it is a few hundred steps up it might be too hard for some elderly people.

Worth the walk, combine with other trips in Sha Tin. Take exit B from the MTR and head for Ikea. You will see the Po Fook Ancestral Halls. I suggest visiting this first as it it is interesting, and you probably won't want to climb again after the 10,000 Buddhas. The steps to the 10,000 Buddhas are at the end of Sheung Wo Che Road, look for the gilded life-size statues on the way. Be aware of false monks begging near the entrance. The monastery is relatively new (completed in 1957) with several impressive shrines (the founder's body is in the main one). You can climb the 9 storey pagoda, and there is a nice small vegetarian restaurant and clean toilets. It is worth visiting Pai Tau village on the way back to the MTR, though there was a lot of construction nearby in early Jan 2015. Continue through the station to exit A, cross the river and follow the walk to Tsang Tai Uk aka Shan Ha Wai, a well preserved Hakka walled village. You can enter the inner walls and the ancestral hall (rest is private). It is hard to find this village, try marking on Google maps. It s also close to Che Kung Temple MTR, reached from Sha Tin MTR or the riverside walk. The temple looks interesting, but I didn't visit. You can hire bikes along the riverside walk, and there are lots of food opportunities in the large shopping centres beside the MTR station.

Amazing piece of culture. If you can take the right exit from the Sha Tin Metro station, and find the path, it is a nice walk, although up a lot of stairs, but worth it when you reach the top. Great views and plenty of photos to be taken.

Quiet, serene, peaceful & healthy. Ten thousand Buddha Monastery is off the beaten track, even for a Hong Konger. Located a stone throw away from IKEA at Sha Tin, the place is an epitome of tranquility, a welcome relief from a bustling city. Be prepared to walk up a medium incline (431 steps). If you're visiting with kids (3 years & upwards), don't worry about it - they can cope (atleast mine did). Once at the top, the monastery itself is beautiful & offered excellent views of Sha Tin township below. The prayer hall, where you will find ten thousand Buddha statues, is fantastic. Do pay attention to the rules around no food and photography inside the main prayer hall. Key things: Total trip time (ex Sha Tin MTR) is about 2 hours. Don't bring food as there is no place you can sit to eat. There is a vegetarian restaurant at the monastery, but we ate at the New Plaza, which houses IKEA. Bring lots of water to keep yourself hydrated (especially in the summers). Don't forget your camera :)
Beautiful. The room of the 10000 Buddhas is beautiful! there is so much gold it is almost hard to take it all in... go early to insure it is not crowded.

Beautiful and peaceful place. This is a well kept secret. It's in HK's new territories and you have to change MTR lines at least 3 times (coming from central) to get there. When you get to the station it's not quite clear how to get to the monastery, however it's just about a 10 minute walk and quite a few steps from the station. As you walk up the stairs the Buddhas on each side of the path make the climb easier and enjoyable. Once you get up there you can enjoy the view, more Buddhas and the breathtaking beauty of the monastery.

Peaceful retreat from shopping. We really enjoyed our visit. The views from the top were lovely and really gave a sense of achievement of how far we had climbed. Be prepared for steps and quite a few of them. The monastery really is peaceful and relaxing compared to the hustle and bustle of the city. Easy to find and the directions from this particular website were spot on. http://www.hongkongextras.com/_ten_thousand_buddhas_monastery.html

Buddha. Be prepared to walk/climb the hill, but you would be not alone. Many Buddha statues are left and right. As you arrive to the top, there is the hall with tousends of buddhas and a courtyard with a big Pagoda & more. Just go higher and you will find beautiful places.

Enjoyable little gem in Sha Tin. We went there one sunny December morning. It's just behind the IKEA building and not particularly well signposted but worth a quick visit. The steps are reasonably steep with Buddhas on the way up on each step. This panicked me somewhat as I did not fancy 5 or 10,000 steps. Luckily there are not that many - most of the Buddhas are in the actual temple at the top. You get a great view from the temple and the pagoda and there is also a nice fishpond a bit further up. Hardly any one there so it was quite peaceful. And there also is a little vegetarian restaurant at the top. And a toilet in case you think you might Sha Tin your pants (my kid's joke of the day....).

Quite an experience. This particular attraction (not to be mistaken with Big Buddha at Lantau) is part of the New Territories of HK. It is near Sha-tin and is relative unexplored. This Monastery is a short walk from the station and a fairly long climb to the top. The stairs are well maintained and perfectly safe and are lined with various Buddha Statues on the sides (hence the name 10,000 Buddhas). Once on the top, there is a Monastery and a temple which is worth visiting.

vegetarian restaurant is surprisingly delicious. It doesn't look like much but the vegetarian restaurant is quite delicious! We really enjoyed the taro shaped like a fish with delicious dipping sauce, and honestly everything else we had including the various mushroom dishes.

Worth the climb!. This was a fantastic outing for us. It was a little complex to get there but the directions in other reviews here are very good and so we found it with no problems. The climb is a bit of a challenge but it was cool (drizzling actually) so we didn't mind. The whole place is quite extraordinary to see! The thousands of gold fibreglass Buddhas lining the walkway all seem to be different. We were amazed to see the caretaker riding up and down the steep path on a strange little vehicle with tractor tracks - presumably the vehicle used to take the Buddhas up to the temple for refurbishment when required. Watch out for the monkeys too... We heard monkey chatter (more like 'yelling') in the bamboo behind us and turned to see two large monkeys leap out of the bamboo, onto the Buddhas heads and across the path - one chasing the other... If anyone had been standing there they could have been hurt!On reaching the temple, we were treated to a gorgeous display of colourful deities and beautiful views. The whole area was so serene and gorgeous - we loved it. A kind Chinese lady told us to go up to the next section which we were grateful about. It was only another few minutes climb but we may have missed it had she not told us. In the top area there wee more temple buildings and a fantastic grotto with even more gold Buddhas, waterfalls and a huge white, stone(?) Buddha... A beautiful sight and certainly well worth the effort!

Felt Like A Thousand Steps to Heaven. If you're like me and my friend who doesn't just want to visit the common tourist spots when traveling, you should try visiting this place. It is quite tricky to find the entrance, but all you have to do is alight at Sha Tin MTR station, and take exit B. Walk along the ramp beside the bus terminus until you reach street level. Continue walking past the Pai Tau Village on your left opposite Grand Central Plaza mall on your right. Turn right on Sheung Wo Che Road (the first street past the mall) and walk along government offices and car-parks until you reach the end of the street with a yellow sign that would direct you to the staircase leading to the monastery.The entrance to the monastery is free of charge. The trek up is quite an exercise but is tolerable. Alongside the path are different buddha statues, and at strategic points are seats where you can rest before continuing the long trek up. After reaching the top, one can sit down, relax and reflect quietly. You can also enjoy the view of the New Territories. There are lots of newly built attractions within the temple which are quite picturesque for selfies/groufies. While enjoying the serenity of the place, make sure to be quiet and not destroy it.The monastery with the 10K buddhas is quite a sight, too.

A walk with the Buddhas. Interesting spiritual trek on foot up the hill to the monastery. It is quite a climb so be prepared. Once on top, enjoy the vistas, the temples, the Buddhas, and the small very humble vegetarian cafe before descending the hill. Bring cash as credit cards are not accepted.

Decoration. Outstanding detail and decoration on these two temples near the monastery. The upper one is the Ten Thousand temple. The detailed decoration on the outside is beautifully done. The carved stone relief panels are equally impressive. Plenty of gilt work make this location quite special. The burning incense adds to the atmosphere & the spiritual experience

Fantastic - two stairs. A must see - lots of stairs. Go up the front way and when you get to the top, the stairs down are to the right - don't get fooled by the signs. There is a public toilet on the way down - an interesting stop.,

Good for tourists who are in HK for long visit.. A very silent and well maintained place. Very peaceful and if lucky you can see few monks near that place. Can visit if you have lot of time since this tour takes almost a day. Can visit Man Fat Sze and many places nearby which is worth a visit.
Worth every minute and every penny. Liked everything, the new additions, the old restaurants the new templeride there is an experience on its own; next time I will walk
Marvellous. It is just behind the po lin monastery. Dont miss it. There are golden tiles with the buddha statue. It is a place of worship for the buddhists.
Stunning. highlight of our visit to HongKong. The monastery is tranquil and very beautiful. We enjoyed seeing the monks going about the business of the monastery .

Worth a visit and great exercise.. = GETTING THERE =If you're taking the red line MTR from Tsim Sha Tsui like we did, you need to change to the green line at either Yau Ma Tei, Mong Kok or Prince Edward. Then change to the light blue line at Kowloon Tong to get to Sha Tin. With Hong Kong's MTR system being one of my favourites (it's super easy to use), it's probably the best way to get to the monastery.To head to the monastery from the MTR, use "exit B: Pai Tau Street, Pai Tau Village, public transport interchange". Once you exit, turn left and walk down the footbridge. A lot of people will be walking down this bridge. On the left you'll see a row of old houses named "Pai Tau Village". Once you get past this row of houses, at the end should be a playground area and on the right are what looks like government buildings. Look for the street Sheung Wo Che Rd and walk to the end of this street. The building on the left is ICAC (Independent Commission Against Corruption) and at the end of the street is the entrance to the monastery. ==> have a look at my photos for an idea of what the area looks like. = PRICING = Other than the cost of catching MTR and spending money on food etc at the New Town shopping mall (located at Sha Tin MTR) or at the monastery's vegetarian restaurant, there's no entrance fee to the monastery, however once you get to the top at the praying halls, there are donation boxes.= DURATION = You could easily set aside a day for the monastery and the New Town shopping mall. For us, we arrived at the shopping mall and had breakfast at Fairwood (a fast food chain serving quite yummy food) before setting off to the monastery. By lunch time, you should be done at the monastery so you can come back to the shopping mall to cool down, have lunch and do some shopping.= TIP =Try to go on a cool, cloudy day because it's a lot of walking up the slanted walkways to the praying halls. If you end up going on a sweltering hot day like we did, make sure you bring plenty of water, maybe a handheld fan, a hat and wear comfortable walking shoes and clothing.As it is a place of worship, there are signs at the praying halls area stating 'no photography'. And as such, it would be wise to respect this and also to keep the noise levels at a minimum.There is a vegetarian restaurant at the praying halls which you can dine at, or like we did, you could finish your visit and head back to New Town shopping mall to have lunch.

Peace at the top. Loved the place... It is not such an easy climb though. the weather was quite hot during our visit but worth the pain. It is amazing to see the work of skilled craftsmen and the number of buddhas is impressive. When you arrive at the top, you have no regrets. Please dont give up... make it to the top...

Great place to stay and visit. Took the advice from this forum and visited whilst in Hong Kong in October 2014. Unfortunately travelled up to the Crematoria like many visitors do first next door to it! Must be a common mistake as they have a notice at the top to tell you got it wrong. There are no lifts or stairs up to Ten Thousand Buddha's.. It is place of worship and not a tourist attraction so you need to be respectful about photos and silence.

Good exercise. . We went the monastery next to the ten thousand Buddha which has escalator and it was a place for cremation and ash storage. That was a waste of time. But we did end up on right temple. A bit of hike to top. It was nicely build and lots of Buddha to see. However it doesn't give a holiness when u visit. I felt it's a little bit commercialized. Overall a good exercise.

far out but very special . Not the most popular tourist attraction but it is lovely here. Quiet, a bit far out the centre and difficult to find. Once there it is stunning. So many Buddhas but be prepared for a lot a lot of stairs
silence. What I like about this place is that its not THE place tourists normally visit. Means its quite silent and not that crowded. Additionnally you get a really nice view :) (no entrance fees)

O.K. only. I saw many Buddhas & monasteries already. There are much more better around the world. Here are only Buddhas made of plastic & painted gold. Climbing up is very exhausting & a callenge. So take your time. Finally its not really worth but for free.
Good exercise. But plastic Buddhas on the way up! We were glad we went but not sure we would recommend. Not so much to see, but good exercise to walk up!

Land of Buddhas. This place is very much secluded and very hard to find the entrance. People generally get confused looking at another temple at the entrance to be this place. There is a very nice Chinese Vegetarian restaurant at the Temple premise on top of the hill. This is a must visit place if you are a traveler to HK..

Very special!!!. Very nice and special place. A bit steep climb up the stairs but very beautiful and original. We arrived to the area and started to look for the place, it's very close to a cemetery so don't be confused. There's a small path near the building in front of the cemetery, you need to enter this path and turn left and there will be a very small sign that it's the Ten thousand Buddha's and you'll see small stairs, enjoy. We came across some fake monks, they try to give you bracelets so just ignore them. You'll see alert signs about these fake monks along the way...be aware.

Like a Buddha Disneyland and amazing views too!. This is an amazing place. It really has more than 300 different large sized Buddha status and then all the small statues, together there really are 10 000 Budhas on this hill!I've seen many Budhist temples but this one is like a Buddha Disneyland, Budhas of all shapes on sizes all along the paths and at the top. And don't stop when you have recached the main temple ant the Pagoda, just a little bit higher will be the amazing view of the icy and BUddha hill.Here are the instructions on how to get there from Sha Tin station. GETTING THERE: From Shatin MTR station exit on the left (provably exit B). Go down the footpath (it is parley elevated walkway) past the market square on your left until you see the big shopping mall Homeland, cross the road to the mall then turn left and then turn right at the next intersection and you will be on Sheung Wo che road, follow that and you will get to Ten Thousand budha sign and beginning of the bath, then just follow the bud has up the hill.

They all have different faces!. It is to the RIGHT of the entrance of the government building- don't be fooled by the lovely gate and hilly garden on the left. Luckily we paused half way up to get water, asked which way to the 10,000 Buddhas?- the lovely lady had a printed sign saying "This is not the 10,000 Buddhas- go back down the hill and turn left".Worth the walk( you need water)- peaceful and not very touristy.

It is Worth Doing The Climb. This is not the monastery beside the big Buddha but the one in Shatin. It is a 10 or 15 minute walk from the MTR and it does seem like 10,000 steps to it but it isn't. Once there it is kinda of surreal looking down to the town of Shatin yet being in this peaceful place. Small place but thousands of buddhas to keep you occupy for a while as you look at how different they are.

Amazing.... I don't think I have ever visited a place such as this. Forgetting the climb up the mount, once you reach the peak, it is the most surreal place I have ever been to. The fact that you are on top of the mountain and see all the hassle of a city underneath of you, while you are in the most peaceful place in Honk Kong, that was just amazing. Definitely worth visiting!

Uphill walk. Right near a subway station, steep walk up, past hundreds of almost-life-sized Buddhas. The temple at the top has one of the best-designed interiors I've seen. (the "10,000" are miniatures that line the walls from floor to ceiling)
OK place. If you like Buddhas (in plural), this is yoiur place at Shatin. Nice walk next to the MTR station, and over 10.000 of them. Really!

An Unexpected Workout. The climb to the top is breathtaking, as in you really lose your breath! It is a steep climb to the top, and maybe exerting the effort does stand for something to Buddhists, but for regular tourists, make sure you have no heart problems if you do decide to clamber up to the main area. Each of the golden Buddha statues have different expressions; some have hair, some were bald, others were smiling and others also were decked in full regalia. The main temple features more golden, albeit smaller, Buddha figures from the floor to the ceiling. Take a couple of hours from your itinerary and make it to the MTR Sha Tin station to get your dose of cardio for the day!

Get your cardio in for the day!. They say you should walk 10,000 steps every day to maintain good heart health, well this excusion will certainly do that and more. The stairs can be a little challenging but take your time and enjoy the Buddhas on the way up, each one has a different expression. Once at the top enjoy some tea and food at the small cafe and then take in the scenery and the temple. My suggestion, go early or late in the day and avoid being there on a hot summer day. November is the perfect time, sunshine but not the famous HK humidity. From there you can take in some shopping at New Town Centre, Sha Tin.

Worth the Climb. So every place you read about this place they make it very clear that there are about 12,800 Buddhas not 10,000. What wasn't so clearly documented is that there are about 12,800 steps to get to the very top of the area. I was here in November and the day was cooler & drier than usual (68 F with a dewpoint in the 50s), and I was still sweating. I don't know how people do the climb in the warm seasons! Be prepared for a hike! And then once yo get to the main part, you can climb just a bit further to the upper levels of the site.But it's worth every step. Although the Buddhas on the way up & some of the other ones seemed kind of kitschy, the temple appeared to be very 'legitimate' (for lack of a better word -- maybe I should say 'respectable'). I was there early and there were many people paying there respects & making offerings. (It just occurred to me that they were also all women, although I don't see how that matters.) The views over Sha Tin were also amazing. I found it very interesting to see the other side of HK. Of the 3 temples I visited today this was the best experience for me.

So many beautiful statues of Buddha!. This place is on the Shatin line of Hong Kong MTR away from the city. It is a small walk 10-15 min from the MTR station to the base of the monastery. Once there, you need to climb over 400 stairs to reach the top which has the monastery. The climb is not steep. On your way you will see statues of Buddha in different avatars. They are all lined up up to the top and are beautiful. There is a main Buddhist temple at the top and a few smaller places of worship as well. There is also a pagoda to climb. There is a vegetarian restaurant that serves Chinese/Cantonese vegetarian food.

Serene and peaceful!. Even though it's a bit of a hike going up all those steps, once you get to the top you can sit and enjoy the panoramic view over Shatin and beyond. The main monastery is beautiful and has been restored to original condition and well maintained. Well worth a visit!

So peaceful and beautiful. Even in a confined timeframe we managed to visit the monastery and well worth the time. As the name suggests you could see many Buddha along the stroll that you take towards the main building. Each of them is simply impressive and creative. There is a bit of walk and climb involved but is well worth for an experience.

Another angle to Hong Kong. This is a fascinating attraction that will give relief from the tedium of high fashion boutiques.and cityscapes.A bit of a climb into the hills to see some lurid and colourful gods in this temple with views over Sha Tin with the Lion rock in the distance.Gaudy but fascinating with a pagoda to climb and a little restaurant where the staff will knock up a local meal in a few minutes to get your calorie count back up.Well worth the trip on the MTR and great for the budding photographer.Don't miss the mummified priest who sits in a glass case in the middle of the temple, revered for dying in an upright posture and the divinity that implies.

fantastic experience. There are footpaths to this attraction. We went via the bee farm and bought some honey. Then went on up to the monastery. It is extremely interesting and as it is free it is well worth a visit. There are seats in case you need a rest going up or down. We had a drink in the cafe. Approximately 400 steps.

Fantastic place - can't believe it's free. Visited with my son. The entrance is close to Sha Tin MTR, tucked away behind a government building but once you are on the steep path up to the monastery you are surrounded by statues of Buddhas all the way to the top (not a trek for those not having a reasonable fitness level), where there are many magnificent statues and other things to see.The main hall is covered with small buddhas on all the walls (there really are more than 10,000) and there's a tower with a spiral staircase which you can climb up for some great views.It's a working monastery with people worshipping and paying respects to dead relatives so you need to be quiet and respectful, obeying the signs.We had some lunch at the vegetarian restaurant. Maybe we just chose the wrong dish but it was pretty awful.I would very much recommend this as a half day away from the frantic pace of the Hong Kong metropolis.

Bad timing?. From the outside, the monastery looked amazing and that is all we can base a review on. I don't know if it was bad timing but were not allowed inside and they were finishing bits off prior to some official event. Plenty of vegetarian food on offer but little else to see.

A great escape from the city. Man Fat Sze, the Ten Thousand Buddha's Monastery is easily accessed from the Sha Tin MTR station and makes for an excellent half day trip out of the main city centre. Crowds get bigger in the afternoons so if you want to see it in peace, go early. Please also pay attention to areas within the temple where taking photos is not allowed.

A really pleasant experience. I visited here earlier in the year. After a healthy walk to the top to get there, there was plenty to see, and it was a humbling and moving experience. The architecture was magnificent and the atmosphere was so tranquil and calm, truly a place to go to get away from the rush and bustle of Hong Kong

Place to go. Located in Shatin, easy to find and different to the other temples. I have visited some others including the oldest temple in HKG, but this one has to be seen, mainly for all the buddahs.
Very moving. We had to wait until a service was over to go into the temple butit was really moving and very beautiful
Great walk. Has to be done and don't be put off by finding the starting point..this was one of our favourite visits in Hong Kong..grea photo opportunities and not just for tourists.

A beautiful and tranquil place to visit, prepare for a nice walk though. I had herd a lot about this Monastery, how ever no words could actually paint an accurate picture of this lovely, peacefully place up on a hill near the village of Sha Tin. Arriving by train is probably the best method of getting to Sha Tin from Hong Kong, I used the MTR smartphone app successfully to find my way there. On the way to the Monastery there is quite a bit to take in and capture with holiday snaps. Probably the most recognisable shop you will notice is IKEA, maybe because of their blue and yellow sign. Also on the way you will see many small stalls and shops selling offerings for the dead, paper clothes and other such items that are burnt to send them into the afterlife to loved ones who have passed away. Man Fat Sze is locate at the top of a near by hill and the path to walk up is situated behind the mall where IKEA is located. Be aware that this is a sloping up hill walk and even though there are a few rest point along the way it is still a good workout and should be taken slowly. You will pass many life sized golden coloured statues of Buddha's each different from the previous ones. I would also recommend wearing very comfortable and appropriate foot wear. As I have pointed out many times a bottle of waster should be taken as well and sipped to keep from dehydrating and spoiling a good days outing. Most importantly take the journey slow,pace yourself and stop occasionally to rest.At the top, well where the temples are, you will see signs asking that no photos be taken inside the temples, for the respect of the Buddhist please follow this request as there is a lot that they do allow you to take photos. Another thing I should point out is that there have been cases of "fake" monks begging for money and there are signs along the walk warning of this. Real Buddhist monks Do Not beg so please do not encourage this activity by giving these beggers in monastic clothing money. Actually when I visited I did not see any but do be aware they are around from time to time.The monastery it's self is rather simple compared to others you can visit but that does not in anyway distract from it's beauty or serenity. In the largest of the temples you can collect a brochure that explains about the founder of the monastery and his actual mortal remains are still located infront of the three large Buddha statues in this temple surrounded by hundred or possible over a thousand small Buddha statues. The complex contains about five temples and a pagoda along with a vegetarian cafe that serves excellent meals or just pick up a cold drink. Man Fat Sze, the Ten Thousand Buddha's Monastery is well worth a visit and makes for an excellent half or near full days outing. The walk continues above the temples up past many other Buddha statues and as ai have mentioned it is well worth the work out just take it slow and pace yourself.

10,000 Buddahs, one on every step to the top. Great Monastery, dating back to 1949, set up by Reverend Yuet Kai.Very well kept and interesting if you have about 1-2 hr to spare, the walk up takes about 30mins of steady stepping..... So a good work out
Fantastic views. We took the tube to get there and walked for another 30 mins up to the hill where the monastery was situated. What a view and a fantastic site to visit. A definite must.

I've done this a dozen time--always a great outing. Just head up to the main metro stop in Shatin and ask the locals for directions. Its an easy but invigorating hike for about 20 minutes to this venerable shrine--but well worth the experience, and not the least for its being off the heavily traversed tourist routes of TST and HK Island. Afterward, either eat at a small place in the mall, grab some fish balls off the street, or (best) take a taxi or bus out to Sai Kung for a stroll and the best seafood in Hong Kong. Spectacular scenery as well.

Wear comfortable shoes. Don't forget to wear comfortable shoes or sports shoes for hiking those steps high up. It is steep and takes you to the monastery about 20-30 mins and then you walk up again to find Guan Yin (Indonesian: dewi Kwan Im) which then you can find peace within yourself. To go down, back to the MTR station just follow the sign, whichever exit you take, just walk down then you will end up on the street where you came from.

Photographers Paradise!!!. Totally loved this place, the walk didn't seem too long to me as I couldn't stop taking photos of the Buddha in different scenarios (it's quite addictive) it was a lovely sunny day so I loved this experience. We ate in the vege cafe at the top (finally some veg food in HK!) this was heaven as a) the food was well priced b) we had a choice, horay. Extensive vege menu, yummy! Best to point at menu as they don't all speak English, very friendly though. You can buy incense for about £1 for tons of it to light in front of the statues. Also lots of cheap trinkets for friends and family. The statues blew me away, all different and unique, awesome! Pretty pagodas here too for tourist piccies. P.S. Ladies the toilets are a bit basic here so take your own tissue!!!

It definitely is worth the effort when reaching the peak!. ten thousand golden buddhas? At first I did not believe it but when I reached the peak and entered the temple, it was where I realized that it really was ten thousand. Such a picturesque scene not to mention having a skyline view of Hong Kong's city-scape.A place to beon ones Hong Kong's trip bucket list!

Tread the path wisely!. Like a previous reviewer we also ended up in the wrong place - the shrine/cemetery - and I have been before (in my defence it was 10 years ago). This meant that we were very hot and tired before we even started the correct ascent! That said, it is worth the long climb up, and if you go to the highest point, you will find a small, ice cold, air conditioned Buddha room- a welcome reward indeed!

Go to the right place. The pros: Very nice, a nice walk and step so good for health.Cost: FreeDown side: quite a walk and steep (for people having issues walking).Drinks/food: There is at the top a shop for drinks and food.To get there it is a little walk from the Shatin station. Where we made a light mistake, was we took a left too early and started visiting a place with two big lions in front plus a lot of stairs. This was in fact a cemetery. So make sure you are going to the right place.Once arrived at the right place, we soon realised that you can't be wrong, you have statues of Monks/Buddhas all over.The temple is really worth while and make sure to walk all around as there are nice things to see in “remote” corners, there also is a waterfall further up once you past the main area.Be careful though, the walk is quite long and it is steep, so for those sensitive to that, be prepared. If it is a hot day, bringing water could be a good idea.

A lot Buddhas to see. I took a taxi from my hotel to the place that was like a 15 min drive, it was cheap and easier to get there, the place is a free entrance so that's good, you need to climbing a lot of stairs but is good at the end, besides the monastery where you can see the 10,000 Buddhas there's a lot more to see and take a lot of pictures, you can keep on going following the stairs that will take you to a 3 more mini monastery's and a big white statue. It's a very nice place to go visit, and it takes like an hour and half to see everything :)

Nothing much. Was quite disappointing of this attraction. Yes, there are a lot of Buddhas, but you get bored quickly. Wouldn't recommend using a lot of time getting there, just for this monastery. Although, combined with other attractions in the area it might be worth it. However, I went to Myanmar a couple of weeks before so this have colored my review.

Hidden serenity. The first thing you need to know is that there are a lot of stairs. But if you are use to going to Buddhist temples you already know that. There are no signs from the Shatin station. Take exit b. Turn left. Follow the pedestrian bridge and the entrance is behind the ikea. I enjoyed this monastery actually. A friend of mine said it wasn't very good, but there weren't very many tourists and I enjoyed looking at the many incarnations of Buddha that the many statues portrayed. There is a vegetarian restaurant at the top of the stairs. I got a snack set for HK$35. It was OK. I would say also to be careful and mindful. There are many trees and bamboo surrounding the monastery. On my way down a branch broke off and was dangerously close to falling on a family with a baby.

Serene and quirky.... The walk up to the top is good fun with plenty of weird and wonderful Buddhas to capture your attention. The top is actually quite peaceful with some nice views. A good way to spend a couple of hours - and it's free.

interesting, very fulfilling to see so many believers. a beautiful place, fulfilling but not really inspiring since no information is offered there. at the bottum there is a reconstructed village with some extremely expenssive stores (2-5 times) alltogether very happy I went

Excellent place and very few tourists around, tricky to reach. *) Nearest MTR: Sha tin, Exit B.*) How to Reach:- Take Exit B- Turn left from MTR station going down the ramp- Walk towards the giant mall, take the first left (you should be in between the mall on the right and a playground/recreational area on the left)- Head towards Sha Tin Government Offices (if you have your GoogleMaps with you, you should be able to locate this)- Foot path to the monastery is exactly behind the Sha Tin Government Offices (if you get lost, just circle the building and you'll eventually find the entrance and some signs leading to the entrance)- There are two entrances side-by-side, the lavish one is the one leading to the cemetary, right beside it on your right hand side there is a narrow ramp going uphill, this is the part that goes to the monastery, there is a easily-missable-tiny-signboard-at-foot-level indicating the same.- A few steps ahead up on the ramp you see two banners on something that looks like a dead-end, but of course is not, take left from here. So far eveything looks like a dumpyard, and you are convinced that you are at the wrong place (which is perfectly normal). - Take a few steps and you will see the statues of Buddha that will convince you that you are at the right place.*) It is a long climb though, with benches where you can take a rest. On the way up, thousands of buddhas will greet you with each one distinct from the other. At the Monastery on first level, there is a restaurant where you can buy food and drinks.*) There are two levels to this place, you know you are at the top level where you see the white buddha, Buddha status against the waterfall and tortoise/turtle lazing in the pond. Make sure you go till the top, the views are amazing from there.*) Entrance is free.*) With over 12,000 Buddhas both outside and inside the temple. Along each side of the path, there are life-sized sitting or standing buddha figures, each having a different facial expression. *) Bring your own water and shade, no drinking water fountain anywhere.*) Toilets available on the first level, did not see any on the second level.*) No pictures allowed in the proper temple/prayer hall, rest everywhere you are allowed to take pictures.*) Very few tourists/locals here, and we went on Saturday.For a detailed trip list feel free to visit http://hongkongandmacauitinerary.blogspot.in/2014/10/hong-kong-macau-itinerary.html

Got tired from hectic big city life? Come here. Totally wonderful, peaceful and lovely place to visit which will definitely impress you with its beauty - and the number of Buddha statues of course! They will be there to both sides of the road as you go up all the way to the Monastery.Beware of fake monks, I met one on the way back even though it was Monday morning and definitely not a touristy time.Getting there is a lot easier than I expected, literally a five minutes walk from Sha Tin tube station up to the sign pointing out to the monastery - climbing up the stairs is a bit tricky though, as the road is quite steep. Monastery and wonderful view of the city from the top will be a decent reward though =)

Definitely worth the climb. I visited the monastery today and I am SO pleased I decided to do so. Getting to Shatin is really easy and finding the way from the MTR station was easy following the directions from previous reviewers (there is a video on Youtube also guiding you step by step). Although the climb is challenging in the heat, most of the way is in the shade (I went around 1pm) so it wasn't too bad. Sadly I didn't see any monkeys but the buddhas gave plenty to marvel at. Getting up to the main temple was easy enough, even with taking it slowly and taking tons of photos along the way, it must've taken about 20 minutes tops. What a beautiful sight when you do reach the top; just stunning. I spent roughly two hours just taking it all in - be sure to go the few extra steps to get to the terrapin pool and get the most magnificent view of the valley below. I didn't mind the slight building work going on at all, it actually gave an interesting contrast to the temple areas. The loos were fine - some of the doors were hanging off but all in all, clean enough and there was soap! The nice thing was that it was not busy - I was alone in the temples most of the time and that was really special. Do go - definitely worth your time and the aching muscles :)
Beautiful. This is an amazing place all the details so much to see. I was so taken in by all the carvings on stuff. They take time to make sure everything is perfect. A must see.

Very beautiful . The signing is poor, hence I climbed extra 300 steps that led to nowhere. But once I reached the right track, it was worth the trouble.After climbing 480 steps, go to the right and climb some more and then come back and turn left. After you see the temple and the big Budha statues, exit through the gate at the opposite side and go down a few steps. You will meet lotsof free monkeys, entire families. Beautiful sight.

Worth a visit. The location is a bit hard to get to. Catch a train to Sha Tin, head towards the Home Central mall then kind of walk around behind it and you see a lane way with a little sign for the Monastery. Walk down the lane way then you begin the ascent up the mountain past the 12,000+ buddha statues. I was wearing slip on ballet shoes but didn't have a problem ascending but if you're scared of heights (which I am a bit), some of the steeper inclines can be daunting. Well worth the effort getting up there though. Look out for monkey poo in the pagodas!!!

steep climb but serene up top. Firstly get there early, due to the climb we were sweating and puffing even in the early morning around 9am. This site was easy to find with instructions from the net, plus a video off youtube. Once there at the start of the climb there are signs with instructions. The stairs up have a ramp which I found easier to get up with. The buddhas have different poses and faces which is interesting plus as a bonus there are seats along the way for a rest.Once at the top, there are several temples to look at and a llittle cafe for drinks. once having viewed these attractions you can climb up further for more temples. There is a little pond with turtles etc which my kids loved. We didnt encounter any fake monks but beware as we saw some in the MTR.Worth a look for the temples alone.

Worth the walk. Definitely worth the walk to see this attraction. Free entry, the only think to watch out for is fake monks. I was stopped by a man in a monk outfit, he offered me a beaded bracelet and appeared to bless me. When I thanked him and went to walk away, he asked me for money. I gave the bracelet back and went on my way. I asked other tourists and they said the same thing had happened to them.Real monks won't do this so don't fall for the the trick. I spent about an hour all together at this site and by the time i was finished he had left, presumably the real employees had asked him to leave.Don't let that put you off though, as you'll miss out on an amazing attraction.

IT'S WORTH IT!. The climb was steep but enjoyable if you take your pace slowly. There's a small restaurant on top. We had the sagu with coconut oil and lemon grass juice,very refreshing and cheap.The view on top was awesome. So glad we went. Even our 3 year old enjoyed the climb.

A long walk - surrounded by hundreds of Buddhas. The walk is a little bit strenuous but the Monastery is definitely worth it. Pay attention to hundreds of different faces of Buddhas. If you still can to to the top of pagoda.

Worth the climb. The monastary is not too far from the train station. The walk to the monestary is lined with many Buddhas. Be sure to take some water with you for the climb, especially if the weather is warm. The various temples are worth seeing. We had a light lunch at the small restaurant at the top.

Some trippy buddhas!. Decided to visit ten thousand Buddhas monastery instead of big Buddha as it seemed a bit less touristy. The walk up to the top is really interesting (and seriously not that challenging as long as you don't mind some steps). So great to explore all the Buddhas! Some with hands growing out their eyes, others with lots of heads, lots patting pet animals etc! Also had a vegetarian meal at the top. It seemed super authentic and no one spoke much english (if at all) but we got by from pointing. Great views of the city from the top too - worth the trip!

Worth the Climb. Found our way by bus and got off near the IKEA store of all places and walked along a narrow path and found the entrance. The climb up the steps made this so worthwhile. So many different life size Buddhas lined the steps are you ascend. We stopped many times to appreciate the work depicted in so many of them. Once at the top is the monastery with more Buddhas to enjoy.

Ten thousand Buddhas monastery. There are two ways up to the monastery. One is very steep and goes past a shanty village. Very few statues of Buddhas until near the top. The other approach is more gentle and the path is adorned with Buddhas on each side. We could not see the sign to go up this side but the majority of people seemed to use it. We used it to come down. Don't do this visit on a very hot day!

Monkeys and Buddhas for free!. My boyfriend and I had a free day in Hong Kong and decided to go to the Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery. At first we were a little frustrated because we got lost coming out of Sha Tin Station (and wound up on the wrong side of the divided highway). REAL WAY TO GET THERE: Find the exit that takes you towards the Government Offices. As you exit, you should see a bus depot on your right. Keep following the signs for the Government Offices. The entrance to the monastery is between the Offices and the Ikea.It is a long climb up, especially in the August heat. There is almost no air conditioning at the monastery, so be sure to dress for the weather. There are no apparel rules for visiting like long pants.What really made the trip cool was the fact that the top pavilion has a small pond with turtles and fish, and when we were descending, the monkeys were out in full force. They were really awesome, but one of the male alphas did make menacing moves at the boyfriend, so don't get too close! There was also a small kid going up at that point and he looked pretty terrified of the monkeys.Bathrooms were the ordinary squat variety, but very clean. (Anytime there's soap in a bathroom in Asia, I call that a win!)

you need water. if you intend to go and see this take the train to sha tin its fun and not far to walk to the gate .if its hot take plenty of water for the walk up there is water and food at the top.its WORTH THE EFFORT .not a lot of tourist go there therefore its not crowded .
Worth visiting. Clearly check the route before going. There are two routes going up and I prefer the one from city central plaza as the road is wider and you can take gorgeous photo easily.

So glad that we went!. We had read about the Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery and it was on our must-see list when visiting Hong Kong.As you climb to the monastery - and it is a steep, steep climb, especially if it is hot and humid - the path is lined with gold buddhas in different poses. Some are serious, some whimsical, some playing instruments - all are wonderful and each is different. Take your time and really look at their expressions - they're lovely and fun. The Temple itself is beautiful and, from what I understand, it actually has about 13,000 buddhas. There are additional temples, terraces, and a pagoda. It's quite impressive and I'm glad we went.The temple is located in the New Territories and is accessible by subway - it is at the Sha Tin stop, Exit B.

410 steps to heaven. A slow climb up 410 steps ( I know cause i counted them all) with smiling buddhas all the way up brings you to the monastery and out buildings with even more buddhas,all caked in gold even the founder is preserved in gold, be it paint or the real stuff.A further climb brings you to more buddhas and temples.By now you must be enlightened or knackered.Its not well sign posted but head out of MTR and take the first left by sports ground ,cross the road down to the gate house of the local cemetery and take the small path along side the wall ,then you will see signs for it.

2nd Time. First time, I went there by myself. This second time, I brought my family with me. It was a hot, humid day and to visit there in such weather is a very bad idea. Though often read from reviews and from the signage around the place, I haven't met a single monk around the place on both my visits. Do not skip the top most part where there's a white (I don't know what material) Buddha with a small waterfall! Its definitely the best part of the temple!

Plenty of Buddhas!. First of all - beware of the fake monks trying to charge you at the entrance by "blessing you". This has been written about in the guide books and websites but still - good to know!They approached us quite aggressively but we jut kept walking!After that it is a steep climb with plenty of steps but the Buddhas keep you company. Well worth the effort!

A steep climb but worth it. As other reviewers have pointed out this is not for anyone who is not in good physical condition. The walkway to the top is lined with hundreds of gold painted Buddhas in all sorts of positions and activities. The temple is a long cab ride from Kowloon waterfront although you can get there by the subway if you know the route and lines. At the top are thousands more Buddhas varying in size from life size to very large to tiny. There is no admission but the monks ask for donations. Allow at least a half hour each way for transit and an hour or more for the climb up and back down,
10000 buddhas. Never seen so many different kind of Buddha.. Once you make it up there, its nice, calming feeling. There are some every old restaurant nested around this community.
A bit of hike but well worth the effort. Fascinating place to visit although tucked away. If you have health problems probably not the best place for you but culturally a treat.

Worth a visit. The cable car trip up to the monastery is in itself an experience not to be missed.The food at the restaurant is different but representative of the local cuisine. Although all the disses were vegetarian it was still very tasty and well presented. Service was excellent.

Good experience, but quite a climb. Nice place to visit and to see, but it is quite a climb up the hill, so take this into account when planning. (might not be so well suitable for the hot and humid days in HK).

Stairway to Heaven. The 10,000 Buddhas Monastery is easy to get to. At Shatin MTR take exit B, turn left, walk down the ramp alongside the bus terminus (just follow the crowd), down to street level, past Pai Tau Village on the left. keep walking to the junction with Pai Tau Street on the left (you will see a shopping plaza with Homesquare and IKEA store). Follow Pai Tau Street and take the first street on the right, Sheung Wo Che Road and follow this street alongside Shatin Government Offices and a multi-storey car parkAt the end of Sheung Wo Che Road is a yellow direction sign for the monastery. After a short walk on the path you will come to the start of the steps. The walk from the MTR station to the start of the path leading up to the monastery takes about ten minutes. Enjoy the climb if you can. There is a Buddha statue on the side of every step. All are different. There are benches to rest on if you get tired, but really it is not that strenuous as likely you will take your time walking and taking photos on the way.Warning: do not give money to the people dressed as monks. They are not real monks. Real Buddhist monks do not ask for money. Actually there are no resident monks at this monastery, it is managed by laypersons.At the top of the steps you come to the main attractions, Wander around and take it all in. There is a large hall with very impressive decorations and many thousands of small Buddha statues. There are other smaller pavilions to visit too. There is also a pagoda.It is worth to climb the steps up the 8 levels inside the pagoda.On this level there is a vegetarian restaurant. English is not well spoken by the staff but it is still worth having a bite to eat there. And have a refreshing drink.Note: on this level there is another entrance/exit at the other end to the main entrance. There are not as many steps to walk. It leads to a small village (and small bee-hive where you can buy honey) and eventually comes out quite close to the Shatin MTR station.Also, there is an upper level to walk to, take the path near the main entrance. It is not as strenuous a walk as the first lot of steps. It is worth walking up to the next level. You get some very good views over Shatin and there are other smaller halls and pavilions to visit. You will even see a small waterfall with small turtles and some goldfish in a small pond.Overall you can allow 2-3 hours for the walk there and back and looking around the monastery.

Vegeterian Lunch at the Monastery. I visited the monastery and enjoyed the vegetarian lunch as part of a guided tour. The lunch was very good and I enjoyed visiting with other tour participants from around the globe. At the end of our lunch a thunderstorm moved in and we were not able to enjoy walking around the area or the cable car ride down. Even with the rain, it was a very enjoyable experience and one I am glad I had.

Beautiful. The place is one of the those that you should not visit while visiting Hong Kong. Yes the climb could be a bit effort physically but then the beauty of the place and the whole visual treats along the path makes it easier and a good distraction from the strenuous climbs. Do not worry as they also have got resting points in between where you catch a breath and at the end of the climb you will be able to visit the temple. There is also a café at the top to grab a bite after your visit

UNIQUE ATTRACTION. We arrived using the MTR to the Sha Tin station. After exiting the MTR station, it's about a ten minute walk to the base of the hill. Take exit B, walk to Pai Tau Street. Take a left on Pai Tau Street. There will be a park on your left as you walk down Pai Tau Street. Turn right before your reach the last building on your right and continue straight to the walkway that leads uphill. It can be a little tricky finding the little sign that leads you to the walkway. It's a small area, so you can't get too lost. It's a steep climb. We had our two kids with us, so we took several breaks. There are a few benches along the way to sit on and catch your breath. Walking up the hill, you will see 1000 different tiny gold buddhas on each side of the walkway. It helps keep the climb interesting. Once you make it to the top, there is a pagoda, a pavilion and the main temple among other sights. No pictures are allowed in the main temple. There is a little cafe at the top, but the menu is limited. The customer service in the little cafe is just ok. The lady working there wasn't very friendly, so we just got a water and decided to eat a late lunch later in Kowloon.

Worth the climb. It is a steep climb up to the monastery but you are truly rewarded when you reach the top. The temple is against a brilliant backdrop for photos too. Try the cafe for cool drinks and vegetarian food.Do not disrespect the statues as we observed whilst visiting, you will be admonished by the custodians. This includes eating/ picnicking along the route.

Interesting!!!. First, be prepared for a climb. Best to make sure you are hydrated. It is some rest points along the path. Your adventure starts with the 1st step, there is a different buddha each step, most of the time on each side. Each is different no carbon copy. At the top there is a restaurant there to relax and regroup. Well worth the experience.
restricted access. The buildings you can currently see are very nice but they are doing a lot of building work at the moment, restricting access to some areas of the monastery

10,000 Buddhas plus 10,000 steep steps, 10,000 insect bites. First, let me start by saying if you have bad knees or are way out of shape this is not for you. We traveled on August 15th and the sun was relentless. There was no charge, but we paid in sweat! The climb was steep and seemed never ending. We felt insect bites everyother step ( felt like mosquitoes ). I had to stop three times during the incline. The climb is lined with hundreds of gold painted life sized Buddhas along the way. BUT . . . When u finally reach the top the work out is well worth it! Gorgeous!! I definetly reccomend this to your list of Hong Kong do's!
Was under renovation. We came up to see the Buddha, unfortunately the Monastery was under a lot of renovations. I bet it will look great when it is done though.

Colourful, Peaceful & a Great Workout!. The Temple of Ten Thousand Buddhas is a very clean, tranquil, and peaceful place. Beware of "false monks" at the entrance who will approach you and claim to bless you and ask for money. Just politely say, 'No thank you" and walk away. There are LOTS of steps, so take plenty of water and get ready for a great calorie-burning workout. This attraction is colourful and a great place for photos. Please keep in mind to be respectful when taking photos, as photographs aren't appropriate in all areas. At the top there is a very inexpensive vegetarian restaurant that serves tasty food. I am very happy that I decided to visit this attraction when in Hong Kong. It is convenient to public transportation. (I personally recommend making a small donation. It is not required, but I believe it is in good taste for tourists to do so.)

A lot of gold painted Buddhas on your climb!. Actually despite my title it is worthwhile going - although I found all the gold buddhas on the way up a little tedious after a while but the views and the temples at the top make up for it! Also there is a little tea shop which is great for a pot of tea and recovering!

Warm climb but worth it. As we were staying in Kowloon we took the hotel shuttle to Sha Tin station and walked to the Temple. In the heat of August it was a taxing climb which was eased by the many Buddhas lining the route. They took all forms from bearded men to angelic women. At the top of the climb the temple was small but impressive and the views over the city anything but small. This temple comes highly recommended.

Spiritual. A very spiritual area, just to walk around.Also there is a vegetarian restaurant, and the food is FANTASTIC !! (I will admit, that as a westerner - the bathrooms were a bit concerning, but still managed).

Very interesting if you are into Buddhas and Buddhism.. Getting to the Monastery takes a couple of metro lines from Kowloon then an uphill walk (stairs too) for about 1/4 mile. Once at the top there is a vegetarian cafe and the main temple with the 12,000 buddhas. The Buddha's are about 10-12 inches high and line the high walls of the temple. No two are the same. it is interesting to see but, worth the entire trip out? Not sure... Super hot and humid in the summer get ready to be drenched in sweat after the walk up. The walk up was almost more interesting to me as it is a cement walk lined with small trees and large Buddha's the entire way up. There were a few other statues at the top of the hill but, I didn't explore further then the main temple as it was just too hot.
Nice monastery worth a visit. This place is full of vibrant colours. The Monastery is nice, when we went the place was very busy but worth a trip.

The Buddhas are incredible. Wait til you get here...and you think you have seen buddhas, not until you get here. The Monastery is fantastic, and serenely sublime. I loved all the buddhas, and the monks were wonderful, and nice to see them working, and praying, etc.
Long walk, lots o steps. We loved it, 13000 Buddhas. Just make sure that you ask around for directions, as the sign are a bit hidden away, and you can waist time walking around unnecessary.

Have lunch here. Even though under construction at the moment, worth a visit. Take a cabla car up, and time around lunch. Buy a meal ticket at the booth (HK$88 for 1 person - vegetarian). Nice experience. Well kept monastery next to Big Buddha!

Worth the trip and the steps.. If you don't like climbing steps then don't come here. But if you are willing to be a little active then this is truly worth it. Each Buddha on the way up is different so they take your mind off the climb. The temple at the top is ......you just have to see it. You thought there were a lot of Buddhas on the way up, well think again. Also the colours and designs of the robes on the statues are works of art.

Great quest!. Among infinite statues of buddas you'll definately find own Budda. There are Budda-alcoholic, Budda-Christ, red-lips Budda, Budda-Shiva, Budda-punk.... And even if you're atheist you'll also find your "god" - there are a lot of jumping monkeys!

Once fabulous - now a buddha theme park. Still worth visiting as the food is cheap and great, the temple and pagoda you can climb still carrying the holy feel. The gold encased body of the founding monk a tad spooky ...But the current abbot has seen fit to create around 300 new life size Buddha statues which seem to be competing in the silly statue competition. Look out for "Ant bit my bum" buddha, angry buddha, beardy buddha, "handy for high shelves" buddha, and near the very top of the site by the waterfall search out Scottish buddha. A laugh a minute, and a bit sad.

Perfect spot for beautiful pictures. Beautiful place to take pictures!Nice monastery just a train ride away from Hong Kong.There was a small shop to buy inscence and water - which is really needed with the hot temperatures.
Pretty Awesome. If you are into buddhism and appreciate all things zen you'll love this place. Found the path with ease; the stairs aren't bad at all, just watch out for the monkeys. I loved it.

Worth the effort. Somewhat further out (MTR Shatin) but once you have climbed the many steps (or even on the way) a rewarding view of many Buddhist sculpures. A temple is situated s few steps higher. Don't carry plastic bags (or similar) which could be grabbed off you by the local monkeys. Simple. But its place I've come back to time and again when I'm in Hong Kong.

Good temple but not so spectacular. Getting there is not very difficult but when you reach the metro station there are no clear signs ... you have to search for a close-bay mall where Ikea is and then you have it on your left. they place is curious with a ramp up full of Buddha statues, each one different from the other. The Temple itself is not very spectacular but its worth a visit (although in my opinion the environment of the Big Buddha is better ...)

Very Unique. If you go here, be sure you can walk the very long path/stairs to go up in the mountain.... That all said, if you can, then go. Getting there is easy, from the subway station just walk around 4 blocks heading to the "IKEA" (In the very nice mall IKEA is located you can have refreshments or a very good lunch after visiting the monastery)... The stairs start 1 block behind the IKEA mall, just behind the Government offices. Once you are there enjoy the +13000 different golden Buddha statutes and the monastery itself, colorful, beautiful and very unique. Few people goes here, so no multitudes, just a nice time to explore a different Hong Kong.... Its is a half day plan.

Great once you find it. Not well sign posted but was great when we eventually found the stairs to the Monastry. There is a LOT of stairs to get to the Monastry so not for everyone esp in 32 degree heat. Is a beautiful Monastry

great half day trip in Hong Kong - free too. It is a beautiful monastery to visit. A little effort to get there, and a little effort to climb up, but well worth it. The golden buddhas are lined along the way up, each one is different, some even very funny. There are many spots worth to check out, so walk all the way to the top to see monks hill, the turtle pond, the white GuangYin, and have a great view of the city with endless mountains. Then walk down to see the ten thousand budddhas hall. The pagoda is massive and beautiful. Great picture opportunity! It was not crowded at all when we visited in a weekday in May, only handful people there. So we had very peaceful time among with so many buddhas. There are two entrances, make sure to take one up and take another down so you will see all the buddha status.

And 40,000 steps.. Easy to find exit MRT at Sha Tin take exit B go down the ramp and follow signs to Govt building, pass the GB and walk 100m to a white ancestral hall on the right take the path just before the white building. There are no signs directing you to this temple for some reason. TBH I thought it looked tacky a bit like Las Vegas on a budget. It's very Chinese and there are lots of Buddhas the best bit is the hall with all the miniature Buddhas. If your not fit don't even try this I'm an ex fitness instructor n in the heat the climb half killed me. No access for the disabled due to location. It's free n if your in the area why not go see. There's a vegetarian cafe there too. It is in a very safe area look out for monkeys.

RELIGIOUS PLACE. The only way to reach this monastry is climbing a lot of stairs. This is not a tourist attraction, but a real monastry so when we reached it we found a very silent and quite place in the middle of the mountains. The golden decoration inside the monastry were beautiful and the only sound we can hear were the preyers. We loved it even though it is not the most famous monastry in HK.

Worth the climb!. Much like many reviewers here - I must emphasise it can be tricky to find the entrance. However, when you do begin climbing the steps you get to view ten thousand Buddhas, all of which are different. It's not packed with tourists and is a great trip if you enjoy your culture.

Nice for 2-3 hour trip. Its bit difficult to find the this place got confused by another big Buddha temple just adjacent to it...take the MTR to sha tin and take exit b ...keep following the ramp till you reach the mall ...from mall take left to govt office...you will find a play ground to you left and mall to the right...at the end you will see a big gate leading to car park ...this is another decent Buddha temple...to get to 10000 Buddha monastery take a small alley just besides the govt office on the right side of the big gate....climb up is good and takes around 30 min ....not much of view from the temple ...the way to the temple and temple itself is amazing...the level of detail in each Buddha is great...after temple you can take a short climb up to the top ...view from there is good...

Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery - 400+ Steps. A good (not so steep) climb to reach, but all the efforts are rewarded with over 10,000 + Buddhas both outside and inside the temple. Things to note :- - No Fee- Nice Trail to main Pagoda but be ready for 45mins-1 hr climb ( at every easy pace) - Good View once you reach the top - Carry your water bottle and lite refreshment- There is a small restaurant at the top- No photography allowed inside the temple but there are lot of the good spots- Try to go all the way up to Turtle pond

great surprise. i didnt know what to expect since i didnt hear about alot of people that went there. the place is very untouristic and thats great. very simple and not fancy. you have to be fit for the stairs! they require some effort.getting there was very easy by train

A little gem in Hong Kong.. You simply have to visit this attraction. There really are ten thousand buddhas and all of them have completely different faces! It is utterly fascinating. Quite a lot of steps but take your time and you'll manage it. Have a meal at the top when you get there - lovely food prepared on the premises and very cheap.

Devine Architecture.... The innovation involved in creating thousands of postures of Buddha is commendable.... The main monestry on the top of the hillock is peaceful... upkeep is niceWorth spending half a day.

Step back and enjoy the walk. The entrance may not be attractive, but the walk is very much worth it. You will enjoy a climb to the top with tree lined path. No worry for direct hot sun. On the top is a huge temple. Walk further up you will find interesting rest stop. We enjoy the outing. Although there is no entrance fee, donation is a great way to upkeep the place.

Stunning View. If you go to Hong Kong you simply have to experience the view from the peak! I would recommend seeing it in both daytime and night time. Expect queues though as with most things in Hong Kong. The queue does move at a reasonable speed though. Stunning view and well worth the wait. Also you have to experience the ride up there seeing the building at a weird angle

Something different. The monastery is near Sha Tin station, another reviewer has given excellent directions - suffice to say, follow the signs for 'government offices'.The monastery is at the top of a path that has many unique Buddha-esque statues lining the way. These statues come in a range of poses, all are golden but some have hair, some seem lost in thought whilst others are pulling funny faces. We walked up here when it was around 35'c and 80% humidity so arrived drenched. However, we didn't feel the walk up was exerting but have recently trekked in Nepal.Once at the temple you can see many more miniature Buddhas along with some other interesting statues. There are also views over this area of Hong Kong. The monastery also sits under the flight path should you be interested in some plane spotting.Another path winds its way to another temple, along with part of a hill covered in more statues. There are drinks and food served here along with clean toilets. It is a bit out of the way but it is free and something different. However, there is no history about the monastery or any of the temples, which is a shame as it is a rather unique and interesting place. I would have likes to have been able to find out more.

Great Place Off the Beaten Path. It's a temple that has over 10,000 life-sized Buddhas along a winding path uphill. That is quite awesome. Guess there isn't much else to see/do here, but going up the path to see the Buddhas, which are all different, is an amazing experience in and of itself. There is a platform in the middle that has the actual temple (no pictures allowed), a pagoda, and a vegetarian restaurant.Keep in mind that the path is steep and long, and it's recommended to bring water (Hong Kong is very hot in the summer). Most people will only want to go until the platform, but one can go higher as well, as the path continues.

Temple. This attraction is not a place on the list by Tourism Board of Hong Kong. But it is a amazing place with many different kind of Buddha on display. It is up on a mini hill that you need to walk up to reach the main temple. Along the path line up with buddhas so it was very interesting.
Temples and devotees. I like the place as it was seen on chinese movies, temples and buddhas. there was an incense area and souviner shops where you can buy crafts and other souviner items

Off the beaten path. The monastery is a little tricky to find as others before me have already posted. However, it is worth the extra effort to seek it out. The statues are all unique and individualized. We encountered only a few other visitors as we climbed the 400 plus stairs to the top. This place is spiritually rich and it is free. Think quiet....they as for our consideration.

A bit of a hidden gem. This was a great place to visit, interesting background information as to its history, a workout to make it to the top, and very few other people there. Had a wonderful time looking finding buddhas that reminded us of friends and family, 10,000 to choose from :). Would highly recommend a visit.

Pocket of Serenity. It's surprising that this site hasn't been actively promoted (as compared to other tourist spots). It's easy to get to (take MTR to Sha Tin), walk past HomeSquare Mall (it has an Ikea Branch), turn right walk a few meters until you reach the back of the Sha Tin Transport Department Building. There is a sign there.It is a long climb though, with benches where you can take a rest. On the way up, thousands of buddhas will greet you with each one distinct from the other. At the Monastery, there is a restaurant where you can buy food and drinks.The place is beautiful. It is a quiet and refreshing getaway from the fast-paced HK lifestyle.

If you are looking for something meaningful in Hong Kong, you must visit the Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery.. Our visit here was fantastic. My family are from Hong Kong and I have travelled to Hong Kong frequently over the years but this was our first visit. For those staying in Kowloon or Hong Kong Island, Sha Tin is easily accessible by MTR or bus although two line changes can be necessary on the MTR. The pathway leading up to the monastery can be steep in parts but there are rails all the way. For those with limited endurance, taking your time is great at the Figures line the walkways making the walk incredibly interesting. At the monastery there are a number of buildings, all with an incredible variety of figures. For information about the monastery, there is some online information, eg Wikipedia, which provides a basic overview and history. Overall, this was a highlight of our Hong Kong visit.

sha tin with a thrill. this not so much visited temple is a climb up one of the hills in sha tin new territories Hong Kong and bring you to another world, a bit of past Hong Kong is still there. All who know the hong kong view of the 80ties, with the first start of real skyscrapers building, the star ferry untouched, will enjoy the sha tin small miracle
Hideaway temple. This temple is at Shatin. You have to walk up more than 1000steps but very worth it. Very beautiful temple.

Lovely culture, beautiful!. The place is very beautiful. Although it is a long climb to the top, it was worth it. Ofcourse once you reach the top, the monastery and the view are just spectacular. Take the climb and a camera. You won't be disappointed.

Hard to find, but worth the trouble. DIRECTIONS:- Make your way to Sha Tin MTR Station- Take Exit B- Turn left from MTR station going down the ramp- Walk towards the giant mall, take the first left (you should be in between the mall on the right and a playground/recreational area on the left)- Head towards Sha Tin Government Offices (if you have your GoogleMaps with you, you should be able to locate this)- Foot path to the monastery is exactly behind the Sha Tin Government Offices (if you get lost, just circle the building and you'll eventually find the entrance and some signs leading to the entrance)Despite reading several reviews on finding the temple, I managed to get lost! However, once I found the entrance (along with 2 other lost travelers!) the walk up the hill was pleasant. Got drenched in the rain as well, but sought refuge in the restaurant at the top of the hill. After a nice hot meal and several cups of hot tea, exploring the temples and plaza was quite rewarding. Make sure you go all the way up to the top where you will be rewarded with a stunning view and a beautiful Buddha statue against the waterfall background. I only stayed for around an hour as the temple closes at 5pm, but would have loved to stay for longer to really appreciate the temples! Would suggest the temple maintenance crew to make better signs though! The ones on the main road were a bit faded and I went all the way up to the top of the cemetery next door only to get strange looks from the families praying to their ancestors! Best part of this though, was it was FREE! :-)

Highly impressed. This was fantastic and I'm glad we made the trip. A little difficult to find - but then everything is a little difficult to find in China. There are signs up warning of fake monks and sure enough we were accosted by two. We just ignored them and walked past but we saw later they had stopped other people and were talking to them. The stairs are pretty easy as long as you take it slow and there are plenty of Buddhas along the way to keep you occupied. The halls at the top are amazing and make sure you climb all the way to the top to see the white Buddha. The pond under it has so many turtles which are fun to watch. A beautiful place to sit and reflect for a while.

Better than big buddha. I think this temple provides a much better experience than big Buddha which is so often the first go to for many tourists than this less commercialised temple. The pleasant views from the temple at sundown combined with the lack of commercialisation and bustling tourists made this a very enjoyable and picturesque experience

Takes a bit of effort but very enjoyable. Just wish they had more info available at the site to explain the history, etc. I went in kind of blind as I wasn't expecting to visit it during my stay in HK but glad I didn't miss it. Definetly a climb. Was pleased to find the little cafe at the top ~ a grapefruit soda was so very refreshing! I went in May. No crowds. Humid though. Not hard to get to tho the entrance is very unassuming.

Fab. a real off the beaten path gem. It was a bit isolated on the moody Sunday morning when I visited, but I didn't feel unsafe. Its an actual place of worship with monks in situ so please wear something respectful. I was cringing when I saw some westerner in bum shorts inside the temple - seriously?!The path is actually just after the small football field just follow the signs to the monastery of which there is plenty. You cant take photos or videos of the inside of the actual shrine, but outside is fine and the statues are amazing. Steps are pretty easy but I wouldn't advise going in heavy rain tho,

Hard to find, go climb but great experience. Take note it's not that easy to find. MTR to Sha Tin take exit B and turn left. Go down the ramp and walk along the footpath with the old village down on you left. The shopping plaza in front of you has two big IKEA signs head for the one at the right hand end of the building (about 100 metres). Walk to the end of the buoying and then turn left. Signs will lead you from there. If you do turn too early and find yourself in front of the cemetery gates take the side path behind the shopping plaza as this will get you back to the main entrance. The Buddhas on the way up are very interesting, unique and some quite amusing. The climb is step and reasonably lengthy but plenty of rest points. It is worth it as the halls and large Buddhas are very impressive as is the preserved in gold lacquer body of Rev Yuet Kai. Remember to also climb some more steps to the higher temples and the water fall. Very peaceful and relaxing place. Take time to have some vege food at the restaurant it was good and reasonably priced.

Great views. Take the time to climb to the very top to see the big white Kanon. Amazing views!BEWARE OF FAKE MONKS ASKING FOR MONEY!! Real monks do not beg and there is no begging allowed on premise. One of the highlights for me was seeing the wild monkeys playing on the buddha statues, it was gorgeous.

What a 'climb'!. Interesting to see the different sculptured faces of each status. Not sure if they are carved based on actual persons but the uniqueness of each is astonishing. But be prepared for a hefty walk up the steps. Though no steep, it is quite a chore if one isn't quite 'fit'. Only hassle is trying to find the place from the MTR station, no clear signs, had to ask someone. Worth a visit nonetheless.

... with 10,000 steps!. Having lived in HKG most of my childhood, I never knew about this place till recently.
