I was blown away!This is culture at it's finest and recommend this to go hand in hand with the Big Buddah on Lantau Island.There is free entry and any food purchased at their canteen goes to their monastery.WARNING: If there are any Monks asking for money / donations at the bottom of the hill, DO NOT give them any money! They are scammers as Monks do not ask for donations. If you do get harrassed, tell them that you will call the Police and alert staff at the top of the hill as they will call the Police. This happened to us and they will not let us go up the hill without giving them any money.

Fascinatinginteraction to break up the bustle of Hong Kong. An interesting excursion enroute to Shenzen, recommend if you head up early then an hour here would still get you to Shenzen before stores open. A steep walk up the hill which is bordered by Buddhas all the way up. At the top is a temple which has over 12000 small Buddhas lining the walls. The plaza at the top is also quite interesting

Worth the long climb.... The monastery has put up large banners warning tourists not to give money to the fake monks, so on this visit there were none to be found. Finding the Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery can be a bit of a challenge. Upon exiting the station walk down the pedestrian walkway and around a slight curve where you will find a cross street with some sports courts on the corner. Take a left turn here and walk partway down the road until you reach a short, dead-end road on your right that looks like a service road between two buildings. At the left end of this street, hidden in some trees is the entrance!

Interesting, and FREE!. This attraction was a very nice surprise for us! At first, we took the elevator and stairs up to what turned out to be some kind of mausoleum...we should have known this from the advertisements for funeral services were all over once we got off the elevator, lol. That mistake was interesting in itself, though...the funeral parlor or mausoleum was walls and walls of small plaques adorning little doors, much like a mausoleum in the US, except each plaque had a photo of the deceased and their name/date of birth and death. Little incense pots and candles were every where. No one looked at us like we were intruding, so we looked around a bit and then headed back to the stairs. The entrance to Ten Thousand Buddhas was not clearly marked, and we had not seen any signs, but we followed a few others along a path that got us there. Ten Thousand Buddhas was built over a period of time by a man who wanted to honor the Buddha. Along each side of the path, there are life-sized sitting or standing buddha figures, each having a different facial expression. We had a fun time guessing what each buddha would be saying, some of the facial expressions were very funny! It was a typically hot and humid Hong Kong afternoon in April, so we were relieved to see a sitting area half way up. Take your time and keep climbing, you'll be happy you did. The views from the top are beautiful!

Make sure you spend few hours there! Wonderful visit. BEWARE OF FAKE MONKS ASKING FOR MONEY!! this to reviewer who warn us of that There was 4 of us, my poor father got cornered by one of the monk. I had to jump in and drag him away before the fake monk ask him for more money. There is also a sign that tell visitors that there is no begging allowed on premise. Spent half a day at the monastery! Had to ask a policewoman for directions when we got off the Shatin MTR. We went on a Saturday and it was very quiet. We took our time climbing up those stairs. Amazing view and scenery. We had a lot of fun looking at all the buddhas. Make sure you go all the way to very top to see the white Kanon. Breathtaking!!Be sure to bring a bottle of water with us, the climb up required it imo. There is a vegetarian restaurant at top where you can buy water, but that's after you climbed all the way up there. Make sure you have lunch at the restaurant, it's well worth it.

A surprising visit. I am usually put off when 'steps' are mentioned but I gave this place a go and was so surprised. The steps up via one route are small and easy to manage with places to rest along the way. The Buddhas start at the bottom of the climb and with so many varied statues it keeps your interest all the way up. Don't stop at the pink pagoda level - go even further and you will be well rewarded. It was damp and cloudy when I did the climb, perfect weather actually. Plenty of photo opportunities and it is hard to decide what not to photograph! The site is rather casual yet beautiful, work is in progress but some areas are freshly painted and well kept. There are wild monkeys around the pink pagoda area and on the route down.

Loved it. I highly recommend visiting this attraction if you're in Hong Kong. If you had to choose between Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery and the Peak Tram, choose the Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery. I mostly enjoyed the view, the tranquility, and the temple. One of the most beautiful Buddhist temples I have ever visited. Sure there is a walk, but honestly, it is not long. I can see how it would be a long walk if you're 70 years old and over.

Very interesting. It is quite a walk... and need to be very careful because most people make the mistake and go to the cemetery with is not far, and doesn't look like a cemetery.Very interesting welcoming by the hundreds of buddhas in their different characters, and once you achieve the summit, the collection of 10,000 buddhas inside the temple are really amazing! something like you would see in Tibet.It is a modern temple but still very interesting...Right at the bottom there is this INCREDIBLE design center/mall with an IKEA.If you enjoy design and decoration... you should give it a look!

Peaceful, worth to visit and it's free. Since we stayed in TST in Kowloon, this place is the quiet side of HK and very peaceful.MTR Ride to EAST line (light blue line) alight at Sha Tin Station , take exit B. walk and look for the IKEA shop then turn to that street and you will see the entrance. From Sha Tin Station it's about 10mins walk from the Monastery entrance it's about 20mins to take the steps upto hill. From entrance you will be fascinated for the different buddhas. Non of them was alike. From here sure you will start to take photos tip you reach the top. Visit to the monastery is FREE. It's worth to visit esp if you are staying in the busy city area of HK, this is a peaceful area to explore.

Hard to find... but worth it. We finally found this Monastery on our third attempt. Google sent us in the wrong direction on day one, and there's a temple in front - so make sure you take the path to the right of the big temple to find it. We also were accosted by a fake monk - there are signs warning you not to donate and stating it is a FREE attraction so do not be fooled. It is a bit of a walk up quite a few stairs but definitely worth it. The Buddhas are all unique - not one is a repeat and it's a calm, peaceful getaway from the busy streets of Central and Kowloon.If you put the Trip Advisor address into google, it will send you to Sha Tin Pass Rd, which is WRONG - make sure you search for Tai Po Road, Sha Tin - this is a completely different area! The East Rail Line on the MTR will take you to Sha Tin and it's easy to find from there.

Worth the trek. A lengthy MTR ride and steep uphill trek are well worth the effort to see the Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery. Beautiful architecture and fascinating to look at. Lots of signs warning visitors not to feed the monkeys, but we didn't see any.

Free and very impressive. I live in HK for almost three years and i visit this place already 4 times. I would reccomend this place to everyone, first of all no fee enterence, very impressive surroundings, little shop with souvenirs and i promise that you will take a hundreds photos! :)
Watch out for fake monks at the bottom. The walk is not too bad and there is lots to see at the top. Watch out for the scammers who put bracelets on you at the bottom and then ask for money.

Fascinating experience.. This monastery was relatively easy to find you just have to make sure you don't mistake the entrance with the ancestral hall. Keep to the right of the ancestral hall and take the path near the building. The steps are steep, but we went in the morning so it wasn't that bad. The statues are very interesting, and the view from the top is quite impressive. Definitely worth the trip.
Very nice place. Go there iin the morning! The 400 steps are no problem, you can have a rest every 50 meters. Donate something to the Monastry, it's worth seeing it!

Steps!. Need to be fairly mobile but there is a wheelchair ramp too as long as the person pushing has a lot of strength or happy to have lots of rests. Buddhas everywhere, At the top you get your reward. It is half way up a mountain! And the gilded corpse is rather strange. Lots of incense and very good for the soul. Take a camera. Toilets. And there is a bus for those who don't want the hike - not sure where from but possibly Shatin. Hard to find entrance located past some green dustbins! Just keep going and you will see the steps . .

A long climb, a good view and spectacular Buddhas. The climb up is really part of the worshipping experience, but very do-able. On the way down (dusk) we were joined by wild monkeys (very cool). The temple complex itsself is very varied is styles of statues, lovely!

We were Monked. Not a good start when we were ripped off for 500HKD and given back 200 Baht (noticed lBaht change ater) as entry fee when some so called monks asked for an entry fee. A little later on signs said free. Our tour guide initially said not all people dressed as monks are monks. She should have said that Monks don't beg. Anyway, was a great monastery to visit. Enjoy all the statues on the way up. They display every human emotion. The temple at the top is amazing as well.

Trickier to get to, but worth it. This place is a little off the beaten path from the standard tourist attractions, but is worth it if you can make it there. The walk up to the temple is a little taxing, so may not be ideal if you cannot handle many steps. We got there a little before it closed, so it was pretty empty, which was even better.

Brilliant experience, genuine off-the-beaten-track feel... Don't miss the Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery if you are in Hong Kong. It's not that far from the city centre and it's well worth a visit. Walking up the steps through a sea of gold buddhas, each one unique in its own way and with different facial expressions, is a really great experience. It's really quiet and peaceful there with very, very few tourists around. Once you get to the top the temple and pagoda are also really worth walking around. We took some fantastic photos and had a lovely peaceful, chilled time up there. It feels like it is right in the mountains. It's definitely one of the more unique experiences we had in Hong Kong. I would go back again if I was visiting the city.From the Sha Tin subway station, walk left when you exit, keep walking down the incline from the station, passing some small shops and houses on your left, and the bus station on your right. When you see the Ikea store in front of you, cross over to it and then turn left. Walk for about a minute until you see the Sha Tin Government Office Building, cross over the street to the building and the turn right and walk straight, you will see a green mesh fence ahead of you and think it is a dead end. But walk straight up to the fence and once you are close you will see the opening and the big sign for the monastery. The walk uphill is not that long and you forget about all the steps because the Buddha statues are so interesting.

Buddha Lovers Dream!!!. For one that loves to see Buddha statues of any sort... this place is a dream... A little difficult to find however and as I asked for directions no one was very good at telling us where to go... As you exit the subway station - head north toward the mountains. Stay on the path to the left of the exit... As you go under the overpass stick close to the government buildings on the left. In the corner of the buildings is a pathway leading to the Buddhas. Once you get to the temple ground themselves there are quite a few steps to the actual temple grounds. As a guy shaped like Buddha you just have to take it slow and plug along up the stairs... there are a lot of Buddhas on the way up to take pictures of... it can be done... Once at the top you are in for a delight... there are way more than 10,000 Buddhas. Check it out!!
Worth seeing. Very cultural but beware a lot of steps up to the top. Don't let it put you off though when you get there it was so authentic!

Worth the climb. For something different, check out the Sha Tin 10,000 Buddhas. The walk up is strenuous but worth the climb. The hall with all the Buddhas is cool.Note, there are 2 access paths. The main one, with the driveway & the carved golden monks is better. The other one is just steps, harder to find, and is quite a steep climb with some narrow steps.

Beautiful and serene. I loved this day trip, one of my favourite parts of Hong Kong. It is about 5 minute walk from Sha Tin station and quite easy to find by following the signs. You probably want to set aside at least 1-2 hours visiting time, not including travel. It is a pretty huge walk up the hill (430 steps) to many different split levels of the monastery past many of the 10,000 Buddha statues that are all very beautiful and different. A lot of the area prohibits photos but as you reach higher up there are some great photo spots. I visited when it was raining on and off and found it to be quiet with very few visitors. It was a beautiful, colourful place with a really relaxing and positive energy. A word of advice, there are 'monks' who linger at the gates and try to sell you things, shoving bracelets onto your wrists. Be assertive and say no... they are con artists!!! Real monks would never try to sell you anything!
Man Fat Sze. A must see - helps non-residents understand more about the Chinese culture. Locals are most happy to explain.

A great spot off the beaten track. The ten thousand buddhas monastery is a great spot to visit, but located way off the beaten track up in the new territories. With free entry, panoramic views from the top, and open expanses of lush greenery, this spot makes for a fantastic day trip.Thete is a bit of a walk to get to the top, but the track is not too steep, and okay for most ages. If rushed, this can be done in a half day, but best to take the whole day and allow some time to explore and soak up the views and the serenity.This was one of the highlights of our recent trip to hong kong, and is highly recommended. If you can visit only one between this and the giant buddha on lantau island, pick here.

Unexpected treat in the New Territories. This is not one of the main tourist attractions you hear of when visiting Hong Kong. Located in Sha Tin in the New Territories, it's way off the main tourist map. However, it's well worth visiting and there really are 10,000 buddhas although a lot of them are very small and inside the main temple building. The climb to the top can be quite arduous especially when it's hot and humid but it's a very picturesque and interesting place so worth the effort.

Gold. It would have helped to have a tour guide explain the meanings of all the Buddhas. There was an employee that gave us a tour of the monastery and even the new building that will open in October....beautiful! She was very knowledgable.

Amazing... A must see!. From the first sight of seeing the statues, it will definitely amaze you. It is an incredible experience and an uplifting one too. The statues were beautiful! However, please be aware you are not permitted to take photos in the temples itself. The walk up to the temple can be very tiring (which I underestimated). But there are seats along the way, so take regular breaks if need be. And DO bring some water, you will definitely need it! Overall, an amazing experience which I highly recommend as a must.

A little gem of the beaten path. A little bit out of the beaten path lies the monastery. The Buddhas are everywhere in this colourful place, with less visitors and more peacefulness than some other places. Highly recommended! I loved it.

No question the best place to see in Hong Kong. If you only have a few hours in Hong Kong, don't listen to the average person who will tell you to go to victoria harbor, go here instead. Go to Sha Tin station and go to exit B. Go left and stay on the sidewalk until you run into the entrance. Note that the gate you will first see is the entrance to a memorial site. On the right hand side is the entrance and trek up to the Ten Thousand Buddahs. It's truly a beautiful experience, visually stimulating, and you can somewhat say you went on a nice hike. Make sure you go all the way to the top. It will be tiring, but definitely worth it. When you're at the top with the triumphant looking army of Buddha's on the hill, go over the rail and get to the middle to get an epic photo op. Some tourists might look at you like you're crazy, but they will envy your picture. Just outside the room of the ten thousand buddahs, go up the spiral staircase to the top and get a great view.

must see. it will take you like 30mins to reach on top, you will have to climb a flight of stairs before you can see the wonderful buddha in that temple. along the way, you can see different face of it.beware of monkeys that will appear suddenly!

Still an unknown to tourists!. This place is jus beautiful. It's not really on the map but easy MTR ride to Sha Tin station. The climb is not fir the faint hearted and is VERY tiring and hard work especially in the sun and the humidity. But wow once up the top it's just so beautiful...buddhas everywhere and every in different. This is a must place to see.

Interesting; Monkeys. You walk up steps past 10,000 buddahs (I didn't count them all) each different. At the top, there are temples interesting to visit. But what really made the trip up the steps rewarding were the monkeys climbing around the various figures. One stold cookies from a visitor and watching them fight over the treats was quite comical.

Well worth the effort. Whilst it is a slog to get up to the top the effort is worthwhile. Definitely take a bottle of water with you as you will probably need to take a few breaks along the way on one of the seated shelters along the path. The slope in sections is almost 1 in 1 so very steep in places. Do not make the mistake I made and take the entrance to the local cemetery as from the bottom it looks very like the entrance to the monastary. Take the path immediately to the right at the end of Pai Tau Street just beyond Grand Central Plaza.

A must see in the New Territories, HK. I was told about the Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery when I first arrived in Hong Kong and I am so glad I made the effort to visit. I was amazed at the size of the Monastery, which begins with a walk up to the main monastery and spreads out to multiple monasteries, a pogoda and even a turtle pool. The views were fantastic and it felt so peaceful, as though it was still not quite yet discovered on the tourist map - If you have the time I would recommend making a visit, it is definitely worth it, and spend some time getting some peace away from the hustle and bustle of the city. Simply brilliant.

A unique monastery. Only is u are in shape, it's a hard walk up the hill for 30 minutes, but it is worth it, the atmosphere is special and most times u feel as you are alone there . The small neighborhood down the hill is also typical and nice to walk around
Pleasant but not extraordinary. It's a nice trip if you have some extra time. Yet, I saw much better Buddhist temples, so don't waste your time if you are busy..

Our favorite spot in HK. This was my wive's and my favorite spot in HK. Quite, very unique and also get some good exercise. To be forewarned, the walk up the stairs is long but the reward at the top is worth it. Whenever we show people the picture from this part of our trip everyone always says, "oh wow!" Bring your camera and watch out for the monkeys!

EXCELLENT DAY FOR A WORK OUT. Had a long walk from Sha Tin station to the Monastery. It was about 100 steps to the top. At least they had breaks along the way with vendors plying you with curios, food and drink. Not so bad though. Eventually you get to the top and get to visit with the 10,000 little Buddhas each with their hands and fingers doing something different, which makes them unique. They said there is an extra one in case one gets broken.
See Lantaue Island. Already reviewed this under Lantau island. Take the metro/subway and the cable car. Well worth an afternoon trip.

Well worth the visit. This is an amazing place where you will see (as the name suggests) ten thousand buddha statues. It is definitely not wheelchair accessible, and I suggest wearing proper shoes for this activity because it involves A LOT of stairs. Once you've done so however, it is worth it due to the amazing view and spectacular temple (and you might even see some monkeys).

Worth a Visit. This is a nice temple and the gold painted figures on the steps going up are fun to see. It's nice because it's a bit out of the way (although very easy to get to on the MTR to Sha Tin), so it tends to be quiet compared to a lot of places in Hong Kong.

A fun experience. You wont get bored all the way leading to the monastery as there are lots of statues escorting you all the way up to the temple. Some of the statues are very kitsch, not very artistic but that makes it more fun. Very easy to reach by metro and if you are lucky you may see monkeys.There is a small canteen in the monastery. I dont recommend it to you, I got sick that night and I suspect it was a couple of snacks I ate there.

Must see!. Amazingly beautiful, serene and inspiring. Well worth the trip. The walk up is 400 steps but the buddhas are so unusual that it passes easily and there are places to stop and rest a bit! Go early to avoid others, we went on a Sunday and by 12 when we were leaving there were a lot of people arriving. Takes a half hour by taxi from HK Island.

Amazing. A bit of a trek uphill, so not for the unsteady / infirm. However, the sheer number of statues is amazing. At the top there is a temple for worshippers. Watch out for the wild monkeys near the temple. Whatever you do, don't feed them

Good exercise - Amazing to see. We took the MTR to Sha Tin and followed the tourist signs after coming out of the station. After a short walk we decided to ask for directions from a friendly local who pointed us to what must have been the back way to the monastery. My friend, who is decidedly the more safety conscious of the two of us was very concerned about the direction we were travelling. Admittedly, we seemed to be going through a neighbourhood which looked to be off the tourist path and every sign post warned us of theft in the area which did nothing to ease the concerns of my travelling companion. After some time we came upon some steep steps up. Towards the top we heard rustling in the trees and after a while we determined that there was a group of monkeys that were playing in the trees which was a lovely thing to watch. Towards the top golden statues started to line the path. The grounds were amazing. There is a vegetarian restaurant available if you happened to be a little peckish after the walk. Views are amazing (I didn't realize how high we had climbed). From what I could discern the place makes it's money from cremations. There are a number of places/buildings in which your ashes could be placed. Beautiful golden cubicles, where the deceased's photos and words of departure are etched. Yes it is a walk and it can be challenging if you do not love getting hot and bothered with walking up and down multitudes of stairs. However, I am happy I took the time to visit this beautiful place. Unique and spiritual. To me it was a glimpse into the path to the afterlife for the local people. I thoroughly recommend the visit.

Strange and Beautiful. Had an easy time using the MRT to get there. Not very touristy. Lovely climb up there with amazing buddha statues. (haha - some of them even looked like people we know). We got to stand in the fantastic greenery on the way up (in the rain - it rains a lot) and just listen to the hypnotic chanting of the monks in a small building. The temple is well worth the climb - there really are ten thousand buddhas and it just skews your sense of perspective. And you can only wonder at the strange large statues in the courtyard. We had lunch there, delicious vegetarian food. Be sure to be respectful and wait until the offering of food to the Buddha has been made first. We wandered out of the main courtyard and saw some interesting deserted dwellings and beautiful life-size, colourful statues of goddesses (sorry, I don't know much about Buddhism). Bonus - you don't have to go back down the way you came up - you get to go down another path lined with even more life-sized statues. Only plan this one activity for the day, as your legs with certainly feel it and its nice to spend lots of time up there just relaxing and enjoying the beauty.
Average. Not very convinced by the historical authenticity of all the statues. Do it if you've got nothing else to do really

Man Fat Sze. Another brilliant free attraction, every buddha is diffrent shape, size & faces, so many to see you dont realise how far or high up you are walking, nice temple and gift shops at the top, walk down on the other path and you will see monkeys in the trees, but beware they can be viciouse

Breath-taking .... hehehe.... ... indeed, to climb 1000 steps or more, passing by numerous golden scholars, up to the interesting main pagoda.My tip, use the escalator to the adjacent smaller temple as a shortcut and just to save energy.

Strangely beautiful oasis of calm in Sha Tin. Easy to find once you're at the Sha Tin MTR stop (or, if you drive, by parking at the Home Square mall below) you should note this has many, many steps so if climbing them all is a problem you might want to rethink a visit. Otherwise, go on a blue sky day and bring a camera. A fascinating and beautifully calm place of respite in a bustling city.

Really nice temple, hard to find!. OK so there happen to be 3 temples and a kind of burial place all in the same area as the 10 thousand temple. We got kicked out of one because it was private, good going tourists! Anyway, if you find the building that is some kind of community service/immigration thing, just walk behind it and you will see the sign for the temple. Real monks don't beg so don't let yourself be harassed by the monks giving you bracelets etc on the way up. Bring water!

Very interesting Place (with monkeys!). The hike was good, a lot of stairs. The temples at the top are great. My favorite part however, were the monkeys! They are everywhere as you hike up the mountain and around the temples. Careful though, they will steal your food!

Ten thousand breaths!. A great place to get to...once you get there! From the base, there's a fairly steep climb...but stopping off to catch your breath every 20 steps or so, would help. Once you make it to the top, the temple is beautiful with several (in excess of 10, 000 I'd say) small buddha stauettes surrounding the three main idols. A beautiful, serene, peacful prayer atmosphere - as in any Buddhist shrine. Gigantig Incence sticks burn outside pervading their fragrance. Also, other stauettes of the buddha in his other forms, one riding a lion, the other, a blue elephant, and a third, with thousands of hands radiating out, blessing all those who seek His grace. Also, a large 'tower of lights' in the courtyard. After the climb down, head for the Ikea showroom (which you pass, on the way up) for some voyeuristic hedonism, also the Ikea Cafe on the 5th floor. Great Swedish meat balls, and some other snacks and bevarages. Like most of Hong Kong, you have to queue up...but very efficiently managed. Seating although about 60-odd, is also in short-supply at times.

Worth seeking out!!. This hidden treasure is amazing a definite must see and not so touristy tooNot signposted, we only found it because of the directions on one of the reviews on here..so take notes!!

A really special place in Hong Kong, and worth the trip!. I've been to Hong Kong 8 times now, and I only discovered this place on the 7th trip after a hotel employee suggested it... I'm so glad he did!The first time we came it was late in the day, near closing time, and we ended up running into some very large red faced monkeys. That was pretty cool. In the last year, since that visit they have added quite a bit to the upper area.I love the hike up with all the different Buddhas along the way, and it's so wonderful to be in such a magical serene place, amidst a lush green mountain with high rise buildings just in the distance. The food is even pretty good too.I will go back every trip now, it's such a special place.

Unique Monastery on a Hill. A friend of mine from Hong Kong told me about it and recommended it.Not very famous but nice! I went there on the 2nd day of Chinese New Year.I saw quite a number of locals, some are aged and I am impressed by their determination of climbing up the hill with hands holding incense and others. The path up was nice, with Buddhas on both side of the path, each Buddha is unique in expression. There are resting areas at intervals for those who need some rest. It seems that those resting are not local, those devotee climbed out non-stop.The setting is nice, not a big place but quite unique. I have not seen a similar one elsewhere!Inside the main hall are thousand of small Buddhas that covered all the walls. Perhaps that is how they got the name. I have been to HK for more than 10X, and 1X to this Monastery. I am glad I made an afford to visit it. It was well worth it. BTW, there is a small little village beside Sa Tin MTR station. Surprised to see some old Chinese homes there !

worth a visit. If you take the MTR it takes around 25 mintues, follow the signs to the Government building but go to the right of the building (do not walk past it) and the path is there, we went past the building and ended up in another temple and had to come back. Really amazing and I am surprised it is not more popular, there were about 8 of us visiting. There are a lot of steps but really worth going to visit.

Worth a visit. HK is not only about shopping, eating and have a nice view of the harbour.This monastery is very interesting and is a good opportunity to leave HK and see the new territories.The number of Buddhas in incredible and after the clim ( a tuff one) there is a nice view on the top

A peaceful climb. This was a lovely surprise finding this. It was an interesting climb to the top with gold Buddhas watching us each one was different. It took a long time to get to top the but it was worth it. The bonus was a great view. The descent was rather quick and there monkeys siting on the fence to say goodbye as we left the path to return to the train station. It was a pleasant way to spend the morning giving an insight to a different culture.

Fascinating. I had low expectations but was fascinated by the huge number of golden Buddhas of all shapes and sizes and each one unique. The long steep path to the temples is lined with happy, frowning, fat, thin, old, young severe, friendly and every other sort of Buddha you can imagine. Definitely worth a visit ahead of the giant Buddha, which is much newer and rather kitch. Just the sheer number of statues is impressive.

Some many statues. Another very steep climb up the steps. All the while there are the Buddahs on each side of the path. Not one of them is the same and then at the summit you enter the temple grounds and on any given day witness the ceremonies and other religious festivals. You do not have to be devout to appreciate all of this. Another must visit location failry close to Sha Tin MTR and bus station.

beware of fake monks. the ten thousand buddahs is nice to visit if you have time but not a must in hong kong. It is pretty much a regular templet at the top of a massive hill and the path to the temple is lined with gold life size models od buddah in various outfits, poses and pulling funny faces. It took a bit of finding as you have to walk down the side of government bulding to find the path. I would also warn entrance is free, but there are some fake monks who stand at the bottom of the path begging, please ignore them.

10,000 Bhuddas and 10,000 steps!. The Monastery was a little bit out in the sticks but was easily reached on the train from Hong Kong island (around 30 minutes or so).It's quite a climb up a hill to get to the actual monastery (with plenty of statues to keep you company along the way) but once up there you get to see the a great view and the monastery itself. There's a small cafe/snack shop up there too, so I took some time out to drink a cup of Jasmine tea and have a quick snack (very cheap prices).Whilst not a "must see", if you feel like you need to get away from the hustle of bustle of the city during your trip then this will be right up your street.
A Part of Real China. We found the place very atmospheric and an ideal contrast to the bustle of Hong Kong. A little steep walk but well worth it.
Worthwhile the journey.. The monastery is on a hill over Sha Tin, and you have to climb thousands of steps to reach the nine storey pagoda and the temple, which is unique.

Amazing Beauty.. This is a must see place if you have time in Sha Tin, a very small walk from the MTR.Be careful, as there are LOTS of stairs and if you are weak in the knees this could pose as a problem. The views from the hill are breathtaking and the elaborate temples for worship are so, so beautiful. You are not allowed to picnic along the way and there is only a small cafe/restaurant to choose from once you are up there.Take note, there are gorgeous wild monkeys that live in dense bushland right beside the temple. If you are lucky enough, you'll be able to see one of these cheekies, sneak into the courtyard to steal a fresh fruit offering!! Enjoy.

Unique experience. We just did this on our own and took the train to Sha Tin and then the short walk to the temple complex. The approach to the temple with the gold painted Buddhas was most unusual and impressive

10000 buddhas. Definitely worth a visit but beware the fake monks who demand money. Just brush them aside and tell them that you have no money. I very pleasant long walk up many stairs to the top but very tranquil and many photo opportunities.
Hidden but worthwhile to go!. Also easy acces by public transport. Steep walk up to the monastery, statues everywhere. A hidden peaceful treasure in a busy city.

Great place to visit to escape the bustle of HK. In order to get there you should take the train to the "Sha Tin" stop and use exit B. Turn left and go down the pedestrian ramp. Once you reach the first street on your left you will see a mall, you should cross the road and turn left. Walk along the street until you reach a huge impressive cemetery. This is not the monastery. The small pathway you are looking for is on your right and is not easy to spot. Go up the pathway and it will lead you straight to the entrance to the hike up to the monastery. Avoid the "monks" at the bottom of the stairway that might approach you. The hike up the staircase to the monastery is part of the attraction. There are many statues with so many different faces. The views from the top are pretty good. The monastery itself is peaceful and very interesting. Make sure you bring a camera and walking shoes.
Excelent place to visit. Surrounded with mistery and beauty, this is a place i really loved, and i recomend a visit also, from top you have a wonderfull view, nice for making some shots

Scam warning. This is a beautiful area to visit - the vibe is so peaceful and the views amazing. Unfortunately I didn't read the postings about the scamming 'fake monks' at the entrance to the stairway. Like previous reviewers these guys approached me, performed some elaborate ritual and then asked for a donation. They saw the contents of my wallet (luckily small) and kept demanding more, more, more. I realised by this stage it was a scam but being a girl by myself with two of these guys in front and one behind me I wasn't about to pull them up on it. In short, definitely visit this place, and don't let this scare you off at all, but learn from others' experiences and don't let these fake monks ruin what should be a beautiful peaceful experience. I've heard if you sternly say you know they are not monks, you do not need to give a donation and to leave you alone you will not have any issues.
Hope you're fit. I didn't count how many steps or how often I stopped but it was worth the effort. If you find yourself in Sha tin pay a visit.

Truly Spiritual Place. The temple is not only interesting from the cultural and architectural standpoint, but indeed is a spiritual place with very positive energy. I think the place is a must visit if you want to deeper explore the local culture and I will definitely go back there if I ever again in Hong Kong to feel these divine vibes.

Amazing temple and great views. Are there really ten thousand buddhas? I do not know, but I can tell you all are different. In order to get here take the metro to Sha Tin, north exit, follow the signs, turn left and hold on... Keep right on the signs. If you are tempted to enter the white temple door you see and the escalators, you are not in this temple but in Po Fook Memorial Hall. It is also interesting to see. To go to the buddhas, keep right and then start climbing up over four hundred steps, each one guarded by golden buddhas at each side. The temple itself is on the top with a large patio with more buddhas. It is really worth going up. Do not forget to go to the other side (from stairs to the right; the temple is on the left) to see the turtles, more golden buddhas and a beautiful white statue. And then turn back to see the panorama.
Impressive. Nice walk to access to the temple. The quantity of Buddhas is very impressive, and the temple looks really well maintained.

Buddhas in HK. Located at a walking distance from the MTR station though finding the entry was quite complicated. The entry was in a narrow place next to the big chinese graveyard. The site is very nice. Fact to know : there are more than 13000 buddhas.
Interesting Cultural Experience. Travelled to the monastery with my friend, who is from HK. Enjoyed the history of the buddhas, the wildlife and indeed the chance to embrace the culture.

Easy to find (if you go well-prepared)!. With research and good advice from other reviewers, had no problems maneuvering our way. Viewing videos and google maps, I found the route running alongside the Po Fook Hill Ancestral Hall to be more of an opened and pleasing trek (rather than walking in between some tall, rusty-old fences - if you had made a right along Shatin Gov't Offices).Here's what we did to get there:1) From Exit B, make a left as you leave the station and keep walking down to the end (note: there is big bus terminus outside, it should remain on your right as you walk away from it).2) At the end, there is a pedestrian ramp, walk all the way down the ramp to street level (note: the old Pai Tau Village can be seen on your left as you walk down the ramp).3) At the end of the ramp, you should see a sign for Shatin Gov't Office. Continue walking the path straight to the end of the street (note: you should see green minibuses down on your right).4) At the end of the street, cross the street so you are on the side of the mall / IKEA (note: be careful crossing the street, there was no traffic light)!5) After crossing the street at the corner, make a left and continue walking along Pai Tau Street. The first street you will see on your right is Sheung Wo Che Road (which runs along Shatin Gov't Office). You will see signs for the monastery. Don't turn in here, keep walking straight..6) Turn right on the NEXT street (which is pretty much the end of the block, where you should see a white-looking arch building - this is the Po Fook Hill Ancestral Hall).7) There is a yellow sign on the ground pointing to the monastery, walk up along the side ramp and you'll be at the entryway in about a minute or so / no time flat! Tips / Notes:1) You will immediately see monks when you reach the entryway. Brush them off / Ignore them / Don't look at them. If you did your research, you will know these are not real monks!!!2) I did not take the advice of previous reviewer and did not bring bug spray. I was the only one who ended up getting bit 4 times on my arm (luckily, it was not itchy, just a little). I should have bought bug spray, there are still some bugs in December...! So take heed!3) Do bring water, good advice mentioned by previous posters. It helped!4) Don't worry, there are benches for sitting at each sections of the path. Rightly situated, not too far apart. No problems with finding a seat as there were not many people there at the time (about 12:30pm).5) Be careful with the handrails, there are some ants that do crawl along the railing!6) You can walk up the 9-story pagoda (at the lower level terrace). If your legs can handle more stairs, give it a walk!It was well-worth a visit, a slight off-the-beaten path excursion!

A bit out of town. A bit out of town on the Metro & a steep climb up a hillside but the ascent is rewarded with the sight of hundred's of life size gilt Buddha statues along the way and a lovely pagoda & pavilion at the top.

Beware of fake monks. Right around the corner of Shatin district office building, where stairs to monastery start, i was met by 3 tough guys in buddhist clothings, who behaved very energetic if not aggressively. They blocked my way and started to "pray" by putting the beads to my forehead and mumbling something mantra-like. One of them put a wooden beads bracelet on my wrist. At first i simple-mindedly thought that they are just collecting the donations and opened my wallet, and took out HKD 20 note, this was my serious mistake as the monk saw more money inside and started to ask for HKD 100! I immediately put off the bracelet and told him that he can keep HK20 i already passed him, but i don't need the souvenirs. He got back but very reluctantly with disappointed look on his face and it felt he would rather rob me if he could. I proceeded upstairs to monastery thinking of this strange behaviour not in accordance with spiritual rank, and immediately saw a sign on the fence saying that you should beware of fake monks, that monks do not just hang round asking for money etc. On my way back i saw them again, they stood a bit aside from trail entrance, tall, muscled, and all three of them were unfriendly staring at me. They were accompanied by another "monk-clothed" accomplice atop a gangster-style motorbike. I don't know why authorities tolerate conmen acting right in front of district office, probably because proper bribe "rent" was paid, but please do not repeat my mistake, do no take out the wallet, if the "monks" insistently block your way, call the police or pretend you want to. Do not let them spoil your mood and your holiday trip.

A must-visit attraction at Hongkong. Well, it’s a sheer loss if you miss out on the Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery (Man Fat Sze) on your Hong Kong trip. In fact I had dedicated almost an entire day at this one spot on my Hongkong vacation last year. And it was well worth it. I found the entire area, which of course spans over more than 8 hectares, fascinatingly well maintained and clean. The walk up to the main monastery is a revelation in itself. Breath-taking I would say. The astounding number of Golden Buddha figures, all in different postures would sure mesmerize you. Surprisingly, there’s no in-house monk at the spot. The facility is managed and maintained by the lay-person. My experience overall was quite memorable and highly recommended to tourists visiting Hongkong.

Do visit this site before it fills with tourists. There no signs at present from the MTR station so follow the instructions that others have given passed the government village up the footpath and climb the steps. I did mention steps didn't I? - so take some waterWhen you get to the vegetarian restaurant and the pagoda (which has still more stairs inside one may climb up) you are not at the top. Keep going up. There are more shrines a reclining Buddha carved into the hill and turtle pond (which I missed on the way up thinking the turtles were stones.Take your time.Do not go back the way you came up. There is another exit from the temple square - SW of the Pagoda through as gate -down different steps with stil more Buddhas and warriors. Take this exit and you come out at the back of the government village on sign posted pathways which lead one to within a short distance of the MTR Station

age is no binding its your wish and will power. In SHA TIN HONG KONG ,located in pai tau village built by yuet kai, nearly 13000 statues of Buddha.It nearly took 8 yrs to complete and another 10 yrs to finish the 12800 Buddha statue the area occupied nearly 8 hectares.ADD:- Tai po road sha tinTake MTR to sha tin stop on the east rail line then go towards IKEA when u see it turn left upPAI TAU street .At the end of the road, there is an imposing government building (sha tin government offices) at which u turn right .At the back of this building is the sketchy looking entrance surrounded by chain link fencing with a sign.Almost 430 steps to climb to the of mountain, U will not get bored to climb to the top as the whole road as golden coloured statues with different expressions, 9 floors of pagoda gives a very beautiful view if it is open ,the temple is open from 9AM to 5PM.

Definitely worth a visit (hike). This tourist site, situated in Sha Tin 沙田, is fast rising as a must-visit for HK trip. It is quite easy to reach; just alight at Sha Tin KCR station exit B and turn left towards the pedestrian slope where you will see some traditional chinese houses on the left. Continue ahead passed a playing court and Grand Central Shopping Centre is just across the road. The road is Pai Tau St 排頭街. Just behind the shopping centre will be Sheung Wo Che St, (上禾輋), where down the street to the end (including some mesh fence walkway) you will find the sign for the 10,000 Buddha Monastery (萬佛寺). The walk up is lined with many gold coloured life-sized Buddha's on both sides and one can just take you time and enjoy the hike up. The climb is relatively easy with small steps and benches at intervals for resting. We did not count the number of buddhas but they definitely all appeared uniquely posed.It might take more than 20 mins to reach the top, over the 500-metre path, where one will see a breathtaking view of the surrounding Sha Tin..... scenic with lots of trees and mountains/hills surrounding the Monastery. There is also a small vegetarian restaurant and a towering 9-story pagoda here (appearing on the HK$100 note). The ambiance is one of tranquility and peacefulness.The temple dates from the 1950s and was founded by Rev Yuet Kai, a devout Buddhist layman who dedicated the last years of his life to constructing the elaborate temple. His preserved body is still presented in the main hall of the monastery in a glass case as the main attraction of the temple.We like the place as it is much less touristy than many other tourists’ attractions. Admission is free but donations are welcome. A little tip; preferably to go during the cooler months so that your hike up will be more comforting. And do be equipped with a comfortable and good pair of walking shoes. :>

Unbelievable & Unique. All the ten thousand Buddhas have been created with lot of effort and have been arranged very nicely on both sides of the steps as you climb. It is a very peaceful and holy atmosphere to see all the disciples of lord Buddha. The steps are nicely made but difficult for the elderly persons to reach all the way. In all, it is a nice landmark to visit. It is little difficult to find from the MRT station Sha Tin but keep walking on the left from the station exit & the entrance to the monestry is inside little ally.

Worth the work - georgeous place. One of the more off the beaten path things I got to do and so glad I did. I travel for work, so I had to really find some time to get to this destination because all together it will probably take about 2 hours. Getting there after you leave the train station is a bit tricky, but I found some directions online and followed them closely and was able to find it in about 10 minutes. I was there in 90F weather, so the walk up the steps was intense but awesome, the many Buddhas and other little things you see along the way are amazing and then the peak? All the work feels like it paid off greatly - great views, amazing temple. ONLY do it if you can walk a good amount and climb many steps though, not good for elderly or disabled. I guess it's becoming a little more known, hopefully that doesn't ruin it. When I was there about 2 years ago I saw only one other white person, unlike other tourist destinations that were full of foreigners - not a bad thing, but hopefully it retains some it's mystique.

Very impressive!. I was very impressed with this place. Located outside the heart of hong kong, this place can easily be reached by mtr to shatin station. There are some good directions from some other posts on how to reach it. I enjoyed that it was not touristy at all, and was a nice moderate hike up to the top. Once to the monastery it was truly impressive how there are over ten thousand miniature buddhas, each with its own unique pose. A truly beautiful place I would highly suggest visiting. The vegetarian food there was excellent, a million times better than the food served at the big buddha.

Hong Kong Highlight. Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery was the highlight of the 10 days my husband and I spent in Hong Kong. We went on a Saturday morning and there weren’t any crowds.I loved the statues and the colorful, ornately painted buildings. Try to go on a clear day. The golden Buddha statues seemed to come alive in the sunlight. It was a photographer’s paradise. If I ever return to Hong Kong, Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery would be the first place I’d revisit.We didn’t see any monkeys! Maybe they sleep late on Saturdays?Two tips: 1) Water. 2) Insect repellant. Bring a bottle of water to drink on the walk up to the Monastery. And if you are prone to insect bites, bring insect repellant. I brought repellant for this trip, but forgot it at my hotel. I got 6 or 7 bites, mostly on my legs. It was a sunny, warm day in November and I was wearing shorts.

Over 12000 Buddhas and a Few Monkeys. We took the MTR from Mong Kok to the Sha Tin station. From the train station head toward Pai Tau street and turn left. There are two entrances/exits. We entered at the entrance to the right which was about a 5-10 minute walk and exited at the entrance/exit at the lower level exhibits. Entrance is free, however we did encounter monks selling little trinkets. Almost seemed a little iffy. We did not purchase any of the trinkets but did put some money in the bowl, it was the least we could do. As previous reviewers stated...be prepared to walk up a lot of steps. The many Buddha statues will help deflect the imagery of remaining steps to the top. Each Buddha is unique and shares its own story by way of expression, color and stance. Not a lot of monkeying around by visitors...just the real ones we encountered upon existing. All in all seeing the many Buddhas and the few monkeys created a fun visit!

A must when in Hong Kong- and how to find it.. A real gem, lots of steps to get to it but worth the effort, so unusual. To find it take the MTR Blue Line(Lok Ma Chau /Lo Wu) to Sha Tin. Take exit A1 or B and go left passing the bus station on your right. Continue right along ramp and along street with road on your right and market/shops on your left. At about 100 mtrs turn left into Pin Tau Street, then after 50 mtrs turn right into Sheung Wo Che Road. Head for the far left corner, there you will see signs for the Monastery and you can see the first Buddhas to the left. See photos.
Nice steep walk. It is actually quiet easy even though the signage from the MTR station could be better. Be prepared for a lot of steps or a steep walk, but it is a nice monastery.

Sha Tin 10,000 Buddhas Monastery. I had decided to visit 10,000 Buddhas Monastery early Sunday morning before heading to Chi Lin Nunnery and Sai Kung Town. 3 places of attraction on Sunday. Shatin East MTR Station Exit B, follow sign boards to walk up village stairway to 10,000 Buddhas Monastery and walk down main stairway to Home Square Building (IKEA) Pai Tau Street. After much walking, I headed to IKEA Bistro and treated myself HK$10 hot dog and Pepsi with free refill to fill my tummy and quench my thirst.

Worth a visit. Hong Kong isn't the best place for culture, but this monastery offers an insight into Buddhist life on the Kowloon side. The monastery itself is relatively small, but it is the walk up to the monastery that is memorable - walking up a winding path that is lined with different buddha statues on either side was an interesting sight. Overall though, don't expect to be amazed - but something worth doing if you have some time

Beware fake monks. There are a lot of steps but if you can manage that, it is a worthwhile experience. Fascinating variety of Buddhas. At the base of the steps, my son and I were greeted by two smiling and genial "Buddhist monks" who placed bracelets on our arms and went through an elaborate "blessing" ceremony of kissing their fingers and beads and then touching our foreheads and then being rather pushy about amount of an expected donation. Having a good opinion of Buddhists, both of us made generous "donations". Partway up the stairs we came upon a sign telling us that "real Buddhist monks would never beg and if someone appears to do so, call the police". So beware of scammers.

Go see it. Beware lots of steps / waking. We took the MRT over (easy) and went early - avoided all the lines. We thought it was beautiful. When you get to the top you will be tired, but happy you did it. There is a lot to see. I called it 10,000 steps lol. If you are not into exercise of have limitations you should skip.

Buddas Galore. The visit to Shatin is well worth the exercise even if you have to ride 3 different trains from Tsim Sha Tsui. As everyone who travels to Hong Kong knows, the MTR and transport system is first rate. Various route instructions tend to be a little confusing but generally if you find one that takes you from Shatin Station to the Government Building in Pai Tau Street you will be OK. but you need to turn right into the street infront of the Gov building and go to the end where you connect to the steep walk to the Monastery. The place has been around for some 60 years and the walk to the top is marked by many and varied Buddah statues some to shock and some to laugh at but all somewhat interesting. The climb is worthwhile for the views over Shatin, New Territories and adjacent hills. The main temple house some 13,000 buddah statues and must be considered as unbelieveable. There are other temples, pagodas and a verandah. The climb to the top is rewarded by a large ivory coloured Buddah and spectacular views. Earlier I mentioned the right hand turn in the directions - if one takes Pai Tau Street to the end and turns right after the Government Building, you are at Po Fook Hill Columbarium which is an awesome landmark which has potential for 100,000 niches. Cemeteries may not be your taste but this visit was a great find and again the views from the ascending stairs is spectacular. Interestingly enough the multi-level home products store houses a typical Ikea store complete with the expected cafeteria. I highly recomend further research of Shatin as there is much more to see and do.

not in many guides. visited ten thousand buddhas monestery and enjoyed it thoroughly, even if it was a hike up the stairs. It is free and only found it on a recommendation from a friend. Free to get in, at the top it is a nice view. Very peaceful and serene place.

Tranquil place amongst the hustle and bustle of Sha Tin. The walk is difficult to find at first, from MTR take exit B (for Buddha) and walk down past buses and Mimi buses, go into little village and find path to the left of the flower shops. The beginning of the walk is well signed. The stairs are many, but stop and check out the view, it is beautiful and green, only minutes walk from the MTR.I enjoyed the temple area and relaxed around the temple. I had a beautiful clear blue sky day, a precious time in Hong Kong. I will return and take friends next visit.

Crazy odd but awesome.. Thousands and thousands of Buddhas in a variety of sizes that form the ten thousand Buddha monastery. You ascend from Sha Tin climbing stairs that are flanked on either side by life size golden effigies that are part of the many beautiful, grotesque and interesting Buddhas to be seen.There is a cafe that is pretty awesome serving an assortment of vegetarian dishes and while we were there we encountered monkeys to add to the overall sense of something completely unique.It was good times.

Nice. You would salute the hardwork of the artists who would have toiled hard to carve such b'ful statues all the way long. There is a pond at the top with turtles and fishes, next to the Kuan Yin Pusa statue. Be ready to climb the never-ending stairs :)

A serene recluse. The ten thousand Buddha monastery is a lovely serene hidden recluse in the midst of the busy Hong Kong. One can reach this place by metro by exiting the "B" exit from the Sha Tin station. Just ask around and people will guide you to the monastery entrance. It's quite difficult to find on its own. There are about 500+ steps to climb, not a very difficult climb in all. And the statues start from the bottom of the climb all the way to the top. The entrance is free. And there is a lovely canteen at the top where you can snack after the visit.

Hidden Gem. Stopped on the way to Schenzen. Not very well signposted (luckily another Tripadvisor member gave detailed instructions on how to get there). Only a five minute walk from the station. Worth a visit. Quite a hike up the hill (all concrete steps).

Hidden gem. Great exercise. Best to bring a bottle of water. Parts of path can be steep. Wear comfortable shoes. Amazing monastery on the top of the hill. I find it peaceful and quiet comparing to it other temples and monastery. Amazing view of Sha Tin.

Great place for locals and tourists. The entrance place is a bit hard to find, you will come down a road with a dead end. Walk around the large building on your right. You will ascend a longer stairway, lined with Buddha statues. The ascent is well worth it. The statues are all unique and fun to look at. On the top, not only an amazing view but also a quite diverse temple complex awaits you.There are numerous photo opportunities in and around the monastery. Due to the stairs that have to be climbed, there are no tourist bus services filling the area. We went on a beautiful fall Saturday afternoon, and there were hardly any people.On top of that, the food at the small restaurant is excellent. It's all vegetarian, trying to simulate popular Chinese dishes, doing a great job at it. And it's cheap, too!

A bit of a uphill walk, but worth it.... Firstly, if you want to visit Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery (Man Fat Sze), make sure you are very familiar with the way to get there. From Sha Tin MTR station on the red line, it's not so clear where to go, particularly when its busy. I suggest you look on youtube for instructions - I'm unable to put a link in this review, sorry - you know you doing ok when you see the Ikea Building/Mall on the corner, turn left, then first right and head to the end of the street and up the hill. While some of the Buddhas might be a bit worse for wear, and do provide interesting studies and the number and variations are impressive. Bring water, as always. After a few stops and maybe half an hour you'll reach the monastery. Be considerate and mindful, its a monastery after all. You are not allowed to take photographs inside, but there's plenty of opportunities to take pictures outside. Make a donation or two. Warning, the toilets at the monastery are not the European type, just a hole in the floor. There is a small area for souvenirs purchasing inside. There's a nice view looking down to the city. A little fitness is helpful, and the walk climbs up most of the way. We found it a very tranquil and calming contrast to the hustle and bustle of the city. Younger children may find it not to their tastes.

hidden delight. well of the beaten track in hong kong is the delightful temple, a hard walk so take plenty of water on the walk up you see many different buddahs and as jennyhola says don't get confused with the mausoleum which I thought this is an easy climb lift and moving staircase nice old man told me it was the wrong place , he also said their are a lot of fake monks outside begging anyway the walk up to top to see the main temple and a café which wasn't open was well worth the effort and views of surrounding area a nice as well

They say 10,000 Actually 12,800. This little advertised site is one you must not miss its situated in Sha Tin but with this one a very good pair of walking shoes is a must, the walk up is lined with many gold coloured Buddha's just take you time and enjoy the site

Amazing monastery. We went to this amazing monastery when we were i Hong Kong and were stunned by the different buddhas that were on display and it was just a great experience. There are quite a few steps that you have to climb, which may be a problem for some. But I must tell you that it is worth it. What was funny was that there were many people dressed up as monks just to ask for money which was sad. There were signs for people to not give money to anyone. Overall this was surely one of my favorite places in Hong Kong. Highly recommended.

Amazing site. Signage to get here is not the best but worth it once you find it. The entrance to this site is actually next door to a chinese mausoleam which was also interesting to tour. All of the buddhas are unique and i believe thr artist had a sense of humour. Lots of great colorful chinese architecture. Grab a grapefruit soda from the vegetarian cafeteria at the top. Very refreshing.

Put this on your to do list!. This is one of my favourite places to visit in HK and prefer this than big buddha statue on lantau and the nunnery and park in diamond hill. So if your short on time I would definitely recommend ten thousand Buddhas! It is free! Peaceful. Lots to stroll around and felt less touristy than the previous attractions mentioned. There are lots of stairs to climb! So dress comfortably- it gets hot! Plenty of shade to take a rest and there is a vegetarian reasturant up there which we didn't try. We spent a few hours here and felt the journey to sha tin from mong kok was definitely worth it. I would highly recommend this place and I would visit here again. We didn't see any monkeys, maybe too hot ? We also didn't come across the fake monks that beg at the entrance, maybe something to be aware of as mentioned in other posts. Enjoy!

Worth the climb.. Not that hard to find from Sha Tin MTR - and well worth the train trip, the walk and the climb. Don't be taken in by fake monks as you enter - I know they're just trying to make a buck, but it was the only time in HK we felt we were being got at, if you see what I mean. I'd recommend picking a cool day and going early, as the steps on a hot humid day would be a real challenge to even the fittest. The Ten Thousand Buddhas Temple is wonderful, even if you feel you've been out Buddha'd. I reckon with this and the Big Buddha, you've done your bit!

Great place to visit with a good view. We went to the 10,000 Buddha monastery which actually has 12,800 Buddhas. We got the MTR to Sha Tin from Nathan Rd, Kowloon costing $9 each for 2 people and the ride was about 20mins. When you get off the train at Sha Tin exit at edit B and turn left towards the pedestrian slop and go down passing some traditional Chinese houses on the left. Go to the end of the road and you will see the bus station on the right, a playing court on the left and a Home Store Shopping Centre across the road in front of you. The road is Pai Tau St, cross over to the shopping centre and turn left making sure it's on your right hand side. The very next street you come to is Sheung Wo Che St, cross over and in front of you is a tall new looking government building, turn right and go down the street to the end (isn't far). On the right across the road is the entrance to the car park for the shopping centre. There is some mesh fence at the end with the sign for the 10,000 Buddha Monastery, go through and turn left and follow to the top. Note, there aren't any signs for the Monastery when leaving the train/bus station so the above directions will get you there. In all the walk to the start is about 5/10 mins. There are a few hundred steps and all the way up on both sides are full size gold Buddha statues all of which are unique. The walk can be tiring especially on a hot day but periodically there are benches to stop and relax if needed. There are monkeys in the trees and we saw a lot but they were bothered about our presence. There are both steps and a slope for prams/buggies/wheel chairs. At the top is the Monastery which is beautiful, there are restrooms but be warned no paper so bring your own if you think you might need to go and a restaurant. The view from the top is impressive and the Monastery itself is amazing with all the Buddhas inside. It won't take you all day but it's a nice couple of hours and well worth a visit.

A Holy Place with an Amazing View of Sha Tin. After the close down of Hongkong Airport last September 23 and 24 due to the storm and the cancellation of our trip to Jiuzhaigou, China, I decided to be a tourist in Sha Tin, New Territory in Hongkong. With three friends, we went to the Sha Tin MTR Station and started the uphill climb to the 10,000 Buddhas Monastery located more than 400 steps to the top of the hill. Beware at the entrance, there were 2 fake monks who stopped us and made some blessings on our forehead. Then, they slipped one bracelet made of plastic jade or red and brown beads on our wrists. Afterwards, the fake monks asked for HK$100.00. We yanked out the bracelets and told them we didn't have a lot of money. When we got to the entrance of the monastery we read the sign. "BEWARE OF FAKE MONKS! THIS IS NOT A PLACE FOR BEGGARS". We then started our ascent and after the zigzagged stairs, we came to a landing and rested. We saw four monkeys, along the path and they seemed to be quite at home despite the tourists going up and down. The climb is easy with the small steps and the path is lined with many life size buddhas. If one looks intently, they look like common Chinese citizens in different positions. Once we reached the top though all the statues look like Buddha...Quan Ying and more buddhas in different poses. The ambiance of the entire place is so holy, tranquil and peaceful for the soul. On the rails of the grounds, one will see a breathtaking view of Sha Tin..... so scenic with lots of trees, mountains and hills surrounding the Monastery. Tired from the climb we had a vegetarian lunch in the small restaurant. Another amazing feature of the monastery aside from the 10,000 buddhas are the hundreds of bonsai trees lining the Buddha statues. From their appearance the bonsai trees count tens to probably hundred years. No wonder this monastery is an attraction for the travelers from outside and within Hongkong.

Worth the hundred steps. This is our 1st trip, we didn't expect the hundred steps. We have 2 young children (2 & 4) and they managed to walk up the hundred steps up to the temple. It's very peaceful and stately.

Must Visit. Be prepared to walk a lot, the good thing is that the place is well shaded and also have benches in midways to relax. The only thing which we didn't like was the resaturant, the so called restaurant was very small and the people at the restaurant were not very welcoming. Most of the people who had food, left most of the food in the plates and we guessed people didn't like the food much therefore we chose to stay away from food and just took cold drinks from there.

Peacefull, away from the busy city. Well worth the time. Follow the directions posted on another post and you'll have no trouble finding it. It's quiet, not a lot of people know about this place, don't know why. There's a nice view from the top. The stairs are pretty easy to climb, they are not steep and there are benches along the way up to stop and rest. We took the metro there. The metro in Hong Kong is easy to use and very clean.

Just amazing -Don't miss this !. Although its a little tricky to find the path, this is one of the best things to see in Hong Kong. Follow the directions given in another review & you'll find your way. Be prepared for a long climb & pick a cool day but it's well worth the effort. Take your time on the climb-there's plenty of seating along the path for spelling yourself. The monastry is absolutely magnificent with tier upon tier of miniature Buddhas inside & so many more statues & temples in pristine condition outside. Don't miss the white buddha by the waterfall on the upper level, its worth the extra climb & the view of Hong Kong is spectacular!There is a very clean toilet there now & the tea room was a delight .A great half day !

Watch out for the monks.... Pros: nice views Cons: First, getting there can be a bit confusing. It is right next to the "Po Fook Ancestral Worship Hall", which has an impressive and decorative entrance gate, several temples and lots of steps built into the side of the hill. After climbing lots of steps and not seeing what we were expecting, we figured out we were at the wrong place. The sign for the 10,000 Buddhas Monastery was laying on the ground pointing towards what looks like a back alley where people walk their dogs (and let them take care of business). Our first encounter was 3 Buddhist monks who were blocking the entrance, approached us and stuck cheap little "bracelets" on our wrists while shaking our hands. They then proceeded to perform some sort of ritual, touching our foreheads with their beads and mumbling something. We're more than a little "weirded out" by this since we aren't Buddhist and aren't interested in whatever it is they're doing. THEN, they pointed to a $100 bill (about $13 USD) letting us know they wanted us to pay for the strings they put around our wrists. Not wanting to create a scene, I went ahead and gave them the $100 and went to move on. Then I found out they wanted us to pay $100 PER PERSON (and there were 5 of us). When I refused, they became very agitated, but not as agitated as they were when I tried to remove the bracelet and give it back to them. I ended up giving them $200 ($26 USD)in total to get out of there, but what a shakedown!!! I don't hang around Buddhist monasteries much, so maybe I should have known better, but we didn't ask for anything from them and for "peaceful" monks, they were certainly aggressive. So if you go and see several monks hanging around the entrance, watch out and avoid them. Don't let them shake your hand and don't let them put any of their garbage on your wrist unless you have some cash to burn...

Not the best.. Unfortunatly we were quite dissappinted with this attraction. Weve been to a few similar places around the world an this seemed to be a very set up tourist spot. The views at the top were good and we got some exercise but wasnt really impressed. Didnt see any monks or people there for religious reasons. Positive- its free. But i would recommend going to the chi lin nunnery instead if your short on time its a beautiful spot.

Worth the tiring, long climb!!!. It was a very hot day, sticky, so the climb was exhausting! But the journey already starts with your first step. The golden statues appear right away and continue, continue, and never stop! It is unbelievable! And at the top the views are magnificent. Not to speak from the several smaller and big temples. We really loved this site. DO bring enough water and mYbe a small bite. Although there is a vegetarian, simple restaurant along the way.

Worth the tiring, long climb!!!. It was a very hot day, sticky, so the climb was exhausting! But the journey already starts with your first step. The golden statues appear right away and continue, continue, and never stop! It is unbelievable! And at the top the views are magnificent. Not to speak from the several smaller and big temples. We really loved this site. DO bring enough water and mYbe a small bite. Although there is a vegetarian, simple restaurant along the way.

What a beautiful place. We went to the Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery and it was honestly the best place I have been to in Hong Kong. It was so cool to see the different sized buddhas, also the experience at the monastery was so calming and amazing. You cannot miss this in Hong Kong. There are steep steps to reach the monastery but let me tell it is all worth it in the end. our visit to this monastery was the highlight of our entire trip.we would definitely recommend it to everyone coming to Hong Kong. This site is a must visit.

absolutely amazing. We decided to make the effort to visit this temple even though Typhoon 3 was passing through as we only have two more days in Hong Kong ,we are in our 60,s and the70,s so took it slowly and it was a wonderful experience the rain did come down very heavily but only for a few minutes. There were lots of little monkeys running all over one of the statues ,on the right of the red pagodas there was another climb that leads to a waterfall with a magnificent white statue and you have a fantastic view of the city .take your own water ,cafe at top looks very dodgy

Don't go alone!. I went there alone and trust me, you wouldn't want to go by yourself! Its just that climbing the stairs alone in a gloomy afternoon with the statues on both sides of the stairway just an arm length away was not such of a good idea. It becomes a little eerie. You get the feeling like dozens of eyes are looking at you and you only. But, otherwise, it's a very nice place. Not packed with tourists like other places in HK are. You could relax a bit from the tense city by looking over Shatin from a high view. When you reach the end of the stairway, you would see the Man Fat Temple. Walk around the place to see more of the bigger statues. Then continue to climb up. There are a lot more to see. At the highest point, there's a big Guan Yin statue and I think its the best statue in there.

Buddhas everywhere and everysize, go on a cool day. Luckily I went when there was clouds and the heat was not high.. Long walk up to the top (2 different paths, so go up 1 and down the other).Some "monks" did ask for donation, but that was before the , "real monks do not beg" signs. heh.The statues were all interesting, with most looking very different (on the path up).Once at the top, wondering around looking at all the different size Buddhas was interesting.I also ate at the veggie restaurant on top, which was basic and good. I do recommend if you like vegetarian foods.(A few days earlier I had viewed a Tao temple in Cebu, so the differences and similarities between the 2 made things interesting).Next to the stairs is a path up, so a wheel chair, stroller could make it up. But it would be rough.I did not find any elevator, nor did I check for a restroom.

much nicer than the big buddha. if you have to deserve the view of this nice monument, as its not easy to find, and if you take (like us) the way over the steps, you really feel like you have done something once you reached the top. but its worth it!

Feeling restless, uneasy? Come here. Located on top of a hill. Nice view.Whenever you find yourself feeling restless and uneasy, coming here would help to relax your mind.With the nice view, it will enhance the relaxing feeling
Almost alive. Eventhough its so hard ro reach the top it was perfect. All the status look like they are gonna move. Only bad thing is it's closed after 5 pm

tranquil and beautiful... Be sure to check your map and ask for directions in going there. Only a short walk from the MTR station, but lets you get up a flight of winding stairs. Along the way you can see many of the golden Buddhas which are very beautifully made. And at the top, grab a quick drink or snack from the snack house before proceeding.. All in all, the place is quiet and serene, best to enjoy with your family. One more thing, there are a couple of entrances, so don't get lost..

One of the most amazing places I have ever been. Do not miss this place!You can get out to the temple by train and then a very short walk from the station to the temple. Amazingly it is not a massive tourist attraction and so is not crowded and commercial like the Giant Buddha.This place is beautiful and tranquil. There is a small café where we had tea and cake - great service with a massive smile! I cannt recommend this place enough.

Nothing to add, just how to get there.... Lovely, that this amazing place is still off the beaten track and quite difficult to find. There are two ways up to the monastry. Both are equally steep, but one is along back alley ways, the other you are helped up by hundreds of life sized buddahs. Some monks may linger there and want some money. They are not monks ! Leave Shatin Station towards Pai Tau village, turn left when you leave station towards Grand Central Plaza, pass the bus station on your right. Turn left into Pai Tau St. Follow that street. Don't turn into Sheing Wo Che Rd. and do not turn left, even when you see a sign. That is the back street. Turn right the following road and go along a narrow alleyway leaving Shatin Gov. Offices to your left. And then it all starts...

Speechless. Before going here I studied the direction shared by others very carefully. Plus you can take advantage of google map image as well. It is really helpful when you can imagine how to get here from the train station. We got to the monastery in no time without getting lost. We saw no monks on the way up but encountered some of them when we were leaving. We also saw 1 who did not change in to monk clothes nearby lol. There is a vegetarian centre in front of the monastery so you can go trekking around meal time and eat there. And one more thing, since the monastery is located on a hill with many trees, make sure to bring insect repellent or wearing long pants (if you feel comfortable).

A Highlight of our stay in Hong Kong.. I had printed off the directions to get to the Monastery from a previous review, which was helpful.
