The entrance was maybe a 10 minute walk from the train station.Of course we encountered the begging"Monks", which we had read about and ignored.It is a decent climb to the top but the Statues are all the way up the steps, so there is plenty to look at on the way and the climb really was not difficult.The Golden Statues are beautiful.Great photo opportunities, and we saw few tourists which was a bonus. Take some insect repellant! we were not prepared for the mosquitos.The shopping mall attached to the train station is a bonus and a great place to stop for a snack and a spot of shopping afterwards.

Beautiful, serene site but please be respectful. Didn't see any fake monks, and there are plenty of signs stating that the monastery is free and that begging is not permitted. So hopefully the problem of fake monks preying on gullible tourists is a thing of the past.This is not a place for those with mobility issues, though I have seen some awesome elderly people take their time and finally get up so many steps. Once you climb the 10,000 steps and pass the 10,000 Buddhas, you are rewarded with a spectacular view of the surrounds, as well as a pagoda and various other religious things.There is a vegetarian restaurant at the top with very reasonably-priced meals (about HK$55 or so).This is not a site of mass tourism, and the monastery wants to keep it this way. There are signs in various languages asking visitors to respect the religious significance of the site, not bring picnics, keep their voices down, etc. Sad that they have to remind people to do this. So if you're the kind of mass tourist who can't be respectful, don't come here. Otherwise, it's well worth the visit.

Even the locates didn't know of this place, really worth the 500stairs to see it.. Was difficult to find had to ask many people after getting off the MTR. But worth the visit. Be really for a tough walk up stairs and stairs, I love it

A very fotogenic temple. A taxi took us to the Ten thousand Buddas monastery, quite a bit outside the center. We could not find the monastery, but we found a temple with several outbuildings including a pagoda. The temple is situated on a hill. The road to the temple is through quite a few steps, the steepness was not bad. Along the way we got to handle a heavy tropical rain shower, fortunately we did have embrellas en there were shelters. The road up was surrounded by large Buddha statues. It is a very exuberant temple. In the temple there are three big walls with thousands of different Buddha statues, very beautiful and impressive. The images in the outbuildings are also very colorful and fanciful. Delicious dinner at the eating house. Just before we would go back there were a number of monkeys on the grounds, the monkeys were chased away by the administrator. Then we descended the hill via a different route. Down the hill we took the subway to our hotel. Hong Kong has a large, modern-looking, subway system where the subways coming and going, an experience in itself.

Worth the trek up the hill!. I stayed in HK for about a week, and not many people seemed to know about this place. I met with some of my friends at my hostel, asking if they wanted to join me. The station was easy to get to but from there it was a bit confusing where to go. We went in to the shopping mall to get a map and directions. From there you have to cross the street and walk up a hill on a bit of a sketchy looking path. The hike up is about 15 minutes. My friends complained the whole way, but once you get to the top it's worth it. There's so many statues along the way up - each unique looking. The temple inside is full of tiny Buddhas all over the walls. The whole complex is very beautiful and a nice escape from the hustle and bustle of the city. We were pretty much the only ones there, so it was nice to escape the crowds. You can climb up the tower, but it's not really worth it since there's no windows at the top to see the view. This place was a hidden gem, and I'd really recommend visiting if you have the chance!

Combine short hike and a visit to massive temple. Going to the temple you need to walk uphills. Along the path you will see those tens of statues of monks. The temple of the 10000 buddha really shows thousands of buddha. Recommend to go to next level to see other great interesting buildings

If you are buddhist or admire statues and religion this place is one not to be missed. Has so many statues on the way up to the hill top and once you are there, you can marvel at the temple and maybe make a prayer. This s one of the famous places to see and pray. Some say it is very surreal and some say prayers will be answered here. give it a go !

long but rewarding walk. Easy to go to from the Sha Tin train station. Since there are few signs leading to the area, look for some online material on how to walk there from the station. The building that houses the 10,000 Buddhas was very nice but don't stop there. Continue to go up the mountain for you to see more (the Buddha at the top near the waterfalls was my favorite). Wear comfortable shoes as it is a very long walk to the top and remember to drink plenty before going up. Previous reviews warned of fake monks....remember that this is a free attraction. With all the signs in the area, I was quite surprised that the fake monks were still there trying to get money from tourists.

Fantastic!!!. From the start of walking going to 10,000 Buddhas Monestery you will be amazed of all the golden buddha statue in all the stairway until you reach the temple, make sure to bring face towel and wear comfortable clothes walking, especially when its sunny day because its really hot. When i reach the main temple wow a lot of buddhas inside the temple they said its more than 12,000 and photos is not allow inside. You can take photos outside and some other statues but not inside the temple, you can also see Shatin city on the top.

Awesome statues. The stairs doesn't end it's keeps on and on and on. Great cardio workout. Take a bottle of water you will need it. This is a must see when in Sha tin. The monastery is amazing with all the 10 thousand Buddha statuettes. I must say when you get to the bottom do try the two floor restaurant, white building, just as you get through the side paths towards the bus stop. It has two steps infront and it has a big red banner with Chinese characters in black. If you fancy real tasty Cantonese food or your favourite dish made this the place. Local food in a clean environment.

Well worth a visit. I've been here a few times. The hike to the top is good exercise. Don't attempt it if you have bad knees or have a heart problem (or take it slowly). It's an interesting place, but it could do with a lick of paint. The view is great on sunny days. In recent years, they've expanded the site snd there are statues of Arhats (Buddhist saints) everywhere. The locals do worship here and it is a working temple, so please respect people's privacy and its not a theme park. On the way to the entrance at the bottom of the hill beware of fake monks (they exist at other temples in HK as well), they're harmless but they're not suppose to be there. On the way down, which is a different path, beware of a colony of rather aggressive monkies. They will grab your bags and rummage for food. Some people think its cute, but it's not and I've got chased up the hill by a monkey. These monkies are wild animals, they can be dangerous and there are no apex predators in the jungles of HK to keep the monkey population at bay. The HK government haven't bothered to do anything either. There isn't much in Shatin for tourists, but this place is worth a visit.

Such a unique experience!. Yes it is a steep climb, and even on a cloudy day you will sweat but it is worth it. The warnings about fake monks are accurate and blake t's review with directions were spot on. Make sure you keep climbing before returning to entrance to see a beautiful waterful and buddha.
So Impressive. Easy to get to from Sha Tin station, and sign posted from the railway. It's a beautiful shrine and there really are 10,000 of them :)

Buddhas and monkeys and 10,000 steps. A little history, a little exercise, a little anger from the local primates, what could be better! 10,000 steps must be walked to get to the many Buddhas, but it's a worthwhile exertion. Local culture mixes with tourist-friendly atmosphere. Would go here again.

Gorgeous monastery but beware the fake monks!. We took a day trip to sha tin to see the monastery and the heritage museum. The monastery is really beautiful set among lush green hills and very peaceful. Our experience was tainted a bit though by men dressed as monks greeting visitors and asking for an admission fee. They were standing at the entrance to the walkway deliberately obscuring the free admission sign and blocking the path. If you come across these people, tell to get lost and keep walking! Real monks will not ask for money. If you want to make a donation to the monastery, there are voluntary donation boxes up top.

Better then Big Buddha!. Choose this place before the Big Buddha! Much better. Do not forget to go all the way to the top with the small waterfall and the pool with the turtles. Be aware of people dressed like munks begging for money. Fake-munks!

Highlight of our Trip. My friends and I headed out in this direction to find a few good hiking trails and ended up being directed to this attraction. We were in workout clothes/hiking clothes and ready for a workout... and that's exactly what we got! I am pretty strong and my legs were shaking by the end, but I wouldn't take it back for anything in the world. Unbelievable statues and only takes a few hours to really see it all at a moderate pace. There are turtles everywhere and just incredible views of the city below. The most amazing thing happened while up there too - we got to encounter some wild monkeys and observe them eating some oranges! I have never been so close to wildlife quite like that and it really made my experience that much more valuable. But it is steep so wear good shoes and put on some sunscreen. I was drenched in sweat because of the high humidity but it sprinkles often enough that you got cooled off pretty easily. I highly recommend it though - it is not too congested with tourists like a lot of attractions in China were so you can actually get wonderful pictures. Easy to get to off of the subway as well which is a plus! Make sure you go to the cemetery (not sure the correct term for this exactly in the Buddhist religion) which is up on the hill before you get to the monastery itself.

Stunning!. This place is absolutely amazing. It's a bit of a mission to get there and there's a bit of a steep hike but it's definitely worth it. The Buddhas, the monastery itself, the view of the city... I also tried the "hot sweet Sago soup with coconut juice" at the eatery which was a surprisingly delicious and refreshing cold dessert.

Worth the Workout. This is a quiet escape from the busy city.Be ready to climb hundreds (or thousands?) of stairs. I wasn't. We had to stop a few times to catch our breath but it also became an opportunity to take photos of the buddhas lining the long stairs. This is obviously all about photo op. Amazing architecture and sculptures. Some figures were really interesting.The view from the top is just amazing. Is this a MUST SEE? YES. This is not your usual HK tourist destination which makes it more unique.TIPS:Bring water. Do not go when the sun is high up. Apply sunscreen if you must.For backpackers, do not bring your packs with you if you can.

Nice place. It s very peaceful and quiet and it s nice to get away from the crowd of HKG for an afternoon. When you reach the station take exit B and go left at the exit. Walk down the pedestrian alley and turn...

Pretty workout. Actually there are 13,000 but in Cantonese, apparently saying ten thousand is enough to mean a lot. The start of the steps to the monastery is a short walk from Shatin MTR.The 431 step path to the monastery is lined on either side with 500 life-size gilded Arhan statues making the journey there and back entertaining and at the top there is a simple vegetarian cafe that serves great food. Not recommended for a hot day but otherwise, a great half day trip out.

Wow, wow, wow!. Even though we were there on a typically hot day Hong Kong day, it was really well worth putting up with the heat! All of the different statues are so amazing in their diversity. The temples are simply beautiful and there is so much to take in - I loved it!!

Beware monk money scam! Apply the monk money test! + directions.. In Hong Kong you will find many people dressed as monks and unsurprisingly at the 10,000 Buddha's temple you are guaranteed to encounter some. To determine whether you are dealing with a pretend monk or a real monk, apply the the monk money test. The test is quite simple, because a monk will never ask you for money. So If someone dressed as a monk asks you for a donation for any reason, including for a blessing they just gave you (most likely without asking you) then they are a monk imposter / scam artist. If they get aggressive in demanding payment, then walk off and ignore them, or if need be call the authorities; as you are on the correct side of the law, not them. The walk up to the temple is quite nice and the path is lined with Buddha's, it's up a short but fairly steep hill which is very slippery when wet. The temple itself is quite nice and there is a basic restaurant there, also a pond with a large number of turtles. To get there take exit B out of the the SHA TIN MTR station and take a left down into Pai Tau Street. Then take a right up the path IMMEDIATELY after the final building on the street (there will be a soccer court to you left)I have attached a photo of where you turn off Pai Tau Street, take the path between the building and the gated uphill driveway, there is only a small sign and this is the only sign between the temple path and the train station.
Nice, of what I could see. Nice place, but was under renovations so we could only a small part of it and many people taking photos around and outside
Loved it. At long climb but worth it,you need to be fit but as I said worth the climb and you can get out there by train

Gold Monks lead the way up the steep inclination!. This is a really great place to visit in Sha Tin. There are many Buddha's here and it attracts a lot of Filipino, malays etc.Best buy some incense for HKD10 and distribute them!

Great fun, super interesting place.. As everyone else has mentioned on here, it was a little difficult to locate. Once there it was a blast! It is a tough walk up the hill, many places are steep and some a bit slippery. Worth the walk just to see the view from the top. Beautiful!

Nice experience. Most important - very close to the Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery there is a temple that many climb to it by a mistake. How to avoid the mistake? if you are climing in stairs and do not see Buddhas every 2-3 meters from the begining you are not in the right way.Very important - take a water with you.

Inner Peace. One of my favourite places in Hong Kong. I arrived in the late afternoon and there was hardly anyone there. It was so tranquil and beautiful. The hike up can be a bit strenuous, but with a basic level of fitness, most people can easily do it. The interesting thing is no two of over ten thousand Buddha statues are in the same pose! All vary in some form or the other. Great place to meditate and get in touch with your spiritual self.

Enigmatic, physically demanding, but worth it.. When I read reviews of walks and the review says "challenging", it's normally directed at children or pensioners. When people here have said "this is hard" - believe them. Take it slow, however, and you are rewarded with a unique vista and an intriguing walk.It is hard to find. Get off the left side of Sha Tin MTR, as you head towards Shenzen. When you come out of the station stay left and head towards Shenzen. You'll see a building on a hill. Head in that general direction and you'll get there.Yep, the monks at the bottom are there. They're used to rejection, so reject them. The walk is an unrelenting climb, but the individual Arhats that flank the path make it always interesting. There's a restaurant 2/3rds up which sells water, which you'll absolutely need by this point.Well worth the trip and energy.

Big Buddha. If you want to go up to see the big Buddha then take this advice. 1) Wear comfortable shoes.2) If you are asthmatic take your puffa/inhaler BEFORE climbing up the steps (trust me on this)3) Remember that it is about the journey and not just getting to the top.I enjoyed going there but I wouldn't go again.

Excellent afternoon. First off all follow the directions from here and head for the grand white gate with Chinese symbols on it dont enter it as it is a cemetery turn right up a path with a tiny sign and follow the directions you will be pleased to know that there are guards at the entrance to stop the begging monks and signs to explain that monks wouldn't beg.

worth a visit. If in Shatin area definitely worth a visit, please get the name written in Chinese so that you can ask for directions, no one not even the taxi drivers have heard of it just 1 KM from it since we were staying at Regal River side hotel which is about 2 Kms from the 10000 Buddha, man fat sze didnt help either, finally someone wrote its name in chinese & we used that, nice place, closes at 5pm, get there early, dark tortuous path to walk up & down the hill.

Nice view from top. The 10K Buddha is in Shatin my family home, it is quite a new attraction (in European terms) and had been steady built up over the years. It is interesting with all the different Buddha, the older more traditional Chinese ones are at the top of hill and I think the most interesting.To get in you have to go alongside a council building on the left, which is signed, do not go towards the temple in front, as you approach, as this is a Chinese cemetery.Be aware this is on a side of a hill, so not recommended for people with walking difficulties, as there are lots of steps, my suggestion is go early morning or late afternoon, as it will be less crowded and cooler especially in the summer. There are also monkeys that live on the hill side, do not feed or attempt to touch them as they are wild and I have seen tourist bitten by them.WARNING – Do not give money to the “Monks” at the bottom of the hill at the entrance, as they are not real, and just buggers dressed up, if you want to donate monies to the temple please do so at the top where there are donation tubs.
Nice, exotic and relaxing. Loved this monastery, plenty to see, great views over the city, some monkeys providing entertainment. Exotic aromas from plants, trees and burners. Authentic experience.
The Big Buddah. Wow - we took a trip up to see the 'Big Buddah' could see him from a few miles away. Great trip, well worth the effort to get there.

Worth a visit. This was a fun place to visit. It took a little time to get out there on the MTR, but I think it is worth it if you have a little time to spare. I enjoyed the walk/hike up the hill among all of the buddha statues, and it was pretty neat how many buddhas there are. I get it with the name and all, but it doesn't really register until you see them all, everywhere. Also, as other reviewers have mentioned, beware of fake monks at the bottom of the hill. For those of you that have been to Mont Martre and Sacre Coeur in Paris, it was very similar tactic. Give you a bracelet and such, and then not want to take it back, but want to be paid for it.

Quite a few Buddahs. This temple was right by where we were staying so it was a no brainer for us to visit but I'd definitly recommend making the trip even if you're further away. Theres a bit of a climb up from Sha Tin to get to the temple, there are two routes but both are decently signposted and paved. The temple itself, as the name suggests has literally thousands of Buddah statues - lifesize ones lining the paths and grounds and mini ones lining the temple itself. All in all, very interesting and picturesque.3 pieces of advice:1. Watch out for the scary barking dogs on the route up to the temple that starts by heading through Pai Tau village out of Sha Tin station2. Watch out monkeys pooing on people from the trees above the path on the main route down from the temple3. Dont buy trinkets from the fake monks that stand just outside the temple grounds

love it. You need to travel to Sha Tin to get there, and then it's a 30 minute walk on uphill paths, but it's a really great experience if you can be bothered to make the effort. I've been twice and will revisit again sometime.

Best hidden treasure in Hong Kong!. For some reason this is never in the TOP lists of things to see in Hong Kong, but for me it is the most amazing place this city has to offer! It is easily reached with an MTR to Sha Tin and from there its a small walk away, unless you get lost as there are no signs! Walk up the 400 steps to the beautiful Monastery. Don't get too close to monkeys if you see them and do not buy stuff from random monks walking around -they aren't real!

Worth the climb but watch out for fake Monks!. Our venture to this location started off on a car park looking down to the foot of the steps up to the temple. We we could see 3 Buddhist Monks on the correct path but could not work out how to get there until a security guard told us to take the path to the side of the car park.We were confronted by the Monks who offered a blessing and lucky bracelets. They then demanded HKD100 from each of us and blocked our way. Luckily a somebody shouted "You don't need to pay them!" at which point they backed down.Half way up the climb to the temple is a notice regarding fake Monks.1) Most Monks are reclusive and if they approach you they would never ask for money.2) The act of begging and actively requesting money is illegal in Hong KongApart from that, once you survive the killer climb (406 steps) the template is jaw dropping.

18 days around the world. If you go there take your time to climb the hill and find out which Buddha look like you and choose the rigth one for you. Not a single one looks like the other so 10.000 possibilities for you. go to the end of the hill with the white Buddha and the waterfall with an outstanding view in the valley.

Beautiful and rich in culture. Jump the metro to Sha Tin and follow the directions in the previous comment by 1X2, best directions to get there! The entertainment started at the station being chased around by megaphone wearing wheelchair beggers. The path to the Buddahs is not well sign posted and may make you think you made a mistake coming here but keep going! The dodgy monks trying to bless me and sell me beads at the gate were very authentic but the smiles were way to big to be sincere. Then the Buddah walk begins, wow very cool all the way up. When you reach the main area you will know it and be greatful you made this trip. Dont forget to go to the top level as well. There is free literature in the main temple with the story of its construction. NOTE take some toilet tissue with you as there didnt seem to be any provision for it at all.

Monastery was absolutely beautiful. great atmosphere, and monastery was really beautiful! quiet surrounding, nice natural environmentit was a great short journey away from the busy city life, it is nice to have some place to chillll living in this concreate jungle

Hard to find but worth it, no crowds either. Found this place today using some tips and asking for help. Take the exit B or one of the A exits but head to the bus terminus area at the Sha Tin station. Make a left and cross the footbridge and then an immediate right. You follow the main road towards the Sha Tin Government Building (little blue signs) then when you get about 5-10 minutes along you come to an intersection with a large pitch on your left and Ikea across the street. Make a left and head to where a nice temple is locate with an arch and large white lions. Facing the temple you want to make a hard right (even further right than the parking lot) and follow a path between the parking lot fence and a big white building. It is paved. About 100 meters in you are at the entrance. Note: it is FREE admission but some swindling monks dressed up may try and ask for a donation. No need, they are not part of the temple. Make a donation at the top if you wish. The temple is awesome and well worth it. Another tip, after exploring head out of the temple and walk straight across the grounds taking in all thestatues. You will find an exit path that is also worth it. Less Buddhas but you should see a few monkeys. Enjoy!

500 steps to the top. I had always said that once you had seen one Buddha statue. you had seen them all but this place certainly proved me wrong. Fascinating but a long climb to the top. Nice little cafeteria halfway up with great spring rolls and very friendly staff even though we shared no common words at all!

Great place to visit. Not the easiest place to get to (you actualy have to take a train - but easy enough with octopus card) - this is a 10 minute walk from the station (and no signs). Come down the ramp to exit the station, follow the road (small village to your right). Turn left after sports ground, and the next right again. The entrance to the monastery is at the end of the road (with a small sign). Steep walk up the hill which is lined with an amazing amount of golden buddhas. Don't miss the hall of the little buddhas at the top.

Interesting if you can find it. It can be a little difficult to find, and it is a bit of a hike to the monastry itself, but along the path are, well, ten thousand Buddha statues, all in a different pose.

Definitely go!!!. Such an amazing site to see your entire pathway lined with buddah statues. Not the best marked place but after exiting the mtr via the piblic transport exit A follow the road towards the government buildings until you find a white arch with lions. To the right of the arch is a car parking area, the monastary trail is the smaller path along the builing to the right of the archway. The trek up is managable but would be tough on hot days, well worth it to see everything including some pesky monkeys!

Fantastic; serene; spectacular. This temple is about 7 miles north of Kowloon, but is well worth the trip. Take the subway which is clean, quick and incredibly cheap and the entrance is a short walk from the subway station. Be sure to research the entrance becuase it is not easy to find. Walking up to the temple the path is lined with gold budda's and every one is unique. At the top is an amazing temple, and a reasonable vegetarian restaurant. Dont be put off by the menu - it's tasty. This trip was a great break from the bustle of the city and really easy to do by train.

Lots of buddhas!. Ten Thousand Buddhas is nice to visit if you have the time. It is a fair distance from Central.It is not an overwhelming place to visit, but it can provide to be interesting to wander around and take photos.

Great experience. Lovely attraction away from the hub bub of Central HK. Really unique in the design and the experience, the stairs are a bit of a killer if you go all the way to the top, but I'd definitely recommend it - the views are excellent! A very calming place, definitely worth the trip out to Sha Tin. Somewhat tricky to find - follow the crowds towards the home shopping centre and it's just the side of that.

A little piece of heaven amongst the rush. I am something of a temple junkie and was quite surprised by the serenity and colour of this temple. Take your time climbing up the walk to the temple. And lots of pictures. Each Buddha is unique and quite playful. I'm definitely returning. The feeling in the main temple had me returning inside a few times. This is a special place. Enjoy a vegetarian lunch in the cafe also. They serve very large plates so if you are not too hungry go for a snack instead.
Maintained very impressive and beautiful. Subway Station Sha Tin, 15 minutes walkingThe entrance is not marked and somewhat hard to find.Go slowly ascends the stairs, or you'll be out of breath.

Lovely and quiet, nice views from the top. We have lived in Hong Kong for four years and only have just visited this place. We liked it a lot. It is not such a difficult walk. Take the exit A or B from the MTR at Shatin and walk down towards the green minibus station. Go down the road between Home square Mall and the Government Building and you will see the signpost and steps up. It is well worth the climb up. There are Buddha statues all the way up the hill. There is a veggie cafe but we didn't eat there. It looks good and we will probably eat there on our next visit to Shatin. There are monkeys but they are not a problem. You can walk further up the hill to visit more shrines.There are toilets. They are clean and well maintained.

Brilliant cultural experience. Fantastic monastery with the most beautiful statues. A real cultural experience. The walk up lots of steps not for the feint hearted on a hot day! Lovely pagoda at the top as well as wild monkeys. Highly recommend.

Went because of Trip Advisor, Big thumbs up. This was a neat place to visit. Buddhas are everywhere. Warning it is a big climb to the top, my wife was ready to bail, and would be rough for children under 10. The reviews that said it is hard to find are are valid, we kind of stumbled to it. We got off at the bus station and went through the mall to get on the other side. Make a right at the end of the walk way and then you will hit a small cultasac on your left, at the end of the cultasac look for some small signs to direct you. At the top is a cafe to rest and get a Coke and some vegetarian egg rolls. Very intersting as a Westerner first visiting a Buddhist Temple.

A big climb but well worth in once reaching the top. Luckily I had a guide book with me to tell me about this place since it wasn't originally on my list of places to go. After seeing this sight, it was well worth the sweaty hot climb to the summit of the hill.  It's location is superb and as others have already mentioned, a very close walking distance to the Sha Tin MTR station. To get there, when you come up out of the MTR, look for Exit A (I believe), and follow the walkway to the left. Keep walking and you will then exit the MTR station. As you look up the ridge and to the mountains you may spot a tall white and maroon colored pagoda. The monastery is in this direction. Keep walking along the same sidewalk you used on the left hand side to get out of the MTR station. As you reach the end of the walkway you'll see a white colored arch with two guardian lions on either side. You are now nearing the location. Turn right when you reach this white arch and keep walking up the small hill PAST this entrance. Then, just look for the yellow with black writing sign that says Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery and then, you will begin your walk up the hill. If you're not entirely in shape for climbing (like myself), you may get very sweaty and need to take a few breaks on the way up. On your way though, there are Buddha statues on either side of the walkway. Once reaching the top, it's the main monastery that's well worth the challenging climb. Very well kept and well painted shrines, statues, and of course Buddhas lining the temple grounds. There is also a small eatery where you can buy food or drinks for those that may want a short rest and a bite to eat.  There are also some different levels you can climb to where other small shrines are located. There are also monkeys wandering about in one part of the temple so watch out. I saw one run along a fence and try to take a swipe at a couple who was unaware it was encroaching towards them.  Anyways in conclusion the trip to the top is worth it as the views are nice and the elements to see within the temple ground are quite cool. That and again, it's yet another destination that's very close to an MTR station much like many other sights in HK.  * Most notably, admission to this monastery is free of charge.

Go during the week. Went during the week with a group on a lovely sunny day and was a really nice walk up the hill. There are quite a few stairs & a ramp so be prepared, wear comfortable shoes and take some water, especially if it's a typically humid day in HK. When you get to the top there are some beautifully painted statues, it's a pity that nothing is written in English so as to know more about their significance and symbolic elements. You are able to enter the temples, as long as you are respectfully quiet. On a clear day, it's a lovely view of HK, especially if you continue all the way up to where there is sometimes a waterfall and a beautifully white statue (though I wonder how long it will last white with all the HK pollution). It was a very peaceful place on the weekday and it's free to go up so it's well worth the visit. It's a very short walk from New Town Plaza and Ikea (if you need some landmarks). You'll be amazed by the number of Buddhas.

Nice to see. You must prepare to climb the steps up to the monastery. But it is a interesting climb, where you will see different "luohan" statues along the climb. You could see that the monastery had became more touristic place than praying place. As I was there during weekend, you can see lots of people including Filipinos taking pictures at the various Buddha statues though there are signages saying photography. It could be interesting to them as there is no entrance fees like big Buddha ad it is easy to reach via mtr.

Relaxing place at the Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery. Me and my husband were supposed to go to Shenzhen, China but unluckily we were not given a Visa so we ended up wandering around Shatin. We visited the "Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery. When we were about to enter, there were 2 people dressed like monks asking for donations.. Good thing we did not give any because we saw a signage "beware of fake monks" as we entered on the main entrance :-) I did not count how many Buddhas built inside the monastery but I believe there are 10,000 or more. There are Buddhas every step of your way and since it is uphill, it was quite tiring but worth it when you reached the top. At the top of the hill, you can find the temple , huge Buddhas, restaurant, souvenir store and of course, the beautiful view perfect for those who love photography. This is not a place where you can have picnic. It is a very peaceful place and one of the place I could recommend for those who come to Shatin, HK, China.

Quite an interesting place but dont except special spiritual atmosphere. Quite an interesting place though I didnt notice any special spiritual atmosphere there. I guess the reason for it is that it's not an acting monastery and managed by laypersons. The temple is situated on the top of the hill and there are numerous gold statutes all the way up. The complex itself has several levels. The pagoda is 9-storeyed colourful building with Buddha's statues inside and outside the pagoda. You can get inside the Pagoda and climb up to the top (good photo perspective from the top of the pagoda). There are many shrines inside the complex. In contrast with general atmosphere the main temple has spiritul atmosphere. There are miniatures of Buddha's statues from the floor to the top and they are lighted with soft light, there are almost 13 000 miniatures and each has a different pose.  You can climb more up and enjoy views over the the area of Sha tin and low level of monastery complex.Unfortunately, people working for this temple are rude and just replying that dont speak English. How to get there: Sha Tin Station, exit B, walk towards IKEA, then climb up following signs.

Interesting but gaudy. It's worth a visit, an interesting walk past all the buddhas up the hill and the turtles in the small ponds were fun to watch. The monk who set the place up in the late fifties is mummified ? in the temple at the midpoint. When I saw the warning about monkeys, I wished we'd gone early in the morning to see them...
Nice to see. Beware of the steps! Lots of steps to walk up to see the Buddhas, lovely once u get up there and good views, but a fair trek if you are unfit like me!
One of the attractions must go. Very near Shatin MTR, just walk from there. However, the stairs to the monastery is shocking, just have to keep climbing and going to reach the top.

Interesting. A steep climb past lots of gold-painted buddhas and hungry monkeys checking for food. Some large, unpainted buddhas too, in settings that make it worth the trip. Disappointed that gates close at 5:30 while shrines and everything on top lock up at 5:00. That way visitors can make the climb and find everything closed up.

Fascinating. This place took a lot of effort to get to but it was well worth it. You can get there by taking the underground to the Sha Tin stop and then a short walk to where the pathway & stairs to the temple start. There are over 400 stairs to the top, but there are benches along the way if you need to rest. Gold Arhat statues line the path all the way to the top. Every single statue is unique. It really was a magical site looking up the path and seeing gold statues into the distance amongst the tree canopy. Once you got to the top of the stairs they open onto a courtyard temple complex with more Arhat statues as well as the main temple hall and pavillions, There is also a large pagoda at one end of the complex. A few more steps up and you reach the upper courtyards with more prayer halls & statues. From here there are some beautful views over the Sha Tin hills. The whole place is really peaceful and generally less touristy than other temple complexes in HK. It also has a buddhist run vegetarian cafe which is both good value and delicious.

Peaceful. I've never been to a temple before and this is my first visit to a place like this. i felt so peaceful while I was there and i was amazed that there are literally thousand of buddhas in the temple.

Interesting. The place is very interesting. There is a path also in the back you can get there but I think it's much longer but offers some stunning view. The fake monks have been cleared out from the front so no hawking anymore. It's an impressive place to see. Don't hope for English signs and explanations but expect some nice views and interesting statue exhibition :)

Good vegetarian meal in a lovely setting. This restaurant / food court sits at the foot of the Big Buddha and provides a good vegetarian meal. You have the option of eating in the interior restaurant or using the take-out service and eating in the exterior courtyard -- either is good.

10,000+ Buddhas!. Found out about this before leaving the UK and well worth a visit. The directions we found on the web sounded complicated but not so hard when we got to Sha Tin MTR. As you stand outside the station look over to the left up the hill and you will see it so you know where you are going. As you get closer there are a couple of signs. Be warned there are lots of steps, all lined with Buddhas. Also, there are monks begging at the entrance but they are nothing to do with the place. The temple is stunning. We googled it before the trip to get the history which makes it all the more interesting.

More than 10,000 Amazing Buddhas!. It was my first visit to a Buddhist Temple so far, however I loved it! From Shatin MTR station, after walking towards IKEA, you should turn right and not confuse it with another similar looking place. There is a narrow passageway to go through to reach the entrance of the temple. All these golden Buddhas on both sides of the temple was a great sight. Even though the long climb to the temple can be a bit tiring, all the different types of Buddhas attracted my attention not even think about my tiredness. However be sure to bring some water with yourself! Upon reaching the temples, all the different colorful statues of different gods are just amazing! There are multiple building to go into, and statues to see. There was a small souvenir shop, and a small restaurant as well next to the temple. I am very glad that I went there now, it just an amazing sight. A completely different sight of Hong Kong, I would say. When you reach the top the contrast of these beautiful statues, with the high-rise buildings, and the green surroundings around them was simply beautiful! Definitely worth a trip! :)

Best temple so far!. Im traveling round China and I love visiting Buddhist temples, this is probably my favorite so far! There is so many statues, buildings and shrines and so easy to get to from the metro, just turn left out the station. The whole thing is free! Only thing we paid for was lunch in the vegitarian restaurant, I loved it and still can't believe there was no meat! Don't give any monks money that are begging! There fake!
10,000 buddas. A hard walk up hill in humidity but so worth it! Don't be fooled by the beggar dressed as a monk at entrance, the monks don't beg.

Excellent - but BEWARE of the fake monks!. We took our children to the 10,000 Buddha Monastery today and was met at the entrance to the walk by some very smiling monks, who I later found out were scammers. (after they took $150hkd off me!) They pushed 'good luck' bracelets onto me, my wife and the kids and then asked for $100 HKD for each item! - BEWARE OF THIS. There are warnings about this but not until you are well into the grounds. A great attraction, but be careful.

Genuine, peaceful, relaxing. Not a touristy location at all, very few people there. Very peaceful, very genuine monastery. Impressive number of statues, great location on the hill with great views.I was a bit hungover and took the brown line and exited at Sha Tin Wai, then cop there explained that I actually need to get back to blue line and get out at Sha Tin station (which I kinda meant to do). You can get there from Sha Tin Wai, but it's an unnecessarily long walk. From the station I just walked towards the hills and asked security at a shopping mall how to get to the monastery. The entrance is really unmarked and is between two hi-rise buildings, just behind the driveway. There is a little sign once you step off the pavement into the greenery. I do have a real GPS (not assisted GPS - no need for internet connection) with good maps on my phone, so I at least know general direction. Without that I think finding it can be a bit tricky.There a lot of steps and A LOT of Buddha statues, some are unassuming, some are amusing and some are quite bizarre. There are several monastery buildings on top and more statues. There is a little simple restaurant and a rest room. Very few tourists, a lot of space and it just doesn't seem like you're surrounded by a huge metropolis. Totally worth the trip if you're a bit more adventurous than regular tourist crowd and want to travel a bit more off the beaten path (although of course there's nothing wrong with going to all the regular touristy places as well).
Pretty neat. Good place to visit. Peaceful. Not as popular and therefore crowded as the big Buddha with the cable car

You must not miss this - Incredible. This was one of the highlights of our holiday - its a hard climb up the 400+ steps but what a fantastic temple at the top and in such beautiful condition. There are more than 10,000 buddas and every one seems to have a different face - it was fantastic - I cannot recommend this visit highly enough. The colours and gold buddas are just amazing - and they seem to be restoring more of it further up the hill.

Budas Heaven. For who enjoy a relaxing and calm place must visit it.To get there is a little bit difficult, but have some people explaining how to get there , and i did it like they said and was easy for me.You must pass from a cemetery first before you can reach the Budas.Before you arrive there is maybe a 10minutes walking up, but no hard, and have some places to rest until you get up. In all the way you have photos of different kind of Budas. Once you arrive there you have like the "Church" of Budas with a lot of them.You have also a restaurant to you can eat or buy some drinks, and a souvenir place where you can buy some gift's.Hope you enjoy.

Least touristy place i visited in HK. Much of HK felt like a tourist trap to me but this monastary did not. It was free to get in which was awesome and between the hike up the path and wandering around when I got there it took about 2 hours of my day. Its fun to take pictures with all of the buddhas along the path but the statues once you are at the top are absolutely beautiful. It was worth the trip!The monastery is hard to find. I could see it from the road but couldn't get to it. Its behind the Grand Central Plaza (a big shoppin mall with an Ikea) and the entrance to the path looks sketchy but there are some plastic signs pointig the way. Just follow te sigs and you will be fine - otherwise, save yourself some trouble and ask for directions.

One of a kind and worth a visit when in Hong Kong. This place is easily accessible from the tube. When you approach follow the signs to the right rather than going towards an escalator which actually takes you to the crematorium (although this in itself is interesting if you do make that mistake).The lead up to the 10 thousand Budhha monastery is probably as fascinating as the monastery itself. The path (yes it is a steep walk) is lined with life sized Buddhas, each individual with a variety of expressions and poses. The monastery itself in contrast is packed (lined wall to wall) with miniature Buddhas (over the ten thousand stated) and is quite The most memorable part of this spot is the many Buddhas along the long and steep pathway leading to the monastery itself. As well as being life sized they are all individual in style, with a variety of expressions and poses. The monastery in contrast is filled to the brim (all of the walls lined) with miniature Buddhas (over 10000) and was equally fascinating. This trip out along was in deep contrast to the bustling Hong Kong and if you have time is certainly worth a visit. One of my highlights of our trips.
Must see. This is a must see in hongkong. u can spend 3hours here with all the ancient collection. worth seeing once

One of the Great Hong Kong Attractions. The first time I was in Hong Kong I lived in a hotel in Sha Tin and Monastery was almost on the door step.I have now been 3 times and I see something different every time. It is a little difficult to find as has been said but is well worth the visit. You should be prepared for a moderately difficult (in terms of the number of stairs ) climb but I have seen some very elderly Chinese making the effort to get to the top so why can I. Currently the very top section is closed for renovation which was a pity for my friend but the main temple is lower and still accessible it is a sight to behold and you need to spend some time there to really appreciate the whole atmosphere.

Many steps, great rewards. This attraction does not seem to be highlighted by the local tourist board possibly due to the incidence of landslips in the past and there is little indication of how to find the path up to the temple. However if you head to the IKEA store at the Home Square, stand facing out from the exit and turn right to pass in front of the Sha Tin Government offices you will see some signage that will lead you to some 460 steps up to the temple. However, if you cross the road in front of IKEA and walk towards the village and shops as far as a set of bollards the turn right, you will find a much easier way up. There are signs,including landslip warnings, but it is a much easier climb. You can return down the steep 460 steps at a comfortable pace.Not surprisingly there were only a few visitors and some of those appeared to spend little time there, perhaps disheartened by the signs requesting no photography in some areas. This is a religious site after all and the staff appeared very tolerant of those, who chose to take photos, provided a degree of respect was shown.The refreshment area is not at all sophisticated but the staff were very friendly and we enjoyed a big pot of tea and vegetable spring rolls for just HK$ 35.The buddhas are amazing though we wished there was some information in English regarding the many characters. We spent over an hour and a half taking in the atmosphere and the overall experience. This is a far better attraction than the well trampled site of the Big Budda. There is no Starbucks or Subway here and no plastic village; just peace, reverence and tranquility and a vivid contrast to the bright lights of bustling Hong Kong.
not for the weak-legged. this is a good climb up all the way to see the magnificent temple of ten thousand buddhas. makes one wonder how did the monks bring up the buddhas by FOOT initiallyy.

Well worth the train ride. Easy to get to by train just a short walk to the monastery. There Is a temple and graveyard just before the monastery well worth a visit the monks are very welcoming but please remember that it is a place of worship and be respectful. The 10000 Buddhas are amazing not a trip for people with walking difficulties as it is a long steep walk but well worth it. The view s from the top are amazing well worth the extra effort to get there. The little cafe serves an amazing vegetarian noodle dishes and hot sweet tea. Do not be scammed by the pretend monks at the bottom of the hill who will bless you and put beads around your wrist and then demand money they are not real monks, go and let them know at the information desk and the real monks will chase them away. Great trip well worth the effort to get there

My second time. To get there , take MTR and get off at Shatin. Entry is free. You can give donations. Most of the buddhas are golden. The area is at the side of the mountain. On your way up you may encounter some naughty monkeys. The area is clean and peaceful. It would be better if they renovated the old building on top.

Must see. We went there after dragon boat festival so it was a little bit crouded, I don't know how it looks on the other days. It's quite far from main tracks in HK but you can always ask someone about direction, the best way is just use a bus - too bad I don't remember the number anymore, but it's the easiest way. When you get out of the bus it's on the other way than horse riding place, you should see signs how to get there. And watch out for fake monks - at the very beggining of the way they 'attack' white tourists and ask them to buy bracelets or for money - they didn't talk to me because my husband is a hong konger but he tried to convince other white tourists to buy. When you go up you will see signs to be aware of that and even ask to call a police. Real monks wouldn't ask for money or to buy stuff. Walk is quite tiring and if you're affraid of butterflies it will be a nightmare to walk for you but all the way you will be enterntained by statues of buddha. On the top you can light incense, eat vegetarian meal, buy some souvenires. Besides the public transport ticket there's no fee. Great experience for free.

Really enjoyed this temple. This is a little bit outside Hong Kong central but accessible by train. It is within walking distance of the train station but you may have to ask for the correct direction. The entrance is next to an office block so you need to search a little bit (don't head for the large temple nearby!) Also avoid the FAKE monks who greet you on the path to the entrance. They want to sell you beads for 50 dollars but will disappear quickly if you mention the police! The buddhas were all different and the temple at the top was really lovely. Also had a cafe which served local tasty, cheap food. It is quite a climb up to the temple, lots of steps, but there are places to stop and rest if you need to.

Nice to visit if you have time in Hong Kong. It is located in the new territories close to Sha Tin. You ave a small hike to go there. Living in Hong Kong, I admit it is a nice attraction but not essential. Many Buddhas with different faces and gestures. Don't expect to find old temples, old sculptures... Nothing is very old in Hong Kong, they usually prefer new contructions, new attractions... Anyway, the atmosphere is very pleasant and quiet.

Nothing to see there. We did not like the place. Everything is new, just built. You do not feel any spirit and atmosphere. Buddas statues are funny but nothing special. You can go there only if you live near or have seen everything in the city.

Nice to see. The 10,000 Buddhas are a pretty nice attraction near the New Territories!It is pretty easy to get there! Get off the MTR station (Sha Tin) and 500 meters further the climb to the plateau starts.It is for free and the Buddhas are pretty nice (and funny). Almost every Buddha looks different and partly very untypically.You can see real, wild monkeys. That's funny but a bit scary at the same time.However, the 10,000 Buddhas are a nice place and when the sun is shining, their appearance is great!This attraction is not a must see, but I can recommend it :)PS: Nearby is an IKEA where you can get cheap hotdogs! Yummy!

Not bad, but not worth the trip. Taking a good 1 hour from Hong Kong by MTR, this is tucked away next to a cemetery (which looks amazingly similar according to the pictures you see in the guidebooks). Very colourful and interesting for a quick visit, but think twice if you want to spend a day out. Ikea down the road is fun if you want some swedish meatballs..

If your in Sha Tin take a Detour. Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery is worth a visit if you are visiting Sha Tin. The Monastery is located on the western side of the Sha Tin Station. It is a good 10 - 15 minute walk to the Monastery from the station. The stairway or escalators to the top of the monastery is quite relaxing. The view from the top overlooking Sha Tin is quite amazing not to mention how quiet it is. They is a shop at the top of stairs for refreshments. Bring your own water if you are planning to climb the stairs. They is escalator and lift for less capable people to get to the the top of the Temple area.

Worth it For Sha Tin. It's worth a visit, maybe not solely for the temple but Sha-Tin itself is worth the trip out of HK into the new territories. The temple is great, and I found it quite relaxing in some of it's quieter corners. The Sha Tin New Town Plaza is a great shopping centre, especially the market section. Lots of nice places to eat too. You can walk along the river or even hire a bicycle on a nice day. We happened to see the Dragon Boat racing at Sha Tin too, so If you are lucky enough to time it right it can be a great day out.

Definitely worth of visiting. It was the only place in HK where i didn't spend half a day waiting in a queue! Even this fact makes this place worth to visit. And I recommend you to go there early in the morning. There won't be many visitors, and you'll be able to feel unique atmosphere of the monastery. When I climbed the stairs I felt like these Buddhas statues are looking at me, they were like judges (angry, kind, indulgent and severe). I have never felt anything like this! I wonder fantasy person who created this place. It is beautiful and full of peace. I spend there 1,5 hours with food but I'd like to have more time for just sit on the stairs and look for green mountains and skyscrapers on the horizon...

Worth it. First and foremost BEWARE of the "monk" at the entrance "giving you a gift" and then asking for money. Other than that the place is amazing. Yes the climb is brutal if you are out of shape like i was but well worth it.

One of the best temple experiences in Hong Kong!. Man Fat Sze, also known as 10,000 Buddha Monastery (free entrance), is one of the more unique temple grounds in Hong Kong and one of our very favorite to visit. This is a place we continue to visit as residents in Hong Kong and a place that continually impresses our guests when they visit. It is well worth consideration for those eager to see some of Hong Kong's more interesting temple visits. Unfortunately, visiting Man Fat Sze requires a rather steep walk up Po Fook Hill, easily a 12-15 minute walk and this can be quite tiring, especially in the summer when its hot outside. However, the entire path is lined with hundreds of golden-colored, life size Buddha statues, each in different poses. Although few of the statues are that individually amazing, collectively they are quite neat to see. Of note, there are several stopping points with seats for those who require break from the long uphill break.Near the top of the path, you encounter the main temple building which is bright red in color. Inside, you will find walls covered with miniature Buddhas and a rather conventional Buddhist temple scene. Outside is a level ground with more life-size Buddha statues, a nice nine-story pagoda and other sacred statues and items that are well worth inspecting. Then you can walk up another a couple additional flights of hillside stairs, which are similarly lined with more Buddha statues. At the top, there are four of five more halls, similarly decorated with either miniature Buddha statues or other interestingly decorated figures. Several viewing spots are also found at these higher levels which afford some very nice views down into the city of Sha Tin. When viewing conditions are poor, which is quite common, these views are not so impressive. Otherwise, these can make a nice place to stop for a couple pictures. Once you've had enough time taking in the endless Buddha statues found throughout the complex, you can begin your descend back down the hill. This can be done by returning down the main path or the alternative path, found on the level area in front of the main temple hall, which leads you down through the village and eventually in front of the Sha Tin MTR station and New Town Plaza Shopping Mall.Overall, we really enjoy Man Fat Sze. While the temple buildings themselves are just ok, it is the presence of so many interesting Buddha statues that makes this a genuinely unique place to visit and one of our best temple experiences in Hong Kong. This is why we visit from time to time and why the 10,000 Buddha Monastery should be considered when you are thinking about what to do/see when visiting HK.Hint: During the summer, its highly advisable to visit Man Fat Sze early in the morning so you can get your climbing done before the heat really starts to set in for the day. The temple officially opens at 9am in the morning.Hint: To find the hill path leading up to Man Fat Sze, you need to walk behind the IKEA building ( Grand Central Plaza). As soon as you pass the IKEA building, turn right on Sheung Wo Che Road. This is a short turn off street which ends quickly and the path up the hill to Man Fat Sze begins there.Hint: A visit to Man Fat Sze takes a bit more time than most allow for. Keep in mind that usually takes between 20-30 minutes to arrive at the temple hall from the Sha Tin MTR because of the need to climb up the steep Po Fook Hill, the climb down is usually as long. If you spend no more than 30 minutes around the temple, you will still need approximately 90 minutes to visit this temple. This is how much time we try to allow for when visiting.Hint: A visit to Man Fat Sze actually fits quite nicely with several other attractions in this area. You can start with a visit to Man Fat Sze, take your lunch at the New Town Plaza Shopping Mall, stroll through Sha Tin Park to the very good Hong Kong Heritage Museum and then make a quick detour to the important Che Kung Temple, just across the river from the Heritage Museum. This is a nice little way to spend half a day in Sha Tin.

Non-sense to visit. The Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery is far worse than other Buddhist temples in Hong Kong. You will find some dirty and old buildings after spending 15 mins on a terribly long stairs with many broken "Buddhas" along side. You can't spend more than 10 mins for searching around but you need to walk for another 15 mins downhill afterward. So, is it non-sense to visit?

Maybe not worth the hike. Well, I've seen a lot of Buddhist temples. And this was, for me, more of the same. Put this at the end of your HK To-do list. There's a pretty good hike to the top, not too strenuous. But, once there, there are two levels to visit. Skip the upper one as it's dirty and unfinished. The main temple is relatively small and, to me, insignificant. However, I enjoyed a nice vegan meal before heading back down.

Well worth the visit - easy half day - not too strenuous. Won't repeat the excellent directions elsewhere...we used them, and they were excellent. Walk up to monastery is steep, but good steps, and only 15 mins. Dont let any comments abiut the steps put you off. The path is lined by large gold Buddhas ....all plastic. However the temples, particularly the 10,000 Buddha temple is really interesting, and one of the great little pieces of culture remaining....if you want to find some culture, then get on the train and go out. Don't worry about first class on the Easr Rail line, go any way...it's no more than 30 mins n the excellent MTR. The 10,000 Buddhas themselves are impressive. The rest of the temple complex is also interesting tho didn't try the veggie restaurant.

Great but beware!. The walk way up to the Monastery is lined with gold monk statues and each one is different. When you reach the top there are some larger elaborate statues and temples. There is a good view from the top. Very nice but spoilt by over use of concrete. Still definately worth a visit if you are close by.We were approached by monks at the start of our walk up who tricked us into donating 300 HK dollars. We realised afterwards that they were infact fakes! There are warnings on the path up that begging is not permitted and that real monks would not beg!

Nice. Worth a visit. Follow directions to a public administration building and turn left BEFORE the building. If you meet some begging monks at the gate don't give them money or buy anything. They are not monks but hustlers or regular beggars.

Nice surprise!. I went there without really knowing what to expect but it turned out to be a lovely surprise. It s very peaceful and quiet and it s nice to get away from the crowd of HKG for an afternoon. When you reach the station take exit B and go left at the exit. Walk down the pedestrian alley and turn left toward the government building. When you reach that building take a right : the entrance is right there and it s free of charge

Was a good walk and interesting. There are alot of steep steps and walking to reach the mountain and also the actual monestry is very interesting to look at. I recommend it if you like to view religious sights

Worth the effort. Take your time to climb up the many many stairs, guided by the live size statues of hundreds of Budha's. At the top enjoy the view and stroll around the different complexes displaying thousands of Budha statue, in every size. Descend the other way and pass through the old village and some more shrines that the monks visit on their way up or down. These are still very much in use, so be respectful. Better not do this on a very hot day, when you are not in great shape, it's a serious climb.

Ten thousand statues lined up. The climb upto the monastery is lined up by lovely statues ten thousands of them. Usually very few tourists go to this place. The Monastery at the top is a serene place and the carvings and paintings are beautiful.

A very pleasant walk up the hill. Especially now that the weather is cooler. It is a few hundred steps up a small hill with gold coloured statues along the path. There is a monastry on top and a small vegetarian restaurant. The path might be a bit tricky to find, it is located behind the government building (Post Office etc.) as you come out of Shatin Station.

Amazing place. I absolutely loved this place. It is a good day to spend but can be a very tiring one. I would watch out for the monkey's.. one of the mothers got annoyed with us and started chasing us hehe. Great time.

Well worth a visit. It's a bit off the beaten track but easy and cheap to get to this attraction on the MTR. After reading other reviews I printed off directions on how to find the place. Actually, it's fairly easy - exit the station near the buses and village then left at the shopping mall and first right past the multi storey car park.Walk up is lots of steps but they are not particularly steep and there's loads of Buddha's to look at. The effort is well worthwhile with plenty to see at the top including the ten thousand Buddha's temple and numerous other striking buildings. We stopped for a drink in the cafe which was nice.Overall, never really been anywhere like this before and genuinely glad we made the effort.

Interesting and uplifting.. I go there at least once a year. I think this place must be amongst the top five places to see in Hongkong. A real feast for the eyes. One needs to climb about five hundred steps up and all the way up are the gorgeous golden Buddha statues on your sides. There are numerous small temples and a nine storied pagoda in the centre. One can climb up the pagoda too and enjoy the view of the place.The place is walking distance from the Sha tin station but is a little difficult to find.There is a very nice Buddhist vegetarian restaurant where the ambience is more canteen style but the food is delicious.
Best of Hong Kong. Very interesting place. Great walk up between all the buddha's and fantastic little restaurant. Nice for breakfast too!

Sort of impressive... sort of not.... We arrived at Sha Tin station and walked to the 10,000 Buddha Monastery and promptly went up the stairs / escalator to the wrong place and ended up in Po Fook Ancesttral Worship Halls - a common mistake as there are some instructions telling you you're probably in the wrong place! Nevertheless - it's still quite a sight inside.The 10,000 Buddhas are found down a small path and then up hundreds of stairs which are lined with gold buddhas - when you first see them it's pretty impressive, there's one either side on every step, but then as your breath starts to leave you, you kind of just want to get to the top!At the top is the actual temple which is impressive - one huge Buddha with thousands of little ones around it. There are more larger gold ones around too. There's a nice little cafe at the top serving fab food very cheaply. There's also soft drinks up there. Wouldn't necessarily say it's worth a special trip but if you have a couple of hours to spare then head along.

Lovely staff, difficult to find, mammoth climb. Firstly, finding this site is nigh on impossible, but happily local people are happy to guide you. Yes! Beware of scamming monk before the chain link fence. You can and should report him! The climb is not for the faint hearted,its no himalaya, sure, but in the 40 degrees heat, not pleasant at all! The site is perfectly nice, but the staff are delightful! Not the best temple in the world, but quite interesting and lush and green surroundings,

worth the effort. I don't believe this is a monastery, but it is a lovely shrine. There are many steps, and the way is steep so consider that when planning your trip. Also there are monkeys on the way that are tame so be careful, I suspect they would bite. The site itself is difficult to find....look behind the government building. And has been said before...the more obvious spot beside the government building is a cemetary. If you find yourself facing an escalator, you are NOT in the right place for the 10,000 Buddhas.

Lots of steps, so bring water!. This shrine is within a five minute walk from the Shatin MTR stop. You have to climb a lot of steps to get to the main temple buildings, but it's worth it. Not many tourists at all, and the temple buildings are well kept up and worth the visit. I don't think there is really a monastery here--at least I saw no signs of one. You are rewarded with a nice overlook at the top of the path over Shatin and the New Territories. Just be forwarned that it is a work-out to get there!

Gorgeous, amazing!!. Not a place to be missed! During my last 2 trips to Hong Kong, I did not know about this fantastic place. Luckily I did not miss it on my 3rd trip.One can see gold-plated Buddhas with different facial expression and postures all the way up right to the top. There are more than 10 000 of them. Unbelievable!!! The view up there is breathtaking and there are many beautiful statues of deities, especially the Goddess of Mercy standing at the bottom of a waterfall. You can really fell the calmness and serenity of the place. The tiring climb up there is worth the effort.

Most challenging and worthy. It wasnt a popular place among tourist because its quite high and you have to walk up for it. I would recommend youngster to mid-age people only come since it was tiring activity. Walking up along the way, there are hundreds of monk statues making you walk in awe. its better to walk in the morning after you ate breakfast for energy. All along the way, i was amaze. once you reach the top, there are 2 separate place you should check out. to the right is the kuanyin statue which is next to the jungle..you can see pond flowing with mountain water. if you go to the left, would be the temple with those 13000 buddha statues. it was small, about 20cm height. but not only that, there are a small pagoda. you can actually go on top of it:)
incredible. So beautiful and well worth a trip. I would suggest doing an afternoon tour. We had a great time. Amazing place

Worth the Effort. If you have the time to journey out into the New Territories, I’d highly suggest making a stop in Sha Tin to trek up to the 10,000 Buddha’s Monastery. Sitting at the top of a hill, reached by winding steps lined with gold-painted plaster Buddhas, the temple is one of Hong Kong’s most intriguing, especially for Western tourists. The complex also features a cheap vegetarian restaurant, which compliments the spiritual experience. The long-dead founder of the monastery is entombed in a glass box, gilt in gold for all to see, inside the main temple. And the 12,000-plus Buddha statues make for endless exploration. Even though the majority of them are only mere inches in height, believe it or not, no two are identical!
A good work out.. Put on your comfortable shoes and cool clothing..! A good exercise trek up to the monastery. Not recommended for those who are very unfit. Worth a visit to see all the deities.

Very glad we went. Amazing! Unfortunately photos not allowed in the actual temple where the 10,000 little buddhas are, but plenty of other things to take photos of! Takes about 15-20 minutes to walk up, but plenty of rest stops along the way, with seats.

A Long Climb - worth the effort. We took the train to Sha Tin and followed the signs to the monastery entrance. There is another temple nearby commemorating the dead and it is interesting to visit but not the 10,000 Buddha Monastery so be careful. Also beware of fake monks who will try and fleece you for donations of $HK100. There are warning signs saying that the genuine monks do not beg, but these guys position themselves before you get to the sign. Don't give them anything!The walk up to the monastery is steep but exhilarating and from time to time monkeys will run across the path. The path is lined with golden statues.The monastery proper has two levels. The first level is especially beautiful with an ornate pagoda and more statues. One of the temples has walls lined with little Buddha statues. Then a further climb to the top temple - worth the effort for the buildings are in excellent repair.This is a Grade 3 Heritage Site and may be a bit off the beaten track, but worth the climb.

A quiet retreat after a long day. We took the train to Sha Tin from downtown. It cost about 80p followed the sign posts and took the long walk up to the Monastery. Yes there are ten thousand buddhas its a wonderful place,full of humble repose and deep contemplation. We had a wonderful morning here just drinking in the atmostphere. The temple is beautiful and all those buddhas are amazing....

hidden jewel in the mountains. its about 500 steps up so its best to go early just follow directions from previous tripadvisor previews or go to Takeme2 and watch the video. had a really good vegi lunch at the on site restaurant. only a couple of people where there, nice and peaceful

plastic Bhuddas on your way and beautiful monastery. You start your way up with many many maaaany steps up. Along your way there are one by one placed statues of Buddha. All different with different face expressions, sizes of belly on pose. However they all are made of plastic and some are a little damaged, but hey! It is still impressive and most likely you will not find it on a typical tourist guides. As I have heard it is due to reason that place does not meet some safety regulations. Well, I did not find anything dangerous there, apart from mosquitos who were eating me badly, but I am delicious so that was expected :) So if you taste good you better get some spray to fight them.The monastery is truly beautiful and you go for a predicting your future there. Basically you pick the jar full of wooden sticks you knee in front of the "altar" and thinking your questions (rather it is love, work or else what) you shake the jar until one stick falls out. Then you go with this stick to the lady working there pay some money sorry don't remember how much but it was a little) and get a piece of paper with written Chinese characters. You must have Chinese speaker with you as then you go to the predicted who is reading your luck or lack of it in future, but he speaks Cantonese... It is a beautiful place to visit, go for it!

A worthwhile climb. This is a place we always take our visitors to. It is a side to Hong Kong we rarely see. The climb is a long one, but there are benches on the way and it is not too steep. I am not fit, but can make it to the top. Don't forget to take water.I love the different Buddhas, they are so cheerful

Worth the trip.. Worth taking the train out to Sha Tin and climbing the steps. Lots to see at the top and great views. Take plenty of water and don't be fooled by the fake monks begging at the bottom of the steps.

Pack a water bottle or ten. My sister and I started out by asking the concierge of the nearby mall where the entrance of the monastery was. She showed us a narrow foot path with a small yellow sign signalling the way to the entrance. The first golden buddha you see marks the start of the climb. Yes, climb! It's a long way up to the actual monastery. The path is lined with different buddhas that watch over the long, winding stairway. How far up is it? If you're in the bottom, you can't see the end of the trail - not until the 60th buddha! Our mistake was visiting the place in September at 12 noon in what felt like 100 degree weather. My sister made it to the final bend, but when she saw that the last few meters were the steepest, she waved the white flag and opted out. I made it all the way up and it was worth the climb. The place was fantastic. The buddhas ranged in size from tiny to gigantic and the atmosphere was solemn. In order to fully appreciate it, this place has to be witnessed first hand. A few tips: Avoid going going in the middle of summer, in the hottest time of the day without a bottle of water. This is an active monastery where people come to worship, be courteous and observe the rules: no food, no turning the place into the park, and speak quietly.Definitely pencil in this place when you take a trip to Hong Kong.
Beautiful. Beautiful golden statues lining the route up to the monastery. Quite a climb in the heat of the summer!
Worth the climb. Lovely Vegi restaurant at the top (we are not veggies) but the path is not easy to find. Walk past and along the side of the Government office!

Worth seeing but be prepared. Definitely worth seeing, but make sure you are prepared for the walk. Not the easiest to find but the locals are used to it and just direct you even before you ask. Its a bit of a trek and not the place to go on a humid day. Also, unlikely to find a taxi locally so keep hold of your map. Overall I think if your on the tourist trail in HK you need to put it on your list.

Lovely little excursion. Peaceful climb - just head out of exit B Shatin East MTR Station, entrance at the end of Sheung Wo Che Road. Take your time to climb, it's not a race....enjoy the peace and tranquility (provided you go there early enough to miss the crowd) and you will like this time away from the crowds that HK is famous for.

a lot of golden buddhas. Forget any advice to check out http://www.10kbuddhas.org/ first (unless you can read cantonese) - even google can't translate it. The current opening hrs are 9-5, 7 days a week, and don't confuse it with the 'cemetery' to the left that has the escalators. If you end up at the escalators go back down the road and take the first left. The entrance is tucked away at the end of the road. The fake monks were there too as per the other reviews.There are a few steps but they are mostly baby steps, and nothing like the famous tiger buddhist temple in Thailand. It is well worth the visit with an interesting temple and pagoda at the top. There are some old buildings which give it a rustic feel in places and I did not see any place to buy water - although there is a small rustic restaurant at the top.The bonus is that you also get to see more of the mainland side of Honkers.

Serenity on high. The entrance to this is hard to find and not to be confused with the funeral home up the escelator and the tip about rogue monks at the pathway entrance was useful as I was able to politley decline their bracelt for cash. I began the climb early afternoon and it was both peaceful and interesting. The top was fascinating and the sense of peace and thousands of colourful buddahs was a great place for contemplation. Take water but in a bag as eating and drinking in the temple area is disrespectful. There is a cafe at the top.

Keeps you fit. It's a long way up if you have not exercised much recently but it's worth to visit if you are a buddha fan and like to be accompanied on the way to the top by human sized golden buddhas.

Interesting. This place is nice. but Do not go out of your way too much to see this. It is very average and not maintained very well. It is fun to see all of the Buddah's in different positions and gestures.

Do this in the cooler months!. Off the beaten track but definitely worth visiting - in the cooler months!There are Ten Thousand Buddhas and a lot of stairs - so come prepared with a hat, drinks and sensible walking shoes.
great. Many buddha with different styles, worth to see and great walk uphill. It was a great job to bring them all uphill.

Interesting!. It seems commercial at first sight, especially the colours. However after we heard the story behind it, it is truly impressive and representative of the Buddhist culture. Worth the climb!
Walking up steps. Many steps lead up to that monastery. Good views over Sha Tin. You can buy food and beverages in the cafeteria up there.

If you visit only 1 temple. Let it be this one. This temple is not so easy to find. And it's very quiet. Yet it is the most interesting one in my view. It is quite a walk up there.
