And it is quite far from the center but it's really worth it. You see 100'ds of big buddhas along the walk up the hill. Once you get there, you'll see even more of them. Very hot. Very enjoyable. Closes at 5pm though. so don't be late!

A day with Buddhas !!. After going to the Giant Buddha in Lantau where it was very touristy, I decided to visit the 10,000 buddhas temple, what a great idea ! It was about 34C when we were there, we ended up completely drenched by sweat at the top, but it was worth it. If you have 2-3h free, i would recommend it.Some of the Buddhas are quite creepy !!

Very hot walk!. Quite difficult to find, went into the cemetry next door first! Its quite a steep walk up the pathway and on a particularly hot day my teenage children moaned and groaned most of the way up. The pathway is lined with Buddhas the whole way up all different. Once at the top it is quite tranquil. We had a bite to eat and drink at the vegetarian cafe which was very good and the staff were very welcoming. The temple at the top was breath taking with all the buddhas.

Extremely Unique. An extremely quirky and unique temple; one of the less well known sights of Hong Kong but one of the most memorable. Definitely more impressive than Big Buddha. We decided to visit on the spur of the moment and it was one of our highlights of HK. The Monastery is situated half way up a very big hill, and there is actually ten thousand small buddha statues lined up from floor to ceiling on all four walls. Surprisingly enough this wasn't the most impressive thing there: the path leading up the hill from the street is lined all the way by hundreds of life sized golden statues of buddha and his followers, each of which is completely individual and some extremely weird! Once at the monastary there is a beautiful garden with pagoda and more statues, which then also lead on further up the hill to a large standing buddha. The monastery is free so if you pass any monks on the way asking for money don't pay out - they are fake monks who make a living from begging. It's not the easiest place to find: from Sha Tin MTR station turn left out of the exit, go down the ramp and bear left, take the second right and you will find the beginning of the path at the end of the street.

Surrounded by blessings.... The climb up to the monestary is truely special as you pass 10.000 different Buddha's all representing their own way of blessing life and looking after you.Pay your respects at the top the hill and you are bound to leave with good blessings. You might be surprised with the variety of Buddha's that are created...!!!

Quirky. The 10,000 Buddhas is great place to visit, the Buddhas leading u the path are all very different. The staff at the little restaurant at the top are very helpful. It is worth going up to the top of the pagoda for the views.
Nice change of scene. it's great to get out of central hong kong and take in some culture - the number of buddhas (though less than 10,000!) is quite impressive and enjoyable.

On the road to enlightment. Steep walk at some points but very worthy. It was great to climb and look at the different status before getting to the temple at the top. So peaceful it is like being in a different world. The small vegetarian canteen is also highly recommended. Lovely people and the best veggie food we ever had (and we are not vegetarians)

Amazing place-worth the climb. Hope you have been working out because this place is 400 steep steps up. But don't dispair, it's worth the climb. Very quiet, and obviously not a tourist trap. People are there because their relatives are memorialized here and because it is very peaceful and beautiful. They have a small restaurant at the top and a gift shop but everyone leaves you alone to ponder and visit. Traditional toilets are kept immaculate. Ikea is just around the corner at the bottom.

10.000 Buddhas and more. we found the way to the monastery in the mountains one of the more interesting experiences in Hong Kong. It rained cats and dogs and were the only visitors where we would expect crowds of people.
One of the highlights. What an awesome place to visit, the big Buddha is another must see

Worth the climb. While we were in Hong Kong in October 2011 we took a trip out to the New Territories to visit the Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery. By taking the MTR train to Sha Tin station, the first thing you see when leaving the station is the old village of Pai Tau, tucked in below the surrounding new developments. With the village on your left continue walking a short distance to the junction with Pai Tau Street, take a left into this street, then take the first right, Sheung Wo Che Road, past the local Government Offices and a multi storey car park. At the end of this road you should see the yellow direction sign for the path and steps leading up to the Monastery.This is where the steep uphill climb of 431 steps to the lower terraces of the Monastery starts and the path is lined with the first of the many more than 10,000 Buddhas that are on display.Admission to the Monastery is free and it is open daily from 9am to 5.30pm, unless there is heavy rain or a Typhoon signal above Level 8. There is a Vegetarian Restaurant on site open every day except Thursday where we ate and enjoyed a traditional meal.

be in awe!. seriously, the place is full of statues of different buddhas (although i got to say they look the same after a little while) but this place is absolutely amazing with the climb up to the temple and the amazing size of the statues inside and outside the temple. absolutely in awe and impressed with the power of faith!

Incredible! A worthy, healthy climb.. Up some 490 steeply ascending steps with full sized golden buddhas lined the path which leads to a couple of temples and pagodas with a beautiful view of the city from above. It is indeed a spectacular collection of buddhas. To get there, get off at Sha Tin MTR station, Walk out to the bus terminus, and continue towards Home Sqaure and IKEA ahead, keep left onto Pai Tau Road, then a right along the Sha Tin Government Building till the end of the sidewalk where the path to the monastery starts. We heard monkeys in the bush but did not see them. Insect repellent is a good idea for those prone to mosquitoes. Allow about 2 hours. A must while in Hong Kong!

Great attraction (helps with jet lag too). We are staying at the Royal Park Hotel located very close to Shatin MTR station. On the first day, we took a 5 minute walk and then a 15 minutes climb up a long flight of steps to the 10000 Buddhas Monastery. Note: the entrance which takes you to the steps are located on the right side of the laneway looking up the mountain. The trek in the afternoon was just long enough to keep us awake during our 1st full day in HK, allowed us to get some exercise and was interesting to see. At the top and at the monetary we were rewarded with the fabulous display of Buddhas statues, a pagoda and a sighting of a monkey in a tree! Worth a visit especially if you are staying in the Shatin.

LOTS of steps, but well worth it! Best statues in all of the monasterys I saw!!!. It's a trick to get there. Map it out.The temple is reached by a STEEP 400+ step path. The path is lined with hundreds of individual, unique, monk statues. Once at the top, there are more statues, some with multiple heads or limbs.The main temple contains around 13,000 miniature Buddha figurines which line the temple walls from floor to ceiling surrounding huge Buddhas. There's also a 9 story pagoda in the courtyard area and a big Buddha you can take a picture of. Near the multi-armed statue is an awesome view of skyrises and everything down below. It's amazing how high up we are. There's also a path that leads further up the hill from the temple to a burial chamber for ashes, a beautiful fountain, more statues and another view of the city.NOTE: Do not get stopped by what appears to be a monk. HE IS NOT A REAL MONK! He is a fake and will "bless you" and give you a bracelet and ask for money. My husband thought he was real and gave him the $100hk he asked for.

A highlight. This was a highlight for us on our trip. This is not a 'touristy' place and difficult to find without instructions on how to walk from the station - sorry I didnt save the but did find them in a review on the Internet. There are over 10000 Buddhas. They line the walk up the pathway which is steep but not too strenuous and are there are also thousands in the temple at the top. The Buddhas lining the pathway all have a different look and expression and so although I have travelled a lot in Asia, this was something different to see. It was not just your traditional temple or monestry. I recommend a visit.
Great place to visit.. This is a great place to go, but be warned if you don't like walking up stairs, give it a miss. It takes a while to get to the top but it's worth it.

Rewarding hike.... Fortunately for me I had a local bring me to the Shatin area to visit this attraction...travelled early June and whilst I see the monks at the beginning of the hike certainly didn't come across any wildlife / monkeys...!The path leading up towards the Monastery has many statutes and you are rewarded with the sight of 10,000 tiny little buddhas inside the Temple...It is a relatively steep and challenging walk, especially when hot & humid...I visited before midday and aside from a group coming down I was the only tourist at the top..!!
Quite a climb but definately worth it !. Amazing site to visit. The vieuw is breathtaking and it is amazing to walk all the way up and enjoy the vieuws of all those statues. Definately a must do !

A long way up. It's a little difficult to climb even for a fit person. The best way is to do it gradually. Take a set of steps then take a little brake. They have some benches along the way so you can rest. You will see your reward when you get to the top. It has a nice view of the city. Don't be fool by the monks begging for money at the entrance. We were told they are fake monks trying to take advantage of the tourists.

A cool hidden monastery. Beautiful place. Be careful of wild animals. I can see how the monastery could be difficult to find however I had no troubles. Upon exiting the mtr, following the signs that lead to the Government Buildings (or Complex), to which that path show lead you past the Pai Tau village on your left and then the Home Square should be directly in front of you with a road. Take the road to the left (towards the mountain) and follow it until the end when there is an entry way to what would appear to be the monastery or temple. THIS IS NOT THE ENTRANCE. Right before it or (along the wall of this complex) is a path. Take the path to the right and then you will come to the entrance of the path to the Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery.The path on the way up is rather step and could be difficult for elders, people with disabilities or people with leg problems. Along the path there are many Buddha statues but at the top is the best, with many statues and pagoda tower and a room full of thousands tiny Buddha statues. There is a restaurant (or shop that serves drinks at the top) and there are also bathrooms.One my way down from the monastery I ran into both a large wild snake slithering its way on the path before me, and then I saw a monkey down from a few branches, look at me, then climb over the wall onto my path to just stare at me. Neither harmed me, or looked harmful, but be careful with children, these animals are still wild.

Beware of the monkeys!. A great place to visit for the day. Be sure to wear comfortable shoes and enjoy the sight of wild monkeys among ten thousand buddhas. Take time out to light some incense and unwind in the peace and quiet.

Historical. This one in Shatin is a stamp in Hong Kong's history of recent decades. It actually houses about 12,000 Buddhist statues. You don't have to believe in Buddhism to visit, but you do need some stamina to walk up the stairs.

The climb is worth it. This monastery is a bit tricky to find. Take exit B when you exit the KCR and keep left all the way thru Pai Tau village or find the entrance to the parking house for Ikea and there is a path up to the temple. DO NOT give money to any monks approaching you -they are fake monks and has nothing to do with the monastery so if you want to support the monastery please donate at the top. It is a beautiful temple with more than 12.400 Buddha figures in all sizes and shapes. It is not overrun by tourists and most of the times I have been there we have been the only tourists. The hike up to the top can be quite tough if it is hot and humid so bring water or hang on until you reach the top and you can buy water or sodas and enjoy a nice vegetarian meal in a small canteen! It is a perfect day out! Don't forget to hit the helpful button if this review helped you :)

Amazing walk up a steep hill. This was more difficult to find that any other of the tourist sites in Hong Kong. Nothing else in the area but it is worth the trip. As the walk up the hill is in the shade and there is a statue every bit of the way it makes it a very pleasant climb. Didn't meet any monks asking for money. The site is truely amazing as the buddhas are never ending. There is a small cafe and toilets. From the Sha Tin train station take the exit to the Pai Tau village, keeping left. Actually follow the sign to the Government building and then walk round the back. As there is so much to see in Hong Kong then most don't make the effort to see this but we were there for 6 days so had plenty time.

Steep climb and good views. There are two main paths to the Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery, but the best path, especially with a pushchair and for shade, is the harder to find entrance next door to the Shatin Government Offices on Sheung Wo Che Road. The other path is through the Pai Tau Village but there are several steep and narrow areas for which you would have to carry baby and fold up the pushchair.Be prepared for a steep climb up and down either way. It is good to stop and look at the Buddhas along the way, and each is supposed to be different.The views are good. There is a small kiosk for drinks (a couple of friendly assistants who entertained our baby). It was not too crowded when we went, as it is a bit off the beaten path. We didn't see any fake 'monks' (but it was last year) but as remarked by several reviewers... Monks never seek money or donations.

i can't count anymore!. this place is so amazing!
with the number of buddha statues that line the route up to the main temple (hundreds or maybe thousands by my count...), it makes one wonder how did the monks who constructed the temple actually managed to achieve the feat of bringing up all the heavy looking statues...
kudos!

Great place, not such a touristy place!. Prepare to walk up a steep way, but worth it and great location for unique pictures with all the Buddha faces along the way. Not much else to do around this area and go only if you had the time to see more relevant attractions in Hong Kong

Grave site to many. Don't get swindled by the "monks" at the front outside the chain link fence, they're fakes and force you to pay $100 HKD per person. Try not to, real monks don't ask for money, nor does the temple charge an entrance fee. Make a donation at the top where the temple and staff are. There's lots, +10,000 Buddhas and other sacred figures, in addition to all the people's remains who rest here. It's worth the hike up the steep never ending hill, but don't pay the phony monk. There's food at the top and washrooms. If you make it to the highest point, you'll see a huge white Buddha, waterfall and lots of turtles! When you get off the MTR stay left out the gates and cross the road, the temple is behind the huge household mall. A little confusing to locate, but it's hidden in the jungle.
Good exercises.... Good exercises, and a payoff panoramic view at the top. Breakaway from shopping, crowded, and high rises. It's a great fun for children.

and ten thousand steps to get there.... well perhaps not 10000. We've taken a number of visiting friends and family to this Monastery and all have enjoyed the day out (you can combine this trip with a number of other activities in Sha Tin). Be warned, this monastery is on a hill and you need to be prepared to walk up quite a few steps to get there. We are not talking Great-Wall steepness here, the steps are fine for anyone of average fitness, but if someone is frail or has a dodgy knee, you might want to skip it.The route up can be a little tricky to find at first. The best way is to take exit B at the Sha Tin MTR into the bus station/podium, walk down the path on the far left hand side of the bus station which brings you down to street level. Follow the road curving to the left towards the Pei Tau Village/Grand Central Plaza (signposts for IKEA) and walk up Sheung Wo Che Rd which separates the shops from the Sha Tin Government offices. This road looks like a dead-end but up at the end on the LHS is the path up to the monastery. This path is lined with large buddha images, each one seemingly more bizarre. There are plenty of reasons to stop walking and snap pictures of them. When you get up to the main monastery, take a moment to pass by it, continuing up the hill for a short way and see the older, less public parts of the complex and the columbarium. The main complex has great views, recently refurbished and thus highly coloured statues, a pagoda and of course the main temple with the the '10000' (and who could tell) Buddhas. Lots and lots of photo moments to be found here. There is a small vegetarian restaurant in the Monastery which is ok for a snack or drink.When walking down, take the path on the RHS of the courtyard at the pagoda end. This path wanders back down into Sha Tin, past some older local houses and brings you out in the Pei Tau village where you started.

A wonderful if somewhat shabby relic of the mid-20th century. Not really a monastery, this temple run by Buddhist laypersons hosts a great many sometimes eccentric sculptures and good views out across Sha Tin. It is truly authentic Hong Kong, and is a good place to get away from the crowds.

Tough to find, hard to climb to, but worth it.. A very unique setting high on a hill not far from the train station. Take the side street beside the House Store. You will see a stone gate to another temple, but look around and follow the signs to the 10,000 teample. Be aware that there may be fake monks at the base of the hill, who will bless you, and give you trinkets, then hold out a bowl for donations. They are very demanding, when I offered 100 HKD, the monk wanted more. The rest of the visit was great and well worth the time and effort.

One of the top 5 attractions in Hong Kong. I rate this one of the top attractions in Hong Kong, only behind the Giant Buddha/Cable Car and Victoria's Peak/Tram experiences. The views walking up the steep hill/steps towards the Monastery are simply stunning! I don't understand why this attraction is not rated more highly on Tripadvisor. When you get there, ignore the escalators and instead walk the path on your right. Ignore the fake and irritating monks at the entrance trying to sell you bracelets and its a short walk past them until you see the steps. It only took us around 15 minutes to reach the middle section but it is worth climbing further up to reach the top. Amazing views of the city and amazing looking buddha statues! Allow approx 2 hrs.Dont leave Hong Kong without experiencing it!

Worth the effort. We travelled Hong Kong totally by public transport which is very easy to get around. The Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery is a little out of the way and a bit of a walk up about 300 steps but I can assure you it is well worth the effort. We have travelled throughout Asia but have never seen anything like this the Buddhas just kept on coming. We enjoyed this much more the the Lantau Island experience!

Amazing history and statues!. absolutely fascinating when you see the tons of buddha sculptures lining the path up to the main temple that is perched in the middle of nowhere. Makes one wonder how the monks did it when they first shifted the statues one by one without modern day technology

Train for the walk up.. In the New Territories so a few sttaions out on the MTR. Easy to find but a steep climb up to the monastery. The climb is lined with Buddha so interesting but take water and rest because it goes on for a bit. Once up there it is great. It's not an entertainment but a place of peace with great views and vegetation that probably has never been disturbed. Really funny sign on the outside toilet wall.
Interesting place. Worth the effort even if the Big Buddha is partly hidden by fog / low cloud .Atmospheric and informative place to visit .

Astounding. Ten Thousand Buddhas MonasteryThis is not one of the top attractions than most tourists think of when coming to Hong Kong but I would consider it a must see. I have been to Hong Kong before and have been to the Peak, Stanley, Ngong Ping, etc. Why is Man Fat Sze a must see attraction, 1) Not touristy so you are surrounded by dozens of sightseers.2) Somewhat off the beaten track but easy to get to. Also free. 3) I've never seen a monastery like this and have been to many in China and Japan.How to get there: Take the MTR East rail to Shatin (light blue line on the MTR map). We caught the train from the large Hung Hom station (but I think you can also catch the train from East TST station - don't quote me). There are frequent trains about every 5-10 mins when we left about 11am. Look for a train with the destination Lo Wu or Lok Ma Chau. Time about 15 minutes. When you arrive at Shatin Station, take exit B, turn left and walk down the ramp alongside the bus terminal. Walk about 50 metres till you reach Pai Tau St on the left (there is a large shopping centre on the corner with an Ikea). Walk down Pai Tau St about 20 metres till you reach Sheung Wo Che St on the right (Shatin Government Offices on the corner). At the end of this short dead end street is a yellow sign directing you to the monastery. Now for the hard bit, a steepish walk, (431 steps) pass "lifesize" golden individual statues (these are not the 10,000 buddhas but Arhans, monks who have not yet achieved full enlightenment to be considered a buddha). Check out all their amazing postures and facial impressions). At the top there is a small vegetarian restaurant. Then you go to a large courtyard where the temple is situated. There are actually about 13,000 small golden buddha ceramic statuettes surrounding the embalmed body of the founder of the monastery - Reverend Yuet Kai who is seated in a glass case. Also in the courtyard is a 9 storey pagoda which you can walk up via a spiral staircase and other pretty amazing statues.But wait, there's more - walk up another set of steps to the upper terrace where further renovations are being undertaken. There is a large Amitabha Buddha statute in one hall but walk further along and see a beautiful white statute of Kwun Yam in front of a waterfall, nice view of Shatin here too.As I said there is no entry fee, open 9-5.30pm daily and the monastery is looked after by lay people, who offer you a pamphlet in Chinese. We were warned about fake monks begging but didn't see any on the day we were there. We were told by one the the lay guides that you could take photos in the halls as long as you do not use a flash.Tip: go to the toilet at the railway station 1st

Fun with monkeys. A winding set of stairs take you to the top of this semi kitsch monastery, and along the way you are very likely to be greeted by monkeys! One word of caution, take the time to read the monkey guidelines at the bottom of the staircase!
go by metro and local train. take a map and go by metro conexion with local train to visit and walking up this beautiful monastery, and envoy the locals and the 1000 budas. Go
Get in good shape now!. It can take awhile to ascend the steps, but boy is it worth every step. Brilliant!

Well worth the trip. As it says there really are 10,000 golden buddhas (although honestly I didn't count them all) and they are all different, not to say a little strange!Very easy to get there by either bus or metro and then a short (10 minute) walk to the bottom of the steps.The walk up is lined with buddhas, you need to be reasonably fit to manage the steps, then at the top there are a number of different temple buildings, more steps and lots more buddahs all the way to a large white buddha at the very top. On a clear day you get a good view of Sha Tin.Avoid visting the cemetry by mistake, the entrance is at the bottom of the steps and has a lift and escalators, it looks like it goes to the same place but you can't get to the monastery.
Nice to see hard to appreciate. Well what can 10,000 buddhas be like? Anyway a slice into the life of the Chinese of that period so that is interesting to those who care about it.

Beware of False Monks. very interesting place to visit but beware of a false monk who may come out of the woods and approach you at the bottom of the stairs . He will do a ritual to bless you, slip a bracelet on your hand then ask for money. We ate lunch ( Japanese noodles with vegetables ) at the restaurant and it was very tasteless. The ladies who served were very nice.

10,000 Buddhas were worth the trip. I highly recommend this excursion. You get to see another part of Hong Kong, away from the glitz. The walk up the hill (lined with Buddhas in different positions/different facial expressions) was fascinating--I couldn't stop taking pictures of the different Buddhas. Didn't seem to be touristy at all.
very unique monastery. it is a very peaceful experience to sit inside the great hall which has the 10k Buddhas
Awesome statues. A bit tricky to find, I would say. But great once you get there! Watch out for fake monks who are after your money...
Top 3 Temples in Hong Kong. Get ready to climb to get to The Temple but worth every step. Two thumbs up !!

When 9,999 Buddhas aren't enough. Simply add one more. Oy oh Oy, you've got some climbing to do. Oh and the Buddhas (which is hindu for Buddy) they are indeed a plenty. Counting them, which is discouraged, yeilds a more accurate count of about 782. Unless you count them tiny ones.

Highlight of our holiday!. I was initially put off by other reviewers who stated it was hard to find but I was so fascinated by photos taken there I researched how to get there. I watched a 8.22 minute YouTube video "How to get to 10000 Buddhas Temple from Shatin station, HK" posted by WalkMe2. It was excellent, I watched the video a couple of times and was able to find our way there without any problems. The walk up is steep, so take a water bottle for a break on your way up. (water is sold up the top) We spent nearly 3 hours at a leisurely pace exploring. I would definitely go back again as I just loved it.
good place to exercise. climbing the stairs itself make the trip worth. peaceful place. a lot of things to see here.

Well worth the travels!. It's not just a normal Temple with the location/stairs and so many buddah's around. If you are not into historical sightseeing and only want one==this is definately worth the trip.(as long as u can handle the stairs.)

Never seen anything like it!. The buddhas lining the sides of the stairs are nothing like we'd ever seen before! Very interesting poses! Worth a visit and once you get to the top, the view is spectacular!

Tough. I went here during my first time in Hong Kong in 2004. It was hot, I wasn't used to the heat and humidity, and I ended up sweating like crazy. It looked like someone had thrown a few water bombs at me! It wasn't signposted well, and there weren't many English-speaking Chinese people to help us, but once you get up to the top it as very cool, and you will feel as though you have earned an achievement. Sha Tin itself is a cool place, too.

Be Ready For A Steep Uphill Climb That's Well Worth It!. It was very steep in places and a long walk, but the views at the top were great!. And all the Buddhas along the way kept it interesting. Don't try this in high heels!

Nice peaceful place to visit, off the beaten track. If you like to visit a less crowded Buddhist temple this is for you, be prepared to climb lots of stairs but no worries, it is quite shady , You will be rewarded with a serene atmosphere at the top and have a look at a Buddhist monk who is embalmed there after his death.

Amazing. It should have been easy to find but some instructions on Trip Advisor completely confused us. When you leave Sha Tin MTR Station, simply go down the ramp, turn left into the main street - Pai Tau Street, walk a few metres, cross the road and turn right into Sheung Wo Che Road. You will have the 'Sha tin Gov office' building on your left and the Grand Central Plaza on your right. At the end of the short street there is a sign - "the Shatin Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery", follow the sign and you will see the start of the steps and Buddhas. The steps are well constructed or you can use the ramp if for example you have a pram. If you are seeing people's back yards on a very poor path (as we were) - you are in the wrong place!I am so glad we persevered, we loved the thousands of Buddhas. A definite favourite of our visit to Hong Kong. Having read other reviews we said No to the supposed monks wanting to bless you at the base.

A beautiful Peaceful Place. Monastery is about 15 mins walk from Shatin MTR station. From the base to the top of the monastery has a steep climb (walk) surrounded by statues of buddha/monks in various positions. On top of the mountain you will find the old temple which is over 80 yrs old. You also get a magnificent view of Shatin skyline from the top of the mountain. There are many architectural structures around the temple with a Pagoda and halls. Must visit place.
Go in the morning. I enjoyed it - the walk to the top can be heavy - walk up early in the mornign during hot months

More like 13,000 Buddhas. This was definitely worth the trip. Just gorgeous and the seemingly never-ending rows of gold Buddhas are kind of mind-boggling. When you get to the top, it just keeps getting bigger and better. I really loved it.

400-step climb, many buddha statues. This place can be reached via the Sha Tin MTR Station. From there, walk towards the government building - it's behind it. About 10 minutes walk from the station.There are about 400 steps from the base to the monastery - with gold plated buddha statues on both sides of each step. Once you reach the monastery, there are more steps going up for you to see more statues and a view of the area. There is also a vegetarian cafe.It's a peaceful atmosphere - as you can see devotees performing religious activities. There are quite a few temples on the hill which houses different gods. Indeed a must see if you are into religious sites.

up the top. this temple is a little out of the way, in the New Territory, behind the crematorium. It's a long, long, climb to the top.. with hundreds of statues lining up either side of the climb. If you don't mind a long climb, it's worth the trip.
Amazing place. A good walk up all the stairs and a real good view over Sha Tin. Genuine place!

Nice. At first I doubt they have so many buddha statues but now is really satisfied . A very long and steep way to climb up but sure is worth the effort. Staffs (especially old ladies) are very unfriendly and rude.

A great trip out of town.. With some help from previous posters on Tripadvisor this complex was quite easy to find. But like a lot of visitors we still made the mistake to take the covered escalator up the hill first. And as said before, this is not the Ten Thousand Buddha’s Monastry. This is the Po Fook Memorial. But with Chinese New Year next day this was an interesting visit also. A lot of people were offering fake money and we saw how this was all burned after praying. We went down again (there was also a plate at this Memorial indicating this was not the Ten Thousand Buddha’s Monastry) and turned left into a small path. We ignored the fake monk and found the entrance. From there it’s a long climb but not a big issue. Along the steps you can see a lot of different Buddha’s so you can take a few rests. At the top you find two levels. On the first level you find a large courtyard with a pagoda, a lot of statues and the main Ten Thousand Buddha’s Temple. On the higher level you will find some more statues and temples.There was no entrance fee for this temple, like any others in Hong Kong.

Worth the hard walk, beware of budhist imposters at base of hill! Scam artists!. Its worth the treachorous walk if you are in to religious statues! If not dont bother. It does have some great views of the city as well. ALSO BEWARE of two buhdist imposters at the base of the hill who will approach you and try to place a beaded braclet on your hand, which then thet will want 120 hk for. Thy are scam artists! Other than that nice place!

An uphill hike but worth it. This attraction is a little difficult to find. When you leave the Sha Tin station walk down the ramp to the new building that has an IKEA in it. Turn left down this small street where you will see a small white building and covered steps up the hill. This is NOT the Ten Thousand Buddhas. Instead take the path to the right of this white building along side the large building. You will think that this has to be the wrong way.The hike up the side of the mountain is lined with gold statues that vary in size, features, and expressions. Stopping to examine the various facial expressions is a good break while hiking up the hill. Once at the top, there are two levels. The lower level has a restaurant (drinks HK$10), a bathroom (though only squatty potties as far as I could tell), a large courtyard with pagoda, and the Ten Thousand Buddhas. There is another higher level with more statues and temples so continue up.We did not pay a fee for this attraction.

Cloudlike serenity above the madness. Emerging at Sha Tin station, took a little road up through the village and many many steps to a sanctuary from the hustle and bustle. There's every conceivable form of Buddha there and even though I'm not a practising Buddhist, I could not resist paying my respects with masses of incense for a few pennies. TIP: Don't cause offence, be sensible with photography, it's a place of worship first and a tourist attraction second and you'll have a good time. Soft drinks were available up there too at a cheap cost and of course there's a loo. I think there's two stepped paths to the site and taking the left as you go up, I can recommend Wong's cafe as a place for a decent lunch, truly authentic and reasonably priced.
Got Dr Shoals ?. if you like to walk this is the place to go. half way up the mountain is the temple many Buda's along the way and History that you will never gain from books.

Incredible hill full of statues. If you are buddhist or admire statues and religion this place is one not to be missed.Has so many statues on the way up to the hill top and once you are there, you can marvel at the temple and maybe make a prayer.This s one of the famous places to see and pray.Some say it is very surreal and some say prayers will be answered here.give it a go !

Amazing. A bit out of town on the Metro & a steep climb up a hillside but the ascent is rewarded with the sight of hundred's of life size gilt Buddha statues along the way and a lovely pagoda & pavilion at the top.

Great hike off the beaten path. Though you can take the MTR fairly close to the monastery, we spent about an hour trying to find the actual path to start hiking up to it. If you're lost, there are a couple food stands, including a pizza shop, on the left as you walk toward the monastery. Ask for directions!The number of stairs up to the monastery is something like 600, so be prepared for a workout, and bring lots of water in the summer.The statues around the monastery were really impressive, especially the 10,000 or so Buddhas inside. Keep going after you reach the monastery as there is more to see. I loved the large white statue at the very top with the small waterfall behind. The view over Shaton is quite beautiful from there, too.
Dismal. Only just ok, staff very rude and unhelpful. Extra charge to enter summit not worth it for the rubbish meal thrown in.

What a climb to the top. It is a very steep climb to the top of the temple of the Ten Thousand Buddhas. So you have to be in a good condition. But when you on top you be amazed about the view and the temples around you. Don´t try to count the Buddhas in the main temple. It is dazzling. You can also go to the top of the Pagoda.
climb long long but very nice!. see alot alot of buddhas, 10000!very holy but have to climb long long

Golden Buddhas as far as your eye can see!. You must visit this Monastery - easily reached by MTR and overground train to Sha Tin. The Ancestral Hall is also worth visiting but the Monastery is mind blowing. You reach it by climbing up and up passing by different forms of Buddha all gilded. It is breathtaking and mystical. The Monastery itself is beautiful with huge Dragons on the Roof, with an outside courtyard complete with large statues of Gods/Immortals,more Golden Buddhas and a Pagoda inset with small Buddhas.It is really worth the climb - I have been visiting Hong Kong for 23 years and have never visited the Monastery before - what an ommission.
absolutely fascinating!. wouldn't have found the place if not for the guide that i hired but this place is absolutely amazing with the numerous buddha statues and how magnificant everything looked!
10,000 PLus. Hard Walk but worth it go up hill to the left of other Monastry for a quieter local walk up
Stairs, stairs and more stairs. I just expected a little bit more after the walk up .... just felt it was overrated and just concrete in the middle of what could have been a more enjoyable visit.

Nice place, nice walk, a getaway from the populated town. The walk to the mid-hill temple is so nice, and you can imagine how a small village turned into a populated town when you get up to the pagoda.

Worth the long and steep walk.. The most memorable part of this spot is the many Buddhas along the long and steep pathway leading to the monastery itself. They are all just larger than lifesize and each has its own expression and appearance. Most have an expession showing some degree of happiness, with some seeming to be caught in outright guffaws. Various ages, amounts of facial hair, and styles of clothing are used. Some have hair on their heads, although most are bald, some are surrounded with laughing children, and some are seated on the backs of animals. The monastery itself has quite a collection of small Buddhas, literally thousands, lining every inch of the inner walls. In the middle of the collection of buildings which are currently used you can see the dilapidated building which was the original monastic center established in the 1950's. The remaining buildings are impeccably maintained and beautiful. To me, as a westerner and non-Buddhist, this monastery seems quirky and even a bit out of sync with my image of Buddhist reverence and simplicity but it made for an interesting, peaceful, and enjoyable diversion from the usual Hong Kong frenzy.

Very spiritual place. Loved it here, lit lots of incense and candles both myself & my mum in law came over very emotional just being inside this place it was very calming amid a bustling city , don't miss it !

Well worth the day trip!. Take the MTR to the New Territories (MTR stop - Sha Tin) and escape the crowds by visiting this monastery nestled in the hills. We used the route recommended in the TripAdvisor App on Android as the monastery is not fully signposted from the station, and the App also suggests other must-see points. Words can't do justice to the wonderful colours and architecture of this place (and for the record there are allegedly nearer 13,000 buddhas at this site!). Only drawback is that the site is accessible by foot only, up 400+ winding steps so is not suitable for the mobility impaired. There is an old-fashioned Chinese bookstore and bee farm on the way down from the monastery, although these were closed on our visit.

Be In Good Shape for the Hike Up to the Temple. Well worth the hike up to the temple although it could be somewhat challenging for some. I gave it a very good rating since no photography is allowed inside the temple (a no-flash photography policy would have been nice). Each statue is of a different person and some of them are unique. A vegetarian restaurant is on-site.

Don't miss. You must see this interesting place while in Hong Kong. The stairs are not difficult at all and, what we didn't know before, you have a chance to walk with little monkeys! That was sooo interesting.The wiew from the monastery is beautiful, air is clean and you feel really special while in this place.If you take bus 170 from Victoria park, Causeway Bay, you can enjoy seeing different parts of Hong Kong on your way to Sha Tin. Don't miss it!

One of my most memorable experiences in Hong Kong. I went in the morning by subway. There are few signs so be sure you've read directions to get there. It's just a couple of minutes to the entrance from the subway. The place is a delightful authentic monastery and a refreshing change from the hustle and bustle of downtown Hong Kong. Well worth the visit, but not for people with weak legs.

Funny Buddha expressions. Last Spring I went friends to this delightful Monastery. The weather that day was really nice and we enjoyed our walk up the hillside. There were Buddha statues lining the walkway and many had very fun comical expressions. At the top were many displays with miniature sized Buddhas. What a fun way to spend a relaxing afternoon.
The place was quite fascinating.. We walked a lot of steps up to the monastery. There were lots of buddha statues. I liked the monastery as it was quite peaceful.

Interesting monastery to see!. The monastery has closer to 13,000 Buddhas and some of these line the path up to the monastery itself and no two on the path are the same. They range from the curious to the comical.The monastery itself is impressive and very ornate and there is a pagoda which you can go up as well as well as a vegetarian restaurant which is quite pricey. Definitely worth a visit,

Exercise and experience. Take the train to Sha Tin and then walk to the street behind the home centre and follow the signs to get some good exercise and education. My 7 year old niece found the experience fun, interesting, educational and a little exhausting. A photo opportunity combined with a learning experience. I felt at peace, a bit out of breath, and content. Go there for a different look at HK's history.

A bit outdated but worthwhile. The monastery is not easy to find, there are some signs missing. Go out of the station (Sha Tin) and walk north-east around a market square. Keep going left, the entrance to the monastery is behind the buildings on your right hand. Less than 5 minutes walking from the station.Having arrived at the entrance is only the beginning. First of all: ignore the monk hanging around the entrance begging for money. He is an impostor.Then there is the staircase... yes the statues are nice, yes there are many statues... yes it is a long staircase.If you reach the top, there you will find the other 9500 buddhas. Most of them in the central hall.A tip: have a cup of tea with the locals in the 'restaurant' next to the central hall. If you are brave or just like Asian food: have a meal there.

Magical. This was just spectacular, and not as hard to find as you would think based on the very confusing directions I found on the internet. In fact it is very well marked with signs and really on my "can't miss" list for Hong Kong. Only caveat is there are a lot of steps so not a good idea if you unable to easily climb stairs. There are two ways to go up so I recommend one way up and the other down. The prettiest was the least traveled one which meanders through several villages. Loved it.

Worth a visit early morning. Despite the somewhat steep climb, it is a venue worth of visiting. I took the road which extrends between the government offices and homesquare where IKEA is and I think it is the better route to take as it does not go through a lot of village houses as the other one does and is more calming. One of the gaudiest temples I've seen but the atmosphere was very calm the time I visited and as I went around 9.30 am only a few visitors were there and the premises wasn't crowded. Plenty of statues along the way up and in the premises. Make sure that you visit the whole complex of temples rather than only the main worship hall. No photopgraphs are allowed inside the temple buidings unfortunately.On the way down, one can take the other exit which is through village houses and ends up near the Pau Tau village which itself is worth a gaze.

Worth the steps!. Apart from choosing the hottest most humid day of a holiday in HK to visit the Monastery (36 degrees and 90% humidity) my daughter and I enjoyed our visit. Yes, there are a lot of steps, but you can take your time and there are areas to rest on the way up with seats. The view from the top (second level) is great and worth the extra few steps up. The monastery is easy to get find when you come out of the MTR Station. It was very quiet - I think we only saw 2 other tourists whilst we were there. Well worth a visit and we (mother 50+ and daughter 20+) would recommend it

How're your leg's feeling now?. Bit tricky finding the place - it's basically through a hole in the fence.We went up to some Ancestral worship halls by mistake, looking for the place.Double mistake was that we did this on a Chineese national holiday so the place was rammed - and we nearly died with the choking smell on incense there (but totally different place - so better get back on track).FIRSTLY - bring your walking shoes... it's a long way up to the first stopping point (only as far as we got). No massively over engineered path to help either.There is a vegetarian restaurant on the plateau with the 10,000 buddhas as well, well worth a nibble stop! (Don't be afraid, I love meat too - but the food was so good I didn't miss it).Very touristy up there, but well worth the climb.Lot's of lovingly created idol's, statues, and symbols.

Many photo opportunities. The Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery is located on a hill. The long path going up is lined with many Buddha statues, each one is different. So there are many excuses to stop and take photos. When you get up there are even more Buddha statues, and a great view. You can also see people practice their rituals of burning incense and brining gifts for those who have passed away. On the way to the monastery you pass Pai Tau village, a small reminder of the time before skyscrapers have begun to dominate the HK sky line. By the looks of it, the small bulidings will soon disappear as well. Getting there: followed the instructions on http://www.hongkongextras.com/_ten_thousand_buddhas_monastery.html and found it easily. Tip: buy water and snaks at the MTR station before going on the trail.

It's great, but it's a very steap hill. Firstly. When you approach there will be a large looking Buddhist Temple and a sign attached to a road sign that points down a dodgy looking pathway to the Buddhas. We chose to ignore this sign, believing it had been misplaced. We walked to the top of the Buddhist Temple and burial ground to discover we had gone the wrong way.We eventually returned to the sign and followed the path. It's well worth the visit, but on a very hot dya it's quite exhausting. We're all reasonably fit and were soaked with sweat by the time we got up the top - It was 36 degrees, but be prepared to take water with you.Well worth the visit, but for the sake of that hill, I won't be doing it again.

OMG they aren’t kidding about the steps people. Easy to find after watching http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L8kkKpHxJpg – it was another thing I can tick off my list been there done that – don’t feel the need to return but sooo pleased we made the effort as it’s an extremely peaceful and interesting place to visit … the statues are overwhelming in their numbers and variety making for some great holiday photos. Yes its a little shabby in places but its cheerful and colourful and worth a visit but we couldn’t help thinking as we stumbled back down those steps passing all the people the young and the very old dragging huge bags of paper offerings up all those steps that we were glad this wasn’t our “local” place of worship (must be all the tai chi that make these little old ladies so fit) There are a couple of bench seats along the way so you can catch your breath - a little rare in Hong Kong... Unfortunately we didnt see any monkeys during our hike but more then made up for that with a stop at Shek Lei Pui Reservoir (on Tai Po Road) on the way back to TST.

Excellent Excursion. I just got back from my visit to 10,000 Buddha's. I took my 16 year old daughter, and another couple that we met on our tour. We all loved our visit to the temple. The walk up is not easy. The hill is steep, and long. You will be exhausted and soaking wet when you reach the top. The buddha's, pagoda and various shrines are beautiful. This was one of the top highlights of my trip. They have a small gift shop with very reasonably priced gifts at the top. There are fortune tellers there also, they read your face, and tell your fortune.I will try to simplify the directions to get here:1. Take the MTR to the Sha Tin station2. Use exit B at the station3. Turn left as exiting exit B4. Follow foot path all the way to the left till you reach the shopping mall.5. Turn left at shopping mall6. At end of shopping mall, turn right (you will be between shopping mall & govt. bldg.)7. Walk to the end, you will see a yellow sign for the temple.

Wonderful place...but rather unkempt. Really easy to find the entrance from the Sha Tin train station. The effort it takes to get to the temple is part of the fun. A great place to go and really explore. The complex is on two levels, so make sure you walk up the second set of stairs as well. Reading the history of the 'monastery' on the internet before we went to visit really enhanced the experience. The sheer number of Buddhas are amazing but some parts of the complex are not looked after and have a neglected feel about them. That aside, a must-see. Highly recommended. The gift shop here was by far the cheapest and most reasonably compared to some other temples we visited. A great place to pick up some souvenirs.

Wow-incredible. This was a hard core adventure-we did the whole thing on public transport, with the kids! We had brilliant instructions to get there from the MTR. The Buddhas lining the steps up are not the 10,000 Buddhas-just extra dudes showing you the way! It's tough going up the steps but if I can make anyone can. My kids loved the steps-weird!Up the top there is so much to see and we were virtually alone. The kids liked lighting giant incense sticks and seeing all the Buddhas in various poses. A nice little shop selling 'things'. When we finished we had lunch at Ikea [ha ha ha] then walked to Sha Tin Park and riverside area, then happened upon some of the Beijing Olympic mascot statues as we left. Great day-all free, apart from Ikea!

Unusual Temple, Tough Climb, Worth Visiting, FREE. This was our third visit to the temple, the last being 5 years ago. The entrance to the temple grounds is an easy but hard to find 5 minute walk from Shatin MTR station (others have provided directions which I won't expand on). Before you go anywhere, ensure you have some water (can be bought from the floor stall next to the entrance to the Ancestral halls or in the MTR station. The path (we take the one behind the government offices) is flanked by life sized gold laquered statues of monks in various poses. Each one is different and the kids had a great time counting them (until they lost count) and imitating them. The path is a steep climb (over 400 steps) so if you can't tackle steep terrain, this temple isn't for you. On arrival at the top of the steps and the main square, there is a small window from where drinks are sold. The main square has several large Buddha statues which have been recently painted and look pretty impressive. Around the outside the square are more life-sized buddhas in ever more bizarre poses (super-human like arms and legs, etc) and a pagoda which is depicted on the HK$10 banknote. The main prayer hall houses thousands of small buddha statues in the walls, again all in different poses. There are also large Buddha statues in front of which (rather creepily) is the embalmed and gold lacquered body of the founder of the the monastery in a glass case. Facing the prayer hall and going to the right takes you to yet further gardens and temples housing statues and it is this area which was devastated by a landslide in 1997. You can still see the effects of this landslide as rear of the house here is enveloped by the hill behind it. Finally you reach a stream area where there is a large white Kwan Yin statue standing on a dragon's back and further buddha statues flanking the stream.You can now return to the main square and exit in the right hand corner (furthest away from the main prayer hall). This takes you past yet more life-sized Buddha statues and into the village at the base of the hill. If you have time, you can visit the Wing Wo Bee Farm before rejoining civilisation. It's also worth peering into the old village houses right outside the MTR station at Pai Tau Village, a Grade III listed building.Also note, do not give money to any monks that you see in the area. They will be persistent but they are not real monks and the temple is trying to stop them begging. There have been several reports in HK papers regarding this and arrests have been made. A great FREE day out at an unusual, one of a kind temple. You can combine the trip with shopping in Shatin town or a visit to the Heritage Museum.

I'd like to update the directions. this really is easy to visit and I'd taken 2 different sets of directions with us.... but the most recent was the most accurate, and I'd just like to add some details. When we exited the train station- you want Exit B (there is also a handy 7-11 here if you need water and a WC). Turn left outside the exit and you'll be walking along a strip of stores for a couple minutes. At the end of that block you will be passing a cement floored outdoor soccer area, with the Square in front of you on the opposite corner. This is where you want to turn left, and you will walk 2 more (but very short) blocks, the first one is the Square, the 2nd one is a govt. building. After you have passed the govt building you will see a pretty gateway and car park. If you look up you can now see the 10,000 Buddha's Monastery area above you. Just walk along the wide sidewalk BETWEEN the govt bldg and the gated parking, the trail head is at the end of that walkway, leading up to your left and there is a sign once you start the trail. You've only walked about 5 min. from the station- it was much closer than we thought and we really enjoyed it. As well as the friendly local monkeys who appeared when we walked back down. We had stopped on our way to Shenzhen- really glad so many had tried to explain that it was easy to do. Not far from Hong Kong at all.

Well worth seeing. This is not a walk for the faint hearted. My mother 77 yrs walked slowly up the paved steep incline to visit the Ten Thousand Buddha monastery. We followed the directions previously posted on Trip Advisor and they were perfect. It took us about 20 minutes to reach the top with stops to take photos even of the monkeys! You arrive at the mid level, there is another small temple further up and more Buddha’s a level down.There is even a small restaurant where you can also buy a cold drink!When I ask Mum ‘what was the best place’ she answers ‘ the ten thousand buddas’ now that’s something!

the best part of our trip to hong kong. the torrential rain, the walk up, the style of the statues, the temple itself, more rain and bad english in the leaflet all made our trip fantastic and unforgettable. if you're going to hong kong, DON'T miss this place, it's really great. there are so many buddha statues to photograph, if you're snap-happy!

Brilliant, Amazing and Insightful. Okay so I had heard numerous good and bad things about the ten thousand buddhas moastery and as we live in HK its easy for us to check it out - I must admit I think we were succesful in finding the place due to a previous submission on trip advisor as it was simple to find. We got off the MTR at Sha Tin and went towards the Home Space mall took a left before the mall and walked to the end before the cemetry entrance. Dont enter the cemetr.. between the government building and the cemetery there is a path that is about 2 metres wide, you should follow that for a hundred metres and then take a left again which will have you at the start of endless steps to the top! Amazing Statues of monks ( i think) but they have done well to create each one with its own unique style. The day for us was a lazy day out and all in all took about two to three hours to see it - definitely worth the trip out to sha tin.

Steep steps but well worth the climb. We followed the directions to 10k buddhas based on Trip Advisor reviews and information in the Lonely Planet guide and managed to find the entrance from the street with no problems. It is a pity the directions to the Buddhas aren't that obvious by the HKTB signs from the MTR exit. Anyway, we stopped a number of times during the climb to take pictures of the various buddhas and views. It was a Sunday so there were lots of people around. We did not have a meal at the restaurant. I recommend visiting this attraction while in Hong Kong as it is good to get out of the city and into the real Hong Kong.

Great temple, lots of buddha statues to photograph, difficult to find. We frequently visit the 10,000 buddha monastery with visitors that come to Hong Kong. Along with the Hong Kong Heritage Museum in Shatin, it makes a great way to spend the better part of a day during a trip to Hong Kong. Unfortunately, it can be a bit tricky getting to this monastery, we don't recommend attempting to walk up to the temple through the village, its just a tad bit tricky if there are not lots of visitors coming down the other way. Instead, aim towards the IKEA building once you exit the Shatin MTR station, you'll need to find your way towards the back of the building that is behind the IKEA building, this is the where the steep footpath begins to ascend to the temple. Once you make your way towards that area, the path is easy to find and there will likely be others making their way up to the temple. Warning: This is a very steep climb and most require rest on occasion. We don't advise this for elderly visitors or those in poor health. While the path of paved, it is steep and takes a good 20 minutes to climb on a good day. The Benefit, if you can make it, is an astonishing number of great buddha statues to photograph. Perhaps the monkeys will be out to entertain you as well. During Chinese New Year, this is a great temple to visit, especially if you can catch the lion dances held there in the morning. Highly recommended.

Best thing we did in Hong Kong - beats Po Lin. We found the right path by following the below directions - go to Sha Tin, heads towards the Home Space mall, cross the road as if entering the mall but urn left to walk down the road, keeping the mall on your right, cross one road, pass the government building and then hit the cemetery. Between the building and the cemetery entrance, there is an alleyway that looks uninviting - trust us, walk up it, and you hit the trail for the climb flanked by awesome statues.Climb the 400+ steps slowly to grab pics of these statues and make your way up to the monastery. Either the statues are of monks or they are incarnations of Buddha - but they are not the 10,000 Buddhas of the title. This is reserved for the main hall of the monastery that has thousands of golden buddhas lining the walls. It helped that the weather was a gorgeous 20/70 degrees (C/F) and the sun was shining and that they had finished some of the construction work I had heard about. As it was New Year, there were lots of Hong Kongese praying, wishing and leaving tributes to Buddha, and it was a wonderful place to sit and watch people. We recommend going back out the way you came into the main part of the monastery and climbing up again as there are several gold statues in the hills and a beautiful white statue as well. Climb down the back way (by the main part of the monastery) and it's a quicker journey, but not as many statues.It was fun and beautiful and really worth the trip out there - it takes about 20/30 mins from TST with 2 changes but we go a taxi for about £9 so we could see more of Hong Kong.

Follow the directions carefully!. We had read about this monastery before our trip but didn't take care to write down the directions before we decided to visit. As a result, we ended up visiting the Po Fook Hill Ancestral Halls first, but no harm done because they were also quite fascinating.We realised our mistake and eventually found the path to the Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery.I may be wrong, but the gold statues lining the walking path up the hill appeared to me to be monks, and the 10,000 Buddhas are housed in the temples on the first and second levels at the top of the hill.It's a very interesting place, although apparently it's no longer an active monastery as monks no longer live there and the facility is managed by laypersons.Well worth a visit, but make sure you don't use flash photography inside the actual temples.

Unusual and worth spending the time to visit. This Temple is about an hour from the City centre by Metro, but worth the trip. We followed the instructions in the previous reviews and found the Temple easily: I think if we had followed the official signposts we may have gone wrong a couple of times as some were placed in obscure positions. The Temple is on a hill, so be prepared for some steep slopes. Entry is free and allow about an hour for your visit.General tip: Real monks never beg.

10000 Buddhas. I have something to add to LiveTraveling review, I just went there based on his review and there are 2 ways to get there. After you walk past the Central Home Plaza mall, make a right on the street in between the back of the mall and in front of the Sha Tin gov't office. Cross the street to the gov't office sidewalk and walk it towards the end of the street. You'll see a small waist high, yellow sign in English. As of this review, there are fences on that part covering the vegetation only, the walk way path is clear to the start of the site. I came back from the site using this path following the locals.If you happen to walk past the gov't office make sure you follow the building because you are walking behind the gov't office to get there. Do not walk up on the street to the other temple because that way doesn't connect to the 10000 buddha path. You should be within literally an arms length from the building when walking this way. The monastery doesn't solicit and like a fool, we gave the monk some money but he was persistent... After I walked down, I heard some locals saying they don't recognize him from the area and that he spoke Mandarin which should give it away. You don't know if he's a monk or something else in guise. We only made it up to the first temple before it started to rain. There's a restaurant up there if you need to get water and drinks. This is the first time, I've been here after coming to HK for the 3rd time.I would also second the recommend using the bathroom at the mall before going back to the train station.

Fantastic - a must do. we followed the detail directions below and had no trouble getting there. definitely go up the back way like suggested. you get to see the buddhas better and if your walking down you don't see them as well. We walked up the slop most (not the stairs) of the way and think this saved our legs a bit. It wasn't that hard of a walk probably took us 15min to get to the top and we stopped a few times a long the way. Once you get to the top it's amazing, to your right are a few more steps to some smaller temples. to your left are the big 10000 buddhas temple. It is amazing you can go inside and take photo's but no flash. It only took us max 1 1/2 hours to do the whole thing and from tst it took us 15min on the train and we had to change twice. The best thing is it is another free activity in hk. We did give the monks some small change and i'm not sure if that was right - if they were part of the temple or just beggers. They were pretty persistent.

Detailed Directions. I am living in Hong Kong, but I used the reviews here to get me to the 10,000 Buddhas. The directions were lacking so here are detailed directions to help you on your journey...Take the East Rail Line to the Sha Tin stop (1st class is only $4 HK more from Hung Hom)Go out Exit B (you will see buses)Go left outside the exit and follow everyone down the pedestrian rampAt the end of the ramp there is an Information Pole with a purplish red sign for the Government Building, which you can follow. OR better yet do the following...Follow Pui Tau Street toward the left.You will see a Mall across the street, currently called Home Square. Cross the street here and go to the left, which will continue to be Pui Tau Street. Pass the Sha Tin Government Building on your right (you are still on Pui Tau Street).You will see a very impressive white cemetery entrance next. (It is a large complex with escalators and stairs, but this is NOT 10,000 Buddhas.) Before you cross the car park entry in front of you to reach the cemetery entrance, there will be a cement path on the right. You will easily miss it since it is between a building and a cement wall with no sign. Take this cement path behind the building and then to the left. You will start seeing the gold buddhas as you start up the hill. If you have any questions about where to go, there are attendants in the cemetery parking area just 30 feet up the ramp. I had to ask directions for the 10,000 Buddhas. The man was very nice and walked me down the ramp and pointed me down the cement path. Please, please ask for directions if you have gotten this far. All you need to say is "10,000 Buddhas?" although a lot of people understand English in Hong Kong.Enjoy the walk!A few recommendations for your journey...- Use the first class compartment on the East Rail Line. The small extra cost is worth it.- There are nice bathrooms on the 1st level in the mall I mentioned above. Pacific Coffee Company is located on the 2nd level...as of January 2010...possibly a good place to stop and relax after your walk.- There are two routes to go up to the top and then back down again. I recommend using the entrance route I described for going up. Although I believe this route up doesn't not have any handrails, I didn't miss them going up. The other route that you could use to go down has a limited amount of buddhas, but there is a hand rail. I suggest that you determine if using a handrail is important to you while making the walk up. If so, take the other route down, but it isn't as impressive. This route will take you through a village but it didn't show the local flavor.- There are three levels of the monastery so make sure you see them all. I recommend going all the way up to the silver statue with a tall waterfall in the back. You can enter the small building all the way up to the 2nd floor. It was a nice experience.- There was a person walking around with a yellow name tag, but the tag did not indicate she worked for the monastery. She didn't tell me her intention, but she was happy to try to give my two year old son and later me a "good fortune" card. I quickly declined because on the streets of Hong Kong this is technique used to get you to give them money. I err on the side of caution because this lady failed to talk or pay attention to my local friend. Also, I didn't appreciate her trying to give something to my son without asking. I was happy to make a donation myself in the donation boxes located everywhere in the monastery.- A general rule in Hong Kong is that religious organizations do not go soliciting money. The locals I know do not give money to any organization or monks on the street collecting money. They just totally ignore them or just say, "no money". I'm told that all the solitors on the street are fake. I've learned that being rude, or what Westerners consider being rude, is not harsh at all around here. - If you are looking to do something while you are out in the New Territories, please read on... We made this walk in the morning and ended close to lunch time. A good way to continue your day is to take the East Rail Line back toward Hung Hom, but get off at Kowloon Tong. Switch over to the Green Line and go a couple stops to Diamond Hill. Here you can follow the signs to Nan Lian Garden and Chi Lin Nunnery. (I would do a web search for specific directions because I forget the exact route. The good thing is that the signs are very good to get you there...not like 10,000 Buddhas.) Nan Lian Garden is impressive to take a leisurely walk around. There is a nice restaurant located inside where seating underneath a water fall. This would make a nice relaxing stop for lunch, which can be hard to find in Hong Kong. Continue walking across to the Nunnery. I hope this information helps you on your travels.

Out Of The Usual. BTW, I lived in HK for a bit and I dint even KNOW about this place until recently!!Its away from the mad hustle of the city, and although the city has its own charm, this place is very serene and beautiful. I loved the trek up the 400something steps. All the way up on either side you will find golden buddha statues, not any two the same! How to get there: Take the MTR & KCR to the Shatin stop.Take exit B. When you exit (after inserting your ticket in the machine) take a left and follow the road down until you reach a road on your left. Take the left onto the road and keep walking until the end. On the right (before the big gate) you will find a tiny sign that reads '10,000 Buddhas'. Its a small sign so be alert for it.

Spectacular!. This is a must-see attraction in Hong Kong. Although there are more than 400 steps to climb, it's a very pleasant hike. The path is lined with lots of buddhas so you can take lots of photos imitating their poses and expressions!At the top, the actual temple houses little golden buddhas, all with unique poses. This had to be one of the most amazing sights I ever came across in my life. The giant Kwan Yu and Guan Yin statues outside were not shabby either.There's also vegetarian restaurant (we didn't try as we didn't know before hand) at the top, which serves lunch for HKD45 - quite the bargain.

Not easy to find - even with the great instructions given in other reviews!. We only got a glimpse of the Buddhas in their shiny gold due to following the wrong path! There is a sign to point you in the right direction, but it still wasn't clear to use which way to go - we got probably a stone throw away and due to it being late in the afternoon and very warm we didn't try and locate the correct path. Maybe next time!

a must see. This place is under construction currently and that's probably why it's not in many guide books. At the big buddha, there are several signs asking for donations for the 10,000 site. So, this place will only get better from now. That being said, it is already a must see! Other reviews have the specific directions which is helpful. I say just go to Sha Tin station and ask a staff member. They'll point you in the right direction. There is a sign or two which will help you along the way too. Not too tough to find. Seeing all the golden statues on the hike up is sweet. Taking picures imitating each pose is so fun even for a 28-year-old like myself. I'm a kid at heart! Once you get to the top, the view is great and so is the monastery. All the mini statues inside and the bigger ones outside make for quite the site. This is a must see in my opinion. Free of charge but I donated a little at the top.

Don't leave Hong Kong without visiting the 10,000 Buddha's !!. Bit of a walk up a steep hill but the buddhas are FANTASTIC !! - we was quite surprised they don't even charge for admission as we would have gladly paid.Well worth a visit !!

Man Fat Monastary aka Ten Thousand Buddhas. www.10kbuddhas.org is the main web site to visit before heading to the 10K monastary. It's a good place to start and determine if you want to hike up the hill or not. The monastary is located in the New Territories at a town called Shatin pai Tau Village, just outside of the Hong Kong city.When and who were the travelers : Late September and three single females in their late 20s.Getting there:We took the train from Hong Kong to the KCR Sha Tin Railway Station. I don't remember how long the ride was, but it was more than 1/2 hr. Taking the train was easy because on each car of the train (at least the one we took) had electronical maps of the train route under the exit/entrance door. There is a blinking light indicating where the train is located on the route. The name of each location on the map were both in Chinese characters and English, which made our journey easy. When we got off, we took the Exit B, walked down the pedestrian ramp and saw the hills to the left. Look for a RED Pagoda, it should be clearly visible from KCR Station. Walk a few blocks north and you'll see an IKEA store sign. Turn left onto Pai Tau Street. Keep to the right side of the road and follow it around to the gate where the signposted path starts. There should be a gray building to the right and the cemetary entrance to the left. This pathway is the best side to reach the top of the monastary. Don't be confused by the White Pagoda on the left of Pai Tau Road. That's the cemetary, not the temple. If you see an escalator and a pretty landscape, you're at the wrong entrace. We made the mistake of going to the cemetary and not look for the sign posted for the monastary. It was all good... we paid respect to ancestors we didn't know.Weather in Sept:It was sunny with scattered shower. Our unbrella were very handy because we used it for both the sunny weather and for the rain. Since we didn't know where we where going, we brought water bottles and snacks for each. We visited on a weekday and so there were hardly any people visiting the area.Attire:We wore long pants, short sleeve shirt and took a light sweater. We wore good walking shoes because there are over 400 steps to climb.Experience:Going up the hill was an easy hike because there are small steps and hand railing on the side to hold on to as you hike up. There are many statues along side the pathway with different emotional expression. Climbing the stairs were exciting at first... after a few hundred steps we needed something to stay excited. Throughout the climb, we started posing with or as the same position as the statues. It kept us busy and entertained. If you have kids, you can have them count the number of statues as they go up. Eventhough each one has numbers... I lost count.Reaching the top was not as I expected... It was quiet (it was a weekday) and it's a flat area on top. I didn't do any research on the monastary before going there. When you reach the top, you are entering from the back corner of the 10K Buddhas Temple. With all the climbing up the hill we got hungry (it was lunch time)and found a small local restaurant on top by the monastary. It should be at the same corner as you took your last hike to the monastary. When you are facing the 10K Buddhas Temple, the local restaurant is to your right side (by the Refectory of the Monastary). To your left is the office and the public restroom. Always bring your own toilet paper. To your back (or across the 10K Buddhas Temple) is the Red Pagoda.In the 10K Buddhas Temple, there is a little store that sells mini souvenirs at very minimal cost. You can also light an incent to pay respect (but not at the main temples), donate money to the monastary for the up keeping, or simply enjoy the temple and the surrounding statues. There is no obligation to anything. Heading down hill, you can take the same pathway or take a rugged path. The rugged path is not like hiking down a jungle, but there are broken path; and that path goes to the back yard of people residence. When looking at the Red Pagoda, with the 10K Buddhas Temples behind you, the rugged pathway exit is located to your right between the Pagoda and Samantabhadra (the White elephant statue which is to the right of the Pagoda). I don't suggest taking this path for those that needs to hold on to railingsI don't remember how long the hike to the top took us, but it was worth for us to see something new and the view was great!

10,000 Golden Buddhas Monastery. The 10,000 Buddhas is worth the steep climb. There are two paths to the main buildings on top of a hill. Leaving the North exit of the KCR station, make your way through the bus terminal and look to the hills to the left. You will see two Pagodas on the top of the hill. The closest Pagoda , white with red trim, is the cemetery. It has a beautiful entrance and escalators but is not the 10,000 Buddhas Monastery. The trail on the left begins in what is left of an old Chinese village and is the steeper of the two choices. Behind the IKEA is a more gentle path. Both paths are lined with golden Buddhas, and you may want to climb one and descend the other. The temple at the top has walls covered with thousands of small Buddhas. The Pagoda has many Buddhas looking out from every window. Seeing the preponderance of Buddhas displayed both outdoors on the path and indoors at the temple is like nothing we have ever come across before. Available is water, sodas, and a few vegetarian treats at the main temple square.
